Chapter 6
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
1-6-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The village president shall be elected for a term provided by statute and shall be president of the board of trustees. (1965 Code § 1-5-1)
1-6-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village president shall have such powers and perform the duties as follows:
A. Generally: He shall sign all commissions and permits issued by the board of trustees and grant all licenses, except as otherwise provided by law and
ordinance, and he shall perform other acts as may be required by law. (1965 Code § 1-5-3)
B. Supervision: He shall supervise the conduct of all officers of the village, examine the grounds of all reasonable complaints made against any of them,
and cause all their violations of duty and other neglects to be reported to the board for correction. (1965 Code § 1-5-4)
C. Signature Authorized: He is hereby authorized to sign, in behalf of the village, all instruments necessary to the prompt prosecution or defense of any or
all actions brought by or against the village, including bonds for injunction. (1965 Code § 1-5-6)
D. Presiding Officer: He shall preside at all meetings of the board, and, except as otherwise provided by state statute, shall have the same powers and
perform the same duties as the mayor of a city. He shall devote to the duties of his office whatever time the faithful discharge thereof may require.
(1965 Code § 1-5-7)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 08-16-16-M1 - SALARIES. Go to new ordinance.
1-6-3: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the village president shall be ten thousand five hundred dollars ($10,500.00) per annum effective May 1, 2013, and an additional
increase of two percent (2%) per annum thereafter to be divided into equal monthly installments payable each month. (1965 Code § 1-5-9; amd. Ord. 12-
07-11-O6, 12-7-2011)
1-6-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM:
During a temporary absence or disability of the village president, the board of trustees shall elect one of its number to act as president pro tem, who,
during such absence or disability, shall possess the powers of the village president. (1965 Code § 1-5-8)
Chapter 7
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
1-7-1: ELECTION; TERM; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board of trustees shall consist of six (6) members, who shall be elected to office for the term as provided by statute. The board shall be the legislative
department of the village government, and shall perform such duties and have such powers as may be delegated to it by statute. (1965 Code § 1-6-1)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 08-16-16-M1 - SALARIES. Go to new ordinance.
1-7-2: OATH AND COMPENSATION1:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 19/307
The members of the board of trustees shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute, and shall receive four thousand five hundred fifty dollars
($4,550.00) per annum effective May 1, 2013, and an additional increase of two percent (2%) per annum thereafter. (1965 Code § 1-6-2; amd. 2009 Code;
Ord. 12-07-11-O6, 12-7-2011)
1-7-3: BOARD MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the finance committee of the board of trustees shall be held on the first and third Tuesday of each month
beginning at six o'clock (6:00) P.M. The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the first and third Tuesday of each month beginning
at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. The meeting place of the board of trustees shall be in the boardroom in the village hall unless otherwise specified by the
board of trustees. (Ord. 12-17-14-O1, 12-17-2014)
B. Special Meetings:
1. Special meetings may be held at any time, on call of the president or any three (3) or more trustees; such call shall be in writing, duly signed, and
shall be presented to the village clerk, who shall proceed immediately to prepare notices of the same, and shall cause them to be served on the
president and members of the board of trustees. Said service shall be made by placing the notice in the elected official's normal correspondence box
and by personal or telephonic notification. Such notices shall describe, in brief, the nature or object of the call. (1965 Code § 1-6-4)
2. Public notice of any special meeting, except a meeting held in the event of a bona fide emergency, or of any rescheduled regular meeting, or of any
reconvened meeting, shall be given at least forty eight (48) hours before such meeting, which notice shall also include the agenda for the special,
rescheduled, or reconvened meeting, but the validity of any action taken by the corporate authorities which is germane to a subject on the agenda
shall not be affected by other errors or omissions in the agenda. (2009 Code)
3. At every special meeting, the call for the same shall be read and afterward filed by the clerk; and no business other than that proposed by call shall
be in order at such meeting. Provided, however, that the notice and call required herein shall be considered waived as to the president or any
member of the board of trustees who is actually present and participates in the business of any such special meeting2. (1965 Code § 1-6-4)
1-7-4: QUORUM:
A majority of the elected voting members, being the trustees and village president, shall constitute a quorum to do business, but no ordinance shall be
passed except upon a favorable vote of the majority of the elected voting members, as provided by statute. (1965 Code § 1-6-5)
1-7-5: RULES OF PROCEDURE:
A. Robert's Rules Of Order: So far as the same is not inconsistent with this code or statutes of the state of Illinois, proceedings of the board shall be
conducted as nearly as may be reasonable under the then most current edition of "Robert's Rules Of Order". (1965 Code § 1-6-7)
B. Testimony Or Comments:
1. It is the policy of the village board to permit comments by members of the public at regular board meetings on agenda items before a vote is taken.
The village board permits comments by members of the public at regular board meetings on any village issue at the end of the meeting.
2. No person shall address the village board without first securing the recognition of the village president.
3. Each person desiring to address the village board shall approach the podium, state his or her name and address for the record, state the subject,
state whom he or she is representing if he or she represents an organization or other persons, and shall limit his or her remarks to three (3) minutes.
All remarks shall be addressed to the village board as a whole and not to any member thereof. No questions shall be asked of a village board
member or a member of the village staff.
4. In order to expedite village business and to avoid repetitious presentations, whenever any group of persons wishes to address the village board on
the same subject matter, it shall be in order for the village president to encourage that a spokesperson be chosen from the group to address the
village board. If additional matters are to be presented by any other members of the group, the president may limit the number of such persons and
limit the presentation to information not already presented by the group spokesperson.
5. Village residents shall be given priority in addressing the village board and all comments total shall be limited to thirty (30) minutes in duration.
Visitors' statements and comments shall be limited to matters relating to the village; language of a lewd, insulting or provocative nature shall not be
permitted; and participants shall conduct themselves in an orderly and civil manner. (Ord. 10-20-09-03, 10-20-2009)
1-7-6: RECORDS:
A. Boards And Commissions, Certified Record: Every board and commission created by the board of trustees shall keep a true and accurate record of all
its proceedings. A copy of this record, certified by the clerk of the board or commission or by two (2) members thereof, shall be filed with the village
clerk and shall become part of the records of the village. (1965 Code § 1-6-8)
B. Tape Recordings: All tape recordings made by village boards and village commissions of their meetings are for assistance in transcribing minutes and
are not the official record of the village. Minutes prepared from these tapes will be approved by a majority vote of the board or commission and are the
official village records. Recording tapes may be disposed of by the village after the minutes have been approved by the board or commission. (1965
Code § 1-6-8; amd. 2009 Code)
1-7-7: STANDING COMMITTEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 20/307
A. The following shall be the standing committees of the board of trustees:
1. Finance Committee: The finance committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: finance department,
purchasing and personnel departments, personnel evaluation and council rules.
2. Public Safety Committee: The public safety committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: police
department, fire department, civil defense and animal control.
3. Public Works Committee: The public works committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the following areas: building
department, street and alley department, maintenance department, sewer department and public buildings, equipment and property.
4. Committee On Permits And Licenses: The permits and licenses committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions associated with
business permits and licenses.
5. Committee On Ordinances And Resolutions: The ordinances and resolutions committee shall have the responsibility to oversee the functions of the
following areas: legal, zoning ordinances and resolutions.
6. Committee On Community Events: The community events committee shall have the responsibility to oversee various community events sponsored
or promoted by the village.
B. The village president shall appoint the members of the standing committees and shall appoint the chairman thereof.
C. Each trustee shall be a member of two (2) standing committees and the chairman of one standing committee. Vacancies on any committee shall be
filled as herein provided for original appointments. (Ord. 05-17-11-O4, 5-17-2011)
1-7-8: VIDEO RECORDING POLICY:
A. Location Of Equipment, Village Boardroom: All persons who are nonvillage personnel using video recording equipment during meetings in the village
boardroom are to set up behind the last row of seats and clear of any doors in an area designated by the village board for video recording equipment.
To prevent a tripping hazard from extension cords, individuals using video equipment shall have their own power source or connect directly to an outlet.
The outlet on the west wall of the village boardroom shall be reserved for the official village video photographer. Tripods shall be positioned so as to not
create a tripping hazard for the audience. Loose wires shall be contained under a tripod or as close to the village video photographer as possible.
Chairs or benches shall not be used to stand on, or as equipment tables. (1965 Code § 1-6-9; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Location In Other Rooms; Witnesses May Refuse To Testify: When meetings are held in rooms other than the village boardroom, an area will be
designated by the chair conducting the meeting for video recording equipment. Witnesses giving testimony at these meetings may refuse to be
recorded if they so choose. (1965 Code § 1-6-9)
C. Violation; Penalty: Any person violating the terms and conditions of this section shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-4-1 of this title. In
addition, the village may take whatever action it may deem appropriate to enforce the terms of this section, including an action for injunction. All
attorney fees and costs incurred by the village in enforcing the terms of this section shall be paid by the violator. (1965 Code § 1-6-9; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 8
VILLAGE CLERK
1-8-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The village clerk shall be elected for a term as provided by statute. (1965 Code § 1-7-1)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
The village clerk shall have and perform the following duties:
A. Issue notices to the members of the board of trustees when directed to do so. He shall also issue notices of the meetings of the board of trustees.
B. Duly direct to the village president all ordinances and resolutions in his charge which may be required to be approved or otherwise acted upon by the
president, together with all papers on which the same are founded.
C. Keep the corporate seal of the village, and all papers belonging to the village.
D. Attend all meetings of the village board, and keep a full record of its proceeds in the journal.
E. Receive all communications addressed to the board. The clerk shall cause all ordinances imposing any fines, penalties, imprisonment or forfeiture, or
making any appropriations to be published in such newspaper as the board shall designate.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 21/307
F. File with the county clerk each year after its passage the annual tax levy ordinance.
G. Record and maintain all ordinances passed by the village board, and all other records of the village not otherwise specifically statutorily reserved to the
custody of any other officer.
H. Perform such other additional duties as now are, or hereafter may be, prescribed by the statutes of the state and provisions of this code. (1965 Code
§ 1-7-3)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 08-16-16-M1 - SALARIES. Go to new ordinance.
1-8-3: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the village clerk shall be four thousand four hundred fifty dollars ($4,450.00) per annum effective May 1, 2013, and an additional
increase of two percent (2%) per annum thereafter. (1965 Code § 1-7-4; amd. Ord. 12-07-11-O6, 12-7-2011)
1-8-4: DEPUTY CLERK:
The village clerk may appoint an individual to serve as deputy clerk. The appointed individual shall receive no additional compensation for the discharge of
the duties of deputy clerk. (1965 Code § 1-7-5)
Chapter 9
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
1-9-1: BONDS OF OFFICERS:
A. Bonds Required: Bonds shall be furnished in such amount and with such surety as may be approved by village board, such bond to be conditioned on
the faithful performance of duties and shall indemnify the village for any loss by reason of any neglect of duty or other acts. The cost of the bond shall
be paid by the village. (1965 Code § 1-21-1)
B. Bond Amounts: Bonds shall be in the following amounts:
Village manager $50,000.00
Director of finance 50,000.00
Clerk 10,000.00
Treasurer 50,000.00
(1965 Code § 1-21-2; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE MANAGER1
1-9A-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; RESIDENCY:
A. Appointment: There shall be the office of village manager, which office shall be filled by the appointment by and approval of a majority of the board of
trustees. (1965 Code § 1-23-1)
B. Term; Contract: The office of village manager shall have an indefinite term. The conditions of the manager's appointment may be set forth in an
agreement, although such agreement may not limit the term of the manager's appointment to a definite term nor shall any such agreement extend
beyond the term of the then sitting village president.
C. Residency: The village manager need not be a resident of the village. (1965 Code § 1-23-2)
1-9A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Intent: In the event that article 5 of the Illinois municipal code2 shall hereafter be amended to enlarge or diminish the powers of the village manager, this
article shall likewise be deemed to be amended so that the village manager's powers and duties are the maximum permitted by law. (1965 Code § 1-
23-6)
B. Powers And Duties Enumerated: The powers and duties of the village manager shall be:
1. To enforce the laws and ordinances within the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 22/307
2. To appoint and remove all directors of departments. No appointment shall be made upon any basis other than that of merit and fitness; except, that if
the chief of the police department or fire department, or both of them, are appointed in the manner as provided by ordinance under section 10-2.1-4
of the Illinois municipal code3, they may be removed or discharged by the appointing authority. In such case, the appointing authority shall file with
the corporate authorities the reasons for such removal or discharge, which removal or discharge shall not become effective unless confirmed by a
majority vote of the corporate authorities.
3. To exercise control of all departments and divisions thereof now in existence or that may be created by the board of trustees, including, but not
limited to, hiring all employees, except as otherwise provided by statute.
4. To have all the powers and exercise all the duties granted elsewhere in the Illinois municipal code to municipal clerks and comptrollers with respect
to the preparation of a report of estimated funds necessary to defray the expenses of the village for the fiscal year for the consideration of the
corporate authorities prior to the preparation of the annual budget.
5. To attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the right to take part in the discussions, but with no right to vote.
6. To recommend to the board of trustees for adoption, such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient.
7. To be the authority responsible for the administration and use of village buildings and facilities.
8. To perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law or may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the board of trustees. (1965 Code
§ 1-23-3; amd. 2009 Code)
9. (Rep. by Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
10. In the event of the manager's temporary absence or illness, the village president hereby delegates his authority under 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/5-3-7 to the village manager to designate a qualified administrative officer of the village as the acting village manager to fulfill the manager's
responsibilities during such absence or illness. (Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; amd. Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE TREASURER
1-9B-1: APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby created the office of village treasurer, an executive office of the village. The village manager shall fulfill the office and duties of village
treasurer. (Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009)
1-9B-2: DUTIES:
The village treasurer shall receive and deposit the monies of the village. He shall, subject to specific directions from the president and board of trustees,
distribute the village funds among authorized depositories, banks and financial institutions. He shall keep books of account, showing all sums received and
all deposits made, and he shall from time to time make a full account of all the financial transactions to the board of trustees. (1965 Code § 1-8-2)
1-9B-3: COMPENSATION:
The village treasurer shall receive as compensation for his services such amount as is budgeted in the annual budget of the village. (1965 Code § 1-8-3;
amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE C. CORPORATION COUNSEL AND VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
1-9C-1: CORPORATION COUNSEL:
A. Office Created: There is hereby created the office of corporation counsel.
B. Appointment: The corporation counsel shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and need not be
a resident of the village. The office of corporation counsel may be filled by a law firm or an individual and may be considered an independent contractor
of the village. (1965 Code § 1-13-1; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Duties: The corporation counsel shall attend all board meetings and shall perform for the village, for the village officials, and for all boards and
commissions such legal services as are designated by the village manager. (1965 Code § 1-13-3; amd. 2009 Code)
1-9C-2: VILLAGE PROSECUTOR:
A. Appointment: The village prosecutor shall be an officer of the village and shall be appointed by the village manager. (1965 Code § 1-13-2; amd. 2009
Code)
B. Duties: The village prosecutor shall represent the village in court for the prosecution of village ordinances relating to traffic violations, parking violations,
misdemeanors and such other matters as may be assigned to the village prosecutor by the corporation counsel. (1965 Code § 1-13-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 23/307
1-9C-3: COMPENSATION:
The corporation counsel and village prosecutor shall receive as compensation for services, an hourly legal fee as negotiated between the corporation
counsel and village prosecutor and the board of trustees. If necessary, the board of trustees shall, from time to time, budget additional funds to
compensate the corporation counsel and village prosecutor for services performed. (1965 Code § 1-13-4; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE D. HEALTH OFFICER
1-9D-1: APPOINTMENT; FUNCTION; COMPENSATION:
There is hereby created the office of health officer. The health officer shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board
of trustees. He shall have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to the health department and shall receive such salary as shall
be fixed by the village board. (1965 Code § 1-17-1; amd. 2009 Code; Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
1-9D-2: POWERS, DUTIES AND AUTHORITY:
A. Supervision: The health officer shall have and exercise a general supervision over the sanitary condition of the village. All orders and directions
emanating from the health department shall be issued in the name of the health officer. (1965 Code § 1-17-2)
B. Powers And Duties Generally: The health officer shall have all powers and perform all duties conferred upon or assigned to him, as such, by the
provisions of this article. He shall be responsible for the enforcement of all laws, ordinances and regulations relating to public health, to sanitation and
to the abatement of nuisances. (1965 Code § 1-17-3)
C. Authority: The health officer shall, when requested by the village president or by the board of trustees, or any committee thereof, furnish advice on all
matters relating to public health and sanitation and to the prevention and control of contagious or communicable diseases. He shall have authority,
subject to the direction and control of the president and board of trustees, to enforce all laws, ordinances and regulations and all orders of the president
and board of trustees relating to public health and sanitation. (1965 Code § 1-17-4)
D. Inspection; Report:
1. The health officer shall carry out and enforce the laws of the state and the provisions of this code relating to sanitation regulations.
2. He shall also inspect all plumbing within the corporate limits of the village to see that the same comply with law and the provisions of this code.
3. He shall, once each month, or more often if required, prepare and file with the president and board of trustees a written report of all acts performed
by him as health officer. (1965 Code § 1-17-5)
E. Right To Arrest: The health officer and each agent or employee thereof shall have the right and authority to arrest or cause to be arrested any person
who violates the state law or the provisions of this code relating to health and sanitation. (1965 Code § 1-17-6)
F. Enforcement Powers: The health officer and each agent or employee thereof, and the police officers of the village, shall have the power to enforce all
the laws of the state and the provisions of this code in relation to the sanitation regulations of the village. (1965 Code § 1-17-7; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE VIDEO PHOTOGRAPHER
1-9E-1: APPOINTMENT:
The corporate authorities of the village may create the position of village video photographer. The village video photographer shall be appointed by the
village president, with the consent of the board of trustees. (1965 Code § 1-22-1)
1-9E-2: INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR:
The video photographer shall be an independent contractor and not considered an employee of the village. While the video photographer shall, at all
times, be subject to the general directions of the village manager or village clerk, it is expected he/she shall perform the duties without specific detailed
supervision to the extent deemed necessary and expected by a video professional. (1965 Code § 1-22-2)
1-9E-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
A. The video photographer shall videotape all village board meetings and committee of the whole meetings, except for closed sessions or executive
sessions. He shall also tape other committee meetings designated by the village manager or village clerk.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 24/307
B. The video recorder may, at the request of the village manager or village clerk, be called upon to provide video evidence at disaster scenes, community
events, etc. However, unless the village manager or village clerk specifically requests the video photographer attendance at said event or location, it
shall be considered voluntary and outside the scope of the duties authorized by the village. (1965 Code § 1-22-3)
1-9E-4: TAPES PROPERTY OF VILLAGE:
All tapes are the property of the village and must be turned over to the village manager or village clerk immediately following the meeting or event being
filmed. It shall be the responsibility of the village manager or village clerk to deliver the films to Cablevision for broadcast. The village manager or village
clerk shall keep an inventory of tapes, accounting for the tapes delivered to Cablevision and expediting their return from Cablevision after they have
completed their broadcast. After broadcast, the village clerk is authorized to receive said copies for a historical permanent record. (1965 Code § 1-22-4)
1-9E-5: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the video photographer shall be established on an annual basis by the village board. However, said compensation shall not exceed
one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month. The video photographer is expected to provide all local transportation necessary and equipment necessary to
perform his duties. (1965 Code § 1-22-5)
ARTICLE F. VILLAGE COLLECTOR
1-9F-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby established the office of village collector in and for the village. This office shall be appointed and have the duties as specified in 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-30-15; 5/3.1-35-120; and 5/3.1-35-135. (Ord. 05-04-11-O1, 5-4-2011)
1-9F-2: APPOINTMENT:
The elected village clerk shall assume the office of village collector unless otherwise determined by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 05-04-11-
O1, 5-4-2011)
1-9F-3: DUTIES:
The collector shall preserve all warrants returned to the collector and shall keep books and accounts in the manner prescribed by the corporate authorities.
The collector shall pay to the treasurer or finance director or other appropriate village official all monies collected from any source. The collector shall also
supervise the everyday activities of the clerical and secretarial staff of the administrative offices of the village of Lyons. The collector shall report to the
village manager. (Ord. 05-04-11-O1, 5-4-2011)
1-9F-4: COMPENSATION:
The village collector shall receive a salary of thirty four thousand dollars ($34,000.00) per year in addition to any other established salaries for any other
positions. (Ord. 05-04-11-O1, 5-4-2011)
1-9F-5: TERM:
The village collector shall serve a term of one year from May 1 to the following April 30 and continue in office unless otherwise appointed by the president
with the consent of the village board. (Ord. 05-04-11-O1, 5-4-2011)

ARTICLE H. DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS
1-9H-1: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
There is hereby created a position of deputy director of public works who shall be appointed by the village manager. The deputy director of public works

Chapter 10
ETHICS
1-10-1: STATE REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The regulations of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/5-15 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/10-10 through 430/10-40 of the state officials and employees
ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this chapter) are hereby adopted by reference and made
applicable to the officers and employees of the village to the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5. (2009 Code)
1-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c). (2009 Code)
1-10-3: INTERPRETATION:
This chapter does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this chapter, however, the provisions of this chapter shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a). (2009 Code)
1-10-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Gifts:
1. The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the village, is hereby
prohibited.
2. The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the village under the act is hereby prohibited.
B. Political Activities: The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee of the village, is hereby prohibited. (2009
Code)
1-10-5: PENALTIES:
The penalties for violations of this chapter shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of the
act. (2009 Code)
1-10-6: AMENDMENTS:
Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date hereof shall be incorporated into this chapter by reference and shall be
applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its
provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this chapter by reference without formal action by the village president and
board of trustees. (2009 Code)
1-10-7: UNCONSTITUTIONALITY OF PROVISIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 26/307
A. If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this chapter shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme
court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This chapter shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the president and board of trustees if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
B. If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address the
remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act, as adopted by this chapter, shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this chapter
relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village. (2009
Code)
Chapter 11
CORPORATE SEAL
1-11-1: CONSTRUCTION:
The corporate seal of the village shall be circular in form, and be so constructed as to impress upon paper the words, "Village of Lyons, Gateway to the
West", and shall be designed to conform with exhibit A attached to ordinance 4-16-96-2. (1965 Code § 1-11-1)
1-11-2: USES; CUSTODY:
The corporate seal shall be and remain in the custody of the village clerk, and his successor in office, to be used by him in all cases provided by the
provisions of this code or the laws of the state of Illinois, and in all such other cases where, by the laws and customs of any state or nation, the use of the
corporate seal of the village becomes necessary. (1965 Code § 1-11-2)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 12-09-15-05 - COMPENSATION. Go to new ordinance.
Chapter 1
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS1
2-1-1: CREATION; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
A. There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners. The village president, with the consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint the
board which shall consist of three (3) members whose terms of office shall be three (3) years, and until their respective successors shall be appointed
and qualified. (1965 Code §§ 2-7-1, 2-7-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. The village president shall appoint the first members of the board. One of the members shall be appointed to serve until the end of the current municipal
year, the second member to serve until the end of the second municipal year, and the third member to serve until the end of the third municipal year.
(1965 Code § 2-7-3)
2-1-2: QUALIFICATIONS; OATH; REMOVAL:
One of the three (3) members of the board shall be a representative citizen of the employer class, one shall be a representative citizen chosen from the
employee class, and the third shall be a representative citizen not identified with the employee class. Each shall possess the qualifications required of
other officers of the village and shall take the oath of office. Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written charges, and after an
opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his or their own defense, before a regular meeting of the corporate authorities. A majority vote of the
corporate authorities shall be required to remove any such member from office. (1965 Code § 2-7-4; amd. 2009 Code)
2-1-3: APPOINTMENT OF POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police departments of the village, with the exception of
the chief of police and the chief of the fire department2, unless the president and board of trustees shall by ordinance to them otherwise provide3.
Appointments to each department other than that of the lowest rank, however, shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment is made;
except, that the chief of the police department and chief of the fire department may be appointed from among the members of the police and fire
departments, respectively, regardless of rank. (1965 Code § 2-7-5)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 27/307
2-1-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS; PUBLICATION:
The board of fire and police commissioners shall make rules to carry out the purpose of this chapter, and rules for appointments or removals in accordance
with the provisions of state law. Said rules, published in pamphlet form, were adopted by the board of fire and police commissioners on September 25,
1995, and the village board on November 21, 1995. (1965 Code § 2-7-6)

Footnote 2: See subsection 6-1-2A of this code for appointment of fire chief.

Chapter 2
E-911 BOARD1
2-2-1: ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
A. Established; Membership; Appointment: The board of trustees hereby establishes an emergency telephone system board ("ETS board"). The ETS
board shall consist of seven (7) members, and appointments shall be made by the village manager, the makeup of which shall at all times comply with
50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/15.4, and any and all other applicable Illinois statutes as regards the Lyons ETS board membership number,
membership qualifications, membership, demographic distribution, powers, authorities, duties and responsibilities. (1965 Code § 2-14-1; amd. 2009
Code)
B. Term: Members of the board shall serve an indefinite term. (1965 Code § 2-14-2)
2-2-2: DUTIES:
A. Duties Enumerated: The duties of the ETS board shall include, but are not necessarily limited to, the following:
1. Planning a 911 system.
2. Coordinating and supervising the implementation, upgrading or maintenance of the system, including the establishment of equipment specifications
and coding systems.
3. Receiving monies from the surcharge imposed and from any other source for deposit into the emergency telephone system fund (the "fund").
4. Authorizing all disbursements from the fund.
5. Hiring, on a temporary basis, any staff necessary for the implementation or upgrade of the system.
B. Expenditures For Certain Purposes Only: All monies received by the ETS board shall be deposited into an emergency telephone system fund. The
village treasurer shall be the custodian of the fund. All interest accruing on the fund shall remain in the fund. No expenditures may be made from such
fund except upon the direction of the ETS board by resolution passed by a majority of all members of said board. Expenditures may be made only to
pay for the costs associated with the following:
1. The design of the emergency telephone system.
2. The coding of an initial master street address guide database and update and maintenance thereof.
3. The repayment of any monies advanced for the implementation of the system.
4. The charges for automatic number identification and automatic location identification equipment, and maintenance, replacement and update thereof.
5. The nonrecurring charges related to installation of the emergency telephone system and the ongoing network charges.
6. Other products and services necessary for the implementation, upgrade and maintenance of the system and including costs attributable directly to
the construction, leasing or maintenance of any buildings or facilities or costs of personnel attributable directly to the operation of the system. The
costs attributable directly to the operation of the emergency telephone system do not include the costs of public safety agency personnel who are,
and equipment that is, dispatched in response to an emergency call. (1965 Code § 2-14-3)
2-2-3: ORGANIZATION:
The board shall choose its own officers as new. (1965 Code § 2-14-4)
Footnote 1: See section 1-7-6 of this code for records and tape recording requirements.
Chapter 3
EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY1
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 28/307
2-3-1: ORGANIZATION CREATED; MEMBERSHIP:
There is hereby created the village emergency services and disaster agency to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate attack, sabotage, or other hostile
action or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with the Illinois emergency management agency act2 (the "act"). This emergency services and
disaster agency (ESDA) shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. (1965 Code § 2-3-1; amd.
2009 Code)
2-3-2: COORDINATOR:
The coordinator shall be appointed by the village manager and shall serve until removed by same. The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the
organization, administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the village manager as provided by statute. (Ord.
04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009)
2-3-3: FUNCTIONS:
The village ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the village as shall be prescribed by statute and by the state emergency operations plan and
program, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the state EMA. In addition, the village ESDA shall perform such duties outside
the corporate limits of the village as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with another political subdivision, municipality, or quasimunicipal
entity entered into as provided in the act. (1965 Code § 2-3-3; amd. 2009 Code)
2-3-4: MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any members of the village ESDA may be designated by the director of the state EMA as members of a mobile support team created as provided in
the act. Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee, while serving within or without the village in the capacity of a mobile support
team member, shall have the powers, duties, rights, and immunities and receive the compensation incidental to their employment. (1965 Code § 2-3-4;
amd. 2009 Code)
2-3-5: MUTUAL AID AGREEMENT:
The coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other municipalities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall
be effective until it has been approved by the corporate authorities of each political subdivision. (1965 Code § 2-3-5)
2-3-6: DISASTER EMERGENCY:
If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of
Illinois of a disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from manmade or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the village ESDA to
cooperate fully with the state EMA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (1965 Code § 2-3-6; amd. 2009 Code)
2-3-7: COMPENSATION:
Members of the village ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village shall be paid for time spent performing ESDA training and duties as if they
were performing their various village duties. (1965 Code § 2-3-7)
2-3-8: STATE REIMBURSEMENT:
The village treasurer shall seek reimbursement from the state for compensation paid and the actual and necessary expenses of paid employees of the
village serving outside the village as members of a mobile support team as provided in the act and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to
ESDA activities as provided by law. (1965 Code § 2-3-8)
2-3-9: AUTHORIZATION:
The corporate authorities may, on the recommendation of the coordinator, make any purchase or enter into any contract necessary to place the village in a
position to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of any disaster, manmade or
natural. In the event of any disaster, the coordinator is authorized on behalf of the village to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may
be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to
village contracts or obligations, as authorized by the act; provided, that if the village board meets at such time, the coordinator shall act subject to the
direction and restrictions imposed by that body. (1965 Code § 2-3-9)
2-3-10: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity, whether compensated or noncompensated, in the village ESDA shall, before entering upon his duties,
subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator:
I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 29/307
Constitution of the State of Illinois and the territory, institutions, and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic:
That I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that
advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence: and that during such time as I am affiliated with the
Village of Lyons ESDA Organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the
government of the United States or this State by force or violence.
(1965 Code § 2-3-10)
2-3-11: OFFICE SPACE DESIGNATED:
The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building for the village ESDA office. (1965 Code § 2-3-11)
2-3-12: APPROPRIATIONS:
The corporate authorities may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law, and may levy a tax not to exceed five cents
($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable property for ESDA purposes only. However, the amount collectable under
such levy shall in no event exceed twenty five cents ($0.25) per capita. (1965 Code § 2-3-12)
2-3-13: NOTIFICATION TO MEDIA:
Prior to conducting an exercise, the village president or his designee shall notify area media with written notification of the disaster training exercise. Such
notification shall indicate that information relating to the exercise shall not be released to the public until the commencement of the exercise. The
publication shall also contain a request that the notice be so posted to ensure that all relevant media personnel are advised of the exercise before it
begins. During the conduct of such exercise, all messages, two-way radio communications, briefings, status reports, news releases, and other oral or
written communications shall begin and end with the following statement: "This Is An Exercise Message". (1965 Code § 2-3-13; amd. 2009 Code)

ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS/PLAN COMMISSION1

Chapter 5
BUILDING BOARD OF APPEALS1
2-5-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is hereby established a building board of appeals as provided by ICC code to provide a hearing process to challenge the decision of the building
director. The building director shall be an ex officio member of the board, but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board shall consist of
members who are qualified by training and experience and who are not employees of the village. The board shall be composed of three (3) members that
shall be appointed from any of the following construction disciplines: an architect or engineer, an electrical engineer or licensed electrical contractor, a
licensed plumber or contractor, a mechanical engineer or licensed HVAC contractor and a licensed contractor or building director from another community.
Such appointments shall be made by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees and shall be for an indefinite period. (1965
Code § 2-16-1; amd. Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
2-5-2: DUTIES:
The building board of appeals shall function as a board of review for those challenging a decision of the building director. The board shall have no authority
to waive the requirements of this code. (1965 Code § 2-16-2)
2-5-3: FEE:
The fee to be charged to file an appeal before the building board of appeals shall be three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). (1965 Code § 2-16-3)
2-5-4: REIMBURSEMENT:
The president and village board of trustees may reimburse members of the building board of appeals for expenses they have incurred in the course of their
duties. (1965 Code § 2-16-4)

Chapter 6
HISTORICAL COMMISSION1
2-6-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERMS:
A. Created; Membership: There is hereby created a Lyons historical commission which shall consist of ten (10) members including a chairperson who shall
be elected by the members. (1965 Code § 2-8-1)
B. Appointment; Terms; Residency: The members of the historical commission shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of
the board of trustees to the following terms: two (2) for one year; two (2) for two (2) years; two (2) for three (3) years; two (2) for four (4) years and two
(2) for five (5) years. The successor to each member shall serve for a term of five (5) years, or the same member shall serve for five (5) years if he is
reappointed. No member shall serve more than two (2) consecutive terms, and all members shall be residents of the village. (1965 Code § 2-8-2; amd.
Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
2-6-2: DUTIES:
The commission shall have the duty of preserving the historical records and artifacts pertaining to the history of the village; of effecting the use of all
historical objects for educational, informational and other proper purposes; and such other related duties as may be delegated by the president and board
of trustees. (1965 Code § 2-8-3)
2-6-3: ANNUAL REPORT:
On or before December 31 of each year, the commission shall file a written report of its activities for the year and recommendations of matters for further
consideration. Such report shall be filed with the village president. (1965 Code § 2-8-4; amd. 2009 Code)
2-6-4: COMPENSATION:
The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. (1965 Code § 2-8-5)
Chapter 7
ANTIBLIGHT COMMISSION1
2-7-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP:
A. Board Created: There is hereby created an antiblight commission for the village. (1965 Code § 2-10-1)
B. Membership: The members of the antiblight commission shall consist of:
1. One trustee of the village, appointed by the village board, to serve as liaison.
2. The village building and code director or his designee. (1965 Code § 2-10-2)
3. Eight (8) residents of the village, who shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for terms of
four (4) years. (Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; amd. Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
4. The village manager or his designee as ex officio. (1965 Code § 2-10-2)
2-7-2: TERMS; APPOINTMENT; VACANCIES; COMPENSATION:
A. Terms: The members of said commission serving ex officio shall serve for the terms of their respective municipal offices. The chair shall be appointed
by a majority of the commission members to serve until the chair is no longer on the board or is replaced by a vote of the majority of the commission
members. (1965 Code § 2-10-3)
B. Appointments: (Rep. by Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009)
C. Vacancies; Removals: All vacancies occurring in said commission shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term of office only, in
the same manner as the original appointments. Any member of the commission may be removed therefrom by the president, subject to ratification by
the board of trustees, for due cause shown.
D. Compensation: All members of the commission shall serve without compensation. (1965 Code § 2-10-3)
2-7-3: ORGANIZATION; PROCEDURE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 31/307
A. Officers; Bylaws: The commission shall elect a vice chair, secretary and such other officers from its own membership, and shall adopt such bylaws
regulating the time, place and manner of holding its meetings and conducting its business as may, in the judgment of the commission, be proper and
necessary in carrying on the work of the commission.
B. Records And Reports: The commission shall keep a written record of its proceedings, which shall be open at all times to public inspection, and shall
also file an annual report with the board of trustees setting forth its transactions and recommendations. In all instances, said commission shall report
directly to the board of trustees.
C. Publicity: The commission may arrange and conduct publicity relative to its authorized activities for the purpose of public understanding. (1965 Code
§ 2-10-4)
2-7-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The commission shall have the following powers and duties:
A. To work toward the correction of blighting conditions by securing the voluntary cooperation of the building owners, if possible, and when necessary, to
call for legal action to secure the results required in the enforcement of applicable ordinances.
B. The commission's authority shall include the observation of blighting conditions from all public areas, notification of owners and occupants of such
conditions, requesting voluntary compliance, and coordination of antiblight campaigns and services. (1965 Code § 2-10-5)
2-7-5: PRIVACY OF RECORDS:
The records of the antiblight commission are exempt from disclosure, where authorized by statute. Disclosure or utilization of such records in such
instances shall require authority of the antiblight commission. (1965 Code § 2-10-6)
Chapter 8
ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY CONTROL BOARD/QUARRY RELATIONS COMMITTEE1
2-8-1: CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM; VACANCIES:
A. Board Created: There is hereby created an environmental quality control board/quarry relations committee (hereinafter referred to as the "board") in and
for the village. (1965 Code § 2-15-1)
B. Membership; Appointment; Term; Vacancies:
1. The chair and six (6) members shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a three (3) year
term. (Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; amd. Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
2. All vacancies in the board shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term of office only. (1965 Code § 2-15-3)
2-8-2: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
A. The board is charged with the responsibility for recommending plans, procedures and regulations to the village board concerning all air, water and land
environmental issues, including, but not limited to, garbage, recycling, airborne emission and discharge of other pollutants into the air, water or on
private or public property.
B. The committee shall also review village monitoring activities with regard to particulate pollution, noise pollution and blasting at the quarry site, and to
make recommendations to the village board. (1965 Code § 2-15-2)
2-8-3: COMPENSATION:
All members of the board shall serve without compensation. The president and board of trustees may reimburse members of the board for expenses they
have incurred in the course of their duties. (1965 Code § 2-15-4)

village, and all employees and volunteers therein. The director shall serve as a liaison to the village recreation board and shall perform such duties as
are assigned to him or her from time to time by the village manager. (Ord. 09-07-2011-O2, 9-7-2011)
Chapter 10
ELECTRICAL COMMISSION1
2-10-1: ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM; COMPENSATION:
A. Established; Membership: There is hereby established an electrical commission which shall consist of six (6) members, as follows: The building director
shall be a member and ex officio chair of the commission; of the other five (5) members, one shall be a registered professional engineer, one an
electrical contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one a representative of a company supplying electricity, and one a representative of an inspection
bureau maintained by the board of fire underwriters or, if no such representative resides in the village, then the chief of the fire department shall be a

Code; Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)

The electrical commission shall recommend safe and practical standards and specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment.
They shall supervise the making of electrical inspections, and shall determine that there shall be compliance with all regulations provided in the electrical
code (title 12, chapter 5 of this code), and: (1965 Code § 2-4-2; amd. 2009 Code)
A. They shall periodically study various regulations and determine the adequacy of same to protect the residents of the village.
B. They shall approve the qualifications of applicants for registration and licensing within the village and may require applicants to submit to examination
as to knowledge and fitness to engage in the business of electrical contractor. (1965 Code § 2-4-2)
2-10-3: REIMBURSEMENT:
The president and board of trustees may reimburse members of the electrical commission for expenses they have incurred in the course of their duties.
(1965 Code § 2-4-3)
