determining whether or not the said premises complies with all the ordinances relating to health, safety and sanitation so as to properly safeguard the
lives and health of the employees engaged therein and customers frequenting same.
B. Issuance Of License: If the village manager is satisfied that the applicant has complied with the provisions of this code regulating health, safety and
sanitation, he shall, upon payment by such applicant to the village clerk of the license fee as provided in section 4-1-3 of this title, issue or cause to be
issued to such applicant a license to conduct and operate such business. (1965 Code § 4-9-2; amd. 2009 Code)
4-9-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
Every such store shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard the lives and health of all persons
employed or trading in such establishments, and adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be provided for such employees. All articles
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 68/307
kept for sale shall be kept free from vermin or any matter of a contagious or infectious nature. No person suffering from an active contagious or infectious
disease shall be employed in such store. All refuse, waste and sweepings shall be removed and disposed of at least once each day and in such a manner
as not to cause a nuisance, and all cleaning shall be done, as far as possible, outside of working hours, but if done during working hours, shall be done in
such a manner as to avoid the unnecessary raising of dust or noxious material. (1965 Code § 4-9-4; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 10
SHOE STORES
4-10-1: DEFINITION:
The term "shoe store", as used in this chapter, shall be construed to mean any building, room, place or premises operated, maintained or conducted for
the sale or offering or keeping for sale of any shoes, boots, slippers, sandals or other footwear. (1965 Code § 4-12-1; amd. 2009 Code)
4-10-2: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required: No person shall establish, operate, maintain or conduct any "shoe store", as defined in section 4-10-1 of this chapter, without first
having obtained a license. (1965 Code § 4-12-1)
B. Application: Any person desiring a license to establish, maintain or conduct such store as described in section 4-10-1 of this chapter shall make written
application to the village clerk stating the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual; or all the members of the firm, if a copartnership; or
names and residences of the principal officers, if the applicant is a corporation; also, the location and description of the premises where such business
is to be conducted. (1965 Code § 4-12-2; amd. 2009 Code)
4-10-3: INSPECTION OF PREMISES; LICENSE ISSUANCE:
A. Inspection Authorized: It shall be the duty of the village manager to have the premises so described inspected by the health officer and fire chief for the
purpose of determining the fitness and suitability of such premises for such business, from a sanitary standpoint, and determining whether or not the
said premises complies with all the provisions of this code relating to health, safety and sanitation so as to properly safeguard the lives and health of
the employees engaged therein and customers frequenting same.
B. License Issuance: If the village manager is satisfied that the applicant has complied with the provisions of this code, he shall, upon payment by such
applicant to the village clerk of the license fee as provided in section 4-1-3 of this title, issue or cause to be issued to such applicant a license to
conduct and operate such business. (1965 Code § 4-12-2; amd. 2009 Code)
4-10-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
Every such store shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard the lives and health of all persons
employed or trading in such establishments, and adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be provided for such employees. All articles
kept for sale shall be kept free from vermin or any matter of contagious or infectious nature. No person suffering from an active contagious or infectious
disease shall be employed in such store. All refuse, waste and sweepings shall be removed and disposed of at least once each day and in such a manner
as not to cause a nuisance, and all cleaning shall be done, as far as possible, outside of working hours, but if done during working hours, shall be done in
such a manner as to avoid the unnecessary raising of dust or noxious material. (1965 Code § 4-12-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 11
BARBERSHOPS AND BEAUTY PARLORS
ARTICLE A. BARBERSHOPS
4-11A-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
BARBER: One who cuts or dresses hair or shaves another.
BARBERSHOP: Any building, room, place or establishment where any hair cutting, shaving or massaging is given or employed. (1965 Code § 4-11-1)
4-11A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; TERM; APPLICATION:
A. License Required: No person shall establish, maintain or operate any "barbershop", as defined in section 4-11A-1 of this article, without first having
obtained a license as hereinafter provided.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 69/307
B. Term: The license shall expire on December 31. (1965 Code § 4-11-2)
C. Application: Any person desiring a license to establish, maintain or operate a "barbershop", as defined in section 4-11A-1 of this article, shall make
written application to the health officer, stating the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual; or all the members of the firm, if a
copartnership; or the names and residences of the principal officers, if a corporation; also, the training and experience of the applicant, the time or
place where the said applicant has obtained his or her required training or state license and the place or places at which it is intended or desired to
conduct said barbershop. (1965 Code § 4-11-3)
4-11A-3: INVESTIGATION OF PREMISES AND APPLICANT:
The health officer shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises named in such application for the purpose of determining the fitness
and suitability of said premises for the conduct of such business, from a sanitary standpoint. He shall also cause an investigation to be made of the
applicant and the qualifications mentioned in the application to determine whether the said applicant is of good character and reputation; to determine if all
the provisions of this code, and laws of the state relative to the operation and maintenance of barbershops, have been complied with; and also, if all
necessary precautions are and will be taken in said establishment to prevent the spread of contagious or communicable disease. (1965 Code § 4-11-4)
4-11A-4: LICENSE ISSUANCE:
The health officer, upon completion of such investigation, shall transmit to the village president such application, together with a recommendation for or
against the issuance of such a license. If the village president shall be satisfied that the applicant or its chief officers (if the applicant be a corporation) is of
good moral character and repute and that the person or persons employed hold the proper state licenses wherever the same is required, the village
president, upon payment by such applicant to the village clerk of the license fee as provided in section 4-1-3 of this title, shall issue or cause to be issued
to such applicant a license to conduct a barbershop. (1965 Code § 4-11-5; amd. 2009 Code)
4-11A-5: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. It shall be the duty of every person licensed to conduct a barbershop to at all times keep the premises where such establishment is conducted in a
clean and proper sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to properly safeguard the life and health of all patrons of such
establishments and of all persons employed in such establishments against communicable and contagious diseases.
B. Clean linen must be supplied for each individual patron.
C. No person suffering from a communicable disease shall be employed in a barbershop.
D. All towels and washcloths used in such establishments shall be washed with soap and water and boiled before being used on another patron. All
receptacles, finger bowls, utensils, vessels, appliances or anything whatsoever used in such establishments shall at all times be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
E. All scissors, clippers, tweezers, needles, razors, scalpels, massage cups, combs, brushes, blackhead removers or other instruments used must be kept
clean and free from infected materials, and must be thoroughly sterilized by the application of an approved disinfectant or by boiling, whenever used
upon any person showing any signs of any disease of the skin or scalp.
F. Shaving mugs and brushes must be thoroughly scalded before being used upon any patron. Headrests must be covered with a clean cloth or paper, and
such covering shall be removed after each use by a patron. (1965 Code § 4-11-7)
4-11A-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The health officer may, at any time, recommend the revocation of any license issued under the terms of this article, and the village president may revoke
such license by notice in writing, and allowing the licensee an opportunity for hearing before the village board of trustees, whenever it shall appear to his
satisfaction from the recommendation of the health officer, or otherwise, that the licensee has violated the provisions of any law of the state, or of any
provision of this code relating to the carrying on of the business named in such license. (1965 Code § 4-11-6; amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE B. BEAUTY PARLORS
4-11B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the terms "beauty parlor", "cosmetic establishment" or "physical therapeutic establishment" are defined to mean any
building, room, place or establishment where any hair dressing, beauty culture, facial massage, or manicuring is carried on; or where massage or Turkish,
Russian, vapor, or other baths are given; or where physical culture, electric, thermic, or other physical therapeutic or cosmetic treatments are given or
employed outside of a regularly licensed hospital or dispensary. (1965 Code § 4-10-1)
4-11B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; TERM; APPLICATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 70/307
A. License Required; Term: No person shall establish, maintain, or operate any beauty parlor or cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishment, as defined
in section 4-11B-1 of this article, without first having obtained a license as hereinafter provided. The license shall expire on December 31 following.
(1965 Code § 4-10-2)
B. Application: Any person desiring a license to establish, maintain or operate a beauty parlor or cosmetic or therapeutic establishment, as defined in
section 4-11B-1 of this article, shall make written application to the health officer stating the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual; or all
the members of the firm, if a copartnership; or the names and residences of the principal officers, if a corporation; also, the training and experience of
the applicant, the time or place where the said applicant has obtained his or her required training or state license, and the place or places in which it is
intended or desired to conduct said cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishments. (1965 Code § 4-10-3)
4-11B-3: INVESTIGATION:
The health officer shall then make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises named in such application for the purpose of determining the
fitness and suitability of said premises for the conduct of such business from a sanitary standpoint. He shall also cause an investigation to be made of the
applicant and the qualifications mentioned in the application to determine whether the said applicant is of good character and reputation; to determine if all
the provisions of this code and laws of the state relative to the operation and maintenance of cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishments have been
complied with; and also, if all necessary precautions are and will be taken in said establishment to prevent the spread of contagious or communicable
disease. (1965 Code § 4-10-4)
4-11B-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The health officer, upon completion of such investigation, shall transmit to the village president such application, together with a recommendation for or
against the issuance of such a license. If the village president shall be satisfied that the applicant or its chief officers (if the applicant be a corporation) is or
are of good moral character and repute, and that the person employed holds the proper state license wherever the same is required, the president, upon
payment of the license fee provided in section 4-1-3 of this title, to the village clerk, shall issue or cause to be issued to such applicant a license to conduct
a beauty parlor or cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishment. (1965 Code § 4-10-5; amd. 2009 Code)
4-11B-5: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. It shall be the duty of every person licensed to conduct a beauty parlor or cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishment to at all times keep the
premises where such establishment is conducted in a clean and proper sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to properly safeguard
the life and health of all patrons of such establishments and of all persons employed in such establishments against communicable and contagious
diseases.
B. All massage tables, couches, beds or similar structures used shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. Clean linen must be supplied for each
individual patron.
C. No person suffering from a communicable disease shall be employed in a cosmetic or physical therapeutic establishment.
D. All towels and washcloths used in such establishments shall be washed with soap and water and boiled before being used on another patron. All
receptacles, finger bowls, utensils, vessels, appliances or anything whatsoever used in such establishments shall at all times be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition.
E. All scissors, clippers, tweezers, needles, razors, scalpels, massage instruments, cups, combs, brushes, blackhead removers or other instruments used
must be kept clean and free from infectious material, and must be thoroughly sterilized by the application of an approved disinfectant, or by boiling,
whenever used upon any person showing any signs of any disease of the skin or scalp.
F. The use of powder puffs, sponges and styptic pencils in any such establishment is prohibited.
G. Shaving mugs and brushes must be thoroughly scalded before being used upon any patron. Headrests must be covered with a clean cloth or paper,
and such covering shall be removed after each use by a patron. (1965 Code § 4-10-7)
4-11B-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The health officer may, at any time, recommend the revocation of any license issued under the terms of this article, and the village president may revoke
such license by notice in writing, and allowing the licensee an opportunity for hearing before the village board of trustees, whenever it shall appear to his
satisfaction from the recommendation of the health officer, or otherwise, that the licensee has violated any law of the state or any provision of this code
relating to the carrying on of the business named in such license. (1965 Code § 4-10-6; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 12
LAUNDRY AND DRY CLEANING SERVICES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 71/307
ARTICLE A. SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES
4-12A-1: DEFINITION:
The term "self-service laundries", as used in this article, shall mean any establishment in which coin operated facilities are available for washing clothes or
for drying clothes, or both, and which is open and available to the general public for use. (1965 Code § 4-22-2)
4-12A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE:
It shall be unlawful to establish or operate any self-service laundry in the village without first having secured a license therefor as herein provided.
Applications for such licenses shall comply with the general provisions relating to applications for licenses and permits. For designated license fees, see
section 4-1-3 of this title. (1965 Code § 4-22-1)
4-12A-3: INSTALLING EQUIPMENT:
Installation of all equipment in such establishments shall be in conformity with the building and zoning laws of the village. (1965 Code § 4-22-4)
4-12A-4: INSPECTION:
It shall be the duty of the village health officer to inspect each self-service laundry at least once every six (6) months. Such self-service laundry must be
kept in a clean condition and shall be free of all vermin, rodents and insects. (1965 Code § 4-22-5)
4-12A-5: HOURS; EXCEPTION:
It shall be unlawful to keep any such establishment open for business between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. unless
there is an adult attendant in charge of the premises during such hours. (1965 Code § 4-22-3)
ARTICLE B. DRY CLEANING MACHINES
4-12B-1: DEFINITION:
An "automatic dry cleaning machine", as the term is used in this article, shall be construed to include and mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of
fabrics and designed to be used or operated by anyone but the owner, or any employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or
contains perchlorethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. (1965
Code § 4-21-2)
4-12B-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to install, operate or maintain any "automatic dry cleaning machine", as defined in section 4-12B-1 of this article, except in compliance
with the provisions of this article; or without complying with all of the provisions pertaining to the installation and operation of such machine herein
contained; or in violation of any laws, rules or regulations of the state department of public health relating thereto. (1965 Code § 4-21-1)
4-12B-3: LICENSE, PERMIT AND FEE:
A. Machine Installation Permit: It shall be unlawful to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without first having secured a permit therefor.
B. Business License; Fee:
1. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of maintaining any such machine for use by the public upon payment of a fee, without having first
secured a license therefor.
2. The annual fee for such license shall be as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this title. (1965 Code § 4-21-3)
4-12B-4: INSPECTIONS; SAFE AND SANITARY CONDITIONS:
It shall be the duty of the village manager to cause such inspections to be made by the health officer and fire chief or his officers as are necessary to see
to the enforcement of the provisions of this article. All such establishments shall be maintained in a safe, clean condition, free from odors, vermin, rodents
and insects. (1965 Code § 4-21-6; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 72/307
Chapter 13
BUSINESSES DEALING WITH PETROLEUM PRODUCTS
4-13-1: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of selling, transporting or storing gasoline, benzine, naphtha or any of the combustibles
mentioned in section 4-13-4 of this chapter without first procuring a license so to do, as hereinafter provided. (1965 Code § 4-18-3)
B. Application For License: Any person desiring a license to sell, keep, store, transport or distribute any gasoline, benzine, benzol, naphtha or other like
volatile combustibles shall make a written application to the village clerk which shall state the name and address of the applicant and the location and
description of the building or place where such business is to be carried on. Such application shall be referred to the fire chief, who shall make an
investigation, and if the location, buildings and equipment comply with the provisions of this code, he shall recommend that the license be issued as
hereinafter provided. (1965 Code § 4-18-4; amd. 2009 Code)
C. License Fee: The fee for a license to sell, keep, store, transport or distribute gasoline, benzine, benzol, naphtha or other similar combustibles per year
or any unexpired portion thereof shall be as follows:
Business Fee
Automobile accessory shops $10 .00
Filling stations:
One pump 10 .00
Each additional pump 10 .00
Garages 10 .00
(1965 Code § 4-18-6)
D. License Term And Conditions: Every such license shall expire on December 31 after its issuance, shall be nontransferable, and shall be good only at
the location therein named. (1965 Code § 4-18-5; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-2: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon compliance with subsection 4-13-1B of this chapter and the payment to the village clerk of the license fee provided in subsection 4-13-1C of this
chapter, the village president shall issue or cause to be issued a license to such applicant, authorizing the licensee to carry on the business specified at
the place named therein for and during the term of the license. (1965 Code § 4-18-5; amd. 2009 Code)
4-13-3: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
A. Buildings Where Products Stored:
1. Every building in which gasoline, benzine, benzol, naphtha, or other like volatile substance is kept, stored or sold shall be fireproof throughout.
2. No such building shall be located nearer than ten feet (10') at its nearest point to any other building, or nearer than twenty feet (20') at its nearest
point to any public street or highway.
B. Filling Stations1: No filling station shall be located nearer than twenty feet (20') at its nearest point to any other building or structure or to any street or
public highway.
C. Lighting; Open Flames: No open artificial light shall be used in any such building or filling station nor open fire or flame shall be allowed in any such
place. (1965 Code § 4-18-7)
4-13-4: STORAGE AND HANDLING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, store, transport, sell or use any crude petroleum, benzine, benzol, gasoline, naphtha, ether or other like volatile
combustibles in such manner or under such circumstances as will jeopardize life or property. (1965 Code § 4-18-1)
4-13-5: MARKINGS ON CONTAINERS:
Every person dealing in or selling gasoline, benzine, benzol, naphtha or other volatile combustibles shall keep the same only in barrels, casks, packages,
cans or measures painted red, and having the word "gasoline", "benzine" or "naphtha" plainly stenciled thereon, in black letters, not less than one-half inch
(1/2") in width. (1965 Code § 4-18-2)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 73/307
4-13-6: ENFORCEMENT; INVESTIGATIONS AND INSPECTIONS:
A. Enforcement: It shall be the duty of the fire chief to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
B. Investigations And Inspections: The fire chief shall have the power to make all investigations and inspections which are necessary, and all buildings,
premises and equipments mentioned and referred to in the provisions of this chapter shall be open at all times to investigation and inspection. (1965
Code § 4-18-8)
Footnote 1: See article A of this chapter.
ARTICLE A. GASOLINE FILLING STATIONS1
4-13A-1: DEFINITION:
The words "filling station", as used in this article, shall be held to mean and are hereby defined as meaning any building, structure, premises, enclosure or
other place within the village where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or stationary, and containing ether, carbon bisulfate, gasoline,
naphtha, benzol, hydrocarbon (gas drips), liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene, turpentine or other inflammable liquids, having a flashpoint below
one hundred eighty seven degrees Fahrenheit (187°F) are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale, or distributing any such liquids from
such containers, tank or tanks; provided, however, that the provisions of this article shall not apply to any place where such inflammable liquids are kept or
sold for medicinal purposes only. (1965 Code § 4-17-1)
4-13A-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; TRANSFER:
A. License Required; Fee: No person shall manage, conduct, operate or carry on the business of a filling station without first having obtained a license
therefor and paying the fee as provided in section 4-1-3 of this title. (1965 Code § 4-17-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Application For License: The application for such license for the business of managing, conducting, operating or carrying on a filling station shall
conform to the general provisions of this chapter relating to applications for licenses, and shall specify the location of the building, structure, premises,
enclosure or other place in which such filling station is proposed to be kept, and the capacity in gallons of the container or tank. Every such application
shall be approved by the police chief and the fire department before a license shall be issued. (1965 Code § 4-17-3; amd. 2009 Code)
C. License Nontransferable: No license granted under the provisions of this article shall be assigned or transferred to any person other than the licensee
named therein to do business or act under such license. (1965 Code § 4-17-5)
4-13A-3: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
If any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall, before the expiration of such license, desire to change the location of the business
conducted thereunder, the licensee shall notify the village clerk and shall furnish all of the information which is required to be furnished on an original
application for license. Every such application for change of location shall be approved by the police chief and the fire department before a change in
location shall be authorized. (1965 Code § 4-17-6)
4-13A-4: CONSENT OF PROPERTY OWNERS:
No person shall locate, build, construct, operate or maintain any filling station without obtaining the written consent of the property owners in accordance
with the provisions of title 13 of this code. (1965 Code § 4-17-7)
4-13A-5: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; INSPECTIONS:
All filling stations shall be conducted and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this code with regard to fire prevention and storage of
inflammable liquids, and shall be inspected by the chief of the fire department or his duly authorized representative at least once every year. (1965 Code
§ 4-17-4)
4-13A-6: RESTRICTIONS:
A. Storage Of Inflammable Liquids: Except as otherwise permitted by this code, storage of inflammable liquids shall be outside of buildings. (1965 Code
§ 4-17-8)
B. Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to permit smoking in any filling station. (1965 Code § 4-17-9)
Footnote 1: See subsection 4-13-3B of this chapter for location restrictions.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 74/307
Chapter 14
VEHICLE REPAIR SHOPS1
4-14-1: DEFINITION:
The term "repair shop", as used in this chapter, means a building or structure in the village in which work or service is performed on motor vehicles; such
work to consist of the replacing of, or adding to or repairing, parts of such vehicles, including frames, wheels, bodies, top or other parts, or the painting or
refinishing of such vehicles. (1965 Code § 4-39-2)
4-14-2: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEE:
A. Licenses Required:
1. Sales: No person shall engage in the business of selling at wholesale or retail new or secondhand motor vehicle tires, supplies, parts or accessories,
whether purchased or exchanged, or kept for sale or exchange, without first obtaining a license therefor. (1965 Code § 4-39-1)
2. Repair: No person shall keep, conduct or operate a repair shop in the village without first obtaining a license therefor.
B. In Conjunction With Salesroom: If an automobile repair shop is managed, conducted, operated or carried on in the same building, structure, premises,
enclosure or other place in which an automobile salesroom is managed, conducted, operated or carried on by the same person, such person is
required to take out only one license, and that license shall be the license which requires the payment of the highest license fee.
C. In Conjunction With Garage: A license to conduct or operate a garage, which has been obtained as required in title 13 of this code, shall be deemed to
include a license to maintain a repair shop, and no additional license or fee is required for the operation of the repair shop. (1965 Code § 4-39-3)
4-14-3: CLEANLINESS; FIRE HAZARDS; OBSTRUCTIONS:
A. Cleanliness; Fire Hazards: All repair shops conducted and maintained in accordance with this chapter shall be kept in a clean condition. Oil, grease,
dirt, refuse and inflammable material of any kind shall not be permitted to accumulate (so as to constitute a fire hazard) or be tracked from any such
repair shop onto the streets or sidewalks of the village.
B. Blocking Streets: No vehicle or other article used in connection with such repair shop shall block the streets, parkways or sidewalks near or adjacent to
such repair shop or interfere with the free use of the streets, parkways or sidewalks by the public. (1965 Code § 4-39-3)
Footnote 1: See subsection 13-12-2K of this code for vehicle repair in residential districts.
Chapter 15
TAXICABS
4-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated, whenever used in this chapter, the following terms shall apply:
FLAT RATE TAXICAB: All public vehicles driven by mechanical power used for the carriage of persons for hire on a flat rate or predesignated charge
basis, except those vehicles commonly known as buses.
OWNER: Every person, firm or corporation having the use or control of one or more "taxicabs", as that term is defined in this section.
TAXICAB: All public vehicles driven by mechanical power used for the carriage of persons for hire except those vehicles commonly known as buses.
TAXIMETER: A mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated, either for distance traveled or for
waiting time, or for both, and upon which such charge shall be indicated by means of figures. (1965 Code § 4-26-1)
4-15-2: JURISDICTION AND ENFORCEMENT:
The licensing and inspecting of taxicabs, the examining of applicants for licenses to drive such taxicabs and the licensing of drivers as hereinafter
provided, and enforcing the provisions of this chapter shall be under the control of the chief of police. The chief of police shall have power to appoint from
the police department such inspectors as he may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof who shall serve as such as part of their
police duties. The inspecting and sealing of taximeters shall be under the jurisdiction of the village clerk. (1965 Code § 4-26-3)
4-15-3: DECLARATION OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY:
A. Declaration; Hearing; Exceptions: No taxicab license shall hereafter be issued unless the president and the board of trustees, after a hearing, shall by
resolution declare that public convenience and necessity require the proposed taxicab service for which application for a license is made; provided, that
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 75/307
such declaration of public convenience and necessity shall not be necessary:
1. For the licensing of the same number of taxicabs licensed for operation and operated by the applicant under the same name and colors, for which
license was issued previous to the effective date hereof, or the renewal of the same number of licenses annually thereafter.
2. For the renewal of licenses to the applicant for the number of taxicabs of the applicant for which the president and board of trustees shall, at any time
prior to the date of application for such renewal, have made declaration of public convenience and necessity. (1965 Code § 4-26-12)
B. Grounds For Declaration: In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the licensing of such taxicabs for which application is made,
the president and board of trustees shall take into consideration whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such proposed or
such additional taxicab service within the village; the financial responsibility of the applicant; the number, kind and type of equipment; the schedule of
maximum rates and rates proposed to be charged; the color scheme to be used by the applicant; the increased traffic congestion and demand for
increased parking spaces on the streets of the village which may result; whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and
pedestrian, will be preserved by the granting of such additional license; and such other relevant facts as the president and board of trustees may deem
advisable and necessary. (1965 Code § 4-26-13)
C. Proceedings After Hearing:
1. If the president and board of trustees finds from the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the
vehicle for which license is desired, it shall notify the applicant of its findings. Within sixty (60) days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish to the
president and board of trustees any and all additional information which may be required, and if the president and board of trustees then finds that
the applicant is the owner or lessee and bona fide operator of the vehicle for which license is desired, and that such vehicle complies with all
provisions of this code, license shall thereupon be issued to the applicant upon the payment of the proper license fee.
2. If the president and board of trustees finds from such investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation
of the vehicles for which license is desired, it shall forthwith notify the applicant of said finding. (1965 Code § 4-26-14)
4-15-4: TAXICAB LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. License Required; Term; Application:
1. No taxicab shall ply upon the streets of the village without first obtaining a license from the village clerk.
2. Such license shall be issued as of the fiscal year and shall be effective for such period of time unless sooner suspended or revoked.
3. Applications for licenses for the taxicabs shall be made to the village clerk by the owner or operator thereof upon blank forms to be furnished by said
clerk, and such application shall contain the full name and address of the owner or operator, the class of the vehicle for which the license is desired,
the length of time the vehicle has been in use, the number of persons it is capable of carrying, and if a motor driven vehicle, the motor power thereof.
Such application shall thereupon be referred by the clerk to the chief of police. (1965 Code § 4-26-4)
B. Vehicle Inspection; License Suspension Or Revocation For Noncompliance:
1. No vehicle shall be licensed until it has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined and found to be in thoroughly safe condition for the
transportation of passengers, clean, fit, of good appearance, and well painted.
2. No license shall be issued to any person having the name or color of his taxicab similar to that of any other person licensed to operate a taxicab
within the limits of the village. The chief of police shall make, or have made, by his inspectors, such examination and inspection, or any inspector
appointed by him shall examine any taximeter attached to any taxicab and see that the same is accurate before the license to operate such taxicab
is issued by the clerk, and report his findings to the village board. Upon approval of the application by the chief of police, said chief shall so endorse
such application and file the same with the clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed fee, issue the license as provided by subsection D of
this section. The village president shall revoke or suspend the license of any taxicab found to be unfit or unsuited for public patronage. (1965 Code
§ 4-26-5)
C. Compliance Required; Surety Bond Or Insurance: No person shall be licensed to operate a taxicab until the owner or operator thereof shall have
complied with all provisions of this chapter, and with all sections of the state law pertaining to a surety bond or the insurance policy issued for the
benefit of any person who might suffer damage by reason of the operation of such vehicle. Before issuing such license, the applicant shall submit to the
village clerk the approval of such bond by the secretary of state, or proof of the issuance of such insurance policy. (1965 Code § 4-26-6)
D. License Card Or Plate: The license to be issued by the village clerk as hereinabove provided shall be in the form of a card or plate which shall contain
the official license number of the taxicab, together with the date of inspection. Such card shall be signed by the village clerk and shall contain blank
space upon which an entry shall be made of the date of inspection of the taxicab by the chief of police or an inspector appointed by him. License cards
shall be of a distinctly different color each year, and in the case of taxicabs, the license number assigned thereto shall in each case be the same as that
issued to the vehicle for that year pursuant to law. Such cards shall be affixed to a conspicuous and indispensable part of each taxicab. The design of
such plates shall be changed annually. The village clerk shall, at the time, issue a vehicle license for such taxicab. (1965 Code § 4-26-7; amd. 2009
Code)
E. License Fees: The annual license fee shall be as specified in section 4-1-3 of this title. Such license fees shall be in lieu of the regular annual license
fees charged by the village for motor vehicles housed in the village as established in this code. No additional charge, except as above provided, shall
be made. In the case of licenses issued on or after May 1 in each year hereafter, one-half (1/2) only of the annual fee shall be paid. (1965 Code § 4-26-
8)
F. Register Of Licensed Vehicles: The village clerk and chief of police shall keep a register of the name and address of each person owning or operating a
vehicle licensed under subsection A of this section, together with the license number and the description, make and necessary dimensions of such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 76/307
vehicle, with the date and complete record of inspections made thereof. Such records shall be open to the inspection of the public at all times, and shall
be public records, extracts of which may be certified for use as evidence by the clerk. (1965 Code § 4-26-9)
G. Inspection Of Taxicabs: The chief of police shall maintain constant vigilance over all taxicabs; see that they are kept in a condition of continued fitness
for public use; and to this end, the chief of police or his inspectors shall inspect all taxicabs from time to time, or on the complaint of any person, or as
often as may be necessary. At least twice each year, the chief of police shall make a written report of all such inspections to the president and village
board of trustees. (1965 Code § 4-26-10)
H. Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses: Licenses granted hereunder are subject to revocation at any time by the village president for good cause
shown, or if it shall have been determined that said taxicab is not in good condition for operation. Licenses, when so revoked or suspended, shall not
be reissued until the cause for such revocation shall have been removed to the satisfaction of the president. (1965 Code § 4-26-11)
4-15-5: DRIVER LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
A. Requirements For Applicants: Every person driving a taxicab must be licensed as such and comply with the following:
1. Applicant for a driver's license must be of the age of twenty one (21) years or over.
2. Applicant for a driver's license must be of sound physique, with good eyesight, and not subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart trouble, or any other
infirmity of body or mind which might render him unfit for the safe operation of a taxicab.
3. Applicant for a driver's license must be able to read, write and speak the English language. (1965 Code § 4-26-17)
4. Applicant for a driver's license must be clean in dress and person and not be addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors and/or controlled substances.
(1965 Code § 4-26-17; amd. 2009 Code)
5. Any person desiring to secure a license as driver of any public vehicle hereunder and used for the carriage of passengers for hire or reward shall
make application in writing therefor to the village clerk, upon a form to be provided by the clerk. Such application shall set forth the name of the
applicant, his residence addresses for the past five (5) years, the dates of such residences, his date of birth, his social security number, his place of
birth, his hair and eye color, his height and weight, his Illinois driver's license number, and a list of any and all convictions for criminal offenses
including traffic offenses, whether he has previously been issued a license as a taxicab driver or chauffeur by any unit of government, whether said
license(s) have ever been suspended or revoked, and the reasons therefor.
6. A recent photograph of the applicant shall also be attached to the application clearly showing the applicant's face.
7. In addition to the foregoing, the applicant shall submit to fingerprinting by a duly authorized peace officer, for the purpose of a criminal background
check, and the applicant shall sign a release authorizing the taking of fingerprints and their use for the purpose of conducting a criminal background
check. No driver's license shall issue until the background check is complete. Each applicant shall receive a copy of any conviction information
received as a result of the fingerprint check. Within seven (7) working days of receipt of such copy, the applicant shall have the responsibility and
obligation to notify the clerk if the information is inaccurate or incomplete. In the absence of a response, the license may be granted or denied based
upon the information in the report.
8. Conviction of a felony or a crime involving injury, attempted injury or threatened injury to another person shall be grounds for denial or an
application and grounds for revocation of a license. (1965 Code § 4-26-16)
B. Examination Of Drivers: Each applicant for driver's license under subsection A of this section shall be examined by the health officer and by the chief of
police, or someone by him designated, as to the applicant's knowledge of the provisions of this chapter, the traffic regulations, and the geography of the
village. If the results of the examinations are unsatisfactory, the applicant shall be refused a license. Each applicant must demonstrate his skill and
ability to safely handle a vehicle by driving it through a crowded section of the village accompanied by an inspector or other representative of the chief
of police. If the chief of police shall approve the application, he shall endorse thereon such approval and return same to the clerk, who shall issue such
license. (1965 Code § 4-26-17)
C. Additional Requirements; License Term:
1. Such driver's license shall also be in such form as to contain the signature of the licensee and blank spaces upon which a record may be made of
any arrest of, or serious complaint against, him. Any licensee who defaces, removes or obliterates any official entry made upon his license shall be
punished by the revocation of his license. (1965 Code § 4-26-18)
2. Driver's licenses shall be issued as of January 1 in each and every year, and shall be valid to and including December 31. (1965 Code § 4-26-18;
amd. 2009 Code)
D. Badge For Drivers: Every person licensed as a driver shall, at all times while acting as a driver of any vehicle licensed under the provisions of this
chapter, wear a metal badge at least one and three-fourths inches (13/4") long and one-eighth inch (1/8") wide and having a number thereon
corresponding to the number of such driver's license. Such badge shall be obtained from the village clerk. Where any driver has obtained a similar
badge in any other municipality in Cook County, Illinois, it shall not be necessary for him to obtain the badge described in this subsection, but he must
at all times wear the badge of this or such other municipality. (1965 Code § 4-26-19)
E. Renewal Of License: The village president may renew a driver's license from year to year by appropriate endorsement thereon. A driver, in applying for
a renewal of his license, shall make such application upon a form to be furnished by the village clerk entitled "Application For Renewal Of Licenses",
which shall be filled out with the full name and address of the applicant, together with a statement of the date upon which his original license was
granted and the number thereof. (1965 Code § 4-26-20)
F. Suspension Or Revocation Of License: A driver's license may be suspended or revoked at any time by the village president for cause. Any such
suspension shall be noted on the license, together with a statement of the reason therefor, and the driver shall be deprived of his badge by the officer
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 77/307
suspending or revoking such license. No driver whose license has been revoked shall again be licensed as a public taxicab driver in the village unless,
upon presentation of reasons satisfactory to the president or in a case where the license has been suspended or revoked by the president, the
approval of the president shall be necessary before the restoration or reissuance of said license. The president shall notify the police department when
any such license is revoked. If any licensed driver shall change his residence at any time before the expiration of his license, he shall forthwith notify
the chief of police of such act. (1965 Code § 4-26-21)
G. License Fees: The following license fees shall be paid for driver's licenses:
For each original license $1 .00
For each renewal 1 .00
(1965 Code § 4-26-22)
H. Records Kept: There shall be kept in the office of the village clerk and the police department a complete record of each license issued to a driver and all
renewals, suspensions or revocations thereof. The village clerk's record shall be kept on file with the original application of the driver for a license.
(1965 Code § 4-26-23)
4-15-6: SAFE, ADEQUATE SERVICE:
Every owner is required to furnish reasonable and adequate service at just and reasonable rates within the village as may be reasonably required to
assure adequate accommodations to the public in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-26-2)
4-15-7: TAXICAB SERVICE REQUIRED; ABANDONMENT:
A. Service: The applicant shall regularly and daily operate his licensed taxicab during each day of the licensed year to the extent reasonably necessary to
meet the public demand for such taxicab service.
B. Abandonment: Upon complete abandonment of taxicab service for the period of ten (10) consecutive days by the owner or operator of such taxicab
service, the chief of police, upon hearing, after five (5) days' notice to the said owner or operator, shall thereupon recommend to the village president
that the license of such owner or operator shall be revoked covering such taxicab of the owner or operator. (1965 Code § 4-26-15)
4-15-8: FLAT RATE AND NONFLAT RATE TAXICABS:
A. Flat Rate Taxicabs: No taxicab operating on a flat rate basis shall travel, pick up or discharge passengers on any public street other than a through
street. Every taxicab stopped or parked for the purpose of picking up or discharging passengers shall be stopped or parked with the right hand wheels
of such vehicle parallel with and within twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb. It shall be unlawful for any driver to permit any person to board or
alight from any taxicab on any side other than the right hand side thereof. (1965 Code § 4-26-24)
B. Nonflat Rate Taxicabs:
1. Taximeters Required: Each taxicab not operating on a flat rate basis must have affixed thereto and in good working order a taximeter. Each taxicab
must be licensed in accordance with the terms of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-26-25)
2. Inspection: No license shall be issued for a taxicab, not operating on a flat rate basis, until the taximeter attached thereto shall have been inspected
as provided by subsection B3 of this section and found to be accurate. (1965 Code § 4-26-26)
3. Testing; Removal: No person owning or operating any taxicab, except cabs being operated on a flat rate basis, shall offer or let the same for hire or
reward anywhere within the village unless the taximeter placed, attached, or installed thereon has been inspected and tested by the inspector; and
no such person shall detach any certified or inspected taximeter from any taxicab and attach the same to any other taxicab, the front wheels of which
are a different diameter from those with reference to which the taximeter was originally tested, unless a new inspection or certification is had on such
taximeter. (1965 Code § 4-26-27)
4. Dial On Taximeter:
a. Each taxicab required to have a taximeter shall, during the period between sunset and sunrise, be equipped with a light which shall be so reflected
upon the dial of the taximeter as to enable the passengers engaging and using such taxicab to read the figures indicated thereon.
b. Every taximeter hereafter placed on a taxicab shall be so arranged that the dial thereof is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such
taxicab or upon alighting from same. (1965 Code § 4-26-28)
5. Unapproved Taximeter: No person shall drive a taxicab to which is attached a taximeter that has not been duly inspected and approved. (1965 Code
§ 4-26-29)
4-15-9: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Violations:
1. Any owner or driver of a vehicle not licensed or equipped in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or of a vehicle, the license of which has
been suspended or revoked, who engages in the business of a public "taxicab", as defined in section 4-15-1 of this chapter, or who attempts to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 78/307
engage in such business or solicits for hire passengers upon the streets, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor.
2. Any person not having been duly licensed as a taxicab driver, or any person whose license as such driver has been revoked, or any person whose
license has been suspended, and who, during the time of such suspension, drives for hire a taxicab upon the streets shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor.
B. Penalties: In addition to the penalty provided in section 1-4-1 of this code, any licensee shall be subject to the suspension or revocation of his license.
The village president may, in his discretion, suspend or revoke a license granted under subsection 4-15-4A of this chapter, pending or in advance of the
criminal prosecution of the licensee. (1965 Code § 4-26-30)
Chapter 16
TOBACCO DEALERS
4-16-1: DEFINITION:
The term "retail tobacco dealer", as used in this chapter, is hereby defined to mean any person selling, offering for sale, exposing for sale, or keeping with
the intention of selling or exchanging at retail, cigarettes or cigarette papers or wrappers in the village. (1965 Code § 4-19-1)
4-16-2: ENFORCEMENT; INSPECTION:
Enforcement of this chapter shall be by the village police department. The police department shall create and institute a system of routine inspection for
the enforcement of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-19-14)
4-16-3: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEE:
A. License Required: No person shall engage in the business of a retail tobacco dealer without first having obtained a license therefor. (1965 Code § 4-19-
2)
B. Term Of License: Every retail tobacco dealer's license shall be issued for one year, ending on December 31. (1965 Code § 4-19-5)
C. License Fee: The tobacco dealer license fee is as set out in section 4-1-3 of this title. (1965 Code § 4-19-4; amd. 2009 Code)
4-16-4: SIGNS:
Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or company operating a business where tobacco or tobacco accessories are sold shall post in a conspicuous
place the following signs which shall be printed in red letters at least one-half inch (1/2") in height on a white card. In the instance where cigarettes are sold
by vending machine, such signs shall be displayed in plain view on the machine. The signs must state the following:
SALE OF TOBACCO ACCESSORIES AND SMOKING HERBS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION
OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A SALE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW.
and
SURGEON GENERAL'S WARNING: SMOKING BY PREGNANT WOMEN MAY RESULT IN FETAL INJURY, PREMATURE BIRTH, AND LOW BIRTH
WEIGHT.
(1965 Code § 4-19-8)
4-16-5: SALES NEAR SCHOOLS:
No person shall sell, give away, barter, exchange, or otherwise deal in any place located within three hundred feet (300') of any building used exclusively
for school purposes, any cigarettes, tobacco, or tobacco product of any form whatsoever used in the making of cigarettes or with which cigarette papers or
wrappers are sold or given away. (1965 Code § 4-19-9)
4-16-6: RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MINORS:
A. Sales To Minors:
1. No person shall sell or give away, or offer to sell or give away any cigarettes or cigarette papers, tobacco, or tobacco accessories, or smoking herbs
to persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
2. Misrepresentation of age to procure such a sale is prohibited by law. (1965 Code § 4-19-10; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 79/307
B. Possession By Minors:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to possess any tobacco products; provided, that the possession by a person
under the age of eighteen (18) years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian shall not be prohibited.
2. Any person violating this subsection shall be subject to a fine of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense and fifty dollars ($50.00) for repeat
offenses if paid within fourteen (14) days of issuance of a citation. After fourteen (14) days, the fine shall be doubled. (1965 Code § 4-19-12)
4-16-7: VENDING MACHINES:
A. License Required: No person, without a retail tobacco dealer's license, shall locate, install, keep, maintain, or use, or permit the location, installation,
keeping, maintenance, or use upon his premises, of any vending machine, automatic vending machine, coin controlled or coin operated machine or
other mechanical device used or intended to be used for the sale or distribution of cigarettes. (1965 Code § 4-19-11)
B. Penalty: Any person found guilty of violating the terms and conditions of this section, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a maximum fine as
set out in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1965 Code § 4-19-11; amd. 2009 Code)
4-16-8: VENDOR ASSISTED SALES:
It is unlawful for any licensee, person, business or tobacco dealer to sell, permit to be sold or offer for sale any tobacco product by means of self-service
displays or any other means other than vendor assisted sales. All tobacco shall be kept in a locked case and will be opened for distribution purposes only
by employees of the licensee. The operation of vending machines shall be controlled by mechanical or electrical means that require operation by the
machine owner or agent prior to each distribution of a tobacco product. (1965 Code § 4-19-13)
4-16-9: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Offenses Committed By Tobacco Dealers:
1. Each offense of this chapter committed by a tobacco dealer is punishable by the imposition of a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). The first offense by a licensee shall result in a fine between one hundred dollars ($100.00) and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). The
second offense shall be punishable by a fine between five hundred dollars ($500.00) and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A third or subsequent
offense shall be punishable by a fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
2. A third or subsequent offense shall subject the licensee to an automatic license hearing as provided by village ordinance for business license
suspensions or revocations. In the event the hearing officer finds that a third or subsequent offense has been committed, the license may be
suspended for up to thirty (30) business days. During the period of suspension, all tobacco products and merchandise shall be removed from display
and all other areas accessible to the public, or the place of business closed.
3. A tenth offense shall subject the licensee to an automatic license hearing as provided for by village ordinance for business license suspensions or
revocations. In the event the hearing officer finds that a tenth offense has occurred, the license shall be permanently revoked.
4. All rulings by the hearing officer may be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction as provided for by law. All suspensions and revocations shall
be stayed until such time as there is a judicial determination of such action.
5. In addition to the fines provided herein, the village may assess reasonable attorney, clerical and court costs in relation to the prosecution and
enforcement of the violation.
B. Purchase/Possession Violation: Any person under the age of eighteen (18) that violates the purchasing or possession sections of this chapter shall be
subject to the following penalties:
1. First violation: Twenty five dollar ($25.00) fine or the completion of an approved smoking cessation program.
2. Second violation: A fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and the completion of an
approved smoking cessation program.
3. Third and subsequent violations: A fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), and
the completion of an approved smoking cessation program, and not less than twenty (20) hours of approved community service. (1965 Code § 4-19-
15)
Chapter 17
MOTELS
4-17-1: DEFINITION:
The term "motel", as used in this chapter, shall be construed to mean any establishment consisting of a group of attached or detached rooms, located on a
single zoning lot or contiguous or adjoining zoning lots comprising one single plot of land, which is kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the
public to be a place where units, with or without self-contained kitchen facilities, are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient,
permanent or residential. These facilities may be described as motor hotels, highway hotels, motor courts, lodges, inns or other similar name denoting that
accommodations are available primarily for transient guests. (1965 Code § 4-23-1)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 80/307
4-17-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; APPLICATION:
A. License And Compliance Required: It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a motel in the village without having first obtained a license therefor or
without complying with all of the provisions of this chapter.
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for such licenses shall be as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this title. (1965 Code § 4-23-2)
C. Application For License: Each applicant for a license to operate or maintain shall file an application with the village stating therein the name and
address of the owner, name and address of the manager, assistant manager, if any, or desk clerk or clerks or any other person or persons having
charge of the operation of the premises; location of the motel; the number of rental units available; the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be
accommodated; and whether or not kitchen facilities are afforded and, if so, the number and location of each such unit. Unless the same shall have
been previously presented and approved, this application shall be accompanied by plans of the motel showing the proposed or existing locations of all
buildings, rooms, toilets, type of heating, sewer connections, exits, driveways and other improvements. (1965 Code § 4-23-5)
4-17-3: CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Compliance With Code: All motels constructed or remodeled so as to create new or additional accommodations shall comply with the provisions of this
code.
B. Size Of Rooms: Motel rooms shall have at least fifty (50) square feet of floor area for each adult person occupying said room, and in no event shall any
room have less than one hundred (100) square feet, exclusive of area required for toilet and exclusive of space provided for clothing racks or closet
space.
C. Number Of Persons Limited: In no event shall more than four (4) adult persons be accommodated in any one individual room.
D. Bathroom: Each rental unit shall be equipped with a private bathroom consisting of toilet, shower stall and/or bath, all within a single enclosed area.
E. Window Area:
1. The window area of each rental unit shall be sufficient to furnish adequate natural light. Twenty five percent (25%) of the required window area shall
be capable of being opened unless some other adequate means of ventilation is provided.
2. The toilet room shall contain at least one window opening to the outside unless some other adequate means of ventilation is provided. (1965 Code
§ 4-23-3)
F. Heat And Heaters:
1. Rooms Heated: Each room, including the bathroom, shall have facilities to keep such room at a minimum sixty eight degrees Fahrenheit (68°F)
temperature. (1965 Code § 4-23-8)
2. Venting Of Room Heaters: All combustion type room heaters shall be vented to the outside.
3. Gas Heaters: If gas heaters are used, the same shall be approved by the American Gas Association or some other recognized testing laboratory that
provides a follow up inspection service; all heaters must be equipped with an automatic shutoff which will operate at flame failure.
G. Water Supply: An adequate supply of safe water shall be provided from a source which complies with the municipal requirements governing the supply
of water.
H. Sewerage And Water Carried Wastes: All sewerage and all other water carried wastes shall be discharged into a municipal sewer.
I. Swimming Pools: Artificial swimming pools used in connection with a recreational area shall be constructed and maintained in a manner which will not
create any health or safety hazards.
J. Mechanical Equipment: All mechanical equipment installed or used in connection with the motel including, but not limited to, electrical, water and sewer
supplies and heating facilities shall be of such standard as to provide a reasonable degree of health and safeguards for the occupants of said motel.
K. Off Street Parking: The zoning requirements of the village with respect to off street parking shall be fully met. (1965 Code § 4-23-3)
4-17-4: SUPERVISION AND MAINTENANCE:
Any establishment shall at all times be open for inspection, and the health officer, police department, fire department and officials of the village may from
time to time inspect any such establishment to see that the following requirements are met:
A. Attendant Or Caretaker: Each establishment shall have at least one competent attendant or caretaker available at all times. It shall be his duty to
receive and deliver telephone messages and mail and to maintain the premises, facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition and
free from rodents and vermin.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 81/307
B. Guest Register: Each establishment shall keep a registration of all transient guests. This register shall include the name, legal residence, make of car,
car license, number and names of persons occupying the rooms, the number or numbers of the rooms assigned to the guest or guests and the date of
arrival and departure. The register shall be available for inspection by law enforcement officers for a period of not less than three (3) years.
C. Sanitation And Safety Requirements:
1. All floors in the bathroom shall be thoroughly washed and disinfected for each incoming guest.
2. All areas shall be kept free from rubbish, litter and inflammable materials at all times, and no inflammable liquids or chemicals shall be kept on the
premises unless the same are in approved types of containers.
3. All sheets, towels and other linens furnished for each rental unit shall be clean and freshly laundered for each incoming guest.
4. All drinking glasses shall be washed and sterilized for each incoming guest. If paper cups are furnished in lieu thereof, such paper cups shall be in
proper dispensers which do not permit the handling of same except by guests.
D. Wholesome Accommodations; Maintenance Of Furnishings And Equipment: The entire establishment shall be so operated in such a manner as to
provide clean, wholesome accommodations to the guests at all times. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, it shall be the duty of the operator
of the establishment to keep the furniture, furnishings and equipment and the premises as a whole in a good state of repair and maintenance.
E. Garbage Removal: In any rental units where cooking facilities are provided, flyproof metal containers shall be supplied for garbage and refuse, and it
shall be the duty of the motel operator to promptly remove and dispose of such garbage and refuse each day.
F. Lighting: Any area or premises of the motel open to use by the public or by all persons staying in or being accommodated in the motel shall be kept
adequately lighted at nighttime. (1965 Code § 4-23-4)
4-17-5: OFFICE MAINTAINED; FIRE EXTINGUISHER:
A. Registration Area: Each establishment shall maintain an office, lobby or other room or lighted drive-in area, which shall be available for the registration
of guests.
B. Fire Extinguishers: For each two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet of floor area on each floor, one 21/2-gallon soda and acid approved type fire
extinguisher or an approved wet water type extinguisher shall be available, but in no event shall there be less than one fire extinguisher on each floor.
In no event shall extinguishers be located so that a person would have to travel more than one hundred feet (100') from any part of the motel to the
nearest extinguisher. (1965 Code § 4-23-6)
4-17-6: NOTICE OF RATES AND RULES POSTED IN ROOMS:
Printed notices shall be posted in each room giving the established rate for said room for one or more persons, and it shall be unlawful to charge a rate in
excess of such rate; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prohibit the motel from establishing other or different rates during seasonal
periods, and nothing herein contained shall prevent the proprietor from changing such published rates from time to time. Such notices shall also prescribe
only reasonable rules and regulations of the establishment, not in conflict with any statute or regulation of the state or provision of this code. (1965 Code
§ 4-23-7)
4-17-7: PENALTY; REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
In addition to the penalty imposed in section 1-4-1 of this code for violation of any provisions of this chapter, the village president shall have the right to
terminate, revoke or suspend any license previously granted; provided, however, that no suspension, termination or revocation of a license shall take place
unless and until reasonable notice of such alleged violation, and an opportunity for hearing, has been given to the licensee. (1965 Code § 4-23-9; amd.
2009 Code)
Chapter 18
DISTRIBUTING PRINTED MATTER
4-18-1: CLASSIFICATION OF PRINTED MATERIALS:
There are hereby designated classes of printed material as follows:
A. First Class Printed Matter: Printed matter of the first class includes religious, political and literary handbills, cards, circulars, sheets, pamphlets and other
printed matter of like character and nature.
B. Second Class Printed Matter: Printed matter of the second class includes mercantile, advertising handbills, card circulars, sheets, pamphlets, shopping
news and other printed matter of a like character and nature.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 82/307
C. Third Class Printed Matter: Printed matter of the third class includes all other circulars and literature such as obscene, lewd, immoral and destructive
circulars and literature of like nature. (1965 Code § 4-25-1)
4-18-2: EXCEPTIONS:
A. Transmitted Or Delivered Materials: Nothing herein contained shall be construed as interfering with or legislating against newspapers, magazines,
pamphlets, periodicals and other printed matter transmitted and delivered in the following manner:
1. Through the United States mail.
2. By the parcel post system.
3. Delivered by carriers to the premises of persons who have lawfully subscribed for the same or by other legal means not contrary to the provisions of
this chapter.
B. Posting Notices: The posting of legal notices of the police department, election notices and all notices authorized by law shall be excluded from the
operation of this chapter.
C. Certain Signs And Billboards: Nothing herein shall be construed as interfering with or legislating against billboards and advertising signs where the
parties have lawfully entered into a contract or have obtained consent of the owner of the premises to carry on such business and engage in such
activity. (1965 Code § 4-25-2)
4-18-3: FIRST CLASS PRINTED MATTER:
A. Distribution Regulations: First class printed matter intended to disseminate knowledge, intelligence and education may be distributed, passed out and
circulated freely within the village, subject to the following rules and regulations:
1. Such handbills, cards, circulars, sheets, pamphlets and other printed matter mentioned aforesaid may be distributed by hand and delivered to
persons (who shall respectively be called receivers and acceptors if they accept the same), but in no case shall such handbills, cards, circulars,
sheets, pamphlets and other printed matter referred to be dropped loosely or scattered by the distributor, receiver or acceptor in and upon any
squares, streets, alleys, parks, public grounds or in public buildings, so as to litter the squares, streets, alleys, parks, public grounds and public
buildings.
2. Provided, that, at meetings, assemblages and at gatherings, educational, religious, political and literary, and at business or mercantile
demonstrations and exhibitions, circuses, shows, theaters and business places, such materials may be passed around freely in and around the
premises to persons attending such affairs. (1965 Code § 4-25-3)
B. Breach Of Peace; Littering: The distributors and circulators of first class printed matter, by their conduct and actions in the distribution and circulation of
same, shall not disturb the peace or cause a riot and shall not blockade, obstruct or congest any streets, alleys, sidewalks, or public places which are
crowded with vehicles and pedestrians, so as to interfere with the flow of traffic on such streets, alleys, sidewalks, or public places and so as to
interfere with the free passage of pedestrians on such streets, alleys, sidewalks, and public places; nor shall such distributors and circulators, receivers
and acceptors of same, throw, drop or scatter about such handbills, circulars, pamphlets and other printed matter so as to litter such streets, alleys,
sidewalks and public places. (1965 Code § 4-25-4)
C. License Or Fee Not Required: No license fee of any kind shall be paid or permission of any kind shall be necessary for the distribution of printed matter
of the first class in the village. (1965 Code § 4-25-5)
4-18-4: SECOND CLASS PRINTED MATTER:
A. Distribution Regulations: No printed matter of the second class shall be dropped or scattered in or about the streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks, public
grounds or other places, public or private, in the village, at any place or at any time, and no such printed matter shall be deposited in and upon a
gangway, parkway, yard, sidewalk, basement, garage, porch (rear or front), stairway, doorstep, alcove, enclosure, or other room of any private building,
nor shall such printed matter be placed or deposited or stuck behind any door, under any door or any doorbell, on a door knob or transom, or on a door
handle or window, or under window ledges, or in crevices, cracks or apertures between doors or otherwise, unless:
1. With the permission and consent obtained from the landlord, tenant or occupant of the premises that such printed matter herein referred may be
placed, deposited or stuck behind any door, under a door or doorbell, on a door knob or transom, or on a door handle or window, or under window
ledges, or in crevices, cracks or apertures between doors or otherwise.
2. The distributor or circulator of the same can show by proper written authority that the landlord, tenant or occupant of the premises has legally
subscribed for or permitted the delivery of the same to the premises.
3. The landlord, tenant or occupant of the premises shall have on the premises an appropriate container, receptacle or box (other than a mailbox) for
the deposit and delivery of the same, where same may be delivered and deposited. The presence of such receptacle, container or box being on the
premises shall be construed as consent and invitation on the part of the landlord, tenant or occupant to allow the deposit and delivery in the
container, receptacle or box of such printed matter. Such printed matter shall not be pasted, affixed, attached, nailed to, or tied by string, rubber
bands, wire or otherwise to any window, door, telegraph, telephone, or trolley pole, electric wire pole, police or fire alarm box, fence, garage, bridge,
viaduct or to any refuse box or container, on any part of any sidewalk, street or alley, park, or public grounds in the village. (1965 Code § 4-25-6)
B. Certificate Granting Permission: In addition to the requirements of subsection A of this section, no person shall distribute any printed matter of the
second class without first having obtained from the clerk a certificate in writing granting said person permission to distribute printed matter of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 83/307
second class in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. No certificate shall be issued or renewed to any person who has been convicted of
violating any of the provisions of this chapter or of a felony, or to any person of ill repute, or to any person whose hands are infected with a skin disease
of any kind that is contagious. (1965 Code § 4-25-7)
C. Distributor's Badge: Upon issuance of the certificate, the person shall receive a distributor's badge which will be displayed on the person of such
distributor at all times while he is distributing printed matter of the second class. The certificate issued shall identify the distributor and his employer, if
any, and shall designate the territory to be traversed and the dates and hours of the distribution. (1965 Code § 4-25-8)
4-18-5: UNLAWFUL MATTER:
It shall be unlawful, and the same is hereby prohibited, for any person to distribute, circulate, possess, pass out, deliver and deposit any obscene, lewd or
immoral literature whatsoever or any literature or writing which advocates the destruction of the democratic form of government, the overthrow of the
federal or state constitution, the destruction of freedom of religion and which advocates any unlawful conduct or the commission thereof, or any printed
matter known as printed matter of the third class, at any time or at any place within the limits of the village. (1965 Code § 4-25-9)
4-18-6: DISTRIBUTING INTO VEHICLES:
Dropping circulars, handbills and other printed matter of any class into passenger automobiles, trucks, taxis, commercial or mercantile vehicles, whether
parked or in motion, and attaching, affixing, placing and sticking same on any part of passenger automobiles, trucks, taxis, commercial or mercantile
vehicles is hereby strictly forbidden and prohibited by persons other than the owner, at any time and place within the limits of the village; provided, the
owner and possessor of any kind of motor vehicle is not prohibited from furnishing, displaying or decorating in his own private motor vehicle with any
cards, signs, placards and the like that may suit him, for the promotion of his safety, pleasure and business as long as the same shall not violate any
provisions of this code and state laws. (1965 Code § 4-25-10)
Chapter 19
GARAGE SALES
4-19-1: DEFINITION:
The term "garage sale", as used in this chapter, shall mean and include "garage sale", "patio sale", "basement sale", "back yard sale", "rummage sale", or
any similar type of sale of common household items, which is held on residential premises to which the general public is invited. (1965 Code § 4-35-1)
4-19-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; INFORMATION; FEE:
A. Permit Required; Information: No garage sale shall be allowed until a permit for such sale shall be granted. The village clerk is authorized to establish
necessary administration procedures for obtaining a permit. The permit shall include at least, but not limited to:
1. Name and address of the permittee;
2. Date on which the last garage sale was held at the above address;
3. A statement that if a permit is granted, the permittee will abide by all applicable codes and ordinances of the village;
4. A statement that all goods and furnishings to be sold are in the possession and title of the permittee and have been in use at said location or have
been in use at another dwelling unit on the same block;
B. Permit Fee: The fee for a garage sale permit shall be one dollar ($1.00); and
C. Display Of Permit: The permit shall be prominently displayed at the location of the sale. (1965 Code § 4-35-3)
4-19-3: EXEMPTIONS:
Upon satisfactory showing that a garage sale is being held entirely as a fundraising activity for a charitable, not for profit, or religious organization, no
permit fee shall be required. (1965 Code § 4-35-4; amd. 2009 Code)
4-19-4: SALES RESTRICTIONS:
A. Number Of Sales; Days; Items:
1. Every owner or occupant of a dwelling unit may conduct not more than two (2) garage sales in any calendar year. Such sales shall extend over not
more than three (3) consecutive days, and shall be limited to household goods and furnishings which have been in use in the dwelling unit located on
the premises on which such sales are conducted or which have been in use in more than one dwelling unit on the same block.
2. No merchandise purchased for intentional sale or resale at a profit may be sold from a private residence. (1965 Code § 4-35-2)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 84/307
