B. Signs: Signs shall be regulated as provided in subsection 12-11-12E of this code. (2009 Code)
C. Loudspeakers Prohibited: No loudspeakers shall be used for promotional purposes during the conducting of any garage sale. (1965 Code § 4-35-5;
amd. 2009 Code)
D. Display Of Goods Or Furnishings: No household goods or furnishings shall be displayed or offered for sale in the following areas:
1. Front Yard: Any portion of a front yard, from the front building line to the public right of way. (1965 Code § 4-35-6)
2. Public Property: Any public property or public right of way. (1965 Code § 4-35-7)
E. Time Of Sale: No garage sale may commence before the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. nor extend beyond the hour of six o'clock (6:00) P.M. (1965
Code § 4-35-8; amd. 2009 Code)
4-19-5: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person holding a garage sale in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed twenty five dollars
($25.00). (1965 Code § 4-35-9)
Chapter 20
CHRISTMAS TREE SALES
4-20-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to exercise or carry on, directly or indirectly, the business of selling cut evergreen trees (Christmas
trees) without first procuring a license therefor from the village clerk. (1965 Code § 4-37-1)
B. Application For License: Any person desiring to operate a business as described in subsection A of this section shall make a written application for a
license so to do to the village clerk. Such application shall conform to the general requirements relating to applications for licenses and shall include the
name of the applicant, the type of business to be conducted and the place where it will be located. (1965 Code § 4-37-2)
C. License Fee: The license fee for a cut evergreen tree sale business license shall be as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this title and shall conform to the
general provisions relating to licensing. (1965 Code § 4-37-4)
4-20-2: BOND REQUIRED; REFUND:
A. Required: In addition to any license fee required by subsection 4-20-1C of this chapter, no license shall be issued under this chapter until the applicant
deposits a cash bond with the village in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each location at which trees are to be sold. (1965 Code § 4-
37-5)
B. Refund; Restoration Of Property: The deposit made pursuant to subsection A of this section shall be refunded to the licensee upon a report by the
building director certifying that the premises used for sale of the cut evergreen trees (Christmas trees) has been restored to its original condition. If the
licensee fails to clean up the premises, the village, after due notice, shall take such action as is necessary to complete necessary repairs and/or
cleanup. The refund shall be reduced by the amount of the cost of said necessary repairs and/or cleanup. No burning of any kind will be allowed at the
site. (1965 Code § 4-37-6)
4-20-3: APPROVAL OF PROPERTY OWNER:
If the applicant does not own the property upon which he proposes to sell the cut evergreen trees (Christmas trees), said applicant shall provide the village
with a letter indicating permission of the property owner to conduct said business on such property. (1965 Code § 4-37-3)
Chapter 21
LIVE SEX ACTS BUSINESSES1
4-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
In this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 85/307
CONSIDERATION: The direct or indirect payment of money or the exchange of any item of value for:
A. The right to enter the business premises, or any portion thereof; or
B. The right to remain on the business premises, or any portion thereof; or
C. The right to purchase any item permitting the right to enter, or remain on, the business premises, or any portion thereof; or
D. The right to a membership permitting the right to enter, or remain on, the business premises, or any portion thereof.
LIVE SEX ACT: Any act whereby one or more persons engage in a live performance or live conduct which contains oral sexual contact or sexual
intercourse.
LIVE SEX ACT BUSINESS: Any business in which one or more persons may view, or may participate in, a live sex act for a consideration.
OPERATE AND MAINTAIN: To organize, design, perpetuate or control. "Operate and maintain" includes providing financial support by paying utilities, rent,
maintenance costs or advertising costs, supervising activities or work schedules, and directing or furthering the aims of the enterprise.
ORAL SEXUAL CONTACT: Oral contact with the penis, vulva or anus.
SEXUAL INTERCOURSE: Penetration into the penis, vulva or anus by any part of the body or by any object or manual masturbatory contact with the
penis or vulva. (1965 Code § 4-45-1)
4-21-2: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to apply to the nonobscene presentation, showing, or performance of any play, drama, or ballet in any theater,
concert hall, fine arts academy, school, institution of higher education, or similar establishment as a form of expression of opinion or communication of
ideas or information, as differentiated from the promotion or exploitation of sex, for the purpose of advancing the economic welfare of a commercial or
business enterprise. (1965 Code § 4-45-7)
4-21-3: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and maintain a live sex act business. (1965 Code § 4-45-2)
4-21-4: NUISANCE DECLARED; ABATEMENT; HEARING:
A. Nuisance Declared: Operation of a live sex act business is a public nuisance per se which may be abated by order of a court of competent jurisdiction.
(1965 Code § 4-45-3)
B. Authorization: The village attorney, in the name of the village, upon direction by the village manager, may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for
an order permitting the village to abate violations of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-45-4)
C. Hearing: After notice to the operator of a live sex act business, the judge shall conduct a hearing and take evidence as to whether a live sex act
business is being operated in violation of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-45-5)
D. Order Of Abatement: If, at the conclusion of the hearing, the judge determines that a live sex act business is being operated in the village in violation of
this chapter, an order shall be entered authorizing the village to abate the violation by closing the business. A copy of the order shall be delivered to the
operator of the business and mailed to the owner of the property upon which the business is located. (1965 Code § 4-45-6)
Footnote 1: See title 13, chapter 5 of this code for adult use provisions.
Chapter 22
NEWSPAPER DISPENSING DEVICES
4-22-1: DEFINITIONS:
"Newspaper dispensing device" means a container, constructed of metal or other material of substantial equivalent strength and durability which is used
for the dispensing of newspapers, fliers, handbills or other similar printed materials either at a cost or free of charge. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-2: PUBLIC PROPERTY LOCATION, APPLICATION, PERMIT AND FEE:
A. No private newspaper dispensing device shall be placed or located within a public right of way, along the streets, thoroughfares, parkways, sidewalks or
on any other village of Lyons property, whether owned or leased by the village, unless a permit has been issued therefor by the village in conformance
with the provisions of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 86/307
B. Applications for such permit shall be made on forms approved by the village for permits allowing for the installation and placement of private newspaper
dispensing devices within the public right of way, along the streets, thoroughfares, parkways, sidewalks or on any other village property within the
village. The applications shall be provided by the director of building and code enforcement upon request. The application must include a site plan and
state the exact location where the applicant wishes to install a newspaper dispensing device. The application must also include a description of and the
size and color specifications for the intended newspaper dispensing device. Misrepresentation of information, false statements or any other fraudulent
information supplied on or with the application shall be grounds for revocation of a permit in compliance with this chapter.
C. Within five (5) business days of receipt of a completed application for a permit and payment of applicable fee, the village shall issue a permit, provided
that the applicant meets conditions contained in section 4-22-3 of this chapter. In the event that the terms and conditions of section 4-22-3 of this
chapter, where applicable, are not met, the village shall, within five (5) business days of receipt of an application for a permit, deny the application, state
the reasons in writing for such denial and notify the applicant, in writing, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the reasons for the denial. Any
such denial may be appealed pursuant to the procedure set forth in this chapter.
D. The applicant shall pay an annual administrative processing fee as established by section 4-1-3 of this title for each location where a newspaper
dispensing device is installed.
E. Permits shall be for a term of one year and shall not be assignable. Permits shall expire on December 31 of each year. Applications and fees for
renewal of permits shall be filed with the director of building and code enforcement no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon December 15 of each
year.
F. A permit shall allow the installation of a newspaper dispensing device only at the location described in the application for the permit. The permit shall
contain a description of the authorized location and permits shall not be transferable from one location to another nor from one person to another.
G. As an express condition of the acceptance of a permit hereunder, the permittee thereby agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the village, its trustees,
officers and employees against any loss or liability or damage, including expenses and costs for bodily or personal injury and for property damage
sustained by any person as the result of the installation, use or maintenance of a device within the village. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-3: PERMIT CONDITIONS:
A. A permit issued for a privately owned newspaper dispensing device shall be subject to and granted upon the following conditions, restrictions and
requirements:
1. Newspaper dispensing devices shall be placed adjacent and parallel to building walls not more than six inches (6") distant therefrom, or near and
parallel to the curb not less than eighteen inches (18") and not more than twenty four inches (24") distant from the curb.
2. No newspaper dispensing device shall be placed, installed, located or maintained:
a. Within ten feet (10') of any fire hydrant or other emergency facility;
b. Within fifteen feet (15') of any intersecting driveway, alley or street;
c. Within five feet (5') of any bus stop, bench, street sign, stoplight, parking meter, streetlight, utility pole, display window, handicap access ramp, or
marked crosswalk;
d. Within five hundred feet (500') of another newspaper dispensing device containing the same newspaper or news periodical;
e. So as to be chained, or otherwise secured, to any tree, utility pole, light pole, parking meter, traffic control post, street signpost, bench, refuse
receptacle or other public property;
f. On or within any median within any public right of way;
g. Within a rectangular area stretching from the entire width of any building entranceway to the curb;
h. At any location where the width of paved clear space in any direction for the passage of pedestrians is reduced to less than five feet (5');
i. Adjacent to parallel or angle parking spaces;
j. Within three feet (3') of any area improved with lawn, flowers, shrubs, planters, or trees.
3. No publication may be displayed, offered for sale, or offered free to the public on any public right of way by means of a newspaper dispensing device
in such manner as to expose to the public view any photograph, drawing or depiction of any kind contained within such publication displaying any of
the following:
a. The genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft perineum, anal region or pubic hair region on any person;
b. Any portion of the breast, at or below the areola, of any female person.
4. The permittee shall maintain the newspaper dispensing device in good working order, in a safe and clean condition, in such a manner so that:
a. It is reasonably free of dirt and grease;
b. It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof;
c. It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon;
d. The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the publications therein are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks,
dents, blemishes and discoloration;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 87/307
e. The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading;
f. The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshaped and the device is level on the ground and not leaning or placed on uneven
portions of ground.
5. A legible telephone number shall be displayed on the newspaper dispensing device for a user to call to obtain a refund in case of malfunction of the
newspaper dispensing device.
6. Newspaper dispensing devices may have the name of the newspaper or the applicable publication displayed on the side, front and back of the
device provided that the lettering is no larger than two inches (2") in height.
7. The newspaper dispensing device shall not be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than the purposes dealing with the display, sale
or purchase of the newspaper sold or distributed free therein.
8. Upon removal of the newspaper dispensing device, the permittee shall restore the property of the village to the same condition as when the
newspaper dispensing device was initially installed, ordinary wear and tear excepted. If those repairs are not made within thirty (30) days, the village
shall undertake that repair work and collect from the owner or permittee the costs thereof, including reasonable attorney fees and related costs of
collection. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-4: REMOVAL:
A. In the event any newspaper dispensing device is placed or remains within any public right of way, street, thoroughfare, parkway, sidewalk or other
village property without a permit being issued for the newspaper dispensing device, or after the expiration or revocation of a previously issued permit,
or in violation of any other provision of this chapter, the village shall send, by certified mail, with return receipt requested, a written notice to the address
of the owner or user of the newspaper dispensing device. The notice shall state the address and telephone number of the village, a description of why
the newspaper dispensing device is in violation of the requirements of this chapter; that the owner or user is ordered to cause immediate removal of the
newspaper dispensing device from public property; and that the newspaper dispensing device will be removed by the village after a date designated in
the notice. The date shall be no less than ten (10) calendar days after the date the notice is mailed; unless the owner or user requests a hearing before
the village board by filing a written appeal with the village manager pursuant to subsection 4-22-5A of this chapter on or before the designated removal
date.
B. If any newspaper dispensing device is still on public property after the ten (10) calendar day period described above, or if an appeal is filed and denied
after hearing before the village board, the newspaper dispensing device shall be removed by the village.
C. The owner of any newspaper dispensing device removed in accordance with the terms of this chapter shall be responsible for all the expenses of the
removal and storage of such newspaper dispensing device. Should the newspaper dispensing device fail to be claimed or should the owners fail to pay
any money due the village, after six (6) months, such newspaper dispensing device shall be disposed of according to law.
D. If a newspaper dispensing device is unused for a period of more than thirty (30) days in that no newspapers, fliers, handbills or other similar printed
materials are placed within the device and offered for sale or for distribution at no cost, the newspaper dispensing device shall be considered
abandoned by the owner or permittee. The procedures of this section shall then be followed. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-5: APPEAL OF DENIAL OF PERMITS; REMOVAL OF DEVICE:
A. The decision of the village manager in refusing to grant or renew a permit shall be appealable. The applicant shall have the right to appeal the decision
to the village board provided that the applicant file a written notice of appeal, including a statement of the grounds of appeal, with the village manager,
within ten (10) calendar days after the date of the notice of denial. The village board shall set a hearing on the appeal at its next regularly scheduled
village board meeting and notice of such time and place shall be given to the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested. The village board
shall have the power to reverse, affirm, or modify the original decision. In making its determination, the village board shall only consider the standards
set forth in this chapter. The decision of the village board shall be rendered the same day as the hearing. The decision of the village board shall be
final.
B. The decision of the village to remove a newspaper dispensing device shall be appealable. The applicant shall have the right to appeal the decision to
the village board provided that the applicant file a written notice of appeal, including a statement of the grounds of appeal, with the village manager,
within ten (10) calendar days after the date of the notice of removal. The village board shall set a hearing on the appeal at its next regularly scheduled
village board meeting and notice of such time and place shall be given to the owner/user of the newspaper dispensing device by certified mail, return
receipt requested. The newspaper dispensing device may remain in place during the appeal period. The village board shall have the power to reverse,
affirm or modify the original decision. In making its determination, the village board shall only consider the standards set forth in this chapter. The
decision of the village board shall be rendered the same day as the hearing. The decision of the village board shall be a final administrative decision
subject to judicial review by the circuit court. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-6: REVOCATION OF PERMITS:
The village manager may revoke a permit issued under the terms of this chapter for any of the following causes, which shall constitute violations of this
section:
A. Fraud, misrepresentation, or any false statement contained in the application for a permit;
B. Violation of any term or condition of the permit granted to the permittee;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 88/307
C. Violation of any term, condition or provision of this chapter or any other chapter of this code.
A permittee may appeal the decision of the village manager to revoke a permit in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 4-22-5 of this
chapter. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-7: EMERGENCY PROVISIONS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the village may remove any newspaper dispensing device from public property which, because of its
location or condition, poses an immediate threat to the health, safety and welfare of the public or a member thereof. Within five (5) business days of the
removal, the village manager shall send, by certified mail, with return receipt requested, a written notice to the permit holder. The notice shall state the
reason for the removal and permittee's right to appeal this decision by filing a written notice of appeal with the village manager. This decision is appealable
pursuant to the provisions of section 4-22-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
4-22-8: ENFORCEMENT:
Except as otherwise specifically stated herein, the village manager or his designee shall be responsible for enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 03-16-10-03,
3-16-2010)
4-22-9: PENALTIES:
Any person or entity who shall be guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine as established by title 1, chapter 4 of
this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for every day a violation continues. (Ord. 03-16-10-03, 3-16-2010)
Chapter 23
OFFERING DRUG PARAPHERNALIA FOR SALE
4-23-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
CANNABIS: Includes marihuana, hashish and other substances which are identified as including any parts of the plant Cannabis sativa, whether growing
or not; the seeds thereof, the resin extracted from any part of such plant; and any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such
plant, its seeds, or resin, including tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and all other cannabinol derivatives, including its naturally occurring or synthetically
produced ingredients, whether produced directly or indirectly by extraction, or independently by means of chemical synthesis or by a combination of
extraction and chemical synthesis; but shall not include the mature stalks of such plant, fiber produced from such stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds
of such plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom),
fiber, oil or cake, or the sterilized seed of such plant which is incapable of germination.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: A drug, substance, or immediate precursor in the schedules of article II of the Illinois controlled substances act, 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 570/201 et seq.
DELIVER OR DELIVERY: The actual, constructive or attempted transfer of possession, with or without consideration, whether or not there is an agency
relationship.
DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: All equipment, products and materials of any kind, other than methamphetamine manufacturing materials as defined in section
10 of the methamphetamine control and community protection act, which are intended to be used unlawfully in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing,
harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing,
concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body cannabis or a controlled substance in violation of the cannabis
control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1 et seq., the Illinois controlled substances act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/100 et seq., or the
methamphetamine control and community protection act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 646/1 et seq.
It includes, but is not limited to:
A. Kits intended to be used unlawfully in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing cannabis or a controlled
substance;
B. Isomerization devices intended to be used unlawfully in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is cannabis or a controlled substance;
C. Testing equipment intended to be used unlawfully in a private home for identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of cannabis or
controlled substances;
D. Diluents and adulterants intended to be used unlawfully for cutting cannabis or a controlled substance by private persons;
E. Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining,
marijuana;
F. Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 89/307
G. Objects intended to be used unlawfully in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing cannabis, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human
body including, but not limited to, the following items:
1. Water pipes;
2. Carburetion tubes and devices;
3. Smoking and carburetion masks;
4. Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials;
5. Carburetor pipes;
6. Electric pipes;
7. Air driven pipes;
8. Chillums;
9. Bongs;
10. Ice pipes or chillers;
11. Glass pipes;
12. Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal
bowls;
13. Roach clips; meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in
the hand;
H. Any item whose purpose, as announced or described by the seller, is for use in violation of this chapter. (Ord. 02-15-11-O1, 2-15-2011)
4-23-2: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to:
A. Items used in the preparation, compounding, packaging, labeling, or other use of cannabis or a controlled substance as an incident to lawful research,
teaching or chemical analysis and not for sale;
B. Items historically and customarily used in connection with the planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding,
converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, or
inhaling of tobacco or any other lawful substance, including, but not limited to: garden hoes, rakes, sickles, baggies, tobacco pipes, and cigarette rolling
papers;
C. Items listed in the definition of "drug paraphernalia" in this chapter which are used purely for decorative purposes, when such items have been rendered
completely inoperable or incapable of being used for any purpose prohibited by this chapter;
D. A person who is legally authorized to possess hypodermic syringes or needles under the hypodermic syringes and needles act, 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 635/0.01 et seq.;
E. Any item that the hearing officer determines was not intended for illicit use. In making such a determination, the hearing officer shall consider, in addition
to all logically relevant factors, the following:
1. The general, usual, customary, and historical use to which the item involved has been put;
2. Any written instructions accompanying the item concerning the purposes or uses to which the item can or may be put;
3. Any oral instructions provided by the seller of the item at the time and place of sale;
4. Any advertising concerning the design, purpose or use of the item involved;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 90/307
5. The manner, place and circumstances in which the item was displayed for sale, as well as any item or items displayed for sale or otherwise exhibited
upon the premises where the sale was made;
6. Whether the person offering the item for sale is a legitimate seller of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of
tobacco products;
7. The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community;
8. The existence of any residue of cannabis or controlled substances on the object;
9. Expert testimony concerning the item's use; and
10. Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner, or of anyone in control of the item, to sell or deliver it to persons whom he knows, or
should reasonably know, intend to use the object for ingesting controlled substances; the innocence of an owner or anyone in control of the item,
shall not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use, or designed for use, as drug paraphernalia. (Ord. 02-15-11-O1, 2-15-2011)
4-23-3: SALE, DELIVERY AND ADVERTISING OF DRUG PARAPHERNALIA UNLAWFUL:
A. No person or store shall display, keep for sale, offer for sale, sell, or deliver for any commercial consideration any item of drug paraphernalia. Each
sales transaction involving drug paraphernalia, or each day on which a store shall offer for sale an item of drug paraphernalia shall constitute a
separate violation.
B. Upon a finding of liability for a violation of this chapter, the hearing officer shall impose a fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation.
C. It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other publication any advertisement, knowing, or under circumstances
where one should reasonably know, that the purpose of the advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of objects used or intended for
use as drug paraphernalia. (Ord. 02-15-11-O1, 2-15-2011)
4-23-4: NUISANCE DECLARED:
A. Any store, place or premises from which or in which any item of drug paraphernalia is kept for sale, offered for sale, sold, or delivered for any
commercial consideration is declared to be a public nuisance.
B. The village attorney, in the name of the village, upon direction by the village manager or acting village manager, may petition a court of competent
jurisdiction for an order enjoining the defendant from maintaining the public nuisance described in subsection A of this section and the village may take
action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement. (Ord. 02-15-11-O1, 2-15-2011)
4-23-5: SUSPENSION OF BUSINESS LICENSE:
In addition to any other penalties already provided for by law and this chapter, a licensed business found liable by a hearing officer, or a licensed business
with an owner, employee or agent found liable by a hearing officer, or a licensed business against which an injunction is entered for selling or offering for
sale an item of drug paraphernalia, may have its business license revoked or suspended by the village manager or acting village manager following a
public hearing in accordance with the provisions of section 4-1-7 of this title. (Ord. 02-15-11-O1, 2-15-2011)
Chapter 24
GUN SHOPS
4-24-1: INTENT:
The legislative intent of this chapter is to provide as much legal protection from the unlawful distribution and use of firearms as allowed by law to a
municipal government. Fully acknowledging a citizen's Second Amendment rights, the Concealed Carry laws of our State, and not intending to impinge on
a citizen's constitutional rights, the Village's Corporate Authorities enact this legislation to help monitor and track the lawful sale of firearms. (Ord. 10-27-
15-O1, 10-27-2015)
4-24-2: ADMINISTRATION OF GUN SHOPS:
A. The Village acknowledges the need for strict and effective measures to minimize firearms being used in crimes. As a non-home rule Municipality, the
Village can only pass and enforce legislation as authorized by the Illinois Constitution, Statutes of the State of Illinois, and case law as decided by the
State and Federal Courts. The regulation of gun shops is administered by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives ("ATF") of the
Federal government.
B. The Village desires to help the appropriate governmental authorities by greater "on-site" monitoring of the sale of firearms within the Village's corporate
boundaries.
C. The Village desires to prevent illegal traffickers by helping regulate gun shops within its jurisdiction to prevent the sales of firearms to straw purchasers
(purchasers who legally can purchase firearms but intend to divert the firearms to those who are not legally authorized to purchase, carry or possess a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 91/307
firearm).
D. The Mayor and Board of Trustees implement the regulations and conditions as prerequisites of obtaining and keeping a business license which allows
the sale of firearms within the corporate boundaries of the Village. (Ord. 10-27-15-O1, 10-27-2015)
4-24-3: RECORDKEEPING:
It shall be the responsibility of the gun shop to keep electronic records of the following information:
A. All trace information received from any law enforcement agency, including, but not limited to, ATF formal TRACE requests, the FTIP requests, and any
other County or Village requests;
B. A record of all persons who purchase more than one firearm within a twelve (12) month period. A separate record is not a requirement; however, a
master list which includes multiple gun purchasers is sufficient. Only a record of purchasers of firearms at gun shops in the Village is required.
C. All paper or electronic records or documents, including any forms filled out by prospective firearms purchasers, shall be tendered to the Lyons Police
Department within forty eight (48) hours of the attempted purchase, or sooner if requested, if the potential purchaser appears not to be a valid or lawful
purchaser as determined by the gun shop dealer. The records do not have to be kept electronically, but kept in a manner that can be transmitted by fax
or e-mail.
D. All electronic records shall be kept for a minimum of five (5) years. (Ord. 10-27-15-O1, 10-27-2015)
4-24-4: COMPLIANCE INSPECTIONS:
A. Currently, firearm dealers may be inspected yearly by agents from the ATF. No other inspections are required by State or Federal authorities.
Commencing December 1, 2015, the Village of Lyons and the Cook County Sheriff, working collectively, will conduct random inspections of any gun
shops in the Village, but no more than twice per year, collectively. These inspections will not interfere with the regular operation of the business and will
include the following:
1. Inspection and approval of an anti-theft safety plan which shall include exterior lighting around the premises; surveillance video cameras, as
generally used in businesses and as currently used by the existing gun shop in the Village (including point-of-sale) (the video shall be maintained for
a minimum of 30 days); alarm systems; safe storage of weapons and ammunition; and fire hazard compliance, as may be required by the
Municipality.
2. Inspection and approval of internal training procedures and inventory audits.
a. Each employee must hold a valid FOID card and have been processed with a background check.
b. Maintain a computerized, alphabetical, electronic listing of all gun sales where the gun was later traced, and maintain a Do Not Sell list.
c. Keep an internal audit of all inventory, and report any loss or discrepancy to the Village within forty eight (48) hours of discovering the loss or
discrepancy. (Ord. 10-27-15-O1, 10-27-2015)
4-24-5: INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT:
The Village and Cook County Sheriff will enter into an intergovernmental agreement (IGA) specifying that enforcement of this chapter is by the Village of
Lyons, in collaboration with the Cook County Sheriff. Only the Village of Lyons may enforce the provisions of this chapter through its business license
regulations and this chapter, itself. (Ord. 10-27-15-O1, 10-27-2015)
4-24-6: PENALTIES:
If there are multiple (more than 2) willful violations of any or all of the items specified above, the Mayor may suspend, fine, and/or revoke the business
license of the gun shop. After the first violation, there may be an additional, random inspection made during that calendar year in addition to the other
inspections as set forth in this chapter. The Mayor may consult with the Cook County Sheriff and any other appropriate law enforcement authorities prior to
imposing any penalty. The holder of the business license is entitled to service of process of the charges, and to a hearing not more than five (5) days from
service of the charges. The Mayor may suspend the business license for up to ten (10) days without a hearing if the business has been found in violation
of this chapter on at least two (2) occasions within a twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 10-27-15-O1, 10-27-2015)
Title 5
HEALTH, SANITATION AND ENVIRONMENT
Chapter 1
FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS
5-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 92/307
The following shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter:
APPROVED SOURCE: Such source as approved by the state department of public health.
EMPLOYEE: Any person who handles food or drink during preparation or serving, or who comes in contact with any eating or cooking utensils, or who is
employed in a room in which food or drink is prepared or served.
FOOD STORE: Grocery store, butcher shop, delicatessen store, confectionery store, bakery store, butter and egg store, milk store, fruit and vegetable
store, fish store, drugstore, ice cream store, or any combination of the foregoing, or any place where food or drink is prepared, handled, stored, offered for
sale, or sold at wholesale or retail.
HAZARDOUS WASTE: A waste or combination of wastes which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics,
may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious, irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or pose a
substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, or disposed of, or otherwise
managed or which has been identified, by characteristics or listing, as hazardous pursuit to section 3001 of the resource conservation and recovery act of
1976 (P.L. 94-580), or which is designated as special, hazardous or toxic, pursuant to other applicable law, ordinance or regulation.
HEALTH OFFICER: The director of the department of health and sanitation of the village or his authorized representative.
ITINERANT RESTAURANT: One operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar gathering.
ITINERANT VENDOR: Any person engaged in the house to house delivery or sale of any products of food and drink.
MUNICIPAL SOLID WASTE: Means and refers to refuse, garbage or other discarded material generated by those residing in residential structures within
the village of Lyons with three (3) or fewer dwelling units. "Municipal solid waste" does not include hazardous waste or waste which any of the facilities to
which it is sent is not permitted to receive.
OPEN AIR MARKET: Any establishment engaged only in the handling and storage of fruits and vegetables offered for sale, or sold at wholesale or retail,
such establishment not being entirely enclosed.
PERSON: A person, firm, corporation, or association.
PLACED FOR COLLECTION: Placed at the curb, alley, or at the back door for collection by the village.
RESTAURANT: Restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other eating and drinking
establishments as well as kitchens or other places in which food or drink is prepared for sale elsewhere.
UTENSILS: Any kitchenware, tableware, glassware, cutlery, utensils, or containers, or other equipment with which food or drink comes in contact during
storage, preparation or serving. (1965 Code § 3-2-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-1-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; STATE REGULATIONS:
A license is required to operate a restaurant, itinerant restaurant, food store, or open air market, or to operate as an itinerant vendor in the village, and
application shall be made on forms provided by the village clerk. Regulation and inspection of these businesses shall be in conformance with provisions of
the "Illinois State Food Service Sanitation Rules And Regulations" as published in the general assembly's Illinois administrative code, title 77, public
health, chapter 1, department of public health: subchapter m, food, drugs and cosmetics, part 750, food service sanitation code. (Ord. 04-15-08-02, 4-15-
2008)
ARTICLE A. DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS1
5-1A-1: PURPOSE; CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
It is declared to be the intention and purpose of this article not to repeal any other codes now in effect applicable to such public areas, and it is hereby
declared that the purpose of this article is to make this article cumulative with all other such applicable codes; provided, however, that if there is any
conflict in language between this article and any other codes applicable to such public areas, the language of this article shall prevail. (1965 Code § 4-31-
11)
5-1A-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT: Any restaurant where meals, sandwiches, cold drinks, beverages, ice cream or other food is served directly to or is permitted to
be consumed by patrons in automobiles, motorcycles or other vehicles parked on the premises.
PUBLIC PLACE: The entire premises occupied by a drive-in restaurant or by the places of business included in a shopping plaza, together with the
parking areas provided adjacent thereto and as a part thereof, and the means of ingress thereto and egress therefrom. (1965 Code § 4-31-1)
5-1A-3: OPERATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Maintain Quiet And Good Order: The owner, lessee or operator of any drive-in restaurant shall maintain quiet and good order upon the premises and
shall not permit disorderly or immoral conduct or loitering thereon, nor shall he cause or permit any noise or nuisance on the parking lot area of the
drive-in restaurant whereby the quiet and good order of the neighborhood are disturbed. (1965 Code § 4-31-2; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 93/307
B. Provide Litter Receptacles: The owner, lessee or operator of a drive-in restaurant shall provide not less than two (2) receptacles for the deposit of trash,
litter, paper, napkins, cups and remnants of food at each exit available to the patrons as they leave the premises. (1965 Code § 4-31-8)
C. Post Signs; Retain Copies Of Regulations:
1. It shall be the duty of the drive-in restaurant operator to post on the premises in a conspicuous location one or more signs, minimum size eighteen
inches by thirty six inches (18" x 36") with letters two inches (2") high, bearing the following legend:
CRUISING IN OR CONGREGATING AND LOITERING OUTSIDE OF A MOTOR VEHICLE IS UNLAWFUL. NO UNOCCUPIED VEHICLE MAY
BE LEFT ON THE RESTAURANT PREMISES WITHOUT THE CONSENT OF THE RESTAURANT OPERATOR.
2. It shall be the duty of the restaurant operator to retain on the premises a copy of this article. (1965 Code § 4-31-12)
5-1A-4: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Disturbances: No person in a public area shall race the motor of any motor vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden stop or start any motor vehicle or
cause to be made any other loud or unseemly noise, nuisance, or disturbance, whereby the quiet and good order of the public area or the surrounding
neighborhood are disturbed. (1965 Code § 4-31-3)
B. Alcoholic Beverages: It shall be unlawful for any person to bring onto a public area any alcoholic beverage and consume or attempt to consume such
alcoholic beverage. (1965 Code § 4-31-4)
C. Unaccompanied Vehicle Parking: No person shall enter the premises of any drive-in restaurant in a motor vehicle of any description and park said
vehicle and leave the premises without getting the consent of the owner or operator of said restaurant; such a parked vehicle may be impounded until
lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois state statutes relating thereto. (1965 Code § 4-31-5)
D. Capricious Driving: No person shall enter any public place in a motor vehicle of any kind and use said public place for cruising, racing, as a shortcut to
another street, or to annoy or endanger any persons or other vehicles lawfully in such public place. (1965 Code § 4-31-6)
E. Loitering: It shall be unlawful for three (3) or more persons to congregate on the premises and linger or loiter at any location on the premises of any
drive-in restaurant other than in the restaurant building or in a legally parked motor vehicle. (1965 Code § 4-31-7; amd. 2009 Code)
F. Littering: It shall be unlawful for any patron of a drive-in restaurant to throw or deposit any of the litter mentioned in subsection 5-1A-3B of this article
anywhere on the grounds or on the streets of the village save and except in the receptacles provided therefor. (1965 Code § 4-31-9)
G. Behavior Restrictions: No person, while in a public area, shall use loud and vociferous, or obscene, vulgar or indecent language, or swear or curse, or
yell or shriek, or make lewd gestures in a manner which will disturb other persons at such place. (1965 Code § 4-31-10)
Footnote 1: See section 4-1-3 of this code for license fee.
ARTICLE B. ICE CREAM PARLORS
5-1B-1: DEFINITION; LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall carry on, engage in or conduct a business of keeping what is generally known as an "ice cream parlor", which is hereby defined as a place
where ice cream, ices and beverages are kept and offered for sale to be consumed on the premises; provided, however, that this article shall not apply to
restaurants or coffee houses where such ice cream, ices, or beverages are sold and consumed in connection with the serving of meals, without first having
obtained a license as hereinafter provided. (1965 Code § 4-4-1)
5-1B-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE AND POSTING; FEE:
A. Application For License; Fee: Any person desiring a license to engage in the business of keeping an "ice cream parlor", as defined in section 5-1B-1 of
this article, shall make written application to the village clerk, stating the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual; or all the members of the
firm, if a copartnership; or the names and residences of the principal officers, if the applicant is a corporation; and also the location and description of
the premises where such business is to be conducted. If the president and board of trustees shall be satisfied that the applicant or applicants, or its
chief officers, if the applicant be a corporation, is or are of good character and reputation, and that the premises where the business is to be carried on
is proper and suitable, the president shall issue or cause to be issued a license, in accordance with such application, upon such applicant or applicants
paying a fee as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this code. (1965 Code § 4-4-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Issuance Of License: Every applicant in compliance with the aforesaid requirements, and the payment in advance of the fee hereinabove set forth to the
village clerk, shall receive a license, which shall authorize the person or persons therein named to keep an "ice cream parlor", as defined in section 5-
1B-1 of this article, in the place designated in the license and for the person designated therein. (1965 Code § 4-4-3; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Posting License: Every person licensed in accordance with the provisions in this article shall immediately post the said license or cause it to be posted
and shall at all times keep it posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where such business is thereby authorized to be conducted. (1965 Code
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 94/307
§ 4-4-4)
5-1B-3: HOURS OF BUSINESS:
No person, licensed in accordance with the provisions in this article, shall keep open any such place during the nighttime between the hours of twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (1965 Code § 4-4-5)
5-1B-4: SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Premises: It shall be the duty of any person licensed to carry on a business under this article to keep the premises at all times where the said business
is conducted in a clean and sanitary condition.
B. Employees: All persons employed or working on said premises shall be kept cleanly clothed.
C. Utensils, Equipment And Facilities: All utensils, refrigerators, pantries or any other places or things whatever which are used for the purpose of storing,
preparing or manufacturing must at all times be kept in a clean, wholesome and sanitary condition.
D. Materials For Sale: No decayed, unwholesome or impure material of any kind whatsoever shall be kept or offered for sale by any person in such
business. (1965 Code § 4-4-6)
ARTICLE C. MOBILE FOOD VENDORS1
5-1C-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
APPROVED EVENT: An event, including, but not limited to, a festival, holiday celebration, religious or charitable event, that is otherwise lawful and
approved, where required, by the proper authorities. Vendors operating in this context shall be registered with the building department.
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR: An individual, enterprise, corporation, partnership or other entity that sells, for profit, food from a motorized motor vehicle by
virtue of patrolling village streets in search of unsolicited or random sales and wherein the vehicle is an integral part of the enterprise. Such activity shall
include, but not be limited to, ice cream trucks, produce trucks, meat trucks and similar enterprises. (1965 Code § 4-44-1)
5-1C-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
Mobile food vending, as defined in this article, shall be a prohibited activity within the corporate limits of the village unless such activity is otherwise in
compliance with this article. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-3: EXEMPTIONS:
Nothing in this article shall prohibit the use of pushcarts, trailers and motorized vehicles to sell food when properly licensed and conducted in conjunction
with an approved event occurring within the village; provided, that such use shall be limited to the duration of the event and shall not meet the definition of
a "mobile food vendor". (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-4: LIMITATION OF LICENSES:
Mobile food vendor licenses shall be limited as follows:
A. Ice cream vendors: One license (1 licensee, maximum 2 trucks).
B. Catering trucks: One license (1 licensee, maximum 2 trucks).
C. Noncategory (other than subsections A and B of this section): One license. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-5: LICENSE AWARDED THROUGH BIDDING PROCESS:
A. Bid Qualifications:
1. Licenses shall be awarded to the highest qualified bidder.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 95/307
2. A qualified bidder is one who:
a. Provides the village with a list of all vehicles utilized for mobile food vending;
b. Provides the village with a list of the full names, addresses, telephone numbers and dates of birth for all proposed drivers;
c. Provides the village with a valid certificate of automobile insurance for all vehicles utilized for mobile food vending;
d. Provides the village with a certificate of inspection approval from the village mechanic for all vehicles utilized for mobile food vending;
e. Provides the village with a listing of the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all food suppliers;
f. Provides the village with a photograph of all vehicles utilized for mobile food vending service;
g. Provides the village with a completed application for the license; and
h. Provides the village with a bid tabulation sheet. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
B. Bid Process:
1. In March of 2004, and each March every two (2) years thereafter, the village shall advertise in a news publication of general circulation in the Lyons
area the village's intent to take bids for mobile food vending licenses. The advertisement shall advise of an open period of thirty (30) days for bidders
to obtain a bid package from village hall and submit same by a date ending the thirty (30) day bid submission process. (1965 Code § 4-44-2; amd.
2009 Code)
2. A bid opening shall be conducted by the village manager or his designee on or about seven (7) days following the bid submission deadline. Bids not
containing the required submissions enumerated in this article shall not be considered.
3. A preliminary bid award shall be awarded by the village manager or his designee based upon the highest bid amount from a qualified bidder for the
license fee. The bid shall not be awarded until all documents contained within the bid package have been verified, and all employee information
contained in the bid submission is checked by the Lyons police department for outstanding warrants, poor driving record, criminal history and
placement on the state of Illinois sex offender registry; further, that in the event an employee is found to have outstanding warrants, a driving record
with convictions for reckless or careless driving, driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, felony use of a motor vehicle, vehicular homicide or
similar offenses within the past two (2) years, a criminal history with felony convictions within the past five (5) years or a conviction at any time for
child molestation, food adulteration or similar offense or current placement on the state of Illinois sex offender registry, shall be cause for denying the
license or requiring the prospective licensee to remove the individual from driving food service vehicles in the village.
C. Licensure: The bid shall be awarded by the village manager upon completion of the verification process and payment of the bid amount by the vendor
to the village. A license shall be good for twenty four (24) months from the date of issuance. In the event a successful bidder is disqualified or revoked,
the village may, at its option, readvertise and rebid, or decline to issue another license for the duration of the license period. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-6: VEHICLE STICKER, APPEARANCE AND MAINTENANCE:
Vehicles utilized for mobile food service vending shall be kept in good mechanical and structural condition. Vehicles shall have a clean exterior and interior
and shall be equipped with automatic signs that extend outward from the vehicle to alert passing traffic to stop and proceed with caution past the truck
while it is stopped and serving customers. Each vehicle shall have the company name affixed to it in a professional, workmanlike manner and in letters
that are a minimum of six inches (6") high. The company name shall be affixed to each side and rear of the vehicle. The vehicle shall also display on the
front and rear bumpers a license sticker issued by the village. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-7: OPERATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Noise: No mobile food service vendor shall cause or have equipment to project noise other than the ringing of bells installed on the vehicle. The bell
ringing shall not be in a manner so as to create a nuisance.
B. Hours And Locations Of Operation: Mobile food vendor hours of operation within the village shall be restricted to between the hours of nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. A vendor shall not operate within one hundred fifty feet (150') of a place of worship or one hundred fifty feet
(150') of Smith park.
C. Food Safety: Food sold or provided by a mobile food vendor shall be kept refrigerated or frozen, where applicable, to provide for food safety. No food
shall be served after its packaged expiration date. Vehicles shall be subject to random inspection by both the village food safety inspector and the
village mechanic. All food service shall comply with state regulations where applicable. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-8: SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
A license may be suspended when a violation of this article is verified by the village and until such time as the violation is cured by the licensee and
verified by the village. The village manager or his designee shall be empowered to order a particular vehicle out of service for violations of this article
without actually suspending the vendor license. (1965 Code § 4-44-2)
5-1C-9: PENALTIES; VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT:
A. Penalties: In addition to license suspension, the village may, at its discretion, issue citations for appearance in the village adjudication hearings or in a
court of competent jurisdiction. A violation of this article, upon conviction or finding of responsibility, shall carry a minimum fine of one hundred dollars
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 96/307
($100.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day in violation shall constitute a separate violation.
B. Vehicle Impoundment; Storage Fee:
1. The village police department is empowered to impound mobile food service vehicles in the event the driver, company or vehicle is found to be in
violation of this article, or if the driver does not have a current driver license, or food safety or vehicle safety is found to be compromised. (1965 Code
§ 4-44-2)
2. The storage fee shall be thirty dollars ($30.00) per day. (1965 Code § 4-44-2; amd. 2009 Code)
Footnote 1: See section 4-1-3 of this code for license fee.
Chapter 2
NUISANCES
5-2-1: NUISANCES DECLARED AND ENUMERATED:
A. Nuisance Declared: In addition to other sections of this code, each of the acts or omissions in this section is hereby declared to constitute a nuisance.
(1965 Code § 9-2-1)
B. Creation Or Maintenance Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain, or suffer or permit to be created or maintained, any
nuisance, or to suffer or permit any such nuisance to exist, or to neglect or refuse to abate the same, or hinder, obstruct or prevent the abatement
thereof. (1965 Code § 9-2-2)
C. Nuisances Enumerated:
1. Offensive Odors: It shall be unlawful to so conduct any business or use any premises as to create an offensive odor which taints the air or renders it
unwholesome or disagreeable to the neighborhood. (1965 Code § 9-2-3)
2. Offensive Substances: It shall be unlawful to deposit any nightsoil, dead animal or other filthy, offensive or noisome substance upon any lot, street,
alley, park or other public place. (1965 Code § 9-2-5)
3. Water Pollution: It shall be unlawful to pollute or render unwholesome or impure the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake, to
the annoyance or prejudice of others. (1965 Code § 9-2-6)
4. Obstructing Public Ways: It shall be unlawful to obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys or public places. (1965
Code § 9-2-7)
5. Offensive, Filthy Premises: It shall be unlawful to keep or permit to be kept in a foul, offensive or filthy condition any premises. (1965 Code § 9-2-8)
6. Garbage, Refuse On Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person, and it is hereby declared to be a nuisance, to permit or suffer any slop, swill,
garbage, stable dripping, offal, filth, refuse, animal or vegetable matter which is liable to become putrid, offensive or injurious to health to remain on
any premises used or occupied by said person for a longer period than twenty four (24) hours at any one time. (1965 Code § 9-2-9)
7. Stagnant Pools: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to permit stagnant pools to stand on any premises owned or occupied thereby.
(1965 Code § 9-2-10)
8. Offensive Businesses: It shall be unlawful to erect, maintain or use any building or other place for the exercise of any trade, employment or
manufacture which, by occasioning noxious exhalations or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the health of individuals or to the public. (1965
Code § 9-2-11)
9. Combustible Material Near Buildings: It shall be unlawful to pile or stack any combustible or inflammable material within the space of fifty feet (50') of
any building; provided, however, that this shall not apply to materials to be used for building purposes. (1965 Code § 9-2-12)
10. Storing Old Automobiles And Junk: It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to store or permit to be stored on any lot, piece or parcel of
land any old automobiles, bathtubs, sinks, toilets and other unsightly junk and miscellaneous debris. (1965 Code § 9-2-13)
11. Animal Related Nuisances: See the following provisions of this code for animal related offenses:
Poultry or fowl, subsection 8-1-1B
Confined animals, section 8-1-7
Noisy animals, section 8-1-8
Slaughtering cattle, section 8-1-9
Animal carcasses, section 8-1-10
(1965 Code §§ 9-2-4, 9-2-14, 9-2-15, 9-2-16, 9-2-17)
12. Expectorating: It shall be unlawful to expectorate upon any sidewalk, or upon the floor of any public conveyance, or any building where a
considerable number of people gather or assemble together. (1965 Code § 9-2-18)
13. Deposit Of Slippery Substances On Public Property: It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful to place, throw, deposit or drop, or cause
to be placed, deposited, thrown or dropped, any peel, rind, slippery substance, nutshells or shucks, fruit, vegetables or refuse upon the floors, stairs,
walks, passages or ways of any public hall, place of public amusement, waiting room or station, public building, or school, or in or upon any sidewalk,
public way, passageway, crosswalk, alley or curb in the village. (1965 Code § 9-2-19)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 97/307
14. Establishing Cemetery: It shall be unlawful, and it is hereby declared to be a nuisance, to establish a cemetery within the corporate limits or within
one mile of the limits of the village. (1965 Code § 9-2-20)
15. Tree Roots Obstructing Sewers Or Drains: Any tree or shrub standing or growing on any public street or on private land abutting thereon, whose
roots obstruct or interfere with the free operation of any public or private sewer or drain in use is hereby declared to be a nuisance, and subject to
abatement as such. Any owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land abutting on a public street or way, upon which land such tree or shrub shall be
standing or growing shall, within ten (10) days after notice from the village president and board of trustees so to do, remove such tree or shrub and
the roots thereof. Any person violating this subsection C15 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. If any such person shall fail to remove such
tree or shrub and the roots thereof within fifteen (15) days after notice so to do, the director of public works shall effect such removal at the expense
of such owner or occupant. (1965 Code § 9-2-21)
16. Traction Engines On Streets: It is hereby declared to be a nuisance for any person to haul, drive, propel or operate any steam or gasoline or diesel
traction engine over or through any street, avenue or alley unless the wheels thereof are equipped with treads which will not injure the pavement.
(1965 Code § 9-2-22)
5-2-2: COMMON LAW NUISANCES:
All acts which constitute nuisances at common law or by the laws of the state shall constitute nuisances under this chapter. (1965 Code § 9-2-23)
5-2-3: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES:
Whenever any nuisance exists or shall be found on any premises contrary to any provision of this code, the village president, by and with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, may, in his discretion, cause the same to be summarily abated in such manner as he may direct, and at the expense of
the person permitting or maintaining such nuisance. (1965 Code § 9-2-24)
Chapter 3
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS1
5-3-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term "hazardous material" means any substance or mixture of substances that is toxic, corrosive, an irritant, strong sensitizer,
flammable, combustible, or that generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means and that may cause substantial personal injury or illness
during customary or reasonably anticipated handling or use or may cause an unreasonable threat to property, the public health or safety, or the ecological
balance of the environment. "Hazardous material" includes, but is not limited to, explosives, radioactive substances, petroleum or petroleum products,
poisons, toxic gases, flammable substances, corrosive substances, and pathogens. (1965 Code § 8-5-1)
5-3-2: DEPOSITS PROHIBITED:
No person shall place, spill or otherwise deposit, or cause to be placed, spilled or otherwise deposited, any hazardous material on any property in the
village or in any village owned building or facility without securing, in advance, proper authorization therefor from the fire chief or other authorized village
official. (1965 Code § 8-5-2)
5-3-3: ABATEMENT; ASSESSMENT OF COSTS:
A. Abatement Authorized: The fire chief or his delegate shall cause any unauthorized deposit of hazardous material on or in any property or village owned
public building or facility to be removed therefrom in a manner consistent with applicable federal and state law as soon as possible. (1965 Code § 8-5-
3)
B. Liability For Costs:
1. Any person responsible for any unauthorized placement, spill or other deposit of any hazardous material shall be liable for the payment of all costs of
removal thereof, including, but not limited to, labor costs, administrative costs and disposal costs.
2. Such payment shall be made within thirty (30) days after service of an invoice therefor by the village.
3. The assessment by the village of costs hereunder shall be in addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by this code or federal or state
law. (1965 Code § 8-5-4)
Footnote 1: See also title 6, chapter 6 of this code.
Chapter 4
ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY
5-4-1: CODES ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 98/307
The village hereby incorporates by reference the following Illinois acts:
A. Environmental Protection: The Illinois environmental protection act, as amended, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq. (1965 Code § 3-12-1)
B. Water Pollutant Discharge: The Illinois water pollutant discharge act, as amended, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 25/0.01 et seq. (1965 Code § 3-12-2)
C. Litter Control: The Illinois litter control act, as amended, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 105/1 et seq. (1965 Code § 3-12-3)
5-4-2: RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INVESTIGATIONS:
The village building department, fire department and police department, and their agents, are empowered under this chapter to enter properties for the
purposes of conducting such investigations so as to determine compliance with said acts, as adopted in section 5-4-1 of this chapter, and to provide such
evidence to the state of Illinois or Cook County agencies for follow up and enforcement by those entities, as required. (1965 Code § 3-12-4)
5-4-3: PROBABLE CAUSE; VERIFICATION OF POLLUTION:
A. Investigation To Verify Existence Of Pollution: Wherein probable cause exists that a violation of such acts, as adopted in section 5-4-1 of this chapter,
has occurred, or where probable cause exists that illegal dumping or polluting has occurred, the village may cause to have conducted those
environmental studies, including, but not limited to, a phase I or phase II environmental impact study, so as to further verify the existence of such
pollution, causation, remediation and enforcement needs.
B. Cost Borne By Property Owner: The cost of such assessment shall be borne by the affected property owner, unless otherwise preempted by state law.
(1965 Code § 3-12-5)
5-4-4: CIVIL REMEDIES:
The penalties proscribed by the acts, as adopted in section 5-4-1 of this chapter, shall not limit the village from pursuing other remedies as provided by
law. (1965 Code § 3-12-6)
Chapter 5
GARBAGE AND REFUSE1
5-5-1: DEFINITIONS2:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they will have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
ASHES: Residue from wood, coal and coke, and residue from the combustion of any material or substances, and soot, cinders, slag and charcoal.
GARBAGE: Waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; from the handling, storage and sale of produce; animal and
vegetable matter; manure; and swill; including decaying animal matter and fish.
MANURE: All excrement of domestic animals and fowl, stable bedding, and all hay, straw, shavings, grass, weeds or leaves which have been used for
stable bedding.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Materials that would otherwise be abandoned or discarded but which can be utilized in the secondary material market.
REFUSE: Combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, wood furniture, and bedding;
noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, crockery, or other mineral
waste; street rubbish, including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, catch basin dirt, and contents of litter receptacles.
SCAVENGER: Any person that manages, conducts or carries on the business of the collection, removal and/or disposal of garbage, refuse or ashes from
businesses or residences or any other places within the village.
YARD WASTE: All accumulations of grass, leaves, plant or shrubbery materials, tree branches or other materials accumulated as the result of the care of
the lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees. "Yard waste" shall also include discarded Christmas trees. The term "yard waste material" shall also connote any
and all materials specified from time to time by 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.270, or any successor to that provision should that definition be broader
than the above. (1965 Code § 3-9-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5-5-2: SUPERVISION:
All matters relating to or affecting the collection, removal or disposal of household refuse or all waste material, or recyclable material, unless specifically
placed under the direction of the health department, shall be subject to and under the supervision and direction of the village inspector or such other
employee as may be designated by the board of trustees. (1965 Code § 3-9-2; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 99/307
5-5-3: COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
A. Collection: Garbage, ashes and miscellaneous waste, yard waste and recyclable material shall be called for and disposed of by the village or its agents
or persons with whom it may contract to perform such services from time to time and shall not be collected or disposed of in any other manner, except
as in this chapter provided; and no such garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste, yard waste and recyclable material shall be allowed to accumulate on
any property or premises for a period longer than the time between calls by the village, its agents or contractors at said property or premises for the
purpose of collecting the same.
B. Special Service: If the waste is of such character or quantity that the regular collectors making the regular trips do not collect such waste, then the
occupant of such premises shall make request for said service within one week after the accumulation thereof. For such special service, the village
agent or contractor, as the case may be, shall make a reasonable charge. (1965 Code § 3-9-11)
5-5-4: CONTRACT FOR GARBAGE HAULING; RATES:
A. Contract: The village president and board of trustees may, in their discretion, enter into a contract with a responsible person to handle all the garbage,
ashes, miscellaneous waste, yard waste and recyclable materials collection, removal and disposal from the village.
B. Establishment Of Rates: The village president and board of trustees shall establish reasonable rates from time to time for the collection and disposal of
garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste, yard waste and recyclable materials.
C. Rate Increases: All rate increases hereinafter provided by the village scavenger and landfill operator shall be added to the established garbage rate as
they occur.
Effective March 16, 2010, the rates for residential garbage collection and disposal shall be as follows:
1. Fourteen dollars four cents ($14.04) per month per unit for a thirty five (35) gallon capacity garbage container and up to one bulk item per week.
2. Eighteen dollars sixty eight cents ($18.68) per month per unit for a sixty five (65) gallon capacity garbage container and up to one bulk item per
week.
3. Twenty two dollars thirty one cents ($22.31) per month per unit for a ninety five (95) gallon capacity garbage container and up to one bulk item per
week.
D. Conflicting Provisions: Where conflicts exist between other village regulations, ordinances and this chapter, the stricter standard shall apply. (Ord. 03-
16-10-01, 3-16-2010)
5-5-5: RECEPTACLES:
A. Receptacles Required And Maintained: It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent of any dwelling, apartment, condo, or commercial building
to provide, and to maintain in good order, adequate, covered receptacles for storage of garbage and recyclable materials.
B. Types Of Receptacles:
1. Such receptacles shall be watertight, durable, secure, and have close fitting covers at all times to prevent the attraction of animals. At no time shall
garbage be put out only in plastic bags without inserting said plastic bags into a covered receptacle. A sufficient number and properly sized
containers shall be provided to accommodate all waste for a seven (7) day period.
2. Yard waste shall be deposited in biodegradable paper bags or such other durable containers used exclusively for the disposal of yard waste. Neither
the paper bag nor the durable container shall have a capacity of more than thirty two (32) gallons.
3. Recyclable material shall be deposited in a durable container separate from any receptacle used for other types of waste, with a capacity of not more
than thirty two (32) gallons.
C. Placement Of Receptacles For Pick Up:
1. Every owner, or the occupant of every house, building, store, flat, apartment, tenement, or dwelling place in the village, of which receptacles for
garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste, recyclable materials, yard waste or any of them have been provided, shall cause such receptacles to be
placed in a convenient area upon said premises for the removal of the contents thereof at such times and in such a manner as the village inspector,
or other village employee in charge, may direct.
2. No receptacle shall be kept on the parkways or in front of any premises other than on pick up days, and said receptacle or receptacles shall be
moved immediately after the pick ups have been made. (1965 Code § 3-9-3)
5-5-6: PREPARATION FOR COLLECTION BY VILLAGE:
A. Draining And Wrapping:
1. It shall be the duty of each occupant, tenant or person in possession of any dwelling to cause all garbage produced in or brought into such dwelling
to be thoroughly drained of surplus liquid, securely wrapped in paper or packed in a covered box or carton, and finally deposited in a garbage
receptacle meeting the requirements of section 5-5-5 of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 100/307
2. Materials of every character to be collected shall be securely wrapped in such manner as to prevent the blowing of same by the wind and shall be
deposited in the receptacle provided for such materials. (1965 Code § 3-9-4)
B. Yard Waste Collection: All yard waste must be deposited in paper, compostable yard waste bags or such other durable container used solely for the
disposal of yard waste, either having a maximum capacity of thirty two (32) gallons. Residents shall be required to furnish their own compostable bags
or durable container. Yard waste material shall be placed at the same location where other garbage and refuse is deposited for removal and collection.
Yard waste material such as twigs, brush and branches not exceeding four feet (4') in length nor more than three inches (3") in diameter which are tied
in bundles not to exceed twenty four inches (24") in diameter with biodegradable twine shall also be collected as yard waste material. The collection
day(s) shall be on the same day(s) when other refuse is collected within Lyons and shall not commence prior to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. Yard waste
materials shall not be allowed to scatter or be spilled. (1965 Code § 3-9-5)
5-5-7: LITTERING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to litter or to perform any act which will cause to be littered any streets, alleys, sidewalks, sewers, curbs, gutters or other
public places in the village with garbage, paper or refuse of any kind. Likewise, no person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the
jurisdiction of the village any substance, article or thing defined in section 5-5-1 of this chapter, in such a manner that it or any of them may be carried or
deposited by the action of the sun, wind, rain or snow, into or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway or other public place or into any occupied
premises within the village. (1965 Code § 3-9-6)
5-5-8: REFUSE AND YARD WASTE IN STREETS AND ALLEYS3:
A. Refuse Deposits Prohibited; Exceptions: No person shall deposit or place in or upon any sidewalk, street, alley, parkway or public place, any refuse of
any kind; provided, that this section shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by an ordinance of the village; nor to goods,
wares or merchandise deposited upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place temporarily in the necessary course of trade and removed
therefrom within two (2) hours after being so deposited; nor to articles or things deposited in or conducted into the village sewerage system through
lawful drains.
B. Yard Waste Removal By Village; Assessment Of Costs; Lien:
1. No person, company, partnership, corporation or other entity shall deposit, place or cause to deposit or place in or upon any gutter, street, alley, or
public way any leaves, grass, or other yard waste. The presence of deposits of leaves, grass, or yard waste in the gutter or street in front of any
property in an amount that exceeds the capacity of a thirty two (32) gallon biodegradable paper bag intended for yard waste disposal shall constitute
a presumption that the owner or resident at that property address is responsible for such illegal disposal of leaves, grass, or yard waste at that
location.
2. In addition to being liable for fines as provided for by this code, in the event the village provides leaf removal service from the street, the actual cost
of such service, including labor, materials, dump fees, equipment rental and/or depreciation, plus a fifty dollar ($50.00) service fee, shall be imposed
upon the owner of the subject property. In the event that the invoice is not paid within thirty (30) days of its issuance, such costs shall be placed as a
lien upon the property as provided for by law. (1965 Code § 3-9-7)
5-5-9: DEPOSITS OF OFFENSIVE MATTER:
A. No pile or deposit of manure, garbage, miscellaneous waste or refuse of any kind or accumulation of any offensive or nauseous substance shall be
