made within the limits of the village; nor shall any person or corporation unload, discharge or put upon or along the line of any railroad, street, highway,
or public place within the village or upon any vacant lot, any manure, garbage, miscellaneous waste, refuse or other offensive or nauseous substances;
nor shall any cars loaded with or having in or upon them any such substance be allowed to remain or stand on or along any railroad, street or highway
within the limits of the village, within three hundred (300) yards of any inhabited dwelling.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or suffer any garbage, offal, refuse or animal or vegetable matter which is liable to become putrid or
offensive or injurious to health to remain on any premises used or occupied by him for a longer period than four (4) hours at any one time. (1965 Code
§ 3-9-8; amd. 2009 Code)
5-5-10: SIFTING OR EXPOSING TO WIND:
No lime, ashes, coal or other substance that is in a similar manner liable to be blown by the wind shall be sifted or exposed in any street or public place, or
in any place within the village where particles therefrom set in motion thereby will pass into any such street or public place or into any occupied premises.
(1965 Code § 3-9-9)
5-5-11: OPEN BURNING4:
No person shall burn any matter or materials within the village except in keeping with the provisions of section 13-8-6 of this code. (1965 Code § 3-9-10;
amd. 2009 Code)
ARTICLE A. COMPOSTING
5-5A-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 101/307
The purpose of this article is to promote the recycling of yard wastes through composting and to establish minimum standards for proper compost
maintenance. (1965 Code § 3-9A-1)
5-5A-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
COMPOSTABLE MATERIAL: Grass, garden clippings, brush, leaves, tree clippings, and other materials accumulated as a result of the maintenance of
gardens, lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.
COMPOSTING: The controlled biological reduction of organic wastes to humus. (1965 Code § 3-9A-2)
5-5A-3: OWNER RESPONSIBILITY:
Every owner or operator shall be responsible for maintaining all property under his or her control in accordance with the requirements of this article. (1965
Code § 3-9A-6)
5-5A-4: MAINTENANCE:
All compost piles shall be maintained using approved composting procedures that comply with the following requirements:
A. All compost piles shall be enclosed in a freestanding compost bin.
B. Compostable materials may be placed in a compost pile; provided, that such materials are placed in such a manner as not to allow them to be
windblown.
C. The depositing of garbage, pet waste, meat scraps or other materials that may attract animals or vermin to the compost pile or which may provide an
obnoxious odor shall be prohibited. Compost piles containing garden debris shall be kept covered, except while turning.
D. The presence of rodents in or near a compost pile shall cause health department regulation and enforcement under subsection 1-9D-2C of this code.
(1965 Code § 3-9A-3)
5-5A-5: LOCATION:
A compost pile shall not be located less than twenty five feet (25') from any neighboring dwelling unit, less than eight feet (8') from any rear or side lot line
or within any required front yard as defined in the village zoning regulations in title 13 of this code. (1965 Code § 3-9A-4)
5-5A-6: COMPOST BIN CONSTRUCTION:
Each compost bin shall be no larger than three feet (3') to five feet (5') wide and no taller than five feet (5') high, and shall be constructed of woven
galvanized wire, block, or brick; or shall be a prefabricated wooden bin, with sufficient openings to allow adequate air movement. (1965 Code § 3-9A-5)
5-5A-7: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of a violation of this article shall be fined in an amount of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any second or subsequent
finding of guilty for any of these offenses shall result in a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). (1965 Code § 3-9A-7)
ARTICLE B. ON SITE MULTI-FAMILY RECYCLING PROGRAM
5-5B-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
MULTI-FAMILY PROPERTY: A property consisting of one or more multi-family structures.
MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE: A building with more than two (2) residential dwelling units which are not included in the village of Lyons curbside refuse,
recyclables and landscape waste collection and disposal service.
OWNER: Any person, corporation, partnership or entity such as a condominium or homeowners' association, jointly or severally having an ownership
interest in a multi-family property or otherwise being responsible for solid waste collection.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 102/307
PRIVATE SCAVENGER: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of solid waste, compostable material and/or recyclable material from any
location within the village not covered by either an exclusive collection contract between the village of Lyons and a contracted hauler or a franchise
agreement between the village of Lyons and a franchised hauler.
RECYCLABLE MATERIAL: A material which would otherwise be abandoned or discarded but which can be utilized in the secondary material market.
RECYCLING: The process by which materials that would otherwise be disposed of or discarded are collected, separated or processed and returned to the
economic mainstream in the form of raw materials or products.
SOURCE SEPARATION: A process that separates recyclable materials from other refuse prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials.
VILLAGE: The village of Lyons or its designee. (1965 Code § 3-13-1)
5-5B-2: RECYCLING PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS:
A. Program Requirements:
1. All owners of "multi-family properties", as defined in section 5-5B-2 of this article, shall be required to institute an on site recycling program, with
collection of recyclable materials to be no less than one pick up per week.
2. Said program shall be instituted on or before July 1, 2003.
3. Multi-family property owners are required to use the village's franchised recyclables collection hauler. Multi-family property owners shall be billed for
such services by the franchised hauler or directly by the village, as determined by the village manager. The fee for such service shall be as
established by the village and the franchised hauler. In the event the franchised hauler is unable to perform, owners shall be permitted to utilize the
services of a private licensed scavenger, who shall be subject to the same regulations herein listed; except, that the private scavenger shall bill the
owner directly for his services.
4. An acceptable recycling program shall include, but is not limited to, the following components:
a. Siting and design of common area collection areas for recyclable materials;
b. Recyclable materials collection;
c. Provision of common area recycling containers;
d. Data collection and reporting;
e. Educational campaign and materials; and
f. Recycling program administration and maintenance.
B. Specific Requirements:
1. Recycling collection areas for residents shall be conveniently located and maintained within common areas in or near the buildings and consist of
separate containers for the purposes of temporary storage of recyclables. Whenever possible, recycling containers should be placed adjacent to
common area solid waste collection containers.
2. Indoor common area collection/storage areas shall be established in accordance with appropriate village fire safety and property maintenance
codes.
3. Exterior recyclables storage areas shall be established in accordance with village requirements for solid waste enclosures.
4. The multi-family property owner shall maintain all recycling areas, including the containers, in a clean, sanitary and litter free manner.
5. On site multi-family structure recycling programs are required to offer collection of a minimum of five (5) of the following types of recyclable materials:
Aluminum, steel, tin and bimetal cans
Chipboard
Corrugated cardboard
Glass bottles (3 colors)
High grade paper
Junk mail
Magazines and catalogs
Miscellaneous ferrous and nonferrous scrap metals
Newspaper
PETE (#1) and HDPE (#2) plastic bottles
Telephone books
6. Recyclable materials shall be source separated from other solid waste prior to collection for the purpose of recycling such materials. Separate
collection containers and collection vehicles shall be employed.
7. The minimum gallon amount of recycling container capacity (total weekly base recycling container capacity) an owner shall provide weekly for each
structure shall be based upon the following formula:
7 gallons x number of studio and 1-bedroom units +
8 gallons x number of 2-bedroom units +
9 gallons x number of 3-bedroom or more units =
total base weekly recycling container capacity
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 103/307
The weekly base recycling container capacity may be met by a combination of container sizes and number of pick ups, such as containers totaling
one-half (1/2) the base capacity picked up twice a week. Capacity per structure may be shifted within the multi-family property if necessary, so long
as the total required capacity is met.
8. The franchised scavenger providing the on site recycling collection service shall be responsible for furnishing and replacing all common area
recycling containers and collection vehicles which are deemed necessary in the recycling program.
9. Multi-family property owners shall notify residents of the availability of recycling services through a formal and ongoing educational campaign and
shall use their best efforts to gain and maintain participation in the program.
10. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized persons to remove or damage any recyclable materials placed in designated containers or the containers
themselves1. Title to recyclable material shall pass to the scavenger when the materials are placed into the collection vehicle.
11. A sale certificate, as required by this code, shall not be approved until such time as compliance with this article is verified by the village inspector.
(1965 Code § 3-13-2)
5-5B-3: REPORTING REQUIREMENTS:
A. Report By Franchised Hauler: Each franchised hauler shall submit a quarterly report to both the multi-family property owner(s) or their designee and the
village and/or its designee that contains the following information:
1. Total weight or volume of refuse collected from multi-family properties it serves within the village.
2. Total weight or volume of yard waste collected from multi-family properties it serves within the village.
3. Total weight or volume of recyclable materials collected from multi-family properties it serves within the village.
4. A summary of recycling services provided to each multi-family property to be submitted only on an annual basis with the fourth quarter report.
B. Applicability Of Report: Quarterly reports submitted to the multi-family property shall only pertain to that property's activity.
C. Aggregate Totals: Quarterly reports submitted to the village shall contain aggregate totals concerning the information listed above for all multi-family
properties within the village's jurisdiction.
D. Due Date: Reports shall be due no later than fifteen (15) days after the close of each quarter. "Quarters" are defined as follows: first quarter (January 1
through March 31), second quarter (April 1 through June 30), third quarter (July 1 through September 30) and fourth quarter (October 1 through
December 31). Reports shall follow the format prescribed by the village. (1965 Code § 3-13-3)
5-5B-4: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The village and/or its designee shall have the right to inspect and examine records pertaining to the collection and disposal or processing of refuse and
recyclables upon request and with reasonable notice. (1965 Code § 3-13-4)
5-5B-5: IMPLEMENTATION AND CONTINUATION OF PROGRAM:
Implementation of on site multi-family structure recycling programs shall be required as provided for in this article. Such programs shall be maintained in
effect regardless of a change in scavenger, hauler or property ownership. Multi-family property owners shall be required to notify the village in writing
within thirty (30) days after a change in their choice of private scavenger. (1965 Code § 3-13-5)
5-5B-6: PENALTIES:
A. Penalty Imposed: A violation of this article, upon conviction, shall, in addition to a loss of license, be punishable by a minimum fine of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), as determined by the village code hearing officer or court of competent
jurisdiction. Each day of noncompliance shall be deemed to be a separate violation.
B. Other Remedies: Prosecution and/or loss of license shall not preclude the village from seeking any other lawful remedy to obtain compliance. (1965
Code § 3-13-6)
Footnote 1: See also section 7-4A-4 of this code.
ARTICLE C. SCAVENGERS
5-5C-1: DEFINITIONS1:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this article, they will have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
ASHES: Residue from wood, coal and coke, and residue resulting from the combustion of any material or substance, and soot, cinders, slag and charcoal.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 104/307
CONSTRUCTION DEBRIS: Any and all materials used, to be used or having been used in the construction of a building or structure, including, but not
limited to, shingles, wood, concrete, plastic, metal, brick and similar items.
GARBAGE: Wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food; from the handling, storage and sale of produce; animal
and vegetable matter; manure; and swill; including decaying animal matter and fish.
PRIVATE SCAVENGER: Any person that manages, conducts or carries on the business of the collection, removal or disposal of garbage, refuse, or ashes
from businesses or residences or any other places within the village.
RECYCLABLE MATERIALS: Materials that would otherwise be abandoned or discarded but which can be utilized in the secondary material market.
REFUSE: Combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper, cartons, boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture,
and bedding, noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans, metal furniture, and small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete,
glass, crockery, or other mineral waste; street rubbish, including, but not limited to, street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt, and contents of litter
receptacles. (1965 Code § 4-38-1)
5-5C-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The village inspector shall enforce the provisions of this article and shall issue such reasonable orders in connection with the carrying on of the business of
a licensed scavenger as he deems necessary to protect the health of the public. It shall be the duty of such licensed scavenger to comply with such orders
and to perform the work required of them in such a way that no nuisance will be created thereby. (1965 Code § 4-38-12)
5-5C-3: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; FEE:
A. License Required; Exceptions: No person shall manage, conduct, or carry on the business of private scavenger, or shall be permitted to remove and
dispose of any matter enumerated in the section 5-5C-1 of this article, without first having obtained a license so to do; provided, however, that no
license shall be required of any person for the removal of manure from his own premises; and provided further, that any person desiring to gather,
remove, or dispose of animal or vegetable refuse and wastes from his own premises without the aid of a licensed private scavenger may do so only
upon the written permission of the health officer, and then only in the manner specified in such permit. (1965 Code § 4-38-2)
B. Application For License: Any person desiring to manage, conduct, or carry on the business of "private scavenger", as defined in section 5-5C-1 of this
article, shall make a written application for a license so to do in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to application for licenses.
The applicant shall state the number of vehicles which he intends to operate or use in said business and what method of disposal and the place thereof
proposed by the applicant. (1965 Code § 4-38-3)
C. Investigation; Issuance Of License: The village inspector shall cause an investigation to be made of the application to determine whether the health,
sanitation and safety provisions of this code applicable to private scavengers have been satisfied. Upon a determination of compliance with the
applicable provisions of this code, the village inspector shall cause a license to be issued to the applicant. (1965 Code § 4-38-4)
D. License Fee: The annual license fee for each private scavenger shall be as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this code and shall conform to the general
provisions relating to licenses. (1965 Code § 4-38-5)
5-5C-4: REFUSE REMOVAL BY VILLAGE:
Nothing in this article shall be construed to conflict with any existing or future provisions of this code concerning the removal and disposal of dirt, filth, litter,
garbage, ashes, manure, offal, swill, dead animals or other materials from the public ways by the village through its contractors or otherwise. (1965 Code
§ 4-38-7)
5-5C-5: SCAVENGER REQUIREMENTS:
A. Service Required: A scavenger licensed by the village shall provide service within the limits of the village on regular, scheduled days, at least once a
week, and more often when necessary, to all persons requiring such service at such rates as are fixed by contract with the village. (1965 Code § 4-38-
8)
B. Workers' Compensation And Liability Insurance: A scavenger licensed by the village shall provide and maintain workers' compensation and public
liability insurance in a minimum amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence with a total limit of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00), with the village named as an additional insured, and a ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) cash or surety bond indebted to the village.
Such bond shall act as a surety to guarantee against damage to village and private property by scavenger equipment and vehicles. (1965 Code § 4-38-
9)
C. Vehicle And Equipment: A scavenger licensed by the village shall use only trucks and equipment that are maintained in safe and proper operating
condition and according to the manufacturer's specifications. All trucks and equipment shall be safely and properly operated and in accordance with the
manufacturer's specifications and applicable state and village regulations. (1965 Code § 4-38-10)
D. Sanitary And Safety Provisions: It shall be the duty of every person who has contracted or undertaken to remove any filthy, offensive or noxious
substance, or is engaged in any such removal, or in the loading or unloading of any such substance to do the same as quickly and as carefully as
possible and free from offense and with as little danger and prejudice to life and health as possible. (1965 Code § 4-38-11; amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 105/307
5-5C-6: LIABILITY OF OWNER AND OCCUPANT:
The owner of the premises thereof, and the user of the garbage collection service, shall be jointly and severally liable for payment for the service on such
premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the
user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. (1965 Code § 4-38-13)
5-5C-7: BILLING AND PAYMENT:
Charges for garbage and refuse collection services rendered shall be included on the customer's water bill and shall be due and payable at the same time
the water bill is due and payable2. (1965 Code § 4-38-15; amd. 2009 Code)
5-5C-8: DISPOSITION OF REVENUE:
All revenues and monies received for the collection of garbage, ashes and refuse and any other monies paid into or belonging to the garbage division shall
be kept and maintained in a separate fund and used only for the purpose of operating and maintaining such division. No monies shall be transferred from
such fund for any purpose except upon vote of the majority members of the board of trustees and then only in the event that such transfer is from funds
declared to be surplus over and above any and all requirements of the refuse division. (1965 Code § 4-38-16)
5-5C-9: HOURS OF OPERATION; NUISANCE CONDITIONS:
Scavengers shall be precluded from operating within the village from seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., and shall be prohibited from
creating nuisance conditions such as noise, dust, vibrations and similar nuisance actions as defined by village ordinances. Scavengers shall be prohibited
from depositing or leaving refuse, garbage, recyclables, construction debris and similar items upon private property, parkways, roadways, sidewalks and
alleys. Exceptions to operating hours may be granted by the village manager based upon extraordinary or exigent circumstances; provided, that such
exceptions will not serve to create a nuisance. (1965 Code § 4-38-17)
5-5C-10: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A scavenger license shall be suspended if, after ten (10) days' notice from the village that such entity owes the village fees or fines, such amount is not
tendered to the village in full. Such suspension may be appealed to the village manager. (1965 Code § 4-38-19)
5-5C-11: RESPONSIBILITY AND PENALTY:
A. Penalty Imposed: Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity who knowingly engages the services of an unlicensed scavenger, and any
person, corporation, partnership or other entity who manages, operates or conducts themselves as an unlicensed scavenger or as a scavenger in
violation of this code is subject to the penalties contained herein. A violation of this code shall be punishable by a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each day such violation exists; further, leach containers, dumpsters, trucks and other property of an unlicensed scavenger found
to be in operation or use for scavenger purposes within the village may be locked, immobilized or impounded by the village. Such property shall only be
released upon demonstration that the scavenger has properly obtained the required village license and paid all fines and fees, including, but not limited
to, an administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus the actual cost of impounding, storing, immobilizing and/or locking such vehicles and
equipment, as determined by the impounding authority.
B. Double License Fee For Unlicensed Scavenger: The license fee for an unlicensed scavenger shall double if said scavenger does not obtain the license
within ten (10) days after being notified by the village to obtain said license. (1965 Code § 4-38-20)
Footnote 1: See also section 5-5-1 of this chapter.
Footnote 2: See section 11-1-3 of this code.
Chapter 6
WEEDS, GRASSES AND VEGETATION
5-6-1: WEEDS PROHIBITED; NUISANCE DECLARED:
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation, or any owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control
of any lot, tract, parcel of land, building or other premises within the village or within its territorial jurisdiction to permit the growth upon any premises within
the village of any noxious weeds, such as blue vervain, buckthorn, burdock, bull nettle, burdock, cockleburs, common milkweed, curled dock, dodders,
field bindweed, giant foxtail, hoary cress, jimson weed, Johnson grass, lamb's quarters, leafy spurge, marijuana or wild hemp, multiflora rose, purple
loosestrife, ragweed, ox-eye daisy, poison ivy, thistle (bull, Canada, sowthistle or musk), quack grass, ragweed (giant, common, or western), Russian
knapweed, rough pigweed, sweet clover, teasel, wild carrot, wild lettuce, wild garlic, wild mustard or like weeds having similar undesirable characteristics
as determined by the public works department or the dean of the college of agriculture of the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana. It shall be
unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain on property within the village. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-2: HEIGHT LIMITATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 106/307
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation, or any owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control
of any lot, tract, parcel of land, building or other premises within the village or within its territorial jurisdiction to permit the growth upon any premises within
the village of any weeds or grass or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, garden crops or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height exceeding six
inches (6") anywhere in the village, or to permit any premises to become overgrown with weeds and brush in such a manner as to become injurious to the
health of the community. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-3: TRIMMING BUSHES AND SHRUBS:
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation, or any owner, agent, occupant or person in possession, charge or control
of any lot, tract, parcel of land, building or other premises within the village or within its territorial jurisdiction to permit the unchecked growth upon any
premises within the village of any bushes or shrubs without trimming the same in such a manner as to prevent such bushes or shrubs from crossing
property lines or obstructing the sidewalk, parkway, street or highway. Moreover, it is hereby declared a public nuisance to permit bushes and shrubs to
become unsightly and unruly, as the same shall be determined by the public works department. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-4: OWNER/OCCUPANT RESPONSIBILITIES:
A. Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village shall cut the weeds and grass on his or her property and on the abutting parkway at all such
times as may be necessary so that such weeds and grass shall not exceed six inches (6") in height.
B. Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village shall trim the bushes and shrubs on his or her property and on the abutting parkway at all such
times as may be necessary to prevent the same from crossing property lines or obstructing the sidewalk, parkway, street or highway or otherwise
become unsightly and unruly, as the same shall be determined by the public works department.
C. If such owner neglects or refuses to cut such weeds or grass so that such weeds or grass exceed six inches (6") in height, or fails to trim bushes and
shrubs in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the village may cut the weeds or grass or trim the bushes and shrubs or authorize some
person to do the same on behalf of the village. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-5: NOTICE TO REMEDIATE AND ABATE NUISANCE:
It shall be the duty of the public works department to cause notice to be served upon the owner or occupant of any premises on which landscaping
conditions are in violation of the provisions of this chapter, and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within ten (10) days. The "notice to remediate
and abate nuisance" may be served either in person or by first class mail. It shall not be necessary in any case to specify in what manner the nuisance
shall be abated, though such notice shall provide sufficient information for the recipient thereof to understand the nature of the nuisance(s). Such notice
shall notify the owner that he or she must abate the nuisance(s) within ten (10) days and shall also contain a copy of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-
7 and the ordinance codified herein and notify the owner that the village may remove or trim the tree(s) and place a lien on the property for the cost of the
removal if the nuisance is not abated within ten (10) days. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-6: ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
If the person served with a "notice to remediate and abate nuisance" under this chapter shall fail, refuse or neglect to abate the nuisance within ten (10)
days, the director of public works shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of all related expenses. Such expenses shall be charged to
and paid by the owner or occupant. (Ord. 02-19-08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-6-7: PAYMENT OF CHARGES; LIEN PROVISIONS:
A. Rendition Of Bill: If weeds, grass, bushes or shrubs are cut or trimmed by the village or by someone directed to perform the same on behalf of the
village, the village shall send a bill for the cost and expense thereof to the property owner, his agent or legal representative or occupant in legal
possession or control of the premises.
B. Failure To Pay; Notice Of Lien:
1. If said bill is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of the date of said bill, the village manager or his or her designee shall cause a notice of lien of the
cost and expense thereof incurred by the village to be recorded in the following manner: The village or the person performing the service by authority
of the village, in its, his or her own name, may file a notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds, or the office of the county registrar of
titles, if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens system. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth:
a. A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof;
b. The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and
c. The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village or someone working on behalf of the village.
2. Such notice of lien shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred. After recording, the notice of lien, together with copies
of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7 and the ordinance codified herein, shall be sent by certified mail or hand delivered to the property owner,
his agent or legal representative or occupant in legal possession or control of the premises and, if different, to the person who received the tax bill for
the preceding year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 107/307
C. Release Of Lien: Upon payment of the cost and expense after the notice of lien has been filed as provided herein, the lien shall be released by the
village or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release shall be recorded of record in the same manner as recording the notice of lien.
D. Foreclosure Of Lien: Subsequent to the filing of the above described lien, the village may cause to be filed a complaint for foreclosure of such lien, or
upon becoming a defendant in a pending lawsuit affecting the premises or real estate, by answer to the complaint, or in the nature of an intervening
petition or cross complaint, the village may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien. The property subject to a lien arising under this
chapter shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the monies owing the village. (Ord. 02-19-08-
03, 2-19-2008)
Chapter 7
TREES AND SHRUBS
5-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
PARK TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names and all areas owned by the village, or to
which the public has free access as a park.
STREET TREES: Trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways
within the village. (1965 Code § 5-4-1)
5-7-2: FORESTRY REVIEW BOARD1:
A. Established; Appointment: There is hereby created and established a forestry review board for the village which shall consist of five (5) members,
citizens and residents of the village, who shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. (1965 Code
§ 5-4-10; amd. Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009; Ord. 05-17-11-O3, 5-17-2011)
B. Term Of Office; Vacancies:
1. The term of the five (5) persons to be appointed by the president shall be three (3) years; except, that the term of two (2) of the members appointed
to the first board shall be for only one year, and the term of two (2) members of the first board shall be for two (2) years.
2. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. (1965
Code § 5-4-11)
C. Compensation: Members of the board shall serve without compensation. (1965 Code § 5-4-12)
D. Duties And Responsibilities: It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer,
a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other
public areas. Such plan shall be presented annually to the village board and, upon their acceptance and approval, shall constitute the "official
comprehensive village tree plan for the village of Lyons, state of Illinois". The forestry review board, when requested by the village board, shall
consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. (1965 Code § 5-
4-13)
E. Operation; Rules: The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the
members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. (1965 Code § 5-4-14)
F. Review By Village Board: The village board shall have the right to review the conduct, acts and decisions of the forestry review board. Any person may
appeal from any ruling or order of the forestry review board to the village board who may hear the matter and make the final decision. (1965 Code § 5-
4-15)
G. Interference With Forestry Board: It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the forestry review board or any of its agents
while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park trees or trees on private
grounds as authorized in this chapter. (1965 Code § 5-4-5)
5-7-3: ARBORISTS:
A. License Required; Fee: It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating or removing trees within
the village without first applying for and procuring a license. The fee for the license shall be as provided in section 4-1-3 of this code; provided,
however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or village employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service
endeavors.
B. Liability Insurance: Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum
amounts of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for bodily injury and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for property damage,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 108/307
indemnifying the village or any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. The noncommercial
removal of trees in excess of twenty feet (20') in height and twenty four inches (24") in circumference shall require the listed insurance in addition to the
mandatory license. (1965 Code § 5-4-45; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-4: PUBLIC TREE CARE:
The village shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares
and public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. The forestry
review board may remove or cause or order to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which, by reason of its nature, is
injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is infected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest.
This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners; provided, that the selection and location of said trees is in
accordance with section 5-7-5 of this chapter. (1965 Code § 5-4-2)
5-7-5: TREE PLANTING ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
A. Permit Requirements:
1. Permit Required: No person shall plant, spray, trim or fasten any wire or rope to, or otherwise interfere with, the free growth of any tree or shrub on
village property without procuring a permit therefor as herein provided. (1965 Code § 5-4-50)
2. Application For Permit: Applications for a permit shall be made on blanks available at the village hall. Such application shall describe in detail the
variety, size and precise location of each tree and shrub that the applicant desires to plant, and the nature of all other work in connection with the
trees or shrubs that he intends to do. (1965 Code § 5-4-51)
3. Permit Issuance Procedure: If the proposed planting or work desired to be done is in accord with the provisions of this chapter, then the application
shall be considered and a permit may be issued thereon, as follows:
a. If the planting or work desired to be done is to be done in a parkway (i.e., in property adjoining a roadway and forming a part of a platted street), a
permit therefor may be issued by the forestry review board if the proposed planting or work complies with the village forestry plan. (1965 Code § 5-
4-52)
b. If the planting or work is to be done in a public park or other public place, except a parkway, the village forestry review board shall submit the
application for permit to the board of trustees, and if the village board finds that the proposed planting or work complies with the village forestry
plan and is in the public interest, the village board shall approve the application, and the permit shall be issued in accordance therewith. (1965
Code § 5-4-52; amd. 2009 Code)
4. Regulations Governing Permit: A permit for planting, trimming or care of trees or shrubs in public property may be granted if the request complies
with the requirements of this section and the village forestry plan. (1965 Code § 5-4-53)
B. Regulations Governing Planting: No tree shall be planted except in accordance with the following regulations:
1. No tree shall be planted where the soil is too poor to ensure the growth of such tree, unless the planter excavates a suitable hole of not less than
thirty six (36) cubic feet and replaces the material removed with loam or other suitable soil.
2. No street tree shall be planted in any parkway adjoining a roadway where the clear space between the curb and the sidewalk is less than six feet
(6').
3. No street trees shall be planted within six feet (6') from the driveway or within ten feet (10') from a street lamp or other public utility structure.
4. No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty five feet (35') from any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb
lines.
5. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet (10') from any fireplug.
6. No street trees, other than those species listed as small trees in subsection D of this section, may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of
any overhead utility wire or over or within five (5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility structure.
7. The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in
subsection D of this section, and no trees may be planted closer to any curb or sidewalk than the following:
Small and medium trees 3 feet
Large trees 4 feet
(1965 Code § 5-4-20)
C. Spacing: The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in subsection D of this section, and no trees may
be planted closer together than the following:
Small trees 30 feet
Medium trees 40 feet
Large trees 50 feet
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 109/307
except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. (1965 Code § 5-4-21)
D. Species Of Street Trees Permitted:
1. The following species of trees can be planted on parkways:
Small Trees (20 To 35 Feet Tall):
Callery pear
Globe Norway maple
Mountain ash
Tatarian maple
Washington hawthorn
Medium Trees (35 To 60 Feet Tall):
Amur cork tree
Amur maple
Birch
Crimean linden
Green ash
Hedge maple
Littleleaf linden
Norway maple
Red maple
Large Trees (Over 60 Feet Tall):
American elm
Gingko
London planetree
River birch
Scarlet oak
Shingle oak
Sugar maple
Swamp white oak
Thornless honey locust
2. No other species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without written permission of the forestry review board. (1965
Code § 5-4-22)
E. Species Of Street Trees Prohibited:
Ailanthus (tree of heaven)
Any fruit tree
Black locust
Black walnut
Box elder
Catalpa
Chinese elm
Evergreens
Honey locust
Mulberry
Poplar (Lombardy, cottonwood, or silver)
Soft maple (silver)
Willow
(1965 Code § 5-4-23)
5-7-6: TREE TOPPING:
It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or village department to top any street tree, park tree or other tree on public property.
"Topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches (3") in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires, or other
obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from the provisions of this chapter at the determination of the village forestry
review board. (1965 Code § 5-4-3; amd. 2009 Code)
5-7-7: STUMP REMOVAL:
All stumps of street and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the
ground. (1965 Code § 5-4-4)
5-7-8: DEAD OR DISEASED TREES; UNCHECKED GROWTH2:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 110/307
A. Dead Or Diseased Trees: It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation, or any owner, agent, occupant or person in
possession, charge or control of any lot, tract, parcel of land, building or other premises within the village or within its territorial jurisdiction to permit the
growth upon any premises within the village of any elm tree infected with a fungus disease of elms caused by Ophiostoma ulmi, commonly known as
Dutch elm disease, or any ash tree infected with Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire, commonly known as the emerald ash borer. It shall be unlawful for the
owner of any property in the village to keep or maintain any such infected tree or deadwood on his or her property.
B. Unchecked Growth: It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance for any person, firm, or corporation, or any owner, agent, occupant or person in
possession, charge or control of any lot, tract, parcel of land, building or other premises within the village or within its territorial jurisdiction to permit the
unchecked growth upon any premises within the village of any trees without trimming the same in such a manner as to prevent any part of such trees
from crossing property lines or overhanging or obstructing views along the sidewalk, parkway, street or highway, as the same shall be determined by
the public works department.
C. Owner/Occupant Responsibilities:
1. Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village upon whose property there is located an elm tree infected with Dutch elm disease or an ash
tree infected with the emerald ash borer shall remove the same immediately upon discovering it or be notified of it, by cutting the same down. The
tree so cut down, together with all of its limbs, shall be cut into lengths not to exceed five feet (5') and placed upon the parkway to be removed by the
village. Upon so cutting the trees and placing them upon the parkway, the owner of said property shall notify the public works department in order
that the same may be removed by the village or its designee.
2. Every owner or occupant of real estate within the village shall trim or remove any and all trees and the limbs thereof on his or her property and on
the abutting parkway at all such times as may be necessary to prevent the same from crossing property lines or overhanging or obstructing views
along the sidewalk, parkway, street or highway, as the same shall be determined by the public works department.
D. Notice To Remediate And Abate Nuisance: It shall be the duty of the code enforcement director to cause notice to be served upon the owner or
occupant of any premises on which landscaping conditions are in violation of the provisions of this section and to demand the abatement of the
nuisance within thirty (30) days. The "notice to remediate and abate nuisance" may be served either in person or by registered mail. Such notice shall
provide information regarding the existence of infected or overgrown trees on the owner's property, and shall notify the owner that he or she must abate
the nuisance(s) within thirty (30) days. Such notice shall also contain a copy of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12 and the ordinance codified
herein and notify the owner that the village may remove or trim the tree(s) and place a lien on the property for the cost of the removal if the nuisance is
not abated within thirty (30) days.
E. Abatement By Village: If the person served with a "notice to remediate and abate nuisance" under this section shall fail, refuse or neglect to abate the
nuisance within thirty (30) days, the director of public works shall proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of all related expenses. Such
expenses shall be charged to and paid by the owner or occupant.
F. Payment Of Charges; Lien Provisions:
1. Rendition Of Bill: If trees are cut, trimmed or removed by the village or by someone directed to perform the same on behalf of the village, the village
shall send a bill for the cost and expense thereof to the property owner, his agent or legal representative or occupant in legal possession or control of
the premises.
2. Failure To Pay; Notice Of Lien:
a. If said bill is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of the date of said bill, the village shall cause a notice of lien of the cost and expense thereof
incurred by the village to be recorded in the following manner: The village or the person performing the service by authority of the village, in its, his
or her own name, may file a notice of lien in the office of the county recorder of deeds, or the office of the county registrar of titles, if the real estate
affected is registered under the Torrens system. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth:
(1) A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof;
(2) The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and
(3) The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village or someone working on behalf of the village.
b. Such notice of lien shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the cost and expense is incurred. After recording, the notice of lien, together with
copies of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12 and the ordinance codified herein, shall be sent by registered mail or hand delivered to the
property owner, his agent or legal representative or occupant in legal possession or control of the premises and, if different, to the person who
received the tax bill for the preceding year.
3. Release Of Lien: Upon payment of the cost and expense after the notice of lien has been filed as provided herein, the lien shall be released by the
village or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release shall be recorded of record in the same manner as recording the notice of
lien.
4. Foreclosure Of Lien: Subsequent to the filing of the above described lien, the village may cause to be filed a complaint for foreclosure of such lien, or
upon becoming a defendant in a pending lawsuit affecting the premises or real estate, by answer to the complaint, or in the nature of an intervening
petition or cross complaint, the village may proceed in its corporate name to foreclose such lien. The property subject to a lien arising under this
section shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the monies owing the village. (Ord. 02-19-
08-03, 2-19-2008)
5-7-9: DUTIES OF OWNERS OF TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY3:
A. Obstructing View: No person shall plant, grow or maintain any tree, shrub, bush or flower that obstructs the view of motorists, cyclists or pedestrians in
such a way as to constitute a danger to the public in the use of the streets, alleys and sidewalks of the village. (1965 Code § 5-4-35)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 111/307
B. Obstructing Streetlights: The owner and the tenant of every lot or parcel of land upon which any trees are now or may hereafter be growing shall trim, or
cause to be trimmed, the branches thereof so that the same shall not obstruct the passage of light from any streetlight in any street, alley or highway to
the adjacent street or sidewalk. (1965 Code § 5-4-36)
C. Trees Overhanging Streets And Sidewalks: Every owner shall trim all branches of any trees now or hereafter growing on his premises which overhang
any sidewalk, street, alley or public highway so that there shall be a clear height of eight feet (8') above the surface of the street or sidewalk. (1965
Code § 5-4-37)
D. Dead Trees On Private Property: Every owner of a parcel of land shall remove all dead, decayed or broken limbs or branches that overhang any
sidewalk, street, alley or public highway. When any of such trees are dead, such owner shall remove the same so that they shall not fall in the street,
alley or public highway. (1965 Code § 5-4-38)
E. Authority To Remove Or Prune: The village shall have the right to prune or remove any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the
proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign, at the expense of the property
owner, if the owner fails to do so, upon fifteen (15) days' written notice by the forestry review board. (1965 Code § 5-4-39)
F. Adequate Guards; Preventing Injury: Anyone doing construction, repair or maintenance work on any property adjoining parks, parkways or other public
property shall place adequate guards around nearby trees and shrubs in such parks, parkways or other public property so as to prevent injury to such
trees. Machinery and implements shall be used in such manner as not to destroy any trees or shrubs on public property. (1965 Code § 5-4-40)
5-7-10: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be, upon conviction thereof, or a plea of guilty, punished as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code.
(1965 Code § 5-4-6)
Footnote 1: See section 1-7-6 of this code for records and tape recording requirements.
Footnote 2: See also section 5-7-9 of this chapter.
Footnote 3: See also section 5-7-8 of this chapter.
Title 6
FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION1
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
Footnote 1: See title 7, chapter 3 of this code for alarm system regulations.
Chapter 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
6-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
A department to be hereafter known as the Lyons fire department, the object of which shall be the prevention and extinguishment of fire and the protection
of life and property within the corporate limits of the village, is hereby created. (1965 Code § 8-1-1)
6-1-2: FIRE CHIEF:
A. Appointment, Qualifications, Term: The fire department shall be headed by a chief, who shall be appointed by the village manager, and his tenure in
office shall depend upon his good conduct and efficiency. The chief shall be technically qualified by training and experience and shall have the ability to
command people and hold their respect and confidence. (Ord. 04-21-09-04, 4-21-2009)
B. Powers And Duties:
1. Generally: The fire chief shall have control, subject to the order and direction of the president and board of trustees, of the fire department and of all
fire apparatus belonging to the village. Whenever any fire apparatus needs repairing, the fire chief shall cause same to be done without delay. The
chief shall be held accountable to the president and board of trustees only and shall make written and verbal reports thereto as the president and
board of trustees may require. All other department companies and officers shall be accountable to the chief.
2. Determine Department Composition: The fire chief shall determine the number and kind of divisions, platoons and companies of which the fire
department is to be composed and shall determine the response of such platoons and companies.
3. Monthly Training: The fire chief shall monitor training and operations concerning the handling of equipment, first aid, rescue work, salvage, a study of
buildings in the village, fire prevention, water supplies and all other matters considered essential to good firemanship and safety of life and property
from fire.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 112/307
4. Records: The fire chief shall see that complete records are kept on all fires, inspections, apparatus and minor equipment, personnel and other
information about the work of the department.
5. Reports:
a. The fire chief shall submit a monthly report to the president and board of trustees containing a statistical analysis of the activities of the firefighting
division, training division, fire prevention bureau, mechanical division and personnel division of the department.
b. The fire chief shall make a complete annual report to the president and board of trustees within one month after the close of the fiscal year. Such
report shall include the information specified in subsection B5a of this section, together with comparative data for previous years and
recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department. (1965 Code § 8-1-2; amd. 2009 Code)
6-1-3: COMPOSITION OF DEPARTMENT:
A. Officers And Members:
1. Designated: One deputy chief, one assistant chief, three (3) captains, five (5) lieutenants and such additional members of the fire department as may
from time to time be prescribed by the president and board of trustees shall constitute the remainder of the fire department, and they shall function as
provided by the rules and regulations of the fire department.
2. Paid On Call Firefighters:
a. Appointment, Qualifications: The department shall be made up of paid on call firefighters, the number of which shall be determined by the
president and board of trustees upon the chief's recommendation. The members shall be appointed by the chief. They shall be able bodied
citizens. Determination of whether applicants for appointment are able bodied shall be made by the chief after a medical and physical examination
has been made in a manner prescribed by the chief.
b. Suspension, Hearing: Any member of the department may be suspended or discharged from the department by the chief and/or a disciplinary
review committee at any time that such action is deemed necessary for the good of the department. On written request of such member to the
president and board of trustees, he shall be given a hearing, public or private, at his discretion, on the charges brought by the chief.
B. Inspectors: The fire chief may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The fire chief shall
recommend to the village the employment of technical inspectors who, when such authorization is made, shall work with the fire chief and the building
department. (1965 Code § 8-1-3)
6-1-4: BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION:
A. Bureau Established: The bureau of fire prevention in the fire department is hereby established and shall be operated under the supervision of the chief
of the fire department.
B. Annual Report: A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the village president. It shall contain all proceedings
under the fire prevention code, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein. (1965 Code § 8-1-4)
6-1-5: FIRE PROTECTION TRAINING:
A. Participation In State Programs: The village hereby elects to participate in the programs provided for in the Illinois fire protection training act1.
B. Fire Certification Required: As a firefighter, an individual must be certified by the Illinois state fire marshal as firefighter II and as having successfully
completed an approved training course as provided in said act. The firefighter II training must be completed by the trainee within his/her probationary
period.
C. EMT Certification Required: All personnel having ambulance related duties must be certified as an EMT "A" (emergency medical technician ambulance)
by the Illinois department of public health. Such training and certification must be completed by the trainee within his/her probationary period. (1965
Code § 8-1-5)
6-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES OF MEMBERS:
A. Fire Prevention Duties: It shall be the function and duty of the fire department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive fires and
to prevent the occurrence or spread of such fires.
B. Police Powers: All regularly appointed members of the department are hereby given the necessary special police powers for the purpose of enforcing
the provisions of this title. (1965 Code § 8-1-6)
6-1-7: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the officers and members of the fire department shall be prescribed from time to time by the village president and board of trustees.
(1965 Code § 8-1-7)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 113/307
6-1-8: FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND:
There shall be a firefighters' pension fund established in the village as provided by statute. (1965 Code § 8-1-8)
6-1-9: BADGE ISSUED:
Each member of the fire department shall be issued a badge designating his rank. (1965 Code § 8-1-9)
6-1-10: FIRE APPARATUS AND EQUIPMENT:
A. Apparatus And Equipment Required: The fire department shall be equipped with such apparatus and other equipment as may be required from time to
time to maintain its efficiency and properly protect life and property from fire.
B. Purchases: Recommendations for the apparatus and equipment needed pursuant to this section shall be made by the fire chief. Said recommendation
shall be approved by, and after approval, shall be purchased in such manner as may be designated by, the president and board of trustees.
C. Storage Locations: All equipment of the fire department shall be safely and conveniently housed in such place as may be designated by the president
and board of trustees.
D. Prohibited Acts:
1. Improper Use: No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment for any private purpose.
2. Injury To Equipment: No person shall wilfully or negligently break, deface or in any manner injure any fire engine hose, equipment or other fire
apparatus belonging to the fire department. (1965 Code § 8-1-10)
Footnote 1: 50 ILCS 740/1 et seq.
Chapter 2
MUTUAL FIRE AID PROGRAM
6-2-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for a program of mutual aid between the village and other municipalities, whereby such municipality will be
obligated to come to the assistance of a neighboring municipality in the event of an emergency, fire or other disaster therein of such magnitude that the
local fire equipment and personnel cannot effectively cope with it. (1965 Code § 8-4-1)
6-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
AIDING MUNICIPALITY: A municipality furnishing fire equipment and personnel to a stricken municipality or to another aiding municipality.
MUNICIPALITY: A city or village.
MUTUAL AID AREA: The territory occupied within the village limits and other areas protected by the following departments and districts: Argonne,
Bolingbrook, Brookfield, Clarendon Heights, Clarendon Hills, Downers Grove, Downers Grove Estates, Forest View, Hinsdale, La Grange, La Grange
Park, Lemont, Lyons, McCook, Pleasantview fire district, Riverside, Tri-State protection district, Western Springs, Westmont, and Romeoville in Cook and
DuPage Counties.
MUTUAL FIRE AID PROGRAM: A plan or program as provided for in this chapter whereby the municipalities participating in the program agree to come to
one anther's assistance in case of emergency, fire or other disaster too large for local equipment and personnel to handle.
PARTICIPATING MUNICIPALITY: A municipality, in the mutual aid area, that participates in the mutual fire aid program by adopting an ordinance
authorizing or approving the program and entering into an appropriate agreement (substantially as provided herein) with other participating municipalities
for rendering and receiving aid in case of emergency, fire or other disaster.
STRICKEN MUNICIPALITY: A participating municipality in which an emergency, fire or other disaster occurs that is of such magnitude that it cannot be
adequately coped with by local fire equipment and personnel. (1965 Code § 8-4-2; amd. 2009 Code)
6-2-3: MUTUAL FIRE AID AGREEMENT:
The president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, hereby authorizes the chief of the fire department, on behalf of the village, to
enter into, and from time to time amend, an agreement with any or all of the municipalities in the mutual aid area defining and putting into effect a mutual
fire aid program, providing generally as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 114/307
A. Request For Aid: In the event that, in the judgment of the officer in charge of the fire department of a stricken municipality, the available fire equipment
and personnel of that municipality are inadequate to effectively cope with an emergency, fire or other disaster therein, said officer may call on a
neighboring participating municipality to furnish fire equipment and personnel (to the extent specified in the agreement) to the stricken municipality for
use either: 1) in assisting at an emergency; or 2) in combating a fire or other disaster; or 3) as a standby reserve to meet other calls that may occur
before the local fire equipment is free to take care of them.
B. Request For Standby Reserve: Each aiding municipality furnishing fire equipment and personnel to a stricken municipality shall have the right to call on
another participating municipality for fire equipment and personnel (to the extent specified in the agreement) as a standby reserve to take the place, in
part, of the equipment and personnel furnished to the stricken municipality until such equipment and personnel shall be returned.
C. Limitation On Furnishing Personnel And Equipment: On receipt of a call under subsection A or B of this section, the aiding municipality called upon shall
(to the extent provided in the agreement) furnish the equipment and personnel called for by the stricken municipality or by the aiding municipality;
except, that each municipality may always be permitted to retain sufficient fire equipment and personnel to fight any fire or to meet any emergency
within its own boundaries that may reasonably be anticipated. (1965 Code § 8-4-3)
6-2-4: MUTUAL FIRE AID PROGRAM ADOPTED:
A. A mutual fire aid program conforming to the provisions of section 6-2-3 of this chapter has been agreed upon by the respective fire chiefs of the
departments and districts of: Argonne, Bolingbrook, Brookfield, Clarendon Heights, Clarendon Hills, Downers Grove, Downers Grove Estates, Forest
View, Hinsdale, La Grange, La Grange Park, Lemont, Lyons, McCook, Pleasantview fire district, Riverside, Tri-State fire protection district, Western
Springs, Westmont, and Romeoville in either Cook or DuPage County, and has been submitted to the authorities of the village. This mutual fire aid
program is subject to change or abrogation by action of the president, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, and the fire chief of
the village, pursuant to section 6-2-3 of this chapter.
B. Unless and until so changed or abrogated, the mutual fire aid program is ratified as a binding agreement between the village and all other municipalities
who shall have adopted said program and shall have assumed the obligations thereby imposed upon them. (1965 Code § 8-4-4)
6-2-5: AUTHORITY TO SEND EQUIPMENT OUTSIDE VILLAGE LIMITS:
The fire chief and the officers of the fire department shall have the authority to send fire equipment and personnel outside the corporate limits of the
village, as provided in the mutual fire aid program agreed to herein, whenever requested to do so by the officers or authorities of any participating
municipality that has agreed to conform to said program and has assumed the obligations imposed upon it thereby; provided, that the fire equipment and
personnel can be spared from service at the time the request is made. (1965 Code § 8-4-5)

B. Deviation; Mutual Aid Call: Deviation from the hospitals and clinics listed in subsection A of this section is allowed only when operating on a mutual aid
call. (1965 Code § 8-1-11)
