6-3-3: AUTHORITY IN CHARGE:
When the service of an ambulance and/or rescue squad is called for, the highest ranking EMS member of the unit shall be in charge of the emergency and
will be responsible for all orders given and action taken. When the situation demands that the police, at the time of emergency, lend assistance, they shall
follow the orders of the member in charge of the unit. The authority of the fire department member extends only to the well being of the injured and not to
the administrative police matters in connection with the emergency calls not involving the incident. (1965 Code § 8-1-11)
6-3-4: VIOLATIONS; DISCIPLINARY ACTION:
A. Any member of the fire department violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject to disciplinary action by the fire chief. Any other village
employee violating any of the provisions of this chapter while in the course of their employment shall be subject to disciplinary action by the employee's
department head.
B. Any members of the fire department, public works department, or the police department violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to
disciplinary action by either the fire chief, the director of public works or the police chief, pursuant to any applicable labor agreement then in force.
(1965 Code § 8-1-11)
Chapter 4
FIRE PREVENTION CODE
6-4-1: CODES ADOPTED:
A. Adoption Of Codes: For the purposes of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, the village
hereby adopts the following model codes:
1. NFPA life safety code 101 (2000 edition).
2. BOCA fire prevention code (1999 edition).
3. NFPA fire prevention code (2000 edition).
4. NFPA 33, standard for spray application using flammable or combustible materials (2000 edition).
5. NFPA 88B, standard for repair garages (2000 edition).
B. Conflicts; Stricter Standards Prevail: Wherein any one of the above codes conflicts with the other or with another adopted code, the stricter standard
shall apply. (1965 Code § 8-2-1)
C. Copies On File: One copy of each of the codes adopted in subsection A of this section is on file in the village offices for public use and inspection. (2009
Code)
6-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases, when used in the fire codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter, shall have the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 116/307
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
GASES: Those gases as indicated in article 8, section 8.1 of the BOCA fire prevention code, 1999 edition, entitled "Scope"; provided, however, that said
section 8.1 shall be amended by adding thereto the following:
Whenever the word "gases" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean those gases as indicated in article 8, section 8.1 of the fire
prevention code, 1976 edition, entitled "Scope"; provided, however, that said section 8.1 shall be amended by adding thereto the following: This
article shall apply to bulk oxygen systems, the storage, handling and use of compressed gases, the gases liquified by means of low temperatures or
cryogenic temperatures.
MUNICIPALITY: The village of Lyons, Illinois.
VILLAGE ATTORNEY: The attorney for the village. (1965 Code § 8-2-2; amd. 2009 Code)
6-4-3: AMENDMENTS:
A. Automatic Sprinkler Systems: Automatic sprinklers shall be installed in all buildings as specified by the codes adopted by the village. Installation of such
systems shall further be required in all new commercial or industrial buildings having five thousand (5,000) square feet total building area or greater.
B. Fire Detection, Alarm And Communication Systems: All new buildings containing apartments (over 3 stories or more than 11 units), assembly, business,
correctional, daycare, educational, hotels/dormitories, healthcare and ambulatory healthcare, high rise, industrial, mercantile, residential board and
care and/or rooming houses shall have a fire detection, alarm and communication system installed. Existing buildings changing to one or more of the
above use groups shall be required to comply with this subsection. Buildings having one or more of the above uses shall further be required to install
such systems prior to sale of same. The design and installation of fire detection, alarm and communication systems shall be in compliance with the
adopted codes of the village. Apartment buildings having less than eleven (11) units or under three (3) stories in height shall have a hard wired smoke
detection system installed, but do not have to have an alarm or communication system. Such detection system shall be designed and installed
pursuant to the requirements of the adopted village codes. The fire chief shall have the authority to modify this requirement based upon the fire risk or
lack thereof associated with the building or use.
C. Spray Booths: All new and existing spray booths shall comply with NFPA standard 33, standard for spray application using flammable or combustible
materials (2000 edition). The authority having jurisdiction shall have authority to modify the requirements of this standard based upon the practical
difficulty of compliance and inherent risk factors associated with the building and use.
D. Automotive Repair Facilities: All new and existing automotive repair facilities shall comply with NFPA standard 88B, standard for repair garages. The
authority having jurisdiction shall have authority to modify the requirements of this standard based upon the practical difficulty of compliance and
inherent risk factors associated with the building and use. (1965 Code § 8-2-3)
6-4-4: ENFORCEMENT:
The fire chief shall be the authority having jurisdiction for this chapter. (1965 Code § 8-2-9)
6-4-5: FIRE LIMITS; STORAGE OF EXPLOSIVES OR FLAMMABLES:
A. Storage Of Explosives And Blasting Agents: The limits referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter in which the storage of
flammable liquids and/or gases in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: All business zoned, industrial zoned and
residentially zoned property in the village except as permitted by the fire chief.
B. Flammable Liquids And Gases:
1. The limits referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter in which the storage of flammable liquids and/or gases in outside
aboveground tanks is prohibited are hereby established as follows: All business zoned, industrial zoned and residentially zoned property in the
village except as permitted by the fire chief.
2. The limits referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter in which the bulk plants for flammable or combustible liquids and/or gases
are prohibited are hereby established as follows: All business zoned, industrial zoned and residentially zoned property in the village except as
permitted by the fire chief.
C. Storage Of Liquefied Petroleum Gas: The limits referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter in which bulk storage of liquefied
petroleum gas is restricted are hereby established as follows: All business zoned and residentially zoned property in the village. (1965 Code § 8-2-5;
amd. 2009 Code)
6-4-6: VEHICLE ROUTES FOR TRANSPORTING DANGEROUS MATERIALS:
A. Explosives And Blasting Agents: The routes referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter for vehicles transporting explosives and
blasting agents are hereby established as follows: First Avenue (Route 171) only.
B. Hazardous Chemicals: The routes referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and
other dangerous articles are hereby established as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 117/307
1. Interstate Transport: The route for interstate shipments is First Avenue (Route 171) only. No stopping or parking of vehicles of interstate shipment
shall be allowed within the limits of the village except for the purpose of inspection by the fire prevention bureau to ensure compliance with the codes
adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter.
2. Intrastate Transport: The route for intrastate shipments shall be determined by the fire chief at the time of issuance of a permit, as the route will differ
depending on the destination of vehicles within the village. (1965 Code § 8-2-6; amd. 2009 Code)
6-4-7: FIRE LANES:
The fire lanes referred to in the codes adopted in section 6-4-1 of this chapter are hereby established as follows: Fire lanes shall be those lanes
designated and required by the fire chief. (1965 Code § 8-2-7; amd. 2009 Code)
6-4-8: ACCESS KEY BOXES:
The fire chief shall have authority to require an approved key box containing keys necessary to gain access to buildings and building areas, for all
occupancies having a fire alarm system. The fire chief may further require such boxes for all other occupancies as he deems necessary for life saving or
firefighting purposes. (1965 Code § 8-2-8)
6-4-9: NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS:
Violations of this chapter shall be noticed through the following process:
A. Violators shall first be issued a notice of violation which depicts the violation, the required compliance and a compliance deadline. A reasonable time
period shall be given for compliance, taking into account the immediacy of the hazard or risk and time required for corrections. Written warnings are not
required for repeat violations occurring within the same twelve (12) month period.
B. Upon expiration of the compliance time, or upon discovery of a repeat violation within the same twelve (12) month period, the enforcing agent may issue
a citation, seek a criminal warrant or seek remedies as provided for by law. (1965 Code § 8-2-10)
6-4-10: APPEAL:
Notices of violation may be appealed to the Lyons fire review committee, provided the required application and filing fee are submitted to the building
department prior to the expiration of the compliance time. The criteria for successful appeal shall be one of the following: a) the violation does not exist; b)
the code was misapplied; or c) the code was misinterpreted. The fire review committee shall consist of the fire chief, village manager, village president,
trustee liaison and building director. (1965 Code § 8-2-12)
6-4-11: PENALTIES:
A violation of this chapter may be prosecuted by code hearing adjudication, civil litigation or criminal process. Each day in violation of this chapter shall
constitute a separate offense. Civil fines shall be no more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per day. Criminal violations shall be a misdemeanor,
punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and/or incarceration of not
more than sixty (60) days, per offense. The village shall not be limited by this section in seeking any and all remedies as provided for by state statutes.
(1965 Code § 8-2-11)
Chapter 5
GENERAL FIRE PREVENTION REGULATIONS
6-5-1: OPEN BURNING1:
No open burning of leaves, uprooted weeds, grass clippings, waste materials, garbage, refuse products, glass or metal containers, paper, wood,
cardboard, ashes and cinders and discarded furniture and clothing shall be permitted upon any private lot or public ground within the village limits. (1965
Code § 8-3-1)
6-5-2: STORAGE OF COMBUSTIBLES, REFUSE AND YARD WASTE ON PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful to permit or store any combustible refuse or materials in such way as to create a fire hazard, or to store or throw any refuse or materials
of any kind on any street, alley or other public place2. (1965 Code § 8-3-2)
6-5-3: BONFIRES:
It shall be unlawful to build or light a bonfire on any public street or sidewalk pavement or so close to any building or other structure as to endanger such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 118/307
building or structure. (1965 Code § 8-3-3)
6-5-4: FALSE FIRE ALARMS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly start or spread or maliciously turn in or cause to be turned in any false alarm in the village. (1965 Code § 8-
3-4)
6-5-5: OUTDOOR FIREPLACES AND RECREATION FIRES:
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
OUTDOOR FIREPLACE: A unit constructed or manufactured, with all the design components in place, that is listed by Underwriter's Laboratories, or
comparable testing agency, that is designed to burn a limited quantity of wood which is burned for recreational purposes and which is designed so as to
contain the ashes and/or embers while in use and when the user is finished.
RECREATIONAL FIRE: A fire ignited and burned in a location outside of a structure for the purposes of amusement and not for the destruction of
refuse, cooking or heating purposes.
B. Recreational Fires: Recreational fires are permitted on residential and other properties subject to the following conditions and restrictions:
1. All such fires shall be contained at all times within an "outdoor fireplace", as defined in subsection A of this section.
2. All such fires shall be in locations that are clear of buildings or structures, electrical lines, and other hazards.
3. No such fire shall be permitted on wooden structures, balconies, porches or other areas attached to any building.
4. All such fires shall be attended at all times by an adult of not less than eighteen (18) years of age, and at all times there shall be a ready source of
water available to immediately extinguish the fire.
5. No person shall cause or allow the smoke or odors from a recreational fire to go beyond the boundaries of his/her property, so as to cause a
nuisance to neighboring properties.
C. Outdoor Fireplaces: Outdoor fireplaces shall not be modified or otherwise altered to create larger fires. Such fireplaces shall at all times be operated
within the manufacturer's specifications and allow for adequate collection of ash. Outdoor fireplaces shall be limited to the burning of firewood only. The
burning of garbage, trash, refuse or similar items is prohibited.
D. Authority To Require Extinguishment: The fire chief or his/her designee shall have the authority to require the immediate extinguishment of a
recreational fire, if he/she deems it necessary, for whatever reason and at any and all times. (1965 Code § 8-3-5)
6-5-6: RENTAL OF EQUIPMENT FOR FIRE USE:
The owner of property on which a fire has occurred is responsible for the actual costs incurred by the village for the use or rental of any equipment or
services not owned by the village or any fire departments providing mutual aid used to fight a fire on the owner's land. (1965 Code § 8-6-1)
Footnote 1: See also section 5-5-11 of this code.
Footnote 2: See also section 5-5-8 of this code.
Chapter 6
EXPLOSIVE MATERIALS1
6-6-1: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required; Revocation; Amount Of Explosives:
1. No person shall have, keep, sell, use, store or give away any gunpowder, guncotton, blasting powder, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin,
fulminate of mercury or any other explosives or combustible materials or other substance or compound or article having properties of such character
that it alone or in combination or contiguity with other substances or compounds may decompose suddenly and generate sufficient heat or gas or
pressure, or all of them, to produce rapid flaming combustion or administer a destructive blow to persons or property; or keep, sell, use, store, offer
for sale, transport or give away any loaded paper or detonators within the corporate limits of the village, excepting in the manner and upon the
conditions herein provided and under a license issued by the duly authorized officer.
2. The village president shall have the power to revoke any such license so issued in case there is any infraction of any of the provisions of this
chapter. (1965 Code § 4-27-2; amd. 2009 Code)
3. The maximum amount of any and all such explosives or combustible materials to be so kept by any such person at any one time shall not exceed
twenty five (25) pounds and shall be stored in metal receptacles constructed and placed to the satisfaction of the chief of the fire department. (1965
Code § 4-27-2)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 119/307
B. Application For License: Any person desiring a license to keep, sell, use, store, offer for sale or give away any gunpowder, guncotton, blasting powder,
giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury, their products or any other explosive or combustible material or other substances referred
to in this chapter, or loaded paper or metallic shot fills or percussion caps or detonators shall make application in writing to the village clerk for a license
so to do. (1965 Code § 4-27-3; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Issuance Of License; Payment Of Fee: When a satisfactory investigation shall have been made by the president of the board of such application, the
president shall transmit the same to the board of trustees for approval, who thereupon shall refer the approved application to the village clerk who shall,
upon payment to him of a license fee as set forth in section 4-1-3 of this code, and upon order so to do, issue to such applicant a license therefor,
authorizing such applicant to keep, sell, use, store or give away at the place designated in his application the articles covered by said application. (1965
Code § 4-27-4; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Blasting Prohibited; Exception: No blasting operations shall be permitted except upon license granted by order of the president and board of trustees.
(1965 Code § 4-27-5)
6-6-2: BOND REQUIRED:
Previous to the issuance of any license as herein prescribed, applicants shall furnish and file with the clerk a bond in the sum of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) with sureties approved by the president and board of trustees, conditioned for the payment of any loss, damage or injury resulting to persons
or property by reason of the use, sale, keeping, storage or giving away of such explosives or combustible materials. (1965 Code § 4-27-6; amd. 2009
Code)
6-6-3: MIXING OR MANUFACTURE OF EXPLOSIVE MATERIALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, assemble or mix, anywhere within the corporate limits of the village, any gunpowder, guncotton, blasting
powder, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, nitrochlorate, fulminate of mercury, their products or other similar combustible or explosive materials. (1965
Code § 4-27-1)
6-6-4: TRANSPORTATION:
A. Certificate Of Fitness: No explosives or combustible materials shall be transported in any vehicle of any sort through the streets unless such vehicle is
in the charge of a competent person holding a certificate of fitness for such person to be issued by the chief of the fire department. Said certificate of
fitness shall be issued only to employees of persons duly licensed to transport, use, sell, keep, store or give away such explosives. (1965 Code § 4-27-
7)
B. Vehicle Requirements And Restrictions:
1. Metal Tools Restricted: No metal tools or other pieces of metal shall be carried within the vehicle except in a separate tool box, and no percussion
caps or detonators or other combustible materials shall be transported in the same vehicle with explosives or other combustible materials.
2. Operation Of Vehicle: The vehicle carrying explosives or combustible materials shall be able to draw the load, and it shall avoid stoppage other than
to load and unload, and no unnecessary stops or stands shall be made.
3. Leaving Vehicle Unattended: No explosives or combustible materials shall be left in a vehicle unless such a vehicle is in the charge of an employee
with the certificate of fitness issued to him as hereinabove provided, and no employee, driver or chauffeur of any such vehicle loaded with explosives
or other combustible materials shall leave it unattended.
4. Identification Markings: Any vehicle carrying explosives shall have painted on the sides and back thereof, in easily legible letters at least six inches
(6") high, the words "Dangerous - Explosives" and shall also have the owner's name displayed thereon to be read easily at a distance of one
hundred feet (100') on each side, and in the event that a licensee has more than one vehicle, each such vehicle shall be plainly lettered and
numbered.
5. Avoid Heavy Traffic Areas: A vehicle carrying explosives and combustible materials shall avoid, whenever possible, those streets on which there are
large numbers of persons or those highways and thoroughfares heavily traveled by motor or other vehicles.
6. Intoxicated Persons; Smoking: No intoxicated person shall be permitted on a vehicle carrying explosive or combustible materials, and no smoking
shall be permitted within ten feet (10') of a vehicle with explosives or other combustible materials. (1965 Code § 4-27-8)
C. Compliance Required: No person shall carry or transport, on any street or elevated car or public conveyance in any railroad car running from point to
point within the corporate limits of the village, any gunpowder, guncotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury, their products or
explosives, or combustible materials of a similar nature, in violation of any provision of this chapter. (1965 Code § 4-27-9)
6-6-5: LABELING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to buy, sell, use, keep, store, give away or deliver to any person within the corporate limits of the village any gunpowder,
guncotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury or combustible materials of similar nature under any false or deceptive marking,
description or other declaration unless the package or receptacle containing such gunpowder, guncotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate
of mercury or combustible materials of similar nature shall be plainly marked so as to inform the person receiving, transporting, storing, or using such
explosives or combustible materials of the true character thereof at or before the time such delivery is made. (1965 Code § 4-27-10)
6-6-6: MINORS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 120/307
It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to sell, use deliver or give away to any minor under eighteen (18) years of age any gunpowder, giant
powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury or combustible materials of similar nature or other dangerous explosives or combustible materials.
(1965 Code § 4-27-11)
6-6-7: STORAGE AREA:
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, store, use or maintain any gunpowder, guncotton, giant powder, dynamite, nitroglycerin, fulminate of mercury or
other explosives of similar nature or combustible materials within two hundred feet (200') of any public highway, street or alley, church, school or public
building or private dwelling, or of any other building, house or dwelling where persons live, congregate, meet or work. (1965 Code § 4-27-12)
Footnote 1: See also title 5, chapter 3 of this code.
Title 7
POLICE REGULATIONS
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
Footnote 1: See title 7, chapter 3 of this code for alarm system regulations.
Chapter 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
7-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
A. Establishment: There is hereby continued, created and established an executive department of the Village to be known as the Police Department. Said
department shall consist of the offices and positions hereinafter enumerated and such others as may be provided from time to time. (1965 Code § 9-4-
1)
B. Composition: The Police Department shall consist of one Chief of Police, who shall be appointed by the Village Manager, one Deputy Chief, three (3)
Commanders and such Sergeants, Patrol Officers and any other employees as may be authorized by the Village Board from time to time.
C. Reduction Of Commanders: The Illinois Council of Police and the Village are parties to a collective bargaining agreement scheduled to expire on
December 31, 2016. Pursuant to that agreement the Village shall not appoint a replacement for any Commander who resigns or retires after the
adoption of this subsection or the date that the collective bargaining agreement is approved by the Village, whichever occurs earlier. On January 1,
2017, any person on active duty holding the rank of Commander shall revert to the rank of Sergeant. (Ord. 06-04-14-O4, 6-4-2014)
7-1-2: SUPERVISION OF DEPARTMENT:
The Police Department shall at all times be subject to the orders and directions of the Village Manager and all rules and regulations of the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners. (1965 Code § 9-4-3)
7-1-3: POLICE CHIEF POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Management Of Department: The Chief of Police shall have the management and control of all matters relating to the Police Department, its officers
and members, subject to orders and directions of the Village Manager, and all rules and regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. He
shall have the custody and control of the offices, stations, equipment, books, records and other property belonging to said department. (1965 Code § 9-
4-4)
B. Keeping Records: The Chief of Police, or someone designated by him for that purpose, shall keep a suitable record of all arrests and enter thereon the
number of arrests, date, name of prisoner, charge, name of officer making arrest, name of the court trying the charge, amount of fine imposed and the
costs, if any, and such other and further information as may be necessary or essential for the maintenance of said records for future reference, and
shall furnish a monthly report thereof to the President and Board of Trustees. (1965 Code § 9-4-5)
7-1-4: DEPUTY CHIEF:
The position of Deputy Chief is created. One Deputy Chief shall be appointed by the Chief of Police and is not subject to the appointment authority of the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (Ord. 06-04-14-O4, 6-4-2014)
7-1-5: DEPARTMENT MEMBERS; POWERS, DUTIES AND REQUIREMENTS1:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 121/307
A. Duties And Powers:
1. Duties Generally: The members of the police force, when on duty, shall devote their time and attention to the discharge of the duties of their stations,
according to the laws of the state and provisions of this code, and the rules and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners and the
department, to preserve order, peace and quiet, and enforce the laws. (1965 Code § 9-4-8)
2. Power To Arrest: The members of the police force shall have power to arrest all persons found in the act of violating any law or provision of this code
or aiding and abetting in any such violation, and shall arrest any person found under circumstances which would warrant a reasonable person to
believe that such person had committed or is about to commit a crime. (1965 Code § 9-4-9)
B. Serving Warrants: The members of the police force shall have power and authority, and it shall be their duty, to serve and execute warrants and other
processes for the summoning, apprehension, and commitment of any person charged with a violation of any provisions of this code, or with any crime
or misdemeanor, or offense against the laws of the village or state. (1965 Code § 9-4-10)
C. Aiding Fire Department: It shall be the duty of the members of the police force to aid the fire department by giving alarms in case of fire and by clearing
the streets or grounds in the immediate vicinity of a fire so that the members of the fire department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the
performance of their duties. (1965 Code § 9-4-11)
D. Report Excavations: It shall be the duty of every police officer, on observing or being informed of any opening or excavation in any public way, to require
the person making such opening or excavation to exhibit the authority or permission therefor. If none has been given by the proper officer, or if such
exhibition thereof be refused, such police officer shall, without delay, report the same to the director of public works, and shall immediately arrest the
person so unlawfully making such excavation. (1965 Code § 9-4-12)
E. Assignment Of Duty: No member of the police force shall be assigned to any duty other than that strictly in the line of police work, except as herein
otherwise provided. (1965 Code § 9-4-16)
F. Attire Of Personnel: No member of the police force, except members thereof assigned to detective or confidential duty, shall wear citizen's dress while
on duty. (1965 Code § 9-4-17)
G. Badge Required: The chief of police shall have power and authority to prescribe an appropriate form of badge to be worn by members of the
department by which, and at all times, the authority and relation of such officers and members of said department may be known. He shall make
suitable regulations as to the wearing of such badge. Every member of the department of police shall wear a suitable badge. Any member who shall
lose or destroy the badge furnished by the village shall be required to pay the cost of replacing such badge. Whenever any member shall leave the
department, he shall immediately deliver his badge to the chief of police. (1965 Code § 9-4-18; amd. 2009 Code)
H. Resignations: No person shall resign any position on the police force except on two (2) weeks' notice in writing given to the chief of police and the board
of fire and police commissioners of the village. (1965 Code § 9-4-19)
7-1-6: COMPENSATION:
The compensation to be paid the members of the police force shall be fixed by the village president and board of trustees by the annual budget. (1965
Code § 9-4-21; amd. 2009 Code)
7-1-7: OATH OF OFFICE:
A. Form Of Oath: All members of the police department shall, before entering upon their duties as police officers, take and subscribe to an oath of office
substantially in the following form:
I do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the United States and of the State of Illinois and that I will faithfully enforce the provisions of
the Village Code of Lyons and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of Police Officer of the Village to the best of my ability.
B. Swearing Of Oath: Said oath shall be subscribed and sworn to before some officer authorized by the laws of the state to administer oaths and a
certificate thereof filed in the offices of the clerk and board of fire and police commissioners. (1965 Code § 9-4-22)
7-1-8: POLICE PENSION FUND:
A. Fund Established: There shall be a police pension fund established in the village, as provided by law. (1965 Code § 9-5-1)
B. Board Of Trustees Of Fund:
1. The board of trustees of the said fund shall consist of five (5) members, two (2) appointed by the village president, and two (2) elected from the
active participants of the pension fund by such active participants, and one elected by and from the beneficiaries of the pension fund. The elections
shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April, and the term of each member shall be two (2) years. (1965 Code § 9-5-2; amd. 2009 Code)
2. The pension board shall meet at least quarterly, as provided by law, and shall hold such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the
pension board. (1965 Code § 9-5-2)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 122/307
C. Disposition Of Funds: All monies derived from taxes levied under the provisions of 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-125, as amended, shall be set apart
by the treasurer to constitute the police pension fund. The following shall also constitute the monies included in said fund:
1. Contributions by police officers under 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-125.1.
2. All monies that may have been accumulated in conformity with any previous legislation establishing a fund for the benefit of disabled or retired police
officers.
3. Donations, gifts or other transfers authorized by state law. (1965 Code § 9-5-3; amd. 2009 Code)
7-1-9: LOST, STOLEN OR SEIZED PROPERTY:
A. Custodian Of Lost And Stolen Property: The chief of police shall appoint from among the members of the police force a custodian of lost and stolen
property. (1965 Code § 9-4-6)
B. Delivery Of Seized Property To Custodian: All officers and members of the department into whose possession may come any property seized or taken
shall deliver the same at once to the custodian unless it is wanted for immediate use as evidence in any case, and in that event, a report and inventory
of the same shall be forwarded at once to the custodian. (1965 Code § 9-4-7)
7-1-10: NEGLECT OF DUTY:
Any member of the police force who shall refuse or neglect to perform any duty required of him, when such refusal or neglect to perform any such duty
shall tend to hinder, obstruct, or impair in any way the proper and strict enforcement of any law or provision of this code, or the rules and regulations of the
board of fire and police commissioners, or the efficiency of the police force, is hereby declared to be no longer qualified to be a member of the police force,
and shall be tried for such violation in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners. (1965 Code § 9-4-13)
7-1-11: RESISTING, INTERFERING WITH OFFICER:
Any person who shall resist any officer of the police department in the discharge of his duties or shall in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent him
from discharging his duty as such officer, or shall offer or endeavor to do so, and whoever shall in any manner assist any person in the custody of any
member of the police force to escape or attempt to escape from such custody, or attempt to rescue any person in custody, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (1965 Code § 9-4-15)
7-1-12: IMPERSONATING AN OFFICER:
No person shall falsely assume or pretend to be a police officer or a member of the department of police, or without being a member of the department of
police, wear in public the uniform adopted as the police uniform, or a reasonable facsimile thereof. No person shall counterfeit or imitate, or cause to be
counterfeited or imitated, any badge, sign, shoulder patch, signal or device adopted by the department of police, nor shall any person use or wear any
badge, sign, shoulder patch, signal or device adopted or used by said department, or any similar in appearance, without authority so to do from the chief of
police. (1965 Code § 9-4-20)
7-1-13: AUXILIARY POLICE:
The village president may, with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees, appoint auxiliary police in such number as may be from time to time
deemed necessary. Auxiliary police shall not be members of the regular police department of the village. Auxiliary police shall not supplement members of
the regular police department in the performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as provided below:
A. Duties: Auxiliary police may be assigned to perform only the follow in duties in the village:
1. To aid or direct traffic within the village.
2. To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
3. To aid in cases of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police.
B. Identification Symbols: Identification symbols worn by auxiliary police shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the Village Police
Department.
C. Police Chief Supervision: At all times during the performance of their duties, auxiliary police shall be subject to the direction and control of the Chief of
Police. (1965 Code § 9-4-27)
D. Firearms: Auxiliary police shall not carry firearms except with permission of the Chief of Police, and while in uniform and in the performance of their
duties, and after completion of training as set by State regulations.
E. Appointment Per State Law: Members of the auxiliary police shall be appointed from the residents of the Village as per State law. (1965 Code § 9-4-27;
amd. 2009 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 123/307
F. Training And Study Courses: Prior to entering upon any of their duties, auxiliary police shall:
1. Receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures as shall be appropriate to the exercise of the powers conferred
herein.
2. Auxiliary police training and courses of study shall be determined and provided by the Village.
G. Fingerprinting, Background Check: Prior to appointment, the fingerprints of any applicant for the status of the auxiliary police shall be taken, and no
person shall be appointed as auxiliary police if such person has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. (1965 Code § 9-4-
27)
H. State Law Applicable Upon Death In Line Of Duty: The Line of Duty Compensation Act2 shall be applicable to auxiliary police upon their death in the
line of duty as described therein. (1965 Code § 9-4-27; amd. 2009 Code)
7-1-14: PART TIME POLICE:
A. Employment: The Village may employ part time police officers from time to time as the Corporate Authorities deem necessary.
B. Duties: A part time police officer shall have all responsibilities of a full time police officer and such specific duties as delineated in the general orders of
Police Department, but the number of hours a part time officer may work within a calendar year shall be restricted. Part time police officers shall not be
assigned to supervise or direct full time police officers. Part time police officers shall be trained in accordance with the Illinois Law Enforcement Training
and Standard Board.
C. Hiring Standards: Any person employed as a part time police officer must meet the following standards:
1. Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties.
2. Be at least twenty three (23) years of age.
3. Pass a medical examination.
4. Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate.
5. Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license.
6. Possess no prior felony convictions.
7. Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged.
D. Discipline: Part time officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the Chief of Police. Part time police officers serve at the discretion of the
Village Manager, shall not have any property rights in said employment, and may be removed by the Village Manager at any time. Part time police
officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders issued by the Police Department. (Ord. 06-05-13-O2, 6-5-2013)
7-1-15: MINIMUM AGE FOR FULL TIME POLICE OFFICERS:
The Fire and Police Commission shall not appoint any person to the position of full time police officer unless that person is at least twenty three (23) years
old at the time of appointment. This requirement shall supersede any minimum age requirement established by the Fire and Police Commission. (Ord. 02-
20-18-O1, 2-20-2018)
Chapter 2
MUTUAL POLICE AID PROGRAM
7-2-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for a program of mutual aid between the village and other municipalities whereby each such municipality will be
obligated to come to the assistance of a neighboring municipality in the event of an emergency of such scope that it cannot be effectively coped with by
the local police department's personnel and equipment. (1965 Code § 9-14-5)
7-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words or terms shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
AIDING MUNICIPALITY: A municipality furnishing personnel or equipment to a requesting municipality.
MUNICIPALITY: A city or village that is a participating member of the mutual aid program.
MUTUAL AID MEMBERS: The following municipalities are parties to the mutual aid agreement: Brookfield, Countryside, La Grange, La Grange Park,
Lyons, Riverside, and Western Springs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 124/307
MUTUAL POLICE: The plan or program as provided for in this chapter whereby the municipalities participating in the program agree to come to one
another's assistance in the event of an emergency of such scope that it cannot be effectively coped with by the village police department's personnel and
equipment.
PARTICIPATING: A municipality that has, by official action of the municipal board, adopted an ordinance authorizing or approving the mutual police aid
program and has entered into an appropriate agreement (substantially as provided herein) with the other participating municipalities for rendering and
receiving aid as provided in the mutual police aid program.
REQUESTING: A participating municipality in which an emergency of such scope that it cannot be effectively coped with by the local police department's
personnel and equipment has occurred or is occurring. (1965 Code § 9-14-6)
7-2-3: AGREEMENT TO EFFECTUATE PROGRAM:
The chief of the police department, with the approval of the village president, is authorized, on behalf of the village, to enter into, and from time to time to
alter and amend, an agreement with any or all of the municipalities that are parties to the mutual police aid agreement defining and putting into effect a
mutual aid program providing generally as follows:
A. Request For Aid: In the event that, in the judgment of the officer in charge of the police department of a participating municipality, the available police
personnel and equipment of that municipality are inadequate to effectively cope with the emergency therein, said officer may call in a neighboring
participating municipality to furnish personnel and equipment to the extent specified in the agreement, to the requesting municipality.
B. Request For Standby Reserve: Each aiding municipality furnishing personnel and equipment to a requesting municipality shall have the right to call on
another participating municipality for personnel and equipment, to the extent specified in the agreement, as a standby reserve to take the place, in part,
of the personnel and/or equipment furnished to the requesting municipality until such personnel and/or equipment shall return.
C. Limitation On Furnishing Personnel And Equipment: On receipt of a call under subsection A or B of this section, the aiding municipality called upon
shall, to the extent provided in the agreement, furnish the personnel and equipment called for by the requesting municipality, or by the first aiding
municipality; except, that each aiding municipality may always be permitted to retain sufficient personnel and equipment to meet any emergency within
its boundaries that may be reasonably anticipated. (1965 Code § 9-14-7)
7-2-4: OBLIGATION OF VILLAGE UNDER PROGRAM:
The village shall furnish personnel and/or equipment, for use outside its boundaries, as provided in the mutual police aid program agreed to as provided in
section 7-2-3 of this chapter, to any municipality that has agreed to conform to said program and has assumed the obligations imposed upon it thereby.
(1965 Code § 9-14-8)
Chapter 3
ALARM SYSTEMS
7-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this chapter the following terms are used, they shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
ALARM BUSINESS: Any business operated for profit, which engages in the activity of altering, installing, leasing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, selling,
servicing, or responding to a burglary or holdup alarm system or fire alarm, or which causes any of these activities to take place.
ALARM EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS: Any person, firm or corporation that sells, leases or installs signaling devices which, upon activation, either
automatically or manually, will transmit an alarm.
ALARM SYSTEMS: Any signaling device which is electronically operated and which automatically sends visual and audible signals over a signal line to be
registered by indicators at a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the police department and fire department and/or alarm company's receiving location,
or which sends, via telephone line to the police or fire department, a recorded message of a burglary, holdup or fire.
ALARM USER: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the village.
AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICE: An alarm system which automatically sends over telephone lines a prerecorded voice message indicating the existence
of the emergency situation that the system is designed to detect.
DIRECT CONNECT: An alarm system which has the capability of transmitting system signals to and receiving them at an agency maintained by the police
communications center.
DIRECT LINE: A telephone line leading directly from a central station to the communications center of the police department or fire department that is for
use only to report emergency signals on a person to person basis.
EMERGENCY ALARM ADMINISTRATOR: An employee of the village, designated by the village manager, whose responsibility it is to coordinate the
administration and documentation of alarm businesses and system performance as it relates to the effective enforcement of the provisions of this chapter.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 125/307
of an alarm system or of his employee or agents. "False alarm" does not include alarm signals activated by violent conditions of nature, telephone line
interruptions, acts of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm business installer or alarm user.
LOCAL ALARM SYSTEM: One which produces an audible signal at the premises protected.
PROPRIETARY SYSTEM: An alarm system sounding and/or recording alarm and supervisory signals at a control center located within protected
premises, the control center being under the supervision of the proprietor of the protected premises. If a "proprietary system" includes a signal line
connected directly or by means of an automatic dialing device to a police communications center, a central station, modified central station or an
answering service, it thereby becomes an "alarm system" as defined in this section.
RECEIVING AGENCY (CENTRAL STATION): An office to which remote alarm and supervisory signaling devices are connected, where trained and
experienced personnel are in attendance at all times to supervise the circuits and investigate signals.
SINGLE STATION SMOKE DETECTOR: An assembly incorporating the smoke detector control equipment and the alarm sounding device in one circuit
operated from a power supply either in the unit or at the point of installation.
VILLAGE ALARM CONTRACTOR: The alarm company contracted by the village for the installation and maintenance of the police or fire department
monitoring systems. (1965 Code § 9-15-1; amd. 2009 Code)
7-3-2: STATE BUSINESS LICENSE, NOTICE TO VILLAGE:
Every individual, firm or corporation that does engage in an alarm system business in the village shall notify the village manager in writing indicating that
such individual, firm or corporation is doing business in the village. Such written notice shall include the name of the business, its address, telephone
numbers where service personnel can be reached, and their license numbers given by the state of Illinois. (1965 Code § 9-15-2)
7-3-3: ALARM USER PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required; Application; Conditions For Issuance:
1. Every alarm user shall obtain an alarm user permit from the village manager or his/her designee for each system used. Applicants already employing
an alarm system on the effective date hereof shall submit an application for a permit no later than sixty (60) days from the effective date hereof;
otherwise, use of an alarm system is prohibited until a permit is secured.
2. The application for an alarm system user permit shall include the following: name, address, and telephone numbers of the alarm user, and the type
of business organization (individual, partnership or corporation). If a partnership, the names and addresses of the partners; and if a corporation, the
names and addresses of the principal officers, and the state where incorporated. The issuance of a permit shall in no way constitute a warranty of
the signaling device involved, and issuance of said permit shall be specifically subject to the village disclaimer of liability as detailed in this chapter
and further detailed in section 2-206 of the local governmental and governmental employees tort immunity act1. (1965 Code § 9-15-9; amd. 2009
Code)
3. The alarm user applicant shall provide a "hold harmless" statement with the application. The hold harmless statement will contain the following
wording:
In consideration of the issuance of a permit for the installation of the requested alarm system or local alarm system, the owner-applicant herein on
behalf of himself and his co-workers, if any, his heirs, administrators, executors and assigns, hereby releases the village, a municipal corporation, its
officers, employees and alarm monitoring contractor, from any and all liability, suits, judgments, claims of any kind or nature, including attorney fees
and court costs arising or which may arise from the use, utilization or maintenance of said alarm system upon the premises at (address), whether
such claim is brought by the applicant or any third party or entity, and the applicant further agrees to defend any legal action, whether it is based on
an allegation, jointly or severally, against the village, a municipal corporation, its officers, employees, and alarm monitoring contractor, for any action
or nonaction on their parts.
B. Permit Fees: The alarm user shall pay to the village a fifteen dollar ($15.00) fee at the time of application for each permit. If the alarm user desires to
renew the permit for an additional period of one calendar year, the alarm user shall pay to the village a renewal fee which shall be paid prior to the first
day of the calendar renewal year. Any permit holder who does not pay the permit fee on or before said last day of the current calendar year shall pay
an additional charge of fifty percent (50%) of the permit fee to defray the extra cost of notice, record keeping and collection.
C. Review Of Application For Renewal: Application for the renewal of alarm user permits will be reviewed by the village manager for acceptance or
rejection of the renewal application.
D. Permits Subject To Revocation: Alarm permits are subject to revocation for reasons outlined in this chapter.
E. Confidentiality Of Information: The information contained in an alarm user permit application required by this section and other information received by
the police and/or fire chief through correspondence or communications with an alarm user shall be securely maintained and restricted to inspection
only by the police and/or fire chief or certain officers or village employees specifically assigned the responsibility for having and processing alarm user
permits in the course of official duties. The police chief or fire chief and any such employee of the village shall not reveal the information contained in
the alarm user permit application or in correspondence or communications with an alarm user to any other person for any purpose not related to this
chapter or official law enforcement matters and without the express written consent of the alarm user supplying such information.
F. Noncompliance: Any alarm system user who operates an alarm system without first obtaining a permit as required by this section, or who, after having a
permit revoked or suspended, fails to disconnect his alarm system, shall be in violation of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 126/307
G. Remedy Defects: For any newly installed alarm system, it is intended that the alarm user will be allowed a period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days
within which to cure or fix any defects in the alarm system. (1965 Code § 9-15-9)
7-3-4: AUTOMATIC DIALING SERVICE; PRERECORDED VOICE MESSAGES PROHIBITED:
Any automatic dialing device transmitting a prerecorded voice message into the police and/or fire department or to a telephone line directly serviced by
telephone company operators to be responded to by members of the police or fire department is prohibited. (1965 Code § 9-15-3)
7-3-5: DIRECT COMMUNICATIONS TO POLICE OR FIRE DEPARTMENT:
A. Termination Of Service Authorized: Upon the favorable recommendation of the police chief and fire chief and the approval of the village manager,
alarms for business premises and residences may be terminated in the police and/or fire department.
B. Central Monitoring System: The village shall provide a uniform central monitoring system to receive alarm signals and perform other related functions
over a signal line or lines at a central location. The system shall have a capacity to meet present needs and the ability to expand for future needs, and
shall be available to those who meet the requirements for permits under this chapter.
C. Right To Charge Line Fees: The village alarm contractor shall have the right to charge line fees, set by contract, during the length of the contract.
D. Rights Of Subscriber: Any subscriber or alarm user who obtains authority from the village manager to terminate its alarm in the police and/or fire
department may contract with any licensed alarm business of its choice for the sale, installation, maintenance, and/or servicing of the alarm system to
be installed on its premises.
E. Responsibility For Obtaining Leased Telephone Line: The alarm subscriber approved for a direct connection to the police department or the alarm
businesses contracting for servicing the subscriber's alarm system shall be responsible for obtaining the leased telephone line between the
subscriber's premises and the alarm receiving equipment, if required, in order to provide an input signal which is compatible with the receiving
equipment used to operate the alarm panel.
F. Transmitting Signal To Central Monitoring System: No alarm subscriber shall utilize a single pair of wires to transmit a burglar or holdup alarm signal and
a fire or other emergency signal. All police related signals shall cause only one signal to be transmitted to the central monitoring system upon a single
stimulus of the alarm device, and no pulsating or intermittent signal shall be allowed. All fire related signals transmitted to the central monitoring system
shall be upon a single stimulus of the alarm device, and no pulsating or intermittent signal shall be allowed. (1965 Code § 9-15-4)
7-3-6: INSTALLATION AND INSPECTION:
A. Compliance With Specifications: All such work pertaining to the installation, modification, service or repair of an "alarm system" in the village, as defined
in section 7-3-1 of this chapter, whether audible or silent, and the servicing thereof, shall be accomplished in accordance with the pertinent
specifications of the village building and electrical codes, requirements of federal regulations concerning security devices in national banking
institutions, regulations and standards provided in this chapter and all other existing laws and ordinances.
B. Right Of Entry For Inspection: For the purposes of enforcing the provisions of all applicable municipal codes and this chapter, the police chief and/or fire
chief and the village inspector shall have the authority, at a mutually agreeable time, to enter any premises in the village or other jurisdictional area in or
upon which alarm systems subject to this chapter are located, to inspect the installation and/or operation of such alarm systems. The right of the police
and/or fire chief to enter for the purposes herein described is in addition to any and all other rights of the police chief and fire chief to enter upon and in
premises within the village pursuant to any other village codes or any state law.
C. Report Of Violations; Remedial Action: If such inspection reveals any violations of the provisions of this chapter, a written report detailing such violations
shall be promptly sent to the village manager and to the owner, lessee or other person responsible for the alarm system violation of this chapter. Such
report shall require correction within thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of the violation discovered, and shall state that a failure to comply may
result in the revocation of licenses and permits. The alarm user may be granted a reasonable extension of time to correct such violations, but in no
event shall said extension exceed a period of thirty (30) days. (1965 Code § 9-15-5)
7-3-7: TESTING EQUIPMENT:
No alarm system designed to transmit emergency messages directly to the police and/or fire department shall be tested or demonstrated without first
obtaining permission from the police chief or fire chief. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm devices not transmitting messages directly
to the police and/or fire department. (1965 Code § 9-15-6)
7-3-8: NOTICE OF DISRUPTION OF SERVICE:
When an alarm business's service to its subscribers is disrupted for any reason by the alarm business, or the alarm business becomes aware of such
disruption, it shall promptly notify its subscriber by telephone that protection is no longer being provided. If, however, the alarm business has written
instructions from its subscriber not to make such notification by telephone during certain hours, the alarm business may comply with such instructions.
(1965 Code § 9-15-7)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 127/307
7-3-9: LIABILITY OF VILLAGE LIMITED:
The village shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals received by the central monitoring center are given appropriate attention
and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the village shall not be liable for any defects in operation of any alarm system, for any failure or neglect of
any person in connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission of signals or the relay of such signals and messages. In the
event that the village finds it necessary to disconnect a defective device, the village shall incur no liability by such action taken pursuant to this chapter.
(1965 Code § 9-15-8)
7-3-10: REPAIR SERVICE:
Each alarm user in the village shall obtain a service contract from a licensed alarm business or have such licensed alarm business available to him on a
twenty four (24) hour basis to make inspections and/or repairs which become necessary for the proper function of the alarm and to minimize false alarms.
(1965 Code § 9-15-10)
7-3-11: ALTERNATE POWER SOURCE:
Each alarm user in the village should provide an alternate source of power for his alarm system to prevent false alarms due to failure of power supplied
from the utility company. Such alternate source of power shall provide a minimum period of power in accordance with applicable fire codes of the village.
(1965 Code § 9-15-11)
7-3-12: OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS:
A. Instructions Required: Every alarm business selling or leasing to any person an alarm system which is installed on such person's premises in the village
after the effective date hereof shall furnish that person with instructions that provide adequate information to enable persons using such device to
operate it properly and, if the device is to be serviced or maintained by another alarm business, shall furnish such other business with a manual or
other information necessary to enable it to service or properly maintain such device.
B. Incomplete Or Unclear Instructions: If the police chief or fire chief reasonably finds such information to be incomplete or unclear, or inadequate to
explain how the device operates and is constructed, he may require the alarm business to revise the information to meet his approval, and then to
distribute the revised information to persons who have had such devices installed as well as to persons subsequently having such devices installed.
(1965 Code § 9-15-12)
7-3-13: SPECIAL ALARM PROVISIONS:
A. Connection To Central Monitoring System: Automatic dialing devices shall, within sixty (60) days from the effective date hereof, be disconnected from
any primary trunk line of the village and shall be keyed to the central alarm monitoring system maintained at the police department. The content of the
recorded message to be transmitted by such device shall be a digital tone approved by the alarm company maintaining the central alarm monitoring
system.
B. Conversion To Digital Tone: All alarm users having an automatic dialing device which does not transmit a digital tone approved by the alarm company
maintaining the central alarm monitoring system shall be given sixty (60) days to obtain a central answering point other than the village. The alarm user
may, at his expense, convert such automatic dialing device to a compatible digital tone.
C. Sound Of Alarms: Local alarms shall not resemble the sound of any emergency signal or civil defense alarm or siren. All local alarms shall have the
capacity to reset themselves within ten (10) minutes. Local alarms presently in use as of the effective date hereof shall have three (3) months to comply
with the requirements of this subsection.
D. Sensory Mechanism: The sensory mechanism used in connection with any alarm system must be adjusted to suppress false indications of fire or
intrusion so that the devices will not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure changes in water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such
as the rattling or vibrating of doors or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation, or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms.
E. Maintenance Of Components: All components comprising an alarm system must be maintained by the permit holder in good repair to assure reliability
of operation. (1965 Code § 9-15-13)
7-3-14: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AND FEDERAL LAWS:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed or applied to necessarily require or excuse noncompliance with any provision of the laws of the state of Illinois or
the laws of the United States. (1965 Code § 9-15-15)
7-3-15: FALSE ALARMS, PENALTIES AND REVOCATION PROCEDURES:
A. Responsibility For Operation And Maintenance: Each person, firm or corporation servicing the operation or maintenance of an alarm of any type
covered by this chapter shall be responsible for any false alarms transmitted by the device which they service.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 128/307
B. Record Of Alarms Transmitted: The emergency alarm administrator shall maintain a record of all alarms transmitted and, pursuant to the required notice
and opportunity to be heard, may revoke the permit for operation of an alarm involved in the transmission of six (6) false alarms in a calendar month
not caused by unusual weather conditions or interruption of any telephone line service which is not the fault of the permit user.
C. Temporary Disconnection For Alarm System Failure: The emergency alarm administrator may order any alarm temporarily disconnected upon twenty
four (24) hours' prior notice in the event of a failure by that alarm system that jeopardizes the operation of other alarm systems in the Lyons central
monitoring system. Pursuant to such action, a letter shall be sent no later than the first regular business day after such disconnect to the user informing
the user of this action. No alarm system shall be reconnected until repairs have been made.
D. Procedure Upon Recording False Alarm: If the emergency alarm administrator records a false alarm from the user's protected premises, the following
procedure shall be utilized:
1. Upon receipt of a fourth false alarm within a calendar or fiscal one-half (1/2) year (6 months), as established by the village board on adoption of this
chapter, the emergency alarm administrator shall issue a false alarm notice to the permit holder for each violation of this chapter which shall require a
penalty per occurrence according to the following schedule:
Penalty Schedule
False Alarm
Per 6 Month Period
Penalty
1st, 2nd, and 3rd No charge
4th, 5th and 6th Police response $ 25 .00
Fire department response 150 .00
7th, 8th and 9th Police response 50 .00
Fire department response 150 .00
10th or more Police response 100 .00
Fire department response 200 .00
Exception: No charge shall be imposed for false alarms for thirty (30) days from the date of installation and/or the date of major alterations, nor shall a
charge be made for false alarms activated by weather related conditions, telephone or electrical interruptions or other such unusual occurrences outside
the ability of the alarm user to prevent.
2. On receipt of the tenth false alarm within the six (6) month period, the emergency alarm administrator shall notify the permit holder and servicing
alarm business by certified mail that any additional false alarms shall be cause to begin the process to revoke the alarm permit.
3. On receipt of the eleventh false alarm within the six (6) month period, the emergency alarm administrator shall notify the permit holder and servicing
alarm business by certified mail that the alarm permit shall be revoked ten (10) days from the mailing date unless the alarm user and/or servicing
alarm business:
a. Submits a report indicating corrective action that has been taken to correct the problems that have resulted in false alarms; or
b. Requests a hearing with the emergency alarm administrator to indicate corrective action that has been taken or is planned, or reasons that the
problems cannot currently be corrected but will be corrected in the near future. Such hearing must take place within twenty (20) days of the mailing
of notice of intent to revoke the permit.
4. If the permit holder submits a written report, the alarm administrator shall determine if the corrective action may reasonably be expected to prevent
further false alarms. If he determines that the actions should prevent additional false alarms, he shall notify the permit holder in writing that the permit
will not be revoked.
5. If a hearing is requested, it shall be held within ten (10) working days of the request. The emergency alarm administrator shall provide the permit
holder with an opportunity to present such information as necessary to explain the false alarms and that actions have been or will be taken to prevent
further occurrences. If the emergency alarm administrator determines that corrective action is being taken to prevent false alarms, the permit holder
shall be advised that the permit will not be revoked.
6. If no report is submitted and no hearing requested, or if the information provided by the permit holder does not indicate that proper corrective action
is being taken to prevent false alarms, the emergency alarm administrator shall notify the permit holder that the alarm permit is revoked and that the
use of the alarm is not allowed.
7. If the permit holder is dissatisfied with the action taken by the emergency alarm administrator, the permit holder may request a hearing before the
village manager or his designee. Such request must be delivered in writing to the village manager within five (5) working days of the receipt of the
notice of revocation, and such hearing must be held within ten (10) days' notice of revocation. A finding shall be rendered within ten (10) days of the
hearing. No alarm will be disconnected by the village during the hearing process, which shall include: a) mandatory time allowed for the appeal of the
decision of the emergency alarm administrator; and b) the maximum time allowed to render an administrative decision.
8. Any building required to have a fire alarm system by the codes of the village or the rules and regulations of the Illinois state fire marshal shall be
exempt from the disconnection provisions of this chapter. However, all other penalties shall remain in effect.
9. No permit shall be issued until all penalties assessed by this chapter have been paid in full to the village offices. (1965 Code § 9-15-14)
7-3-16: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
The failure of any person to:
A. Obtain an alarm service system permit as required by this chapter;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 129/307
B. Obtain an alarm user permit as required by this chapter;
C. Obey any order of the emergency alarm administrator of suspension or revocation of an alarm service permit or an alarm user permit; and/or
D. Correct any other violation of the provisions of this chapter; (1965 Code § 9-15-15)
constitutes an offense punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day
that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1965 Code § 9-15-15; amd. 2009 Code)
