B. Authority To Kill: If any dangerous, fierce or vicious dog cannot safely be taken up and impounded, such dog may be killed by any police officer of the
village; provided, however, that in all cases where any dog so killed has bitten any person or caused an abrasion of the skin of any such person, it shall
be the duty of the police officer killing such dog to forthwith deliver the carcass and the brain of such dog to the health department of the village for
examination. (1965 Code § 9-7-37)
8-3-9: IMPOUNDMENT; NOTICE; REDEMPTION:
A. Place Of Impoundment Designated; Impoundment Authorized: The village manager shall designate a place or places for the purpose of impounding
dogs, cats and other animals. It shall be the duty of all police officers to seize and impound any and all animals running at large in the village, and the
owner or keeper of such animal shall pay the impoundment fee agreed upon between the village manager and the designated pound. (1965 Code § 9-
7-38)
B. Notice To Owners:
1. Upon the impounding of any animal, the village shall notify the owner or keeper of the animal, personally or by mail, of such impounding, unless the
owner or the keeper is unknown and cannot be found. The notice shall advise the owner or keeper that unless he applies for redemption of the
animal, the animal will be destroyed or disposed of by the village at the end of three (3) days, unless a dog is impounded because it is considered or
alleged to be dangerous, fierce or vicious, or that it has bitten or injured or attempted to injure any person, or because it is suspected of having
rabies. In any of these instances, the period shall be fifteen (15) days instead of five (5) days after the notice has been given.
2. If the owner of the impounded animal cannot be identified, the animal will be destroyed or disposed of as the village manager shall determine and
direct. (1965 Code § 9-7-39)
C. Redemption Of Animals:
1. Except as herein provided, any animal impounded may be redeemed by the owner or keeper thereof at any time before the destruction, sale or other
disposition of such animal, upon payment of the redemption fee charged by the pound per day, or fraction thereof, to defray the cost of keeping the
animal, any pick up fee charged, and if the dog is not already licensed, payment of a full annual license fee for the current license year.
2. If a dog impounded is held on complaint that it is dangerous, fierce or vicious, or that it has disturbed in any manner the quiet of any person or
neighborhood, or that it has bitten or injured or attempted to injure any person, such dog shall not be redeemed until such complaint has been
disposed of, and then only if permitted under the order of the court which passes on such complaint.
3. No redemption shall be made of any dog suspected of having rabies unless and until it has been determined that the dog is not so afflicted. (1965
Code § 9-7-40)
8-3-10: NUMBER OF DOGS AND CATS LIMITED:
A. Single-Family Residences: In single-family residential districts, as defined in the zoning regulations of the village, no person shall suffer or permit more
than three (3) dogs or cats to be on or remain in and about any one single-family residence.
B. Multi-Family Units: In multi-family residential units, the total amount of dogs and cats shall be no more than one dog or cat per unit. The property owner
shall determine how to divide the total allocation per building to each tenant, but in no case shall an individual tenant have more than three (3) dogs
and cats. (1965 Code § 9-7-44; amd. 2009 Code)
8-3-11: CONTROL AND REMOVAL OF DOG AND CAT EXCREMENT:
A. Removal Of Excrement Required:
1. No owner, keeper or person in control of a dog or cat shall cause or permit such dog or cat to be on any public property, public park or public street,
or on private property not owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control, unless such owner, keeper or person in control of such
dog has in his immediate possession a device for the removal of dog and cat excrement and a depository for the transmission of the same to a
receptacle located upon property owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control. (1965 Code § 9-7-46; amd. 2009 Code)
2. No owner, keeper or person in control of any dog or cat shall fail or refuse to immediately remove excrement left by such dog or cat on any public
property, public park or public street, or on private property not owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control of such dog or cat
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 147/307
and to transmit and deposit the same in a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by such owner, keeper or person in control of
said dog or cat.
B. Time Limit: It shall be unlawful to permit any dog or cat excrement to remain on property owned or possessed by a dog or cat owner or keeper for
longer than twenty four (24) hours unless deposited in a watertight receptacle with a close fitting cover. (1965 Code § 9-7-46)
8-3-12: DEFECATION BY DOGS OR CATS UPON PROPERTY OF OTHERS:
It shall be unlawful to permit any dog or cat to defecate upon the property of any but the owner thereof or upon any private property without the permission
of the owner of said private property. (1965 Code § 9-7-47; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 4
PIGEONS
8-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they will have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
CARRIER PIGEON: Homing and racing pigeons which have the name of the owner stamped upon the wing or tail, or are banded upon the leg with the
name or initials of the owner or with an identification or registration number stamped on the band.
DEPARTMENT: The health department of the village and shall include the head of such department or any employee acting in his stead.
LOFT: Any structure in which carrier pigeons are housed.
RACING PIGEON: A pigeon registered with a national pigeon racing organization and used as a game competitive bird. The pigeons are not to be
identified or classified as fowl when raised and used in the sport and hobby of racing carrier pigeons. (1965 Code § 9-7-85)
8-4-2: PIGEONS PROHIBITED; EXEMPTIONS:
Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall raise, maintain, keep or act in such a manner as to attract pigeons or other similar fowl. The
conduct prohibited by this section includes setting out food. The prohibition contained in this section shall not apply to carrier pigeons. (1965 Code §§ 9-7-
86, 9-7-87; amd. 2009 Code)
A. Registration: The owner, keeper, or person having custody of any carrier pigeon shall register such pigeon with the village clerk. The clerk shall keep a
complete registry in a book to be kept for that purpose, of the name and address of all owners, keepers, or persons having custody of any carrier
pigeons, the type of pigeon, the owner's identifying mark, as stamped on the pigeon or on the leg band, and the number of pigeons kept on the
premises. (1965 Code § 9-7-88)
B. Certification: The owner, keeper, or person having custody of any carrier pigeon shall provide the clerk with a copy of the registration of the pigeons with
a national pigeon racing organization or a certificate signed by a licensed veterinarian or other authority certifying that the pigeons are homing or racing
pigeons. (1965 Code § 9-7-89)
C. Identifying Mark: All carrier pigeons shall have the name of the owner stamped upon the wing or tail or be banded upon the leg with the name or initials
of the owner or with an identification or registration number stamped on the band. (1965 Code § 9-7-90)
8-4-3: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF LOFT:
A. Compliance With Zoning And Building Regulations: All lofts shall comply with the setback and height requirements for accessory structures in the
zoning district in which it is located. The loft shall comply with the building code and shall be maintained at all times in a clean, orderly condition and
kept in good repair. (1965 Code § 9-7-92)
B. Annual Inspection; Fee:
1. The village health officer shall annually conduct an inspection of every loft in the village to ensure that the lofts are kept in a sanitary condition and
are in good repair. (1965 Code § 9-7-93)
2. The owner, keeper, or person having custody of any carrier pigeon shall annually pay to the village a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee. (1965
Code § 9-7-94)
8-4-4: KILLING OR WOUNDING CARRIER PIGEONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, not the owner thereof, to shoot, kill, maim, or injure any Antwerp or homing pigeon, commonly called carrier pigeon,
knowing the same to be such, or entrap, catch, detain or remove any mark, band or other means of identification from such pigeon; provided, that such
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 148/307
pigeon, at the time, shall have the name of the owner stamped or marked thereon or have thereon a band with the owner's name initialed or numbered.
(1965 Code § 9-7-95)
8-4-5: NUISANCES DECLARED:
It is hereby declared a nuisance for the owner of carrier pigeons to feed, house or train carrier pigeons in such a manner as to attract other birds to the
training house or feeding areas. It is also declared a nuisance for the owner of carrier pigeons to feed, house, or train their pigeons in such a way that
pigeons defecate upon another's property. Further, it shall be a positive duty of a carrier pigeon owner to remove or otherwise clean up the defecation of
their pigeons or other birds attracted to the training, housing or feeding areas of their carrier pigeons. This obligation shall extend to the licensee's property
and all public and private property where the owner consents to the entry of the licensee upon his property. (1965 Code § 9-7-96)
Chapter 5
KENNELS AND CATTERIES
8-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following terms are used in this chapter, they shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the content makes such meanings
repugnant thereto:
CATTERY: Any establishment or premises wherein or whereon cats are kept for any purpose.
KENNEL1: Any lot or premises on which three (3) or more domesticated animals more than four (4) months of age are housed, groomed, bred, boarded,
trained or sold, or which offers provisions for minor medical treatment. (1965 Code § 9-7-55; amd. 2009 Code)
8-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
No person shall manage, conduct or carry on the business of operating a kennel or cattery without first having obtained a license therefor. In case the
business of buying or selling or dealing in birds, dogs, and other small animals used as household pets and for domestic purposes is conducted, operated,
managed or carried on in connection with the business of a "kennel" or a "cattery", as defined in section 8-5-1 of this chapter, in the same premises, and
by the same person, then only one license need be obtained, and that license shall be that which requires the payment of the highest license fee under the
provisions of section 4-1-3 of this code. (1965 Code § 9-7-56; amd. 2009 Code)
8-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
A. Application: Any person desiring to conduct, carry on or operate a "kennel" or a "cattery", as defined in section 8-5-1 of this chapter, shall make a written
application for a license so to do, which shall conform to the general requirements relating to applications for licenses. Such application shall also state
the number of animals which is proposed to be kept in the establishment or premises for which application for license is made. (1965 Code § 9-7-57)
B. Investigation By Health Officer; Issuance Of License: Upon receipt of such application, the health officer shall cause such investigation to be made as,
in his judgment, is necessary for the issuance of the license hereinbefore referenced. Upon completion of such investigation, the health officer shall
forward such application, together with his recommendations, to the village president, whereupon, in his discretion, he shall cause a license to be
issued to such applicant upon the payment of the license fee. (1965 Code § 9-7-58)
8-5-4: METAL TAGS:
With such kennel or cattery license, there shall be issued a number of appropriate metal tags equal to the number of dogs or cats authorized to be kept in
the kennel or cattery. Such tags shall be made in a form so that they may be readily distinguishable from the individual dog registry license tags required
for the same year. The licensee of a kennel or cattery shall at all times keep one of such tags attached to the collar of each dog or cat over six (6) months
old kept by him under such license. Such tags may be transferred from one dog or cat to another in the kennel or cattery whenever any dog or cat is
removed. (1965 Code § 9-7-59)
8-5-5: REMOVAL OF DOG OR CAT:
No dog or cat bearing any tag shall be permitted to stray or to be taken anywhere outside the limits of the kennel or cattery, unless such animal is on a
leash or is taken out temporarily for the purposes of hunting, breeding, trial show or exhibition. (1965 Code § 9-7-60)
8-5-6: SANITATION PROVISIONS:
All kennels and catteries shall be kept free and clean from decaying food and from filth of any kind. The kennels, buildings and pens shall be whitewashed
or disinfected from time to time and shall be kept in a sanitary condition satisfactory to the health officer. (1965 Code § 9-7-61; amd. 2009 Code)
Footnote 1: See also section 13-2-2 of this code, definition of same term.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 149/307
Chapter 6
VETERINARY HOSPITALS
8-6-1: DEFINITION:
The term "veterinary hospital", as used in this chapter, shall mean any institution, place or enclosure used for the harboring or reception, for care or
treatment, of two (2) or more horses, dogs, cats or other animals. (1965 Code § 9-7-70)
8-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; INVESTIGATION:
A. License Required; Fee: No person shall manage, conduct or carry on the business of operating a veterinary hospital without first having obtained a
license therefor. The license fee required shall be as indicated in section 4-1-3 of this code. (1965 Code § 9-7-71)
B. Application: Any person desiring to conduct, carry on or operate a "veterinary hospital", as defined in section 8-6-1 of this chapter, shall make a written
application for a license so to do, which shall conform to the general requirements relating to applications for licenses. Such application shall also state
the number of animals which is proposed to be kept in the establishment or premises for which application for license is made. (1965 Code § 9-7-76)
C. Investigation By Health Officer; Issuance Of License: Upon receipt of such application, the health officer shall cause such investigation to be made as,
in his judgment, is necessary for the issuance of the license hereinbefore referenced. Upon completion of such investigation, the health officer shall
cause a license to be issued to such applicant upon the payment of the fee required. (1965 Code § 9-7-77)
8-6-3: SANITATION PROVISIONS:
All veterinary hospitals shall be kept free and clean from decaying food and from filth of any kind. The kennels, buildings and pens shall be disinfected
from time to time and shall be kept in a sanitary condition satisfactory to the health officer. (1965 Code § 9-7-72)
8-6-4: CONFINEMENT OF ANIMALS FOR OBSERVATION FOR RABIES:
Provisions shall be made in each veterinary hospital for securely impounding any animal confined for observation for rabies. Special precautions shall be
taken to securely and separately confine any such animal during such period of observation, and a report shall be made to the health officer of any such
animal so confined. (1965 Code § 9-7-73)
8-6-5: REPORT OF DISEASES:
It shall be the duty of any person in charge or control of a veterinary hospital to make a report to the health officer of any contagious or infectious disease
which may exist in such hospital. (1965 Code § 9-7-75)
Chapter 7
HENS
8-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
CHICKEN: An individual animal of the species Gallus gallus domesticus.
COOP: A structure that is designed to house hens which is enclosed on all sides with a roof, door and windows.
DWELLING UNIT: As defined in title 13 of this code.
DWELLING UNIT, SINGLE-FAMILY: As defined in title 13 of this code.
DWELLING UNIT, TWO-FAMILY: As defined in title 13 of this code.
HEN: The female of the species Gallus gallus domesticus or chicken.
ROOSTER: The male of the species Gallus gallus domesticus or chicken.
RUN: An outdoor area that is enclosed on all vertical sides by fencing. The run must be attached to or must surround a coop with a doorway or hatch that
allows access into the space by hens.
YARD, FRONT: As defined in title 13 of this code.
YARD, REAR: As defined in title 13 of this code.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 150/307
YARD, SIDE: As defined in title 13 of this code.
ZONING LOT: As defined in title 13 of this code. (Ord. 04-21-15-O3, 4-21-2015)
8-7-2: HEN REGULATIONS:
A. No person shall possess a hen unless a license has been issued as set forth in this chapter.
B. The number of hens allowed shall be a maximum of three (3) hens per property.
C. Roosters are prohibited within the village.
D. Licenses will only be granted to persons who reside on zoning lots with single-family and two-family dwelling units.
E. Care for hens shall follow the following provisions:
1. No hen shall be permitted to run at large. Hens shall be kept in a designated coop or run. Hens may be allowed to exercise in a rear yard with a six
foot (6') or higher fence with supervision.
a. If the coop and run are not within a fenced yard, hens must be kept within the coop and run at all times.
b. Fences must meet the standards outlined in title 12 of this code.
2. Feed must be stored in a fully enclosed, rodentproof container.
3. Hens must be kept in coops.
F. Housing for hens shall follow the following provisions:
1. Rear Yard Locations: The coop and run shall be located in the rear of the residential structure. The coop and run are allowed in the rear yard, but not
the side or front yards.
2. Location From Property Line: The coop and run shall be located at least five feet (5') from the property line and at least twenty feet (20') from any
neighboring dwelling.
3. Design: The coop must be built to provide ventilation, shade, protection from precipitation, protection from cold weather and to be secure from
predators, wild birds and rodents.
a. Openings in windows and doors must be covered by wire mesh or screens to deter predators.
b. Access doors must be sized and placed for ease of cleaning.
c. The enclosed run must be attached to the coop or must surround the coop. The sides of the run must be made of fencing or wire mesh that
discourages predators.
d. The run must be enclosed on all sides, including the top or roof plane.
4. Size: The coop shall provide a minimum of four (4) square feet of floor area per hen. The run shall provide a minimum of eight (8) square feet of floor
area per hen.
a. Coops will be considered an "accessory structure" as defined in title 13 of this code and must meet all standards outlined therein.
b. Coops over one hundred twenty (120) square feet will require a building permit.
5. Sanitary Condition: The coop and run shall be kept in a clean, dry and sanitary condition at all times. Manure, uneaten and discarded feed, feathers
and other waste must be removed regularly and at a minimum of once per week.
a. Odors from hens, manure or related substances shall not be detectable from property lines.
b. Manure must be stored and disposed of. Manure may be composted. All manure not composted must be removed from property regularly and at a
minimum of once per week.
G. No person shall maintain a coop without first obtaining a license from the village.
1. License Denial: The village may deny a license to any person who:
a. Owes money to the village; or
b. Has, in the last five (5) years prior to application for a license under this section been convicted or pled guilty to any violation of this title, title 12,
chapter 8, "Property Maintenance Code", or title 13, "Zoning Regulations", of this code.
2. Issuance: All licenses pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. Licenses may be automatically renewed if the
licensee has been in compliance during the previous year.
3. Eligibility: Only persons residing in one- and two-family dwelling units are eligible for a license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 151/307
4. License Per Lot: Only one coop license will be issued per zoning lot. A zoning lot consisting of multiple platted lots shall be considered one lot.
5. Nontransferable: Coop licenses are nontransferable.
6. Costs:
a. The coop license shall cost twenty five dollars ($25.00). This license shall renew automatically if the licensee is in compliance with all standards
set forth in this chapter.
H. In addition to the general penalty previously set forth in section 8-1-12 of this title, the owner of the coop is subject to the following additional penalties:
1. A person found to be keeping hens without a coop license will have seven (7) days from notification to achieve compliance with this chapter.
2. A licensee found to be in violation of the standards outlined in this chapter will have seven (7) days from notification to achieve compliance. If
compliance is not achieved, the license will be revoked. The licensee may apply for a new license, subject to site inspection. If the licensee is found
to be in compliance after inspection, a new license may be issued.
3. If the licensee is found to be in violation of these standards three (3) or more times, the license will be immediately and permanently revoked.
I. Hens, coops and runs not maintained according to this chapter shall be deemed a public nuisance. (Ord. 04-21-15-O3, 4-21-2015)
Title 9
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
Footnote 1: See title 7, chapter 3 of this code for alarm system regulations.
Chapter 1
MOTOR VEHICLE LICENSES
9-1-1: DEFINITION:
As used in this chapter, the term "motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is propelled otherwise than by muscular power, including, but not limited to,
motorcycles, motor driven cycles, pole trailers, reconstructed vehicles, road tractors, school buses, semitrailers, special mobile equipment, specially
constructed vehicles, trackless trailer coaches, trailer trucks and truck tractors. (1965 Code § 10-14-1)
9-1-2: VILLAGE VEHICLE LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. Annual License Required; Fee; Exemptions:
1. Each owner of a motor vehicle, motorcycle, or motor driven cycle who resides within the village, or whose vehicle has its situs or base within the
village, shall annually purchase a license for such vehicle and pay to the village an annual license fee for the use of such vehicle on any public street
or highway within the village. (1965 Code § 10-14-2)
2. The United States, the state, units of local government and school districts created under the laws of the state shall be exempt from the requirement
to obtain an annual license and pay the annual license fee for all vehicles owned by said public bodies and used exclusively for the public purposes
of said public body. Owners of "commercial motor vehicles", as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18b-101, that are registered under 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-402.1 shall be exempt from the requirement to obtain an annual license and pay the annual license fee. (1965 Code
§ 10-14-2; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Use Of Licensed Vehicle:
1. No person shall use, or cause or permit any agents or employees to use, any motor vehicle whose owner resides within the village or whose situs or
base is within the village upon the public streets or highways in the village unless such vehicle is licensed.
2. Leased or rented vehicles may be licensed in the name of the owner or custodian of the vehicle, and if such vehicle is in custody of the resident of
the village assigned its total use, that person shall be required to license such vehicle in accordance herewith unless said vehicle has a current
license from another corporate entity.
3. It shall constitute prima facie evidence that a motor vehicle is operated upon the public streets or highways within the village when the motor vehicle
is registered to a named person at an address within the village boundaries or when the motor vehicle has its situs or base within the village.
C. Situs Or Base: A motor vehicle has its situs or base where it is principally garaged or from whence it is principally dispatched or where the movements
of such vehicle usually originate.
D. Resident Owners: Resident owners of motor vehicles shall not be required to display on their vehicles the license required herein if their vehicles are
displaying a license issued by the place wherein the vehicle has its situs or base.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 152/307
E. Commercial Vehicles:
1. No commercial vehicle shall be parked in the village for any length of time unless a current vehicle license sticker is affixed to its front windshield
from the village or from some other corporate entity.
2. Such commercial vehicle may be licensed in the name of its actual owner, or in the name of the person in the village or entity which is the custodian
of the vehicle. (1965 Code § 10-14-2)
9-1-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; ISSUANCE:
Every owner of a motor vehicle shall make application to the village clerk upon forms which set forth the name and address of the applicant and a
description of the motor vehicle for which the license is desired. Upon payment by the applicant of the license fee, the village manager or his/her designee
shall issue a license, which shall be attested by the village clerk, authorizing the use of such motor vehicle within the village until the expiration of such
license. (1965 Code § 10-14-3; amd. 2009 Code)
9-1-4: SCHEDULE OF FEES:
The fees to be paid annually as provided in this chapter, to the village, shall be as follows:

9-1-5: LICENSE FEES DUE AND PAYABLE:
A. Annual Payment: The license fees required under this chapter shall be due and payable annually on or before May 1 of each year. Beginning in 2012
and thereafter, the license shall be issued for each year beginning May 1; provided, that if the owner or operator of any vehicle comes into possession
or ownership of the same, for operation on the streets of the village after December 31 of any license year, then and then only, the license fee shall be
one-half (1/2) of the annual fee provided in section 9-1-4 of this chapter.
B. Purchase Deadline: The owner of a motor vehicle who resides within the village shall purchase and display a license emblem on or before June 30 of
each year for each motor vehicle owned on June 1 of that year.
C. Vehicle Acquired During License Year: For each motor vehicle purchased or acquired during the license year, but not owned on June 1 of that license
year, by any owner who resides within the village, such owner shall transfer a previously issued sticker emblem or purchase a new vehicle sticker
emblem and display the same on the purchased or acquired vehicle within fifteen (15) days of such purchase or acquisition.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 153/307
D. Additional Late Payment Fee: Each owner of a motor vehicle required to purchase a motor vehicle license by this chapter who fails to pay the
prescribed fee on or before the deadline established by this chapter shall be required to pay, in addition to the required fee, a late fee as provided in
section 9-1-4 of this chapter, which shall expire after the deadline or due date thereof. This late fee is in addition to the penalties described in
subsection 9-1-8B of this chapter.
E. New Residents: Each owner of a motor vehicle who becomes a resident of the village after June 1 of any year shall purchase and display a license
emblem within thirty (30) days of establishing permanent residency in the village. Permanent residency shall be evidenced by the establishment of an
account with the village water department, the initiation of a lease term or any other evidence deemed appropriate by the village clerk as proof of
residency.
F. Prior Delinquencies: All owners and operators of motor vehicles who are required to have and obtain a motor vehicle license, as provided in this chapter,
for the year previous to the year for which a license is applied for, and who have not paid the fee nor obtained the license for the previous year, shall
not be entitled to a license for the current year unless the fees, and any applicable penalties, for the previous year or years have been fully paid. (Ord.
11-16-2011-O1, 11-16-2011)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 03-05-19-O1 - VEHICLE STICKER FEES. Go to new ordinance.
9-1-6: STICKERS OR PLATES GENERALLY:
A. Attaching Sticker Or Plate To Vehicle:
1. Upon the issuance of a license under this chapter, the village clerk shall deliver to the applicant a decal bearing a number and the name of the class
to which the vehicle in question belongs and the year for which the license is issued, and it shall be the duty of such applicant to affix such decal in a
conspicuous place on the right side of such vehicle where it can be easily seen; which sticker shall indicate the class to which the vehicle belongs
and the year for which such license was issued; and the sticker shall be fastened upon the lower inside corner of the windshield on the right hand
side thereof.
2. It shall be unlawful for any licensed motor vehicle, although duly licensed, to be used upon the streets, avenues, or alleys of the village unless such
sticker is attached thereto.
3. It shall be the duty of the applicant for a license under this chapter to use a motor bicycle or motor tricycle upon the streets, avenues, or alleys to
affix such license upon such vehicle in such a position that the number thereof may be clearly visible.
B. Issuance Of Duplicate License; Fee:
1. If and whenever a motor vehicle license issued by the village clerk by virtue of this chapter is lost or has been destroyed, or when the motor vehicle
for which the license is issued is sold or destroyed, a duplicate thereof shall be issued by the village clerk to the person to whom such motor vehicle
license was originally issued; provided, that application for such duplicate license shall be made in writing by the person to whom the original was
issued, which application shall be accompanied by the affidavit of the applicant stating his/her name, age, address, place and conditions under which
such motor vehicle sold, and to whom, or that the same was destroyed, the amount of the license fee paid therefor by him/her, date of payment, and
if destroyed, the manner of its destruction.
2. The applicant shall pay to the village clerk a fee of two dollars ($2.00) for the issuance of the duplicate license sticker. Such a license sticker so
issued as a duplicate shall be plainly marked as such. (1965 Code § 10-14-6)
9-1-7: REMOVAL OF STICKER OR DECAL; TRANSFER OF VEHICLE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any sticker referred to in section 9-1-6 of this chapter from any motor vehicle and to transfer the same to any
other motor vehicle, or to sell or transfer the same to any other motor vehicle, or to sell or transfer any motor vehicle without first removing and destroying
the license sticker. The license from a transferred or destroyed motor vehicle shall be presented with the application for a duplicate sticker thereof. (1965
Code § 10-14-7)
9-1-8: PENALTIES:
A. Penalty Imposed: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined no less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense. (1965 Code § 10-14-8)
B. Fines For Specific Violations: Any person violating section 9-1-2, or 9-1-5 or 9-1-6 of this chapter for failure to purchase and properly display a valid
vehicle license, of the class required by section 9-1-4 of this chapter, shall be fined as provided in section 9-2-4 of this title. (1965 Code § 10-14-9)
9-1-9: ENFORCEMENT OF LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
Citations or tickets for violations of this chapter may only be issued to a vehicle owner for a vehicle that is either registered in the village or that is required
to be registered in the village by the owner pursuant to this code. (Ord. 11-16-2011-O1, 11-16-2011)
Chapter 2
ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES

9-2-1: OBEDIENCE TO POLICE; DIRECTING TRAFFIC:
Members of the police department and auxiliary police assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in accordance with the provisions of
this title or in emergencies as public safety or convenience may require, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with any lawful
order, signal or direction of a police officer. Except in case of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by law to direct or attempt to
direct traffic. (1965 Code § 10-2-1; amd. 2009 Code)
9-2-2: SCENE OF FIRE:
The fire department officer in command or any firefighter designated by him may exercise the powers and authority of a police officer in directing traffic at
the scene of any fire or where the fire department has responded to an emergency call for so long as fire department equipment is on the scene in the
absence of or in assisting the police. (1965 Code § 10-2-2)

2. The police officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in court, in the first instance, issue to such alleged violator, a citation (P ticket):
a. Advising said person that he has violated a specified ordinance;
b. Requesting him to make payment in an amount applicable to said alleged violation as set forth above as settlement of said violation claim; and
c. Informing him that upon failure to so settle, a complaint will be filed in the circuit court of Cook County charging him with such violation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 156/307
B. Settlement: Pursuant to said citation, the person so accused of said violation may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect to such code
violation by paying to the village the applicable amount as shown in the schedule set forth as the settlement amount in subsection A of this section,
within a period to be specified in said citation, not more than fourteen (14) days from the time said alleged offense was committed. Such payment shall
be made in accordance with the instructions contained in the aforesaid citation, at the village office, where a receipt shall be issued for the money so
received, and said amount shall be promptly remitted to the village treasurer to be credited to the proper municipal fund.
C. Final Notice; Penalty: In the event that the person to whom said citation is issued fails to settle and pay said violation within the time specified in the
citation, a final notice shall be mailed to him. When, in fact, the final notice has been mailed, the violation may then be settled and compromised by
paying two (2) times the amount set forth in subsection A of this section, up to a maximum of ninety dollars ($90.00), within the time specified in the
final notice.
D. Issuance Of Complaint: In the event that the person to whom the citation is issued fails to settle and pay said violation claim within the time specified in
the final notice (if one is served or mailed to him), then the police officer is authorized to cause the citation (notice to appear, P ticket) to be served upon
said alleged violator, and is authorized to file the same as a complaint in the circuit court of Cook County and prosecute the same. The officer, as an
alternative, may file a formal complaint in the circuit court of Cook County in lieu of the citation.
E. Court Penalty; Settlement Before Court Date: In the event that payment is not made within the time prescribed in the final notice and the citation or a
complaint is filed in the circuit court, payment of any fine and costs shall be in such amounts as may be determined and established by the circuit court,
but not to exceed the sum of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any one violation; provided, that the offenses may be settled and compromised
for the amount specified in the notice to appear at least ten (10) working days before the court date. Such amount shall be two (2) times the amount set
forth in the schedule set forth in subsection A of this section, plus ten dollars ($10.00).
F. Correction Of Violation: The payment of an amount as settlement herein will not excuse securing of and the payment of a license fee provided for in this
code and correction of the violation.
G. Parking Violations: The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state in the
name of said alleged violator; or in the alternative, in the event that a vehicle sticker issued by a municipality has been issued in the name of and to
said alleged violator, shall be proof that said alleged violator was in control of or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at the time of such
alleged violation. The commercial lessor of any vehicle, whether or not the registered owner, shall be responsible for such parking violation and subject
to the penalty therefor. (Ord. 06-18-14-O2, 6-18-2014)

9-2-5: PENALTIES:
A. Penalty Imposed: Unless otherwise provided, any person violating the terms and conditions of this title shall be subject to a fine of not less than thirty
five dollars ($35.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), with each and every day that a violation is allowed to exist constituting a
distinct and separate offense under the terms of this title. (1965 Code § 10-2-4; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Injunctive Relief: In addition, the village may take whatever action it may deem appropriate to enforce the terms of this title, including an action for
injunction.
C. Attorney Fees And Costs: All attorney fees and costs incurred by the village in enforcing the terms of this title shall be paid by the violator. (1965 Code
§ 10-2-4)
ARTICLE A. IMMOBILIZATION OF TICKET OFFENDERS (BOOT)
9-2A-1: AUTHORITY FOR IMPLEMENTATION:
The chief of police shall have the authority for implementing the parking enforcement provisions of this article. (1965 Code § 10-19-7)
9-2A-2: IMMOBILIZATION FOR VIOLATIONS, WARRANTS OUTSTANDING:
A motor vehicle parked upon the public way at any time may, by or under the direction of an officer or member of the police department, be immobilized in
such a manner as to prevent its operation, if there are three (3) or more outstanding or otherwise unsettled traffic violation notices, or one or more warrants
issued for any such violations pending against the owner of such motor vehicle. (Ord. 08-17-10-O1, 8-17-2010)
9-2A-3: NOTIFICATION:
A. Notice Upon Vehicle: Upon immobilization of such motor vehicle, the officer or employee shall cause to be placed on such vehicle, in a conspicuous
manner, notice sufficient to warn any individual that such vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move such vehicle might result in
damage to such vehicle.
B. Notify Vehicle Owner: As soon as practicable, the officer or employee shall inform the owner of the immobilized vehicle of the nature and circumstances
of the prior outstanding or unsettled traffic violation notices or warrants for which, or on account of which, such vehicle was immobilized. (1965 Code
§ 10-19-2)
9-2A-4: RELEASE:
A. Conditions For Securing Release: The owner of such immobilized vehicle, or other authorized person, shall be permitted to secure release of the
vehicle upon:
1. The depositing of the bond for his appearance in court to answer for each violation; and
2. Depositing the amount of the fine or penalty for each violation for which there is an outstanding or otherwise unsettled traffic violation notice or
warrant, and the payment of the fees as required by section 9-2A-6 of this article.
B. Right To Appear In Court: The owner of an immobilized vehicle, or other authorized person, shall have the right to a postimmobilization court date to
determine the validity of such immobilization, towing and any towing or storage charges. Such court date must be requested within fifteen (15) days
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 159/307
after the vehicle is immobilized. (1965 Code § 10-19-3)
9-2A-5: LENGTH OF IMMOBILIZATION:
The immobilizing device or mechanism shall remain in place for forty eight (48) hours unless the owner has complied with section 9-2A-4 of this article. If
such compliance has not occurred within forty eight (48) hours, the vehicle shall be towed or impounded. Towing and storage fees, as specified in section
9-2A-6 of this article, shall be paid, along with fees specified in section 9-2A-4 of this article before the owner of such vehicle, or authorized person, shall
be permitted to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle, unless the owner has posted bond and requested a court date as specified in section 9-2A-
4 of this article. (1965 Code § 10-19-4)
9-2A-6: IMMOBILIZATION FEE:
The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall be subject to a fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for such immobilization. The owner of an immobilized vehicle
which was subsequently impounded shall be subject to a fee of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for immobilization, plus the towing and storage charges
actually incurred by the village in such cases. (Ord. 06-17-08-04, 6-17-2008)
9-2A-7: UNAUTHORIZED REMOVAL:
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to attempt to remove or to remove the vehicle immobilizing device. (1965 Code § 10-19-6; amd. 2009
Code)
9-2A-8: RIGHT TO HEARING:
Nothing in this article shall be construed to deprive any person of the constitutional right to a hearing or trial as to the violations charged. (1965 Code § 10-
19-8)
9-2A-9: PENALTY:
Whoever violates any provision of this article for which no specific penalty is otherwise provided shall be punished as provided in section 1-4-1 of this
code. (1965 Code § 10-19-8)
ARTICLE B. IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES USED IN ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES
9-2B-1: ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES ENUMERATED; IMPOUNDMENT PROVISIONS:
A. Impoundment Authorized; Liability For Fees And Charges: A motor vehicle operated with the permission, express or implied, of the owner of record that
is used in connection with any of the following violations for which the driver or registered owner is arrested shall be subject to tow and impoundment
by the village, and the owner of record of said vehicle shall be liable to the village for an administrative processing fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
in addition to any towing and storage fees for the following violations:
1. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission or attempted commission of any offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and
forfeited pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1 et seq.; or
2. Driving under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or other intoxicating compounds, in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-501; or
3. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in connection with the commission or attempted commission of any felony offense or in a felonious violation of
the provisions of the Illinois cannabis control act1; or (1965 Code § 10-22-1)
4. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in connection with the commission or attempted commission of any offense in violation of the Illinois controlled
substances act2; or unlawful use of a weapon in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1; reckless discharge of a firearm in violation of 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5; or unlawful possession of a firearm and firearm ammunition in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1;
or (1965 Code § 10-22-1; amd. 2009 Code)
5. Driving while driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303; except,
that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving), or due to failure to
comply with emission testing; or
6. Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possession, or attempting to solicit or possess "cannabis" or a "controlled substance", as defined
by the Illinois cannabis control act3, or the Illinois controlled substances act4; or
7. Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois vehicle code5, where the period of
expiration is greater than one year; or
8. Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois vehicle
code, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or
9. Operation or use of a motor vehicle by the driver or registered owner against whom a valid, executable federal, state, or municipal warrant has been
issued.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 160/307
10. Operation or use of a motor vehicle in connection with the commission or attempted commission of any offense in violation of the sections of the
Illinois criminal code related to prostitution or soliciting prostitution, including the following sections:
720 ILCS 5/11-14
720 ILCS 5/11-14.1
720 ILCS 5/11-15
720 ILCS 5/11-15.1
720 ILCS 5/11-16
720 ILCS 5/11-18
720 ILCS 5/11-18.1.
B. General Regulations:
1. This article shall not replace or otherwise abrogate any existing state or federal laws or village ordinances pertaining to seizure, towing and
impoundment.
2. The owners shall be subject to all fees set forth in this article in addition to any penalties that may be assessed by a court of law for the underlying
violations.
3. This article shall not apply to a vehicle which was stolen at the time of impoundment so long as the theft was reported to appropriate police
authorities within twenty four (24) hours of its discovery.
4. Fees for towing and storage of a vehicle under this article shall be those approved by the chief of police and shall be uniform for all similarly situated
vehicles.
C. Probable Cause: Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is subject to tow and impoundment pursuant to this article, the
officer shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility authorized by the police department, if the towing of the vehicle is supported by probable
cause or is in furtherance of public safety or community caretaking functions. Prior to towing, the officer shall notify any person identifying himself as
the owner of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, and who was physically present at
the scene of the alleged violation, that the vehicle will be towed and impounded and of their right to an administrative hearing to be conducted during
the village's regularly scheduled monthly adjudication hearing which occurs on the fourth Tuesday of every month. (1965 Code § 10-22-1)
9-2B-2: NOTICE AND ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
A. Right To Request Administrative Hearing; Bond Required:
1. Under subsection 9-2B-1C of this article, the person in control of the vehicle shall be notified at the time of the towing of the vehicle of the right to
request an administrative hearing. Within forty eight (48) hours after a vehicle is towed/impounded pursuant to this article, the village shall notify the
owner of record by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address of the owner as it appears in the records of the secretary of state, of the
towing/impoundment of the vehicle. The notice shall inform the registered owner of the right to request an administrative hearing of the violation of
section 9-2B-1 of this article at the village's regularly scheduled adjudication hearing which occurs on the fourth Tuesday of every month.
2. The registered owner, or his/her designee, must post a five hundred dollar ($500.00) bond with the police department to appear at an administrative
hearing to determine whether the vehicle was used in connection with a violation set forth in section 9-2B-1 of this article. The five hundred dollar
($500.00) bond must be posted within ten (10) days of the mailing of the certified letter notifying the owner of the tow/impoundment of the vehicle.
The village police department shall hold the cash bond in escrow until such time as the hearing is completed in conformance with this article. Upon
posting the bond, the owner/designee shall be provided a release to claim the vehicle from the towing company and will be notified of the date, time,
and location of a hearing that will be conducted pursuant to this section.
3. The hearing shall be conducted by the adjudication hearing officer of the village who is appointed by the village manager.
B. Conduct Of Hearing; Decision; Disposition Of Bond:
1. The owner/designee shall appear at the administrative hearing, and all interested parties shall be given an opportunity to be heard at the hearing. At
any time prior to the hearing, the hearing officer may, at the request of the village or the owner/designee, direct witnesses to appear and give
testimony at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and hearsay evidence shall be admissible only if it is the type
commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
2. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was used in connection with a violation set
forth in this article, the hearing officer shall enter an order finding the owner of the vehicle civilly liable to the village for an administrative fee of five
hundred dollars ($500.00), and the bond held in escrow by the village shall be forfeited in payment of the administrative fee.
3. If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing officer shall enter a default order in favor of the village.
4. If the hearing officer finds, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the vehicle was not used in connection with a violation set forth in section 9-2B-
1 of this article, the hearing officer shall order the immediate return of the cash bond. (1965 Code § 10-22-2)
9-2B-3: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE A DEBT TO VILLAGE:
The administrative fee imposed pursuant to this article shall constitute a debt due and owing the village. The debt may be satisfied by the bond posted
pursuant to this article, or where no bond is posted, by cash, money order, certified check or approved credit card payment service. If a hearing is not
requested by the posting of a five hundred dollar ($500.00) bond as provided for in section 9-2B-2 of this article and the administrative fee is not paid
within ten (10) days for vehicles older than seven (7) years and within thirty (30) days for vehicles less than seven (7) years old, the vehicle shall be
deemed unclaimed and disposed of in the manner provided for by law for the disposition of unclaimed vehicles under the Illinois vehicle code. (1965 Code
§ 10-22-3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 161/307
9-2B-4: VEHICLE POSSESSION:
Except as otherwise provided by law, no owner, lien holder or other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a vehicle impounded under this
article until the bond or administrative fee is paid. Whenever a person with a lien of record against an impounded vehicle has commenced foreclosure
proceedings, possession of the vehicle shall be given to that person if he or she pays the village administrative fee. (1965 Code § 10-22-4)
9-2B-5: LIEN HOLDER:
A lien holder asserting its right to possession of an impounded vehicle pursuant to its conditional sales agreement may obtain possession of such vehicle
by paying the applicable towing fee and submitting a photocopy of the conditional sales agreement and title certificate, an affidavit stating that the
purchaser is in default of the agreement and an indemnification certificate executed by an authorized agent of the lien holder. (1965 Code § 10-22-5)
