C. Fifteen Minute Parking For Pick Up Only: The following parking limitation is established for:
Street Side Area
Joliet Avenue West 108 feet south of the intersection of Ogden Avenue and Joliet Avenue and extending south 170 feet
(Ord. 04-20-10-02, 4-20-2010)
9-6-11: HANDICAP PARKING SIGNS:
A. Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
ACCESSIBILITY: The means by which a disabled person overcomes physical barriers to access his residential property.
DISABLED PERSON: Any resident of the village who has met the criteria of the state of Illinois for obtaining and has actually obtained a handicap
license plate or motor vehicle placard.
HANDICAP PARKING SIGN: A sign erected by the village decreeing a specific public area to be for motor vehicle parking by handicapped persons
only.
B. General Requirements:
1. Request For Sign: All requests for handicap signs shall be in accordance with this section.
2. Condition For Issuance: A handicap parking sign shall only be issued under the following prerequisites:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 174/307
a. The disability must be permanent in nature as determined by the Illinois secretary of state.
b. Only the resident for which the handicapped signage is issued shall be parked in the designated handicapped space.
c. The applicant must hold title to the vehicle for which the signage has been installed.
d. The applicant must reside at the address at which the sign is requested.
e. If the residence for which the signage is requested includes a driveway or garage, and if the distance from the driveway or garage is less than the
distance from the requested handicapped designated parking space, then no handicapped parking sign will be installed.
3. Reasons For Denial Of Request Or Removal Of Sign: The village shall deny an application for a handicap sign or remove a handicap sign for one or
more of the following reasons:
a. Fraudulent or misleading information provided on an application.
b. The applicant is not disabled or has recovered from his disability.
c. The applicant no longer lives at the subject address.
d. A nuisance or hazardous condition will be created by the installation of the sign and/or its attendant handicap parking space.
C. Application Requirements:
1. Filing Of Application With Police Department: Persons seeking the issuance of a handicap parking sign shall fill out an application for such sign at
the police department.
2. Documentation Of State Plate Or Placard: The applications shall be submitted with documentation from the state of Illinois establishing that the
applicant has obtained a handicap license plate or placard from the state.
3. Proof Of Residency Adjacent To Sign Location: Proof of residency adjacent to the public sign location shall be presented with the application.
4. No Fee: There shall be no fee for the application. (Ord. 08-18-09-01, 8-18-2009)
9-6-12: SIGNS POSTED:
Appropriate signs shall be posted in all areas where parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitation or prohibition. (1965 Code § 10-10-10)
9-6-13: REGISTRATION, PRIMA FACIE PROOF:
The fact that an automobile which is illegally operated or parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such
person was in control of the automobile at the time of such violation. (1965 Code § 10-10-11)
9-6-14: IMPOUNDMENT OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES:
A. Whenever any vehicle is parked illegally in such a manner as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic or interfere with the sweeping or repair of
streets or removal of snow therefrom, the chief of police, or any person authorized by the chief of police, is hereby authorized to cause such vehicle to
be removed from the public street and conveyed by or under the direction of a member of the police department to an authorized garage or storage
area. (1965 Code § 10-10-14)
B. Any vehicle parked in violation of traffic regulations or any vehicle parked so as to obstruct the free movement of traffic or to cause a traffic hazard may
be immediately removed upon order of the police department. Any such vehicle removed by the police department shall be kept under the control of
the police department until the owner or authorized agent pays a reasonable cost of removal and storage in addition to the penalty provided for such
improper parking. Any such vehicle shall be deemed to be improperly parked after a period of three (3) minutes, unless said vehicle is parked in a
regularly marked parking area, when it shall be deemed to be improperly parked after any period of time longer than that designated by a meter or
proper sign. (1965 Code § 10-11-8)
C. If at any time a vehicle is parked upon private property without the consent of the owner of such property, the police department is hereby authorized to
remove said vehicle therefrom and to cause the same to be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of, provided the owner of such private
property has first signed a complaint against the owner or operator of said vehicle. Any such vehicle removed by the police department shall be kept
under the control of the police department until the owner or authorized agent pays a reasonable cost of removal and storage in addition to the penalty
provided for such improper parking1. (1965 Code § 10-11-9)
9-6-15: FINES:
The fines for all violations of this chapter shall be as provided in section 9-2-4 of this title. (1965 Code § 10-10-25)
9-6-16: RIGHT TO HEARING:
The registered owner of the vehicle cited has a right to hearing and to review by the village adjudicator under title 1, chapter 5, article A of this code. Any
individual requesting such hearing shall be required to present a bond prior to said hearing that shall be the face value of the current fine as well as pay an
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 175/307
administrative court fee of thirty five dollars ($35.00). Should an individual be found not liable (not guilty), said fee may be refunded upon order of the
hearing officer. (Ord. 06-19-07-06, 6-19-2007)
ARTICLE A. COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKING1
9-6A-1: COMMERCIAL VEHICLE PARKING IN ALL ZONING DISTRICTS:
A. Overnight Parking: No commercial vehicle or portion thereof with a license above a B plate or licensed for a gross weight, including vehicle and cargo,
of eight thousand one (8,001) pounds or more may be parked overnight on any street of the village. "Commercial vehicles", excluding transport
vehicles, as defined in section 9-3-2 of this title that are licensed below a B plate or for a gross weight of vehicle and cargo of eight thousand (8,000)
pounds or less are permitted to park overnight on any street of the village, provided such vehicle has a valid village vehicle sticker.
B. Parking Prohibited In Certain Areas: No commercial vehicle with a license above a B plate or licensed for a gross weight, including vehicle and cargo, of
eight thousand one (8,001) pounds or more shall be parked at any time on any parkway or public way in the village; nor shall any such vehicle be
parked on the front setback area between the plane of the front of the building and the front lot line.
C. Vehicles Used As Warehouses Or Storage Bins: No commercial or recreational vehicle shall be used for warehouses, storage bins or loading bins
within the village.
D. Parking On Private Property: No commercial vehicle shall be parked or stored on private property unless:
1. Such parking or storage is conducted on land improved with concrete or asphalt as regulated by the village zoning regulations and otherwise
approved by the village as a commercial parking lot, truck terminal or accessory parking lot.
2. Such parking is conducted as part of a village licensed truck terminal or commercial parking lot, or the parking of the vehicle in question is accessory
to and on site at a licensed commercial or industrial use.
E. Parking On Unimproved Or Unoccupied Land; Penalties:
1. Parking or storage on unimproved or unoccupied land, or in accessory parking lots while not accessory to the lawful primary industrial or commercial
occupant, or while such enterprise is closed, is expressly prohibited.
2. Vehicles in violation of subsection E1 of this section are subject to immediate immobilization as provided for in chapter 2, article A of this title. The
fine for a violation of subsection E1 of this section shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each twenty four (24) hour period in violation. The
registered vehicle and/or property owner may be cited as responsible parties for this violation. Such violations may be appealed to the village code
hearing officer, provided a bond in the amount of the total fine is filed with the village as enumerated in chapter 2, article A of this title. (1965 Code
§ 10-18-1)
9-6A-2: LOCATION OF COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLES:
A. Use Of Enclosed Garage Or Building: All commercial vehicles and recreational vehicles, except as otherwise provided in subsections B and C of this
section, shall be parked within a totally enclosed garage or other building or parcel of land in any residential district.
B. Rear Yard Parking: In the rear yard, open parking of a recreational vehicle shall be permitted, in addition to private passenger vehicles; provided, that
only one such vehicle may be so located in the open, in the rear yard; and screening in the form of shrubbery, fencing or other means adequate to
shield such vehicle from adjoining properties is provided and maintained. A recreational vehicle with collapsible walls shall be stored in a collapsed
position.
C. Side Yard Parking: In the event that the residence and garage buildings are so located on any lot or parcel of ground in any residence district that, in the
opinion of the zoning administrator, either no rear yard exists or physical access to the rear yard for open parking of a recreational vehicle as provided
in subsection B of this section is not possible or otherwise feasible, then and only then, the open parking of such recreational vehicle may be permitted,
in addition to private passenger vehicles, in any side yard area located at the side of the main residence building and to the rear of the actual building
line or any front portion of such residence building; provided, that only one such vehicle may be so located in the open in the side yard, and screening
in the form of shrubbery, fencing or other means adequate to shield such vehicle from adjoining properties is provided and maintained.
D. Lot Line Restrictions: Location of a parked vehicle shall conform to all lot line restrictions of the village zoning regulations. (1965 Code § 10-18-2)
9-6A-3: OCCUPANCY OF VEHICLES FOR LIVING QUARTERS PROHIBITED:
While parked, stored or otherwise kept on any improved lot or parcel of ground in any zoning district, no recreational vehicle shall be occupied or used for
living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes, and no water, gas, sewerage or electrical service connection shall be attached to such vehicle. (1965 Code
§ 10-18-3)
9-6A-4: TEMPORARY LOADING AND DELIVERIES PERMITTED:
Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, any recreational vehicle may be parked in the driveway area of any residentially improved lot or parcel of
ground in any residence district for loading or unloading purposes for a continuous period not exceeding forty eight (48) hours, and any commercial vehicle
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 176/307
may be parked in the driveway area of any residential lot or parcel of ground for a temporary period of time necessary to make deliveries or other service
to the property owner. (1965 Code § 10-18-4)
9-6A-5: TRANSPORT VEHICLES REGULATED:
A. Prohibited Parking: Transport vehicles, including limousines, taxicabs, hearses, buses, ambulances and similar vehicles, are prohibited from being
parked or stored on any public street, parkway, sidewalk, private or public drive or private property located within areas zoned or utilized as residential
within the village.
B. Exceptions: Exceptions to subsection A of this section are as follows:
1. Wherein such vehicles are in the process of picking up, delivering, transporting or otherwise engaged in actual transportation of human cargo as part
of a lawful commercial enterprise.
2. Public or private school buses parked on school property or on the street while driver occupied awaiting student pick up.
3. One limousine and one taxicab, owned or operated by a Lyons resident, parked upon his own private residential property on an improved surface,
provided it is not otherwise in conflict with village ordinances. The parking of such vehicles shall be on an improved surface in a location that would
otherwise be approved for a residential driveway and may not in any way be parked over a public sidewalk or parkway. If, in the determination of the
code enforcement officer, the limousine can properly and safely access the back yard, such parking shall be placed in that location.
4. Private accessory parking lots within the village limits may be utilized for the parking of one school bus that is otherwise operated solely for the use
of a public or private accredited educational institution and operated by a Lyons resident. Written authorization for such parking must be obtained
from the owner of the parking lot and from the village code enforcement officer. Approvals for a second or subsequent bus shall be prohibited until
such time as the preceding approval has been withdrawn. The village shall base its decision on the availability of parking on the lot, the potential
interference with business and traffic and whether such parking will be significantly out of character with the neighborhood and zoning district. The
code enforcement officer shall communicate all approved parking locations to the police department to assist in the prevention of mistaken
enforcement. (1965 Code § 10-18-5)
9-6A-6: FINES:
The fines for all violations of this article shall be as provided in section 9-2-4 of this title. (1965 Code § 10-18-6)
9-6A-7: CONFLICTS; STRICTER STANDARDS PREVAIL:
In the event this article conflicts with any other village code provision or village ordinance, the stricter standard shall apply. (1965 Code § 10-18-7)
Footnote 1: See also subsection 13-12-2I of this code.
Chapter 7
PEDESTRIANS
9-7-1: RIGHT OF WAY:
A. Signals Not In Place: Where traffic control signals or pedestrian control signals are not in place or in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right
of way, slowing down or stopping if need be, for a pedestrian crossing the roadway or street within any marked crosswalk or within any unmarked
crosswalk. (1965 Code § 10-9-1; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Signals In Place: Whenever stop signals or flashing red signals are in place at an intersection or a marked crosswalk between intersections, the
pedestrian shall have the right of way over the drivers of vehicles; and at such marked places, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest
crosswalk, and any pedestrian within or entering the crosswalk at either edge of the roadway shall have the right of way over any vehicle so stopped.
C. Stopping For Vehicle Stopped At Crosswalk: The driver of a vehicle shall stop before entering any crosswalk when any vehicle proceeding in the same
direction is stopped at such crosswalk for the purpose of permitting a pedestrian to cross. (1965 Code § 10-9-1)
9-7-2: CROSSING ROADWAYS:
A. Direct Route: At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at any
place other than a crosswalk, he shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (1965 Code § 10-9-2)
B. Use Of Crosswalks:
1. Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
2. No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district. (1965 Code § 10-9-5)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 177/307
C. Obedience To Signals: At intersections where traffic is directed by a police officer or by a stop and go signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to
cross the roadway other than with the released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1965 Code § 10-9-3)
9-7-3: STANDING IN ROADWAYS, ON SIDEWALKS:
A. Roadways:
1. No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a safety zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. (1965 Code § 10-
9-2)
2. No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. (1965 Code § 10-9-6)
B. Sidewalks: It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near as reasonably possible to the building line or curb line, if such
standing interferes with the use of said sidewalk by other pedestrians. (1965 Code § 10-9-4)
9-7-4: WALKING ALONG ROADWAYS:
A. Sidewalks Provided: Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon any adjacent roadway.
B. Sidewalks Not Provided: Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the
left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic and, upon meeting a vehicle, shall step off to the left. (1965 Code § 10-9-6)
9-7-5: PEDESTRIANS WITH DISABILITIES:
The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way to a pedestrian with clearly visible disabilities. (1965 Code § 10-9-7; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 8
VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION
9-8-1: SAFE VEHICLES REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to drive or move or for the owner to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any highway, any vehicle or
combination of vehicles which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person or property, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all
times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required by statute, or which is equipped in any manner in
violation of state statutes. (1965 Code § 10-12-4)
9-8-2: CLEAR VISION; MIRROR:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which is so loaded or in such a condition that the operator does not have a clear vision of all parts of the
roadway essential to the safe operation of the vehicle. Any vehicles with the view of the roadway to the rear so obstructed shall be equipped with a mirror
so attached as to give him a view of the roadway behind him. (1965 Code § 10-12-1)
9-8-3: LIGHTS:
A. General Requirements: It shall be unlawful to operate or park on any street any vehicle not equipped with adequate lights conforming to the
requirements of state law; provided, that vehicles may be parked at nighttime without lights on any street or portion thereof designated by ordinance as
a place where vehicles may be so parked at nighttime. (1965 Code § 10-12-9)
B. Motor Vehicles, Motorcycles And Trailers: During the period from sunset to sunrise, or at any other time when visibility is so limited as to require the use
of lights for safety, every motorcycle operated on any street or other public place in the village shall carry and exhibit one lighted lamp, commonly
known as a driving light, and every motor vehicle, two (2) such lighted lamps showing white lights, or lights of a yellow or amber tint, visible at least five
hundred feet (500') in the direction toward which each motorcycle or motor vehicle is proceeding, and each motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer shall
also exhibit at least one lighted lamp which shall be so situated, as to throw a red light visible for at least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse
direction; provided, that every trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000) pounds or less, including the weight of the trailer and maximum
load, shall be equipped with two (2) lighted lamps, one on each side of the rear of such trailer, which shall be so situated as to throw a red light visible
for at least five hundred feet (500') in the reverse direction. (1965 Code § 10-12-17)
C. Vehicles Owned By Firefighters: Any motor vehicle owned or fully operated by a firefighter may be equipped with not to exceed two (2) lamps which
shall emit a blue light as provided by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-215(c). (1965 Code § 10-12-8; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Bicycles: Every bicycle, when upon a street during the period from sunset to sunrise, shall be equipped with at least one lighted lamp exhibiting a white
light, or light of a yellow or amber tint, visible from a distance of five hundred feet (500') to the front of the bicycle and with at least one lighted lamp
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 178/307
exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear. (1965 Code § 10-12-16)
9-8-4: SIGNAL LAMPS AND DEVICES:
A. Every motor vehicle and trailer having a gross weight of three thousand (3,000) pounds and less, including the weight of the trailer and the maximum
load, shall be equipped with a signal lamp or signal device which is so constructed and located on the vehicle as to give a signal of the intention to stop
which shall be red or yellow in color, and signals of intention to turn to the right or left, all of which signals shall be plainly visible and understandable in
normal sunlight and at night from a distance of one hundred feet (100') to the rear but shall not project a dazzling or glaring light; except, that a stop
signal need be visible only from the rear.
B. All mechanical signal devices shall be self-illuminated during the period from sunset to sunrise or when visibility is limited as to require the use of lights
for safety. (1965 Code § 10-12-13; amd. 2009 Code)
9-8-5: HORNS AND WARNING DEVICES:
A. Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a good and sufficient audible signaling device in efficient working condition. Such signaling device shall be
sounded when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of a vehicle, but such horn or other signaling device shall not be sounded for any
purpose other than as a warning of impending danger.
B. No motor vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle, shall be equipped with a siren or gong signaling device. (1965 Code § 10-12-7)
9-8-6: BRAKES:
It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon a street unless such vehicle is equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good working condition, as
required by the state traffic law, or to operate any vehicle which is so loaded that the operator does not have ready access to the mechanics operating the
brakes of such vehicles. (1965 Code § 10-12-6)
9-8-7: TIRES; NONSKID DEVICES:
A. It shall be unlawful to operate on any street any motor vehicle which is not equipped with tires conforming to the requirements of the Illinois state traffic
law. (1965 Code § 10-12-14)
B. It shall be unlawful to operate upon any street any motor vehicle equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or nonflexible portion
thereof comes into contact with the pavement or roadway. (1965 Code § 10-12-11)
9-8-8: NOISE CONTROL; MUFFLERS:
A. It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle which makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise.
B. No driver of any motor vehicle shall operate or permit operation of any sound amplification system which can be heard outside the vehicle from seventy
five (75) or more feet unless the system is being operated to request assistance or warn of a hazardous situation. This subsection does not pertain to
authorized emergency vehicles or vehicles engaged in advertising. (1965 Code § 10-12-3)
C. No motor vehicle shall be operated on any street unless such vehicle is provided with a muffler in efficient actual working condition. The use of a cutout
is prohibited. (1965 Code § 10-12-10)
9-8-9: GAS AND SMOKE EMISSIONS:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or
as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles. (1965 Code § 10-12-2)
9-8-10: SIZE AND LOAD OF VEHICLES:
A. The maximum width, length and height of any vehicle and its load shall not exceed the limits expressed in the Illinois state traffic law.
B. No passenger type vehicle shall be operated on the streets with a load extending beyond the line of the fenders on the left side of the vehicle nor
extending more than six inches (6") beyond the line of the fenders on the right side thereof.
C. No combination of vehicles, coupled together, shall consist of more than two (2) units, but such limitation shall not apply to vehicles operated in daytime
when transporting pipes, poles, machinery and other objects which cannot be readily dismembered, nor to such vehicles operated at nighttime by a
public utility when engaged in emergency repair work; but such loads carried at night shall be clearly marked with sufficient lights to show the full
dimensions of the load.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 179/307
D. No part of the load of a vehicle shall extend more than three feet (3') in front of the extreme front portion of the vehicle. (1965 Code § 10-12-12)
9-8-11: SPILLING LOADS:
No vehicle shall be so loaded that any part of its load spills or drops onto any street or alley in the city. (1965 Code § 10-12-5)
9-8-12: ENGINE BRAKING PROHIBITED:
No person shall operate or cause to be used or operated within the village an engine braking system that emits excessive noise on any motor vehicle
within the village. For the purposes of this section, an engine braking system shall be deemed to be any device which uses the force of the engine in any
motor vehicle to slow or alter the speed of the vehicle by the application of force to the drive train thereof, including, but not limited to, engine brakes,
exhaust brakes, or other similar systems. A motor vehicle shall be deemed to be emitting excessive noise if the vehicle is operating an engine braking
system, and if the motor vehicle is not equipped with an adequate sound muffling system on the exhaust of the motor vehicle. It is a defense to this section
that the driver used an engine braking system that emits excessive noise in an emergency to avoid a collision with a person or another vehicle. (Ord. 08-
21-13-O1, 8-21-2013)
Chapter 9
MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR DRIVEN CYCLES
9-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, except where the context otherwise requires:
AREA: The geographical boundaries within which an operating motorcycle or operating motor driven cycle can be heard.
MOTOR DRIVEN CYCLE: Every motorcycle, including every motor scooter propelled by a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) horsepower, and
every bicycle with motor attached.
MOTOR VEHICLE OR VEHICLE: A motorcycle or motor driven cycle.
MOTORCYCLE: Every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact
with the ground, but excluding a tractor.
NONRESIDENT: Every person who is not a resident of the state of Illinois.
NONRESIDENT'S OPERATING PRIVILEGE: The privilege conferred upon a nonresident by the laws of the state of Illinois pertaining to the operation by
such person of a motor vehicle, or the use of a vehicle owned by such person, in the state of Illinois.
OPERATOR: Every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a motor vehicle upon a street or who is exercising control of or steering a vehicle
being towed by a motor vehicle.
RACING OF MOTOR: The sudden acceleration or deceleration of the motor of a motorcycle or motor driven cycle.
STREET: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way, including alleys, publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to use of the
public for purposes of vehicular traffic.
STUNTING: Operating a vehicle in a manner causing it to weave or suddenly change course, or the loss of body contact with the seat by a driver or
passenger, and not for the purpose of safe operation of such vehicle.
TOURING: Any repetitious driving in the same area which causes a disturbance or is done with the intent of calling attention to an operator of a motorcycle
or motor driven cycle. (1965 Code § 10-15-1)
9-9-2: OPERATION OF MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR DRIVEN CYCLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated a motorcycle or motor driven cycle upon any street within the corporate limits of the
village except in compliance with the following:
A. Driver's License Required: The operator of such vehicle shall have upon his possession a valid driver's license issued by the state of Illinois (or if such
operator is a nonresident, such operator shall have upon his possession evidence of a nonresident's operating privilege) and which has not been
suspended, limited or canceled.
B. Condition Of Vehicle: Such vehicle shall, at such time of operation, be capable of performing in accordance with the standards then fixed by the motor
vehicle laws of the state of Illinois and by the ordinances of the village.
C. Compliance With Vehicle Laws: The operator shall operate said vehicle in accordance with the motor vehicle laws of the state and ordinances of the
village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 180/307
D. Noise Control; Muffler; Exhaust System: Such vehicle shall be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order, sufficient to prevent excessive
or unusual noises; and no such vehicle shall be equipped with any muffler cutout, removable exhaust pipe cover, or any bypass in a muffler, or any
muffler from which the baffle plates, screens, or other original internal parts have been removed or altered; nor shall any such vehicle be equipped with
an exhaust system which has been modified in a manner which will amplify or increase the noise emitted by the motor of such vehicle above that
emitted by the exhaust system originally installed on the vehicle; nor shall such vehicle be equipped with an exhaust system which has been modified
or altered in any way from that furnished by the vehicle manufacturer; provided, however, that equipment equivalent to that originally installed may be
substituted when parts are replaced.
E. Ability To Operate: Before operating a motorcycle or motor driven cycle upon a public street, the operator thereof shall have first become sufficiently
proficient in the operation thereof to control said vehicle without unreasonable danger to others; and if said vehicle is rented, leased or borrowed from
another, said operator shall first have demonstrated to the lessor, renter or lender of such equipment that he is sufficiently proficient to operate such
vehicle upon a public street without unreasonable danger to others.
F. Minors: No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall purchase, rent, lease or borrow a motorcycle or motor driven cycle unless he has first
obtained written consent from either of his parents, or his legal guardian; and no such person under eighteen (18) years of age shall take possession of
and operate any motorcycle or motor driven cycle unless, on the occasion of such purchasing, or on the first occasion of such renting, leasing or
borrowing of such motorcycle or motor driven cycle, such person under eighteen (18) years of age obtains and files with such seller, renter, lessor or
lender an acknowledgment in writing, signed by either parent of such minor or such minor's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by such
lessor, renter or lender or his duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is granted for such child to purchase a vehicle, or to rent or borrow a
motorcycle or motor driven cycle from such renter, lessor or lender, and that such parent or guardian consents to such sale, and/or consents to the
renting, leasing or lending of a motorcycle or motor driven cycle to such child, and assumes full legal responsibility for acts or actions of such child in
the operation of any such motorcycle or motor driven cycle then or thereafter sold, rented, leased or lent to such child; and such responsibility and
commitment of such parent or guardian shall continue until it is revoked in writing by either parent or by said guardian by written instrument delivered to
such seller, lessor, renter or lender.
G. Passengers: No motorcycle or motor driven cycle shall be operated in such a manner that it carries more than one passenger in addition to the
operator, nor shall it be operated in any manner that places a passenger in front of the operator.
H. Side By Side Operation: Not more than two (2) motorcycles or motor driven cycles shall be operated side by side in any one lane of traffic upon any
street.
I. Prohibited, Dangerous Operations:
1. No motorcycle or motor driven cycle shall be operated in any manner so as to cause a disturbance in any area of the village. Touring, stunting, or
racing of motors are prohibited in any hospital or nursing home area and in residential areas.
2. No operator of a motorcycle or motor driven cycle shall engage in maneuvers, stunting or other operations dangerous to himself or his passenger or
to the persons or property of others; and except, when done for the better control of a vehicle, in emergencies or to maneuver rough passages of a
street, an operator must at all times keep body contact with the saddle or seat of such vehicle. (1965 Code § 10-15-2)
J. Handgrips: No person shall operate a motorcycle or motor driven cycle having handgrips higher than the height of the shoulder of the operator when the
operator is seated in the normal driving position astride that portion of the seat or saddle occupied by the operator. (1965 Code § 10-15-2; amd. 2009
Code)
9-9-3: BUSINESSES RENTING, LEASING OR LENDING MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR DRIVEN CYCLES:
A. Regulations: Any person engaging in the business of renting, leasing, or lending motorcycles or motor driven cycles shall:
1. License Required: First obtain a license as provided in this chapter.
2. Age Of Licensee; State License Required: Be twenty one (21) years of age, if an individual or manager of a corporation, and shall possess any
license required by the laws of the state of Illinois.
3. Application For License: Make application for a license on forms provided by the village clerk and containing the following:
a. If an individual, the name and address of the individual.
b. If a partnership, the name, residence and business address of each partner.
c. If a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized, and if a foreign corporation, whether authorized to
do business in the state of Illinois and the names of the principal officers, directors and local representatives, their residences and business
addresses.
d. The location where the business of renting motorcycles will be conducted, and the number of motorcycles that will be maintained on the premises
for rental purposes.
4. Location: Not conduct such business within any zoned residential district or within two hundred feet (200') thereof.
5. Records Kept: Maintain precise records of vehicle rental indicating the name of the person to whom the rental was made, his address, the registered
motor number of the vehicle rented or leased, together with other identifying data, the parent or guardian's written approval of a minor's application
and his agreement to be responsible for the action of such minor in the use of the vehicle, the date and hour of its rental and the time of its return to
the possession of the licensee.
6. Minors: Not rent to anyone under eighteen (18) years of age until he has on file in his possession an acknowledgment in writing, signed by either
parent of the applicant's legal guardian, in the presence of and witnessed by the licensee or his duly authorized agent, to the effect that permission is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 181/307
granted for such child to rent, lease or borrow a motorcycle or motor driven cycle from such renter, lessor or lender, and that such parent or guardian
consents to the renting, leasing or lending of a motorcycle or motor driven cycle to such child, and assumes full legal responsibility for acts or actions
of such child in the operation of any such motorcycle or motor driven cycle then or thereafter rented, leased or lent to such child, and such renter,
lessor or lender may rely upon such written consent as compliance with this chapter until it is revoked in writing by written revocation, signed by
either of such parents or by such guardian, and delivered to such renter, lessor or lender.
7. Driver's License Required: Rent vehicles only to persons who have and can show a valid motor vehicle operator's license.
8. Maintenance Of Vehicles: Maintain all motorcycles in a safe manner and provide each with all equipment required by law.
9. Hours Of Operation: Operate the business between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. There shall be no rental after
ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. or the returning of motorcycles between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight and eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. (1965
Code § 10-15-3)
10. Financial Responsibility: Provide proof of financial responsibility in compliance with all pertinent provisions of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-101
et seq. (1965 Code § 10-15-3; amd. 2009 Code)
11. Number Of Vehicles: Have only the number of rental motorcycles on the premises as provided for in his application.
12. Compliance With Laws: Comply with all ordinances and regulations of the village, including any reasonable regulations set by the chief of police to
effectuate this chapter. (1965 Code § 10-15-3)
B. License Fee: The annual license fee for a person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or lending motorcycles or motor driven cycles shall be as
provided in section 4-1-3 of this code. (1965 Code § 10-15-4; amd. 2009 Code)
9-9-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the terms or provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (1965 Code § 10-15-6)
Chapter 10
ABANDONED, WRECKED, INOPERABLE VEHICLES1
9-10-1: DEFINITIONS2:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
ABANDONED: Any vehicle in a state of disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition or any vehicle that has not been moved or
used for seven (7) consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
ANTIQUE OR HISTORICAL VEHICLE: Any vehicle twenty five (25) years of age or older.
DERELICT VEHICLE: Any inoperable, unregistered, discarded motor vehicle, regardless of title, having lost its character as a substantial property and left
unattended without justification on the owner's and, contrary to the public policy expressed in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-301.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle from which the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or
other parts have been altered, or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power. "Inoperable motor vehicle"
shall not include a motor vehicle which has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary
service or repair operations.
OWNER: A person who holds legal title of a vehicle, or in the event a vehicle is the subject of an agreement for conditional sale or lease thereof with the
right of purchase upon the performance of the conditions stated in the agreement and with the immediate right of possession vested in the conditional
vendee or lessee or in the event a mortgagor of such vehicle is entitled to possession, then such conditional vendee or lessee or mortgagor shall be
deemed the "owner" for the purposes of this chapter.
PARK OR PARKING: The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not.
PART: Any vehicle shell, essential part, component part or chassis.
PROPERTY: Any real property within the village which is not a street or highway.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of a highway and every way publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to
the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic.
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, whether subject to or
exempt from registration, excepting, however, bicycles, snowmobiles and devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. (1965 Code § 10-11-1;
amd. 2009 Code)
9-10-2: ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES PROHIBITED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 182/307
A. No person shall abandon a motor vehicle or other vehicle, or any part thereof, on any street or highway in the village. No person shall abandon a motor
vehicle or other vehicle, or any part thereof, on private or public property anywhere in the village.
B. A person commits abandonment of a vehicle when he is the owner of a vehicle that is within the village limits and that vehicle is:
1. Left unattended and is creating a traffic hazard or nuisance because of its position in relation to the highway;
2. Left unattended and its physical appearance is causing the impedance of traffic;
3. Left unattended upon any public way and is parked illegally and in violation of the law;
4. Occupying any portion of a street or alley in violation of a limited parking zone for a vehicle of five (5) times the permitted parking time;
5. Has not been moved or used for seven (7) consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted;
6. In a state of disrepair, rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition and its apparently deserted; or
7. Left unattended upon private property without the property owner's consent. (1965 Code § 10-11-2)
9-10-3: ABANDONED, INOPERABLE, JUNKED VEHICLES DECLARED A NUISANCE; EXEMPTIONS:
The presence of an abandoned, wrecked, dismantled, inoperable, rusted, junked or partially dismantled vehicle or parts thereof on any streets or public or
private property is hereby declared a public nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. This section shall not
apply to any vehicle enclosed within a building on private property or to any vehicle held in connection with a business enterprise actively operated with an
office on the subject premises and properly operated in the appropriate business zone pursuant to the zoning laws of the village. (1965 Code § 10-11-3)
9-10-4: ABANDONED, WRECKED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLES ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
A. Storing, Parking Or Leaving Dismantled Or Inoperable Vehicles Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any owner or any person in charge of a vehicle or
other personal property to park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any vehicle of any kind which is in an abandoned, wrecked,
dismantled, inoperable, rusted, junked or partially dismantled condition, whether attended or not, upon any street or other public property within the
village for a period of time in excess of seventy two (72) hours. (1965 Code § 10-11-3)
B. Notice Prior To Removal:
1. Any vehicle left at any place within the village on any street or other property in violation of subsection A of this section shall not be removed and
impounded as provided herein until the police department shall have given written notice to remove said vehicle seventy two (72) hours prior to the
intended removal date. Such notice shall be given by:
a. Affixing notice on such vehicle; and
b. Sending notice by mail to the owner of such vehicle at his last known address if the owner is reasonably ascertainable.
2. The notice shall contain the request for removal within the time specified in this chapter, and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with
the notice to remove, the village or its designee shall undertake such removal with the cost of removal to be levied against the owner. (1965 Code
§ 10-11-14)
C. Removal Of Vehicle: If, after proper notification as outlined in subsection B of this section, the vehicle is not removed by the owner, the police
department shall remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the corporate limits of the village on any village property which
reasonably appears to be in violation of subsection A of this section or lost, stolen or unclaimed. Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully claimed
or disposed of in accordance with 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-204 to 5/4-213. (1965 Code § 10-11-15; amd. 2009 Code)
9-10-5: ABANDONED, WRECKED OR INOPERABLE VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
A. Storing, Parking Or Leaving Dismantled Or Inoperable Vehicles Prohibited3: It shall be unlawful for any owner or any person in charge of a vehicle or
other personal property to park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of any vehicle of any kind which is in an abandoned, wrecked,
dismantled, inoperable, rusted, junked or partially dismantled condition, whether attended or not, upon any private property within the village for a
period of time in excess of seven (7) days. (1965 Code § 10-11-21)
B. Notice To Remove:
1. Whenever it comes to the attention of the police department that any nuisance, as defined in section 9-10-3 of this chapter exists in the village, a
notice in writing shall be served upon the occupant of the land where the nuisance exists, or in case there is no such occupant, then upon the owner
of the property or his agent, notifying them of the existence of the nuisance and requesting its removal in the time specified in subsection A of this
section. (1965 Code § 10-11-22)
2. The police department shall give notice of removal to the owner or occupant of the private property where the nuisance is located at least seven (7)
days before the time of compliance. Such notice shall be given by: (1965 Code § 10-11-23)
a. Affixing notice on such vehicle; and
b. Sending notice by mail to the owner of such vehicle at his last known address if the owner is reasonably ascertainable; and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 183/307
c. Sending notice by mail to the person owning or controlling the property on which such vehicle is located; or (1965 Code § 10-11-23; amd. 2009
Code)
d. If none of the above methods is possible, then by posting notice in a conspicuous place upon the private property on which the vehicle is located.
(1965 Code § 10-11-23)
3. The notice shall contain the request of removal within the time specified in this chapter, and the notice shall advise that upon failure to comply with
the notice to remove, the village or its designee shall undertake such removal with the cost of the removal to be levied against the owner or occupant
of the property. (1965 Code § 10-11-24; amd. 2009 Code)
C. Removal Of Vehicle; Notice:
1. If the violation described in the notice has not been remedied within the seven (7) day period of compliance, the chief of police or his designee shall
have the right to take possession of the vehicle and remove it from the premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere, hinder or refuse to
allow such person or persons to enter upon private property for the purpose of removing a vehicle under the provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code
§ 10-11-27)
2. Within forty eight (48) hours after removal of such vehicle, the police department shall give notice to the registered owner of the vehicle, if known,
and also to the owner or occupant of the private property from which the article was removed, that said vehicle or vehicles have been impounded or
stored for violation of this chapter. The notice shall give the location of where the vehicle or vehicles are stored and the costs incurred by the village
for removal. (1965 Code § 10-11-29)
D. Responsibility For Removal And Costs: Upon proper notice, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked, dismantled or inoperable vehicle and the owner or
occupant of the private property on which the same is located shall be responsible for its removal. In the event of removal and disposition by the
village, the owner or occupant of the private property where same is located shall be liable for the expenses incurred. (1965 Code § 10-11-28)
9-10-6: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The chief of police or his delegated representative may enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting such vehicle or
vehicles, posting notice thereon and removing and impounding such vehicle or vehicles, and it shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the chief of
police or his delegated representatives from entering upon private property for purposes of carrying out his duties hereunder or to interfere with him in the
lawful performance of his duties under the provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code § 10-11-4)
9-10-7: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. In addition to such penalty, fines shall be as
provided in section 9-2-4 of this title. (1965 Code § 10-11-5)
Footnote 1: See also subsection 13-12-2H of this code.
Footnote 2: 65 ILCS 5/11-40-3; 625 ILCS 5/4-301.
Footnote 3: 65 ILCS 5/11-40-3; 625 ILCS 5/4-201.
ARTICLE A. IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION PROVISIONS
9-10A-1: PROCEDURES TO BE OBSERVED:
The police department shall follow the provision of this article whenever a vehicle is towed for being in violation of this chapter. (1965 Code § 10-11-34)
9-10A-2: SEARCH OF VEHICLE; DISPOSITION OF CONTENTS:
All towed vehicles shall first be searched for valuables and the contents inventoried. Said inventory will be kept on file until the vehicle is disposed of. If the
vehicle is not reclaimed, the contents will be sold by the village and the proceeds deposited in the general fund of the village. (1965 Code § 10-11-35)
9-10A-3: REPORTS ON TOWED VEHICLES:
When a vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed listing the color, year of
manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number, license plate year and number of
registration sticker year and number displayed on the vehicle. The records shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed
to, reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. (1965 Code § 10-11-36)
9-10A-4: OWNER UNKNOWN:
A. Records Searches: When the police department cannot determine the identity of the registered owner or other legally entitled person, the department
will cause the motor vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by a directed communication to the Illinois secretary of state for the
purpose of obtaining the required ownership information. The department will further cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the state police to be
searched by a directed communication to the state police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. The information determined from this records
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 184/307
search will be used by the department in sending a notification by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the vehicle is
held, requesting that disposition be made, and setting forth information concerning the future public sale of the vehicle. (1965 Code § 10-11-37)
B. State Police Notified: When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to possession of a vehicle cannot be identified from the registration files
of the state, or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable, the police department shall notify the state police for the purpose of identifying
the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled to possession of the vehicle. The information obtained shall be used in sending notification by
certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising him where the vehicle is held, requesting that disposition be made and setting forth the
public sale information. (1965 Code § 10-11-38)
9-10A-5: OWNER KNOWN; REMOVAL REQUIRED:
When the registered owner or the person entitled to possession of the vehicle can be ascertained, such person shall remove the vehicle within seven (7)
days after being requested to do so by the police department under the notice provisions of this chapter. The penalty provided in section 9-10-7 of this
chapter shall be in addition to the provisions for removal and reclamation of such vehicle provided in this article. (1965 Code § 10-11-39)
9-10A-6: RECLAMATION OF VEHICLE:
A. Any time before a vehicle is sold at a public sale or disposed of as provided in this article, the owner or person legally entitled to its possession may
reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police department proof of ownership or proof of the right of possession to the vehicle. No vehicle shall be
released to the owner or other person under this subsection until all the towing and storage charges have been fully paid for such vehicle. The cost of
redemption shall include the actual cost and expense of said removal, in addition to storage charge of thirty five dollars ($35.00) per day for all
automobiles and trucks under a B class and fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for all trucks over a C class, and said costs and expenses shall be a lien in
favor of the village. (1965 Code § 10-11-40; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Any person claiming to be the owner of any impounded vehicle shall make written application therefor to the police department and shall furnish such
additional proof as may be required to establish said ownership. If he shall present to said department the proof of his ownership of said impounded
vehicle prior to the date of actual sale thereof, then the property itself shall be delivered to said owner under these conditions, but if said property has
been sold, then the department shall endorse its findings of ownership with a copy of the written application, which application and findings shall be
addressed to the village clerk and presented within one year after said sale, then such balance of the proceeds of the sale, after deductions, shall be
paid to said owner. (1965 Code § 10-11-45; amd. 2009 Code)
9-10A-7: DISPOSAL OF UNCLAIMED VEHICLES:
A. Owner Known: Whenever any abandoned vehicle is seven (7) years of age or newer, and remains unclaimed by the registered owner or other person
legally entitled to its possession for a period of thirty (30) days after notice has been given as provided in this article, the police department shall cause
it to be sold at public sale to the highest bidder. Notice of the time and place of the sale shall be posted in a conspicuous place for at least ten (10) days
prior to sale on the premises where the vehicle has been impounded. At least ten (10) days prior to the sale, the department shall cause a notice of the
time and place of the sale to be sent by certified mail to the registered owner or other persons known by the department to be legally entitled to the
possession of the vehicle. Such notice shall contain a complete description of the vehicle to be sold and what steps must be taken by any legally
entitled person to reclaim the vehicle. In those instances where the certified notification specified herein has been returned by the postal authorities to
the department due to the addressee having moved, or being unknown at the address obtained from the registration records of the state, the sending
of a second certified notice shall not be required. (1965 Code § 10-11-41)
B. Owner Unknown:
1. When the identity of the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of an abandoned, lost or unclaimed motor vehicle of
seven (7) years of age or newer cannot be determined by any means provided in this article, such vehicle may be disposed of in a manner
authorized by this article without notice to the registered owner or other person legally entitled to possession of the vehicle.
2. When an abandoned vehicle of more than seven (7) years of age is impounded, as specified in this article, it will be kept in custody for a minimum of
ten (10) days for the purposes of determining ownership, the contacting of the registered owner by the U.S. mail, public service or in person for a
determination of disposition, and an examination of the state police motor vehicle files for theft and wanted information. At the expiration of a ten (10)
day period, without the benefit of disposition information being received from the registered owner, the police department will authorize the disposal
of the vehicle as junk. (1965 Code § 10-11-42)
3. An exception to the above is provided for if, in the opinion of the police department, the vehicle has value of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more
and can be restored to safe operating condition. In this event, the police department may authorize its purchase as salvage, and the secretary of
state may issue a salvage certificate if the vehicle is bonded in the manner as provided to certificates of title under the 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/3-100 et seq. A vehicle classified as an antique vehicle may, however, be sold to a person desiring to restore it. (1965 Code § 10-11-42; amd. 2009
Code)
9-10A-8: REPORTS AFTER RECLAMATION OR DISPOSAL:
When a vehicle in the custody of the police department is reclaimed by the registered owner or other legally entitled person, or when the vehicle is sold at
public sale or otherwise disposed of as provided in this article, a report of the transaction will be maintained by the police department for a period of one
year from the date of sale or disposal. (1965 Code § 10-11-43)
9-10A-9: DISPOSITION OF PROCEEDS:
When a vehicle located within the village limits is authorized to be towed away by the police department or its agent, and disposed of as set forth in this
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 185/307
article, the proceeds of the public sale or disposition, after deduction of towing, storing and processing charges, shall be deposited with the village
treasurer and shall be kept in a separate fund for a period of one year from the date of receipt, and if, at the end of said year, the former owner of said
property has not made satisfactory proof of claim, then the balance of said proceeds of sale shall be credited to the corporate fund of the village. (1965
Code § 10-11-44)
9-10A-10: NONLIABILITY OF POLICE AND TOWING SERVICE:
No police officer or towing service owner, operator or employee shall be held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered
owner, former registered owner or his legal representative, or any person legally entitled to possession of the motor vehicle or other vehicle when the
vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided in this article. (1965 Code § 10-11-46)
Title 10
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY

Chapter 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
10-1-1: BENCHES:
As of the effective date hereof and with the exception of bus stops, advertising benches are prohibited on public ways and property in the village1. This
limitation shall not apply to decorative benches placed by the village. No decorative bench shall be installed or maintained without a permit obtained from
the village clerk. The permit application shall include the location of the proposed bench or benches and such other information as required by the village.
(1965 Code §§ 5-7-1, 5-7-2, 5-7-3; amd. 2009 Code)
Footnote 1: See also subsection 12-11-13A2 of this code.
Chapter 2
DES PLAINES RIVER
10-2-1: FISHING HOURS IN VILLAGE:
Fishing hours in the village are established as being permitted only from dawn to dusk. (1965 Code § 9-1-55)
10-2-2: VILLAGE RIVERWALK:
A. Definition: The area known as the "Lyons riverwalk" shall be generally defined as that geographic area adjacent to the Des Plaines River on the north,
Riverwalk Drive on the south, the Riverwalk Condominiums on the west and Joliet Avenue. The definition of the "Lyons riverwalk" shall include all
landscaped and grassy areas, service walks, improved areas, sea walls, pathways, parking areas and the Hofmann Tower, located within the defined
geographic area.
B. Regulations: The following regulations pertain to the Lyons riverwalk:
1. Fishing and camping shall be prohibited. Tents shall be prohibited except as permitted by the village for special events.
2. Open containers of alcohol or the consumption of alcohol shall be prohibited.
3. Physical entry into the fountain or placement into the fountain of any animals, litter, debris, human or animal waste, or any other material or
substance shall be prohibited.
4. Animals shall be prohibited except for those trained and assigned for assistance to the disabled, or domesticated canines kept on a leash at all
times. Animals that are otherwise brought lawfully onto the premises shall not be unlicensed, unvaccinated or constitute a nuisance or threat to
patrons of the riverwalk or to the property therein.
5. State statutes, county laws and regulations and village ordinances attendant upon illegal acts shall be enforceable at the Lyons riverwalk. (1965
Code § 9-1-60)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 186/307
Chapter 3
PARADES AND OUTDOOR EVENTS
10-3-1: APPROVAL REQUIRED:
No parade or procession shall be allowed on any public way, nor shall any open air meetings be held in or upon any public way or upon any ground
abutting upon any public way, until approval is first obtained from the president and board of trustees. In its approval, the president and board of trustees
shall consider if such parade, procession or open air meeting shall be held for any unlawful purpose, tend to be a breach of the peace or interfere with the
peace and quiet of the residents of the village and/or create the need for expenditure of village resources. As part of the approval process, the village
board may require reasonable conditions to be met, including whether the applicant shall provide a bond or insurance certificate, in an amount determined
by the board, for the purpose of naming the village as an additional insured or bonded party to protect the village from liability and indemnify the village for
liability arising from the event. Such insurance and/or bonding shall also serve as a guarantee against the failure of the applicant to reimburse the village
for personnel, cleanup, equipment and damage costs incurred by the village in association with the parade, procession or open air meeting. (1965 Code
§ 9-11-1)
10-3-2: APPLICATION FOR APPROVAL:
Application to conduct a parade or procession or open air meeting shall be made in writing to the village manager at least thirty (30) days prior to the event
and shall include the following:
A. Name of person and group in control and/or responsible for the event.
B. Purpose. (1965 Code § 9-11-2)
C. Route, provided on a map, detailing where the parade or procession is to proceed and/or identifying the location of the open air meeting. (1965 Code
§ 9-11-2; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Starting time and duration of the event.
E. Total amount of participants. (1965 Code § 9-11-2)
10-3-3: NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS:
No parade, procession or open air meeting shall be conducted with more than one hundred fifty (150) participants unless expressly waived by the
president and board of trustees. (1965 Code § 9-11-3)
10-3-4: EXCEPTIONS:
A. Funeral processions conducted by a licensed funeral director are exempted from the regulations contained within this chapter; however, funeral
directors requiring assistance from the village for traffic control shall be responsible for preplanning the event with the police department. All overtime
expenses associated with the provision of such service shall be reimbursed to the village by the funeral director.
B. The thirty (30) day submission rule may be waived by the village manager if, in his opinion, less than thirty (30) days are required for all preplanning and
presentation to the village board.
C. All parades, processions and open air meetings conducted or sponsored by the village are exempt from the requirements of this chapter.
D. When, in the opinion of the village attorney, the provisions of this chapter conflict with constitutionally guaranteed freedom of speech, such provisions
shall not apply. (1965 Code § 9-11-4)
10-3-5: REIMBURSEMENT OF COSTS TO VILLAGE:
The applicant, individual and/or group shall be required to reimburse the village for all personnel, cleanup, equipment and damage costs associated with
the parade, procession or open air meeting. A deposit may be required by the village board to offset such anticipated costs, which may be forfeited in the
event such costs are not directly reimbursed to the village. (1965 Code § 9-11-5)
10-3-6: PENALTIES:
A. Civil Penalty: Any person in violation of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). Such violations shall be adjudicated by a code hearing officer or court of competent jurisdiction. (1965 Code § 9-11-6)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 187/307
B. Criminal Penalty: Any person failing to heed the order of the police department through its duly appointed representatives to cease, discontinue or
disburse a parade, procession or open air meeting in violation of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor as provided by Illinois state statutes1.
(1965 Code § 9-11-7)
Footnote 1: See subsection 1-4-1B of this code.
Chapter 4
CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAYS
10-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this chapter, shall be construed as hereinafter defined:
DRIVEWAY: A bituminous, concrete or similarly surfaced area on a zoning lot upon which vehicles may be driven or parked and which may provide access
to parking spaces.
DRIVEWAY APRON: A hard surface area from a street pavement to a zoning lot which provides vehicular access to a driveway.
GARAGE: A detached accessory building or portion of a principal building used or occupied for the parking or temporary storage of automobiles, travel
trailers and/or boats of the occupants of the premises. (Ord. 04-21-15-O2, 4-21-2015)
10-4-2: EXISTING CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAYS:
No person shall be allowed to maintain a curb cut or driveway apron in an R-1, R-1A or R-2 zoning district unless the driveway apron provides access to a
driveway and a garage. (Ord. 04-21-15-O2, 4-21-2015)
10-4-3: CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAY PERMITS:
No person shall be allowed to construct a curb cut or driveway apron in an R-1, R-1A or R-2 zoning district without first obtaining a permit from the village.
A permit shall not be issued unless the purpose of the curb cut and driveway apron is to provide access to a driveway and a garage. (Ord. 04-21-15-O2, 4-
21-2015)
10-4-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day
that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. (Ord. 04-21-15-O2, 4-21-2015)
Title 11
WATER AND SEWER
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
