Chapter 1
MUNICIPAL UTILITY SERVICE
11-1-1: DESIGNATION:
The service of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village to its inhabitants shall be known as the "municipal utility service of the village
of Lyons". (1965 Code § 5-1-1)
11-1-2: RATES AND CHARGES:
A. Schedule Of Charges: The charges for the use of the municipal utility service of the village are hereby established as follows:
1. Monthly service charge for the municipal utility service of the village to single-family residential customers with meter sizes up to two inches (2") shall
be seventeen dollars fifty cents ($17.50). Included in the monthly charge are the first two thousand (2,000) gallons used per single-family residential
account, per month.
2. Monthly service charge for the municipal utility service of the village to multi-family residential (residential dwellings with 2 to 3 family units)
customers with meter sizes up to two inches (2") shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). Included in the monthly charge are the first two thousand
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 188/307
(2,000) gallons used per multi-family residential account, per month.
3. Monthly service charge for the municipal utility service of the village to commercial and large multi-family customers with meter sizes up to four
inches (4") shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). Included in the monthly charge are the first two thousand (2,000) gallons used per commercial and large
multi-family accounts, per month.
4. Monthly service charge for the municipal utility service of the village to commercial and large multi-family customers with meter sizes between four
(4) and six inches (6") shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Included in the monthly charge are the first two thousand (2,000) gallons used per
commercial and large multi-family accounts, per month.
5. Monthly service charge for the municipal utility service of the village to fire line service shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). Included in the monthly
charge are the first two thousand (2,000) gallons used per fire line meter, per month.
B. Water Rates: There are hereby established rates and charges for the use and consumption of water services supplied by the municipal utility service to
each and every consumer, based on the amount of water consumed or supplied, as shown by the consumer's water meter or meters as follows:
1. Residential Users:
a. First Four Thousand Gallons:
(1) Effective August 1, 2014, the first four thousand (4,000) gallons of water shall be included in each bimonthly residential billing period, and said
charge shall be charged to the account of such consumer. Each bimonthly billing period shall include two (2) consecutive monthly charges for a
total of four thousand (4,000) gallons.
b. Excess Of Four Thousand Gallons:
(1) Effective August 1, 2014, for all water in excess of four thousand (4,000) gallons used during each bimonthly residential billing period as
indicated by each meter, there shall be a charge of ten dollars fifty cents ($10.50) for each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of said four
thousand (4,000) gallons.
2. Commercial And Large Multi-Family Users:
a. First Four Thousand Gallons:
(1) Effective August 1, 2014, the first four thousand (4,000) gallons of water shall be included in each bimonthly commercial and large multi-family
billing period, and said charge shall be charged to the account of such consumer. Each bimonthly billing period shall include two (2) consecutive
monthly charges for a total of four thousand (4,000) gallons. (Ord. 07-02-14-O1, 7-2-2014)
b. Excess Of Four Thousand Gallons:
(1) Effective August 1, 2014, for water in excess of four thousand (4,000) gallons up to one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons used during each
bimonthly commercial and large multi-family billing period as indicated by each meter, there shall be a charge of fourteen dollars ($14.00) for
each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of said four thousand (4,000) gallons.
(2) Effective August 1, 2014, for water in excess of one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons up to one million (1,000,000) gallons used during
each bimonthly commercial and large multi-family billing period as indicated by each meter, there shall be a charge of nine dollars ($9.00) for
each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of said one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons. This rate for each one thousand (1,000) gallons
of water used in excess of said one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons up to one million (1,000,000) gallons shall be increased to the following
schedule:
August 1, 2015 $ 9.50
August 1, 2016 10.00
August 1, 2017 10.50
August 1, 2018 11.00
(3) Effective August 1, 2014, for water in excess of one million (1,000,000) gallons used during each bimonthly commercial and large multi-family
billing period as indicated by each meter, there shall be a charge of twelve dollars ($12.00) for each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of
said one million (1,000,000) gallons. (Ord. 11-19-14-O1, 11-19-2014)
C. Sewer Rates: There are hereby established rates and charges for the use of sewer services supplied by the municipal utility service to each consumer.
Each customer shall be billed fifty cents ($0.50) per one thousand (1,000) gallons billed in each bimonthly billing period.
D. Water Meter Fees: Village customers must pay all associated costs for new water meter installation as determined at the time the connection permit
application is submitted and which are separate from connection fees referenced below. These costs shall include the material cost of the meter and
necessary accessories, plus labor for installation and inspection. This water meter fee must be paid before the water service is turned on. For
customers who are not village residents, the cost shall be one hundred fifty percent (150%) of all associated costs for new water meter installation as
determined at the time the connection permit application is submitted, as referenced above. The water meter shall be the property of the village but the
user shall be responsible for maintenance of the meter and replacement of the meter for any reason, including, but not limited to, wilful or malicious
damage, negligence or damage sustained by freezing or caused by hot water backing through the same, except for the normal scheduled replacement
of the water meter by the village after the meter's normal life expectancy which is generally fourteen (14) to twenty (20) years.
E. Water And Sewer Connection Fees: There is hereby established the following water and sewer connection fees for each new user connecting to the
village's water and sewer systems:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 189/307
Single-family $4,000.00
2 and 3 unit residential 5,000.00
Nonresidential and residential in excess of 3 units:
1 inch service $ 6,000.00
2 inch service 15,000.00
3 inch service 35,000.00
4 inch service 50,000.00
6 inch service 75,000.00
(Ord. 07-02-14-O1, 7-2-2014)
11-1-3: BILLS FOR SERVICE; PAYMENT; DELINQUENCIES:
A. Clerk To Render Bills And Collect Charges: It is hereby made the duty of the village clerk to render bills for the municipal utility service and all other
charges in connection therewith, and to collect all monies due thereon. (1965 Code § 5-1-8; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Due Date; Late Charge: Bills for charges for municipal utility service shall be due and payable within fifteen (15) days from the date the bill is rendered.
An additional charge equal to ten percent (10%) of the bill or twenty five dollars ($25.00), whichever is higher, shall be added to all bills not paid within
fifteen (15) days from the date the bill is mailed. (Ord. 07-02-14-O1, 7-2-2014)
C. Payments:
1. Combined Bill; Payment In Full Required: Charges for municipal utility service, if itemized separately on one bill, shall be considered as for one
combined service, and no partial payment of the bill will be accepted as in payment of any separate item of the bill. (1965 Code § 5-1-7)
2. Payment By Check; Insufficient Funds:
a. The village clerk is authorized to accept checks, money orders or other drafts in payment of utility bills. (1965 Code § 5-1-13; amd. 2009 Code)
b. Any checks, money orders or other drafts that are not accepted by the bank for whatever reason will be deemed to be nonpayment of the bill, and
the provisions of subsections D and E of this section will be followed. For any checks, money orders or other drafts that are not accepted by the
bank and are returned to the village, the following penalties will apply:
(1) First occurrence: Twenty five dollars ($25.00).
(2) All subsequent occurrences within one year: Fifty dollars ($50.00). (1965 Code § 5-1-13)
c. The village clerk is authorized to request payment in cash if two (2) or more checks, money orders or other drafts have been returned by the bank
within one year. (1965 Code § 5-1-13; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Delinquent Charges A Lien: In the event charges for the municipal utility service are not paid within thirty (30) days after the rendition of the bill for such
service, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent, and thereafter, such delinquency charges shall constitute a lien upon
the real estate occupied by the user to whom the service is supplied, and the clerk is hereby authorized and directed to file a sworn statement showing
such delinquency in the office of the county recorder of deeds, and the filing of such statement shall be deemed notice for the payment of such charges
for such service. (1965 Code § 5-1-5)
E. Discontinuance Of Service For Unpaid Charges:
1. If the charges for the municipal utility service are not paid within thirty (30) days after rendition of the bill for such service, such service shall be
discontinued as provided by state law. (1965 Code § 5-1-6)
2. If the village shuts off or terminates water service for any reason, including for delinquent or unpaid charges, the user whose service is terminated
shall pay to the village a shutoff fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). If service to any user has been terminated for whatever reason, the user shall pay a fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00) to reestablish service. Service will not be reestablished to any user that has a delinquent bill. The village manager shall have
discretion to waive any applicable service termination or reestablishment fees as provided herein. (Ord. 09-21-2011-O2, 9-21-2011)
11-1-4: REVENUES:
A. Separate And Apart; Delivery To Treasurer: All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the municipal utility service shall be held by the
collector separate and apart from his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the village, and all of such sum, without any
deductions whatsoever, shall be delivered to the treasurer not more than ten (10) days after the receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals
as may from time to time be directed by the board of trustees. (1965 Code § 5-1-9)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 190/307
B. Waterworks And Sewerage Fund: The treasurer shall receive revenues from the municipal utility service and all other funds and monies incident to the
operation of such service, as the same may be delivered to him, and deposit the same in a separate fund, designated as the "waterworks and
sewerage fund", and the treasurer shall administer the fund in every respect in the manner provided by state law.
C. Accounts And Records; Annual Audit: The treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in
which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the municipal utility service, and at regular annual intervals, he shall
cause to be made an audit, by an independent auditing concern, of his books to show the receipts and disbursements of the municipal utility service.
(1965 Code § 5-1-10)
11-1-5: LIABILITY FOR SERVICE:
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the municipal utility service shall be jointly and severally liable for payment for the service
on such premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof
and the user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. (1965 Code § 5-1-3)
Chapter 2
WATER AND SEWER REGULATIONS1
11-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the
meanings indicated in this section:
SERVICE PIPE: Any pipe which is installed for the purpose of connecting the water mains of the village to the individual premises where water conveyed
there is to be consumed.
SEWER CONNECTION: That part of the sewerage system extending from the sewer main into the premises served.
SEWER MAIN: That part of the sewerage system intended to serve more than one sewer connection.
WATER MAIN: All that part of that water distribution system consisting of pipes and fittings used for the purpose of or in connection with the transmission
of water from the source thereof to the service pipes of the water users of the system. (1965 Code § 5-2-1)
11-2-2: CONNECTIONS, INSTALLATION AND REPAIR:
A. Water Mains And Service Pipes:
1. The village inspector(s) will inspect all connections made to any water main.
2. The service pipe shall be of copper and shall be a minimum of one inch (1") diameter.
3. All demolition projects or other discontinuation of water service lines shall require such service to be terminated and capped at the water main in a
manner approved by the village engineer.
4. All new construction shall require a new water service line in compliance with this chapter and the village plumbing code.
5. Existing lead based service lines or other water service lines not in conformance with this section and the village plumbing code may be ordered by
the building director or his designee to be replaced with conforming material as part of major rehabilitation or construction projects.
6. The installation, termination, replacement and service of underground water service shall be inspected and approved by the building director or his
designee prior to covering same. (1965 Code § 5-2-2)
7. A separate stop and waste cock shall be placed on the service pipe just inside the building wall on the influent side of the water meter. Such stops
shall be equal in quality to the service cock. (1965 Code § 5-2-3)
8. The service pipe from the service cock to the building and the stop and waste cock shall be of copper and shall be installed and properly maintained
by the owner. The owner shall keep the stop box free from dirt, stones or other substances that may or could prevent access to the service cock. The
buffalo box, shutoff or B box shall be located in the parkway or on village property. (1965 Code § 5-2-4)
B. Sewer Mains And Service Pipes:
1. The village inspector(s) will inspect all connections made to any sewer main.
2. The service line shall be SDR 26, cast iron or Amvet Nobell tile.
3. All demolition projects or other discontinuation of sewer connections shall require such connections to be capped at the main or in the parkway, as
required by the village engineer.
4. All new construction shall require a new sewer connection to the main in compliance with this chapter and the village plumbing code.
5. The installation, termination, replacement and service of sewer lines shall be inspected and approved by the building director or his designee prior to
covering same.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 191/307
C. Line Repairs: All repairs on service pipes from the service of shutoff boxes (which should be located between the curb line and sidewalk line or located
on village property) and plumbing systems of buildings shall be made at the expense of the owners of the premises served. Repairs to the service
pipes between the service and the shutoff box and the meter must be completed within ten (10) days of notification of the need for such repairs. The
village, through its village manager, village president, or by an employee directed to do so by the village manager or village president, is authorized to
disconnect water service to any building when the owner or occupant thereof refuses or fails to complete repairs within the time prescribed. The village
may, in case of emergency, repair any service pipe, and if this is done, the cost of such repair work shall be repaid to the village by the owner of the
premises served. Failure to repay said cost will result in a lien being placed against the property. (1965 Code § 5-2-2)
11-2-3: TURNING WATER ON AND OFF:
A. No licensed plumber or other person shall interfere in any way with service pipes installed by the water department, and no such person shall be
permitted to turn water on or off at the service cock, except for the purpose of testing his work, in which case, the service cock shall be left in the same
condition and position as he found it. Any plumber called upon to shut off water and drain pipes in any premises shall do so inside the building only.
B. Where the water for any reason has been turned off by the village, no person except authorized representatives of the village may turn it on again.
Whenever this rule is violated, the village may shut off the water at the buffalo box at the main, and the owner shall pay the entire expense incurred by
the village for doing this work before the water may be turned on again. (1965 Code § 5-2-5)
11-2-4: METERS2:
A. Metered Water Required; Location: A proper connection shall be provided upon each property supplied with water in an accessible location at least
three feet (3') above the floor and in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works or authorized representative. Every water customer shall have
a water meter, approved by the director of public works, attached to his water supply pipes at his own expense. On premises where there is no
basement or cellar, the meter shall be installed in the utility room or outside in a meter pit, the location of which shall be approved by the director of
public works. Where it is necessary to set the meter in a pit, such pit shall be built at the owner's expense, as directed by the director of public works,
and to his satisfaction. (1965 Code § 5-2-6)
B. Damage To, Interfering With Meter Prohibited: No person, except an authorized employee of the village, shall break or injure any water meter seal or
change the location of, alter or interfere in any way with any meter. (1965 Code § 5-2-7)
C. Responsibility For Care And Protection From Damage: The owner or occupant of the premises where a meter is installed shall be held responsible for
its care and protection from freezing and from injury or interference by any person. In case of injury or damage to the meter, or in case of its stoppage
or imperfect operation, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give immediate notice to the village manager.
D. Bypassing Meter Prohibited: All water furnished by the village and used on any premises must pass through the meter, and the owner or occupant shall
not permit any bypass or connection around the meter to be constructed or maintained.
E. Inoperable Meter; Estimate Of Charges: If any meter becomes out of order or fails to register, the consumer will be charged at the average quarterly
consumption rate as shown by the meter over the period of the preceding four (4) quarters when the meter was accurately registering. (1965 Code § 5-
2-8)
F. Testing Meters:
1. Water meters one and one-half inches (11/2") or larger will be tested for accuracy by the Village in 1993 and every five (5) years thereafter. Fifty
percent (50%) of the cost of testing the meter will be paid by the property owner and the other fifty percent (50%) by the Village. In the event that the
meter is found to be reading more than two percent (2%) less water than actually passes through it, the cost of repair and retest of the meter will be
paid by the property owner. If the meter is found to read more than two percent (2%) more water than actually passes through it, then the cost of
repair and retest will be paid by the Village. (1965 Code § 5-2-9)
2. The fee for testing meters at the request of the owner for meters one and one-half inches (11/2") to six inches (6") shall be two hundred twenty
dollars ($220.00) for testing and four hundred dollars ($400.00), plus parts, for testing and repair. (1965 Code § 5-2-9; amd. 2009 Code)
3. The fee to test or repair any other size meter shall be determined by the Director of Public Works and approved by the Village Board.
4. If, after testing, the meter is found to register greater than five percent (5%) more water than actually passes through it, then said meter shall be
replaced by the Village, and the fee advanced will be refunded to the owner. (1965 Code § 5-2-9)
G. Remote Read Meters:
1. Effective May 1, 2018 every water customer shall allow the Village to attach a remote read water meter, approved by the Director of Public Works, to
the customer's supply pipes at the Village's expense. Any customer who fails to allow the Village to attach a remote read meter by May 1, 2018 shall
pay fifty dollars ($50.00) per month in addition to all other charges for water assessed by the Village and shall also pay a one time fee of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the installation of the remote read water meter.
2. Effective May 1, 2021 every water customer shall allow the Village to attach a remote read water meter, approved by the Director of Public Works, to
the customer's supply pipes at the Village's expense. Any customer who fails to allow the Village to attach a remote read meter by May 1, 2021 shall
pay two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month in addition to all other charges for water assessed by the Village and shall also pay a one time fee of
nine hundred sixty five dollars ($965.00) for the installation of the remote read water meter. (Ord. 01-16-18-O1, 1-16-2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 192/307
11-2-5: STEAM BOILERS:
No steam boiler shall be directly connected to the service pipe, and before water may be supplied to any such installation, the owner shall make such
provisions thereof as may be required by the Director of Public Works. (1965 Code § 5-2-11)
11-2-6: FIRE PROTECTION:
A. Where pipes are provided for fire protection on any premises or where hose connections for fire apparatus are provided, each such connection or
opening of the service pipes shall have not less than twenty five feet (25') of fire hose constantly attached thereto, and no water shall be taken through
such opening or hose for any purpose other than for extinguishing fires, except for the purpose of testing such fire equipment. No such test of fire
equipment may be conducted unless a special permit is first secured from the Fire Chief.
B. Fire hydrants may be opened and used only by the Village or by such persons as may be specifically authorized by the Village.
C. No person shall, in any manner, obstruct or prevent free access to any fire hydrant by placing or storing, temporarily or otherwise, any object or
materials of any kind within twenty feet (20') of the same. (1965 Code § 5-2-13)
11-2-7: MISREPRESENTATION; IMPROPER USE OF WATER; WATER LEAKS:
A. The water supply may be cut off from any premises if such water service was obtained through misrepresentation or if any unauthorized use or wilful
waste of water is found.
B. No deductions shall be made nor rebates allowed to any consumer of water due to any leakage in any water pipe, tank, or device. The amount of water
registered by any meter measuring water supplied to any building, structure or premises shall be charged and paid for in full, irrespective of whether
such water was lost by leakage, accident or otherwise. (1965 Code § 5-2-10)
11-2-8: OUTSIDE WATER USE RESTRICTIONS:
The President and Board of Trustees recognize that it is not necessary for established lawns to be sprinkled every day from May 15 through September 15
of each calendar year, and further, under certain specified circumstances, other nonessential outside water uses must be curtailed as follows:
A. Hours: Lawn sprinkling and watering is permitted from one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and from six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. until twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Sunday, Wednesday and Friday of each week from May 14 through September 15, unless a total
ban is ordered by the village president as authorized herein.
B. Outside Use Prohibited: The village president is authorized to order the temporary cessation of lawn sprinkling, vehicle washing and other nonessential
outside water uses when the water supply or water pressure of the village is at a level inconsistent with the continuation of such uses and poses a
serious hazard to the public health, safety and welfare and endangers the ability to supply sufficient water for firefighting and other essential purposes.
(1965 Code § 5-2-12)
C. Penalty: Any person who refuses to cease or curtail using water for unauthorized purposes or who uses water for sprinkling or watering on times and
days other than those authorized shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1965 Code § 5-1-12;
amd. 2009 Code)
11-2-9: USE OF NONPOTABLE WATER PERMITTED3:
Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit the use of nonpotable water for gardening, irrigation and similar uses. (1965 Code § 5-2-19)
11-2-10: IMPROPER USE, DAMAGE TO SYSTEMS; RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE:
A. No person shall put any substance which is or may become explosive or any other improper substance into a sewer or any connection leading to a
sewer that will tend to clog or stop free passage of substances usually conveyed through or in sewers or drains. (1965 Code § 5-2-14)
B. Any person who shall wilfully or carelessly break, damage, deface or destroy any sewer, cesspool, culvert, catch basin, manhole, water pipe or hydrant
laid or placed in, upon or under any thoroughfare or public place within the village shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1965 Code § 3-8-1)
C. It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or cause to be connected any drain carrying or to carry any toilet, sink basement drain, septic tank,
cesspool, industrial waste or any fixture or device discharging polluting substance to any stormwater drain or sewer. (1965 Code § 3-8-2)
D. Whenever a connection has been made to the sewer system of the village, it shall be the responsibility and expense of the owner of the property served
by such connection to maintain said service from the property to the village sewer system. (1965 Code § 5-2-15)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 193/307
11-2-11: EXCAVATIONS:
Whenever it shall be necessary to open the street for the purpose of inspection or repair of any sewer line or connection, or for the purpose of inspection
or repair of any water line or connection, such opening shall be made, and the village inspector(s) will inspect for proper connection and repair prior to
backfill and street restoration. Said work shall be paid for by the property owner. (1965 Code § 5-2-16)
11-2-12: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
A. Inspections: The director of public works, or any of his authorized agents, shall have free access at all reasonable hours to inspect any premises
supplied with water, and the fact that the owner or occupant of such premises accepts and uses water supplied by the village shall constitute a consent
to the making of such inspection. No person shall refuse to admit said authorized representatives to any premises for such purpose. In case any
authorized representative is refused admittance, or is in any way hindered in making the necessary inspection or examination, the water may be turned
off from such premises after giving twenty four (24) hours' written notice served either personally or by first class mail upon the owner or occupant
thereof. If the village discontinues water service for failure of the water consumer to respond to a request to enter the premises, the property owner
shall remain responsible for the established turnon fee. (Ord. 08-19-08-02, 8-19-2008)
B. Installation And Maintenance Of Electronic Registering Meters: The director of public works, and any of his authorized agents, including contractors
authorized by the village, shall further have free access at all reasonable hours for the purpose of installing and maintaining thereafter new electronic
registering water meters on all premises in the village, and the fact that the owner or occupant of such premises accepts and uses water supplied by
the village shall constitute a consent to such installation and maintenance. No person shall refuse to admit said authorized representatives to any
premises for such purpose. In case any authorized representative is refused admittance or is in any way hindered in making the necessary installation
or maintenance, the water may be turned off from such premises after giving twenty four (24) hours' written notice, served either personally or by first
class mail, upon the owner or occupant thereof. (1965 Code § 5-2-12)
11-2-13: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Pursuant to subsection 11-2-7A of this chapter, the water supply may be cut off from any premises if such water service was obtained through
misrepresentation or if any unauthorized use or wilful waste of water is found.
Should it be determined that water service has been disconnected without authorization from the village for the purpose of misrepresentation,
unauthorized use or waste, and should the village cut the water supply of the premises where such violation has occurred, the village may execute the
following actions:
1. Charge the customer for the cost of a new replacement meter.
2. Charge the customer for all labor costs for the replacement of a new meter.
3. Charge a punitive fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) (appealable to the village adjudicator).
4. Charge the reconnection fee as established in this chapter.
5. Charge for all administrative costs.
B. Any violation of this chapter by any individual, company, partnership or other entity shall be punishable by a maximum seven hundred fifty dollar
($750.00) fine per occurrence. The village shall also have the right, upon proper notice to the responsible owner or occupant and failure of any such
entity to correct a violation of this chapter, to correct such violation(s) at cost to the property owner if the violation in question presents an immediate
threat to the life, safety and/or welfare of any individual. The village shall further have the right to shut off the affected utility service in the event that a
violation of this chapter is an immediate threat to the life, safety and/or welfare of any individual and/or such disconnection is necessary to preclude
water loss. (Ord. 08-19-08-02, 8-19-2008)
Footnote 1: See subsection 12-2-16C of this code for tap fees and permit fees.
Footnote 2: See subsection 12-2-16C of this code for meter costs.
Footnote 3: See chapter 3 of this title for cross connection control; see section 12-6-4 of this code for prohibited use of groundwater as a potable water
supply.
Chapter 3
CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
11-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following definitions:
AWWA: The American Water Works Association.
AWWA STANDARDS: The standards described in AWWA C506-78 (R83) and any related provisions.
APPROVED CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL DEVICE: A device that is approved by the Illinois plumbing code for connecting a private water system to
a public water system to prevent possible infiltration from a private water system to a public water system.
APPROVED INSPECTOR: A person certified and approved by the IEPA as a cross connection control device inspector.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 194/307
APPROVED WATER METER: A water meter issued by the village of Lyons for purposes of connecting a private water system to a public water system.
CODE: The Illinois plumbing code and the administrative regulations authorized and promulgated pursuant to the Illinois plumbing code.
CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER: The person designated and approved by the Lyons corporate authorities as the village of Lyons code enforcement
officer or equivalent office and his/her designee.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any connection of a private water system to a public water system in the village of Lyons.
IEPA: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
PRIVATE WATER SYSTEM: All mains, pipes and structures and appurtenances that are designed and intended to receive for private use water distributed
from a public water system and which is not part of the public water system.
PROPERTY: Any separate parcel, zoning lot, building or unit of a building that is served by a separate connection to a public water main.
PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM: A public supply of potable water for distribution to the public including all mains, pipes and structures and appurtenances
owned and/or maintained by the village through which water is obtained and distributed to the public including, but not limited to, intakes and cribs,
reservoirs, storage tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended for use for the purpose of furnishing potable water to the
public. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-2: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
A. No person shall connect, maintain a connection or allow a connection of a private water system to the public water system in the village without the
knowledge and approval of the code enforcement officer, and all such connections shall be subject to inspection pursuant to the Illinois plumbing code
at the time that a connection is made and thereafter as provided in this chapter.
B. No connection to the public water system shall be allowed in the village unless:
1. An approved water meter is installed;
2. The connection is made at the point of the installed water meter;
3. The connection is made with an approved cross connection control device installed at the water meter connection; and
4. The connection is otherwise established and maintained in compliance with the Illinois plumbing code.
C. No water from a private water system shall be allowed to enter a public water system regardless of the connection used. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-3: NEW CROSS CONNECTIONS:
A. New cross connections shall be made only as follows:
1. Cross connection shall be made only at the water meter;
2. Only approved cross connection control devices shall be used;
3. The approved cross connection control devices shall be installed only by a licensed plumber;
4. The approved cross connection control devices shall be installed only in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, the code and all other
applicable IEPA or other regulations; and shall be inspected and tested by an approved inspector on the date of installation, and the test results shall
be reported to the code enforcement officer within ten (10) days from the date of testing; and
5. All new cross connection devices shall be inspected at the time of installation.
B. If the inspection reveals the cross connection control device is not working properly, the device shall be serviced as follows:
1. For fixed air gap separation devices, any corrections to eliminate improperly bypassed air gaps and other service required for proper functioning of
the device shall be made within forty eight (48) hours after the test indicating the need for service.
2. For dual check assemblies, any service required for proper functioning of the device shall be performed within fifteen (15) days after the test
indicating the need for service.
3. For reduced pressure principle backflow prevention devices, any service required for proper functioning of the device shall be performed within five
(5) days after the test indicating the need for service. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-4: EXISTING CROSS CONNECTIONS:
A. Improved Commercial And Industrial Property Or Residential Property:
1. Every owner and occupant of improved commercial and industrial property or of residential property which includes one or more of the following: an
underground lawn irrigation system, an automatic fire suppression system, a water heater which exceeds one hundred fifty thousand (150,000)
BTUs, shall have an affirmative obligation to arrange an initial inspection and testing of that property's cross connection by an approved inspector in
accordance with this chapter and the code, and such inspections and testing shall be completed prior to January 1, 2009, in order to determine:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 195/307
a. Whether the cross connection was made only at the water meter;
b. Whether an approved water meter was used;
c. Whether an approved cross connection control device was used;
d. Whether the approved cross connection control device, if any, was installed in compliance with the code and all applicable IEPA and AWWA
standards and is working properly; and
e. Whether any danger of infiltration exists from the private water system to the public water system.
2. Every owner and occupant of improved commercial and industrial property or of residential property as described in subsection A1 of this section
shall have an affirmative duty to submit or cause to be submitted an inspection report and testing results generated by an approved inspector to the
code enforcement officer office by January 1, 2009, and by January 1 of every year thereafter.
B. Other Properties:
1. The code enforcement officer is hereby given the authority to identify properties, other than commercial and industrial properties and residential
properties on which an underground sprinkler system is installed, to be inspected and tested for the purposes identified in subsection A1 of this
section.
2. Within sixty (60) days from the mailing of a written notice, put in the regular mail to the address of the property, from the code enforcement officer
that the property has been identified for cross connection inspection and testing, the owner and/or occupant of such property shall have the
affirmative duty to schedule and complete an inspection of the property with an approved inspector for the same purposes described in subsection
A1 of this section.
3. The owner and/or occupant whose property has been identified for cross connection inspection and testing shall submit or cause to be submitted an
inspection report and testing results to the office of the code enforcement officer within ten (10) days after the date of initial inspection and testing or
within seventy (70) days from the notice mailing date, whichever is sooner.
4. The code enforcement officer shall have the additional authority to investigate and test commercial, industrial and other properties served by the
public water system for the same purposes identified in subsection A1 of this section and to survey the results of all investigations and testing.
5. If any cross connection is discovered that is not in compliance with this chapter, the property owner/occupant shall bring the property into compliance
with this chapter by removing any connection and/or cross connection control device and/or water meter that is noncompliant and/or by installing an
approved water meter and/or an approved cross connection control device within sixty (60) days of mailing of a written notice of the noncompliance,
at his/her own expense. All newly installed approved cross connection control devices shall be installed, inspected and tested as provided in
subsection A1 of this section. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-5: INSPECTIONS AND TESTING:
A. Annual Testing Required: Owners and/or occupants of all commercial and industrial property, or residential property as described in subsection 11-3-4A
of this chapter, having a cross connection shall have an affirmative obligation to retain an approved inspector to conduct an inspection and testing of
the cross connection annually prior to January 1 of each year, and the inspection report and test results shall be reported to the office of the code
enforcement officer annually by February 1 of each year. Inspection and testing of an approved cross connection control device shall occur more
frequently than annually if suggested by the manufacturer of the device.
B. Reports And Records:
1. The code enforcement officer shall maintain original records of the inspection and testing reports and make them available for inspection by IEPA
personnel in accordance with state statute, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4(e).
2. Each cross connection control device installed on property in the village shall have a tag attached listing the date of the most recent inspection and
testing, the name of inspector, and type and date of repairs.
3. As a part of the inspection and testing reports, a maintenance log for each cross connection control device installed in the village shall be maintained
by the owner and/or occupant of each property that contains a cross connection, and the log shall, at a minimum, include:
a. Date of each test.
b. Name and approval number of persons performing the inspection or test.
c. Test results/inspection.
d. Repairs or servicing required.
e. Services performed and date completed.
4. All inspection and testing records shall be filed with the office of the code enforcement officer after an initial inspection and testing and on an annual
basis in order for the owner and/or occupant of each property that contains a cross connection to remain compliant with this chapter. (Ord. 07-15-08-
02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-6: REQUIRED INFORMATION:
All owners and/or occupants of any property in the village served by a connection to the public water system of the village shall furnish to the code
enforcement officer any information requested regarding the cross connection, water meter, private water system or water use on such property within ten
(10) days of a written request for such information. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 196/307
11-3-7: THREAT OF CONTAMINATION; DISCONNECTION FROM SYSTEM:
A. Any illegal or improper cross connection, device or installation that poses a threat of contamination to the public water system, and any violation of this
chapter, the code or the AWWA standards shall be considered a danger to the public health, safety and welfare.
B. If the code enforcement officer determines that a property has an illegal or improper cross connection, device or installation in violation this chapter, the
code or the AWWA standards, and the owner and/or occupant has failed or refused to comply with the provisions of this chapter, the code enforcement
officer may give notice in writing to the owner and/or occupant of the violation and that the water service to the property may be discontinued on a date
not less than five (5) days from the date of the notice (hereinafter "5 day notice") if the owner and/or occupant does not take immediate and appropriate
steps to eliminate the violation and proceed diligently to bring the property into compliance with this chapter.
C. The code enforcement officer is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service to any property on which a known or presumed violation of
this chapter exists, under the following circumstances:
1. At any time following the issuance of a five (5) day notice, if the property owner and/or occupant fails to take immediate and appropriate steps in
compliance with this chapter to eliminate the violation and/or fails to proceed diligently to bring the property into compliance with this chapter;
2. At any time following the issuance of a five (5) day notice if, in the code enforcement officer's determination, discontinuation of water service is
necessary to eliminate a threat of contamination to the public water system that is likely, even if the property owner and/or occupant has taken
immediate and appropriate steps to eliminate the violation and is proceeding diligently to bring the property into compliance with this chapter and to
eliminate the danger of contamination of the public water system;
3. Upon verbal notice, without delay, if the code enforcement officer or IEPA and discontinuation of water service is necessary to eliminate an imminent
hazard to the public health, safety and welfare; or
4. Without notice to any party, if the code enforcement officer or IEPA determines that contamination of the public water system is immediate and
discontinuation of water service is necessary to eliminate an immediate hazard to the public health, safety and welfare.
D. If water service is discontinued without written notice, the code enforcement officer shall provide written notice as soon as practicable following the
discontinuation of water service identifying the reason for discontinuation and of the steps that are necessary to restore the water service.
E. Water service that is discontinued shall not be restored until all illegal and improper cross connections, devices or installations and any dangers to the
public health, safety and welfare have been eliminated, any violations of this chapter have been remedied, and a reconnection fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) is paid to the village.
F. Neither the village nor any employee or agent of the village, including the code enforcement officer, shall be liable to any person for injury, damages or
lost revenues that may result from discontinuation of the public water supply to a property in accordance with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 07-15-08-
02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-8: PRESUMPTION OF ILLEGAL OR IMPROPER CROSS CONNECTION:
If any property owner and/or occupant fails or refuses to schedule and allow an inspection, to submit the inspection and testing results or to provide other
information that is requested as provided in this chapter, the property shall be presumed to have an illegal or otherwise improper connection to the public
water system as defined by applicable IEPA and AWWA standards and regulations. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-9: RESPONSIBILITY FOR CLEANUP COSTS:
If any contamination of the public water system occurs as a result of an illegal or otherwise improper cross connection, cross connection device or
installation as defined by applicable IEPA and AWWA standards, the owner(s) and/or occupant(s) of property from which the contamination occurred shall
be jointly and severally liable for the costs to eliminate the contamination and to clean up and purify the public water system and all other costs associated
with and resulting from such contamination including, but not limited to, the initial and follow up testing of the system as deemed necessary and
appropriate by the code enforcement officer and/or the IEPA. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-10: ADMINISTRATIVE FEE:
The village hereby establishes an annual administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for all industrial, commercial, and residential properties as
described in subsection 11-3-4A of this chapter for the recordation and administration of this chapter and other services provided by the village in
compliance with the Illinois plumbing code, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 320/35, and the Illinois administrative code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890.
(Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
11-3-11: VIOLATIONS; FINES AND OTHER REMEDIES:
A. Violations: In addition to the failure to comply with the terms of this chapter as noted herein, the following actions shall also be considered violations of
this chapter:
1. The making of any statement, representation, or certification that a person knows or should have known to be false in response to any request for
information or in any application, record, report, plan, or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this chapter;
2. The interference or tampering in any way with any inspection or test performed pursuant to this chapter; and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 197/307
3. The interference or tampering with any properly installed approved cross connection control device.
B. Fines: Any person who is found to have violated any provision of this chapter may be fined in amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues. A fine or fines may be imposed separately from and in addition to the discontinuation of water service.
C. Other Remedies: In addition to a fine or fines and/or discontinuation of water service, the village may seek an injunction or other remedies available as
deemed necessary and appropriate by the code enforcement officer. (Ord. 07-15-08-02, 7-15-2008)
Title 12
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Footnotes - Click any footnote link to go back to its reference.
Footnote 1: See title 7, chapter 3 of this code for alarm system regulations.
Chapter 1
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT1
12-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
BUILDING DIRECTOR: An individual or department designated by the village manager.
MINOR VIOLATIONS: Violations that are primarily cosmetic or aesthetic in nature that cannot be cured at the time of inspection due to weather or other
just cause. (1965 Code § 7-16-1)
12-1-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
A. All persons, partnerships, corporations and other entities shall comply with the provisions enumerated in this title including, but not limited to, all
referenced codes. (1965 Code § 7-1-4)
B. Any individual, partnership, company, corporation or other entity acting in a licensed professional capacity with regard to the sale or occupancy of
property shall be responsible for ascertaining the requirements of this chapter and not be party to a circumvention of same. (1965 Code § 7-16-9)
12-1-3: CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY2:
A. Certificate Required: A certificate of occupancy is required prior to each new occupancy by commercial, industrial or similar uses in all nonresidential
zoning districts within the village and/or occupancies requiring a village business license. A new occupancy shall include a change in business
ownership, change in use and/or change in occupancy. (1965 Code § 7-16-2)
B. Compliance Required: A standard condition for all certificates of occupancy shall require all premises and buildings to be maintained in compliance with
village building, zoning and fire codes, as well as the latest version of the village property maintenance code. (1965 Code § 7-16-6)
C. Inspections:
1. An inspection shall be performed by the building director prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Such inspection shall verify that the
property is in compliance with all building, fire, property maintenance and zoning regulations of the village. A certificate of occupancy shall not be
issued without such verification. An exception to this requirement is that a conditional certificate may be issued if there are minor violations, and the
new owner or occupant provides a signed affidavit accepting responsibility for correcting such violations within a specified period time as determined
by the building director, not to exceed six (6) months.
2. The primary standard for occupancy inspections shall be the latest version of the ICC international property maintenance code, the village zoning
ordinance, the village sign ordinance and the latest version of the NFPA life safety code. Applicable sections of the village building, electrical,
plumbing and mechanical codes may also be applied. (1965 Code § 7-16-2)
D. Suspension Of Certificate: A certificate of occupancy shall be suspended in the event that an owner or occupant of the building or premises for which
the certificate has been issued is convicted or found responsible by a court or code hearing department of competent jurisdiction of being in violation of
one or more of the codes enumerated in subsection B of this section. The subject property shall thereafter not be occupied and not operate in any
manner until such time as the attendant violations have been cured and the corrections verified by the building director. (1965 Code § 7-16-7)
12-1-4: INSPECTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 198/307
A. Real Estate Sale Inspections:
1. Certificate Required: All owners of real estate shall be required to obtain a certificate of sale inspection prior to selling, changing or transferring
ownership to another entity.
2. Failure To Obtain Certificate: In the event that a seller fails to obtain the requisite inspection certificate, he or she shall be in violation of this chapter
and shall be subject to the penalties contained herein, and in the event that a seller fails to obtain the requisite inspection certificate, the purchaser or
transferee shall become responsible for obtaining all inspections and compliances required by this chapter.
3. One- And Two-Family Uses: A certificate of sale inspection shall only be issued for one- and two-family uses upon verification by the building director
that the real property and all improvements are in substantial compliance with the latest version of the ICC international property maintenance code
and current village zoning ordinance.
4. Multi-Family, Commercial, Industrial And Similar Uses: A certificate of sale inspection shall only be issued for multi-family, commercial, industrial and
similar types of uses upon verification by the building director that the real property and all improvements are in substantial compliance with the latest
version of the ICC international property maintenance code, village zoning ordinance and currently adopted building, electrical, plumbing, sign and
mechanical codes.
5. Conditional Certificate: A conditional certificate may be issued if there are only minor violations, and the new owner provides a signed affidavit
accepting responsibility for correcting such violations within a specified period time as determined by the building director, not to exceed six (6)
months. (1965 Code § 7-16-3)
B. Rental Inspections:
1. The building code official is authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and
premises located within the village, not otherwise occupied, or to be occupied, by the owner in order that the building code official may perform his or
her duty of safeguarding the health, safety, and welfare of the occupants of any such dwellings and of the general public, preserve property values,
and enhance property tax revenues. All inspections made under this subsection will be performed in strict compliance with the guidelines established
in this subsection.
2. The building code official is authorized to enter, examine and survey the interior of the dwelling unit under the following circumstances:
a. Upon a vacancy or change of occupancy at the property;
b. Upon owner or tenant request or complaint; or
c. When there is probable cause to believe a code violation may exist. Probable cause may exist, but is not limited to, observation of the exterior of
the property which leads the building official or his authorized representative to conclude that code violations may exist on the interior of the
property, or upon request of the fire or police departments, who, after entering the interior of the property, have reason to believe that building code
violations may exist.
Under subsections B2a and B2b of this section, the building code official or his authorized representative will strictly limit the inspection to the
specific dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit that is changing or has changed occupancy or for which the owner or tenant has identified in his or
her complaint for determining whether or not there is compliance with all relevant provisions of this title. Under subsection B2c of this section, the
building code official or his authorized representative may examine and survey all dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and the premises of the
reported property, for the purpose of determining whether or not there is compliance with all relevant provisions of this title.
3. No inspection will be made under this subsection unless and until the building code official has provided the owner of the dwelling, dwelling unit, or
rooming unit and, if occupied, the tenant of the dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit with at least three (3) business days' written notice of an
inspection. The notice must be either personally delivered or mailed, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the owner and to the
address of the property to be inspected. The notice, at a minimum, must:
a. Identify the property to be inspected and date and general time frame of the scheduled inspection, set no more than within a three (3) hour block
and in no event any earlier than nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or later than four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., Monday through Friday,
b. Provide the basis for the inspection, with specific reference to the relevant basis set forth in subsection B2 of this section,
c. Explain the scope of the inspection, with specific reference to all relevant building and life safety codes establishing the code requirements, and
d. Provide the name and contact information of the building code official or his authorized representative, with an invitation to contact the official or
representative with any questions, concerns, or requests to reschedule the inspection date and time.
4. The owner or the owner's authorized agent and the occupant, if occupied on the date of inspection, of every dwelling, dwelling unit and rooming unit
will give the building code official or his authorized representative access to such dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit and its premises upon
presentation of proper identification and a written schedule of the specific areas and facilities to be inspected, examined and surveyed on a form
prepared and signed by the building code official. If any owner or the owner's authorized agent, or the occupant, if occupied as of the date of the
inspection, refuses to permit access or entry into such dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit or any part thereof with respect to a scheduled
inspection authorized by this section, the building code official will file a petition setting forth the basis for the inspection with and obtain a warrant to
inspect or an order from a court of competent jurisdiction authorizing the building code official or his authorized representative entry into the property
for the purposes of conducting the scheduled inspection.
5. Owners of nonowner occupied dwellings, dwelling units, or rooming units must contact the building code official after a dwelling, dwelling unit, or
rooming unit has been vacated or upon change in occupancy to schedule an inspection as required under subsection B2a of this section. Failure of
an owner to comply with the provisions of this subsection B5 may result in a suspension or revocation of the owner's certificate of occupancy for the
building and imposition of a fine as established in this chapter.
6. The building code official or his authorized representative will deliver within ten (10) business days after an inspection a written inspection report
either personally or by mail, return receipt requested, to the addresses where the inspection notification was sent. The report will, at a minimum,
provide:
a. Date and time of the inspection,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 199/307
b. Name and contact information of the person who conducted the inspection,
c. Basis for the inspection, as provided in the notice,
d. Areas of the property inspected,
e. Findings of the inspection, with specific references to specific code violations, if any,
f. Required repairs, alterations, or other corrective actions with a date upon which all repairs, alterations, or other corrective actions must be
completed,
g. Date and general time frame of a follow up inspection, set no more than within a three (3) hour block and in no event any earlier than nine o'clock
(9:00) A.M. or later than four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M., Monday through Friday, and
h. Provide the name and contact information of the building code official or his authorized representative, with an invitation to contact the official or
representative with any questions, concerns, or requests to reschedule the inspection date and time.
7. Every occupant of a dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit will give the owner thereof or his agent or employee access to any part of such dwelling,
dwelling unit, or rooming unit or its premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs, alterations, or other corrective actions as
are necessary to bring the dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit into compliance with this title or with any lawful rule or regulation adopted or order
issued pursuant to this title.
8. The owner of the dwelling, dwelling units, rooming units and premises shall be charged a fee in the amount of the same as a residential sale
inspection to defray the cost of any inspection under this subsection B. (Ord. 04-21-09-01, 4-21-2009)
C. Commercial, Industrial And/Or Business Use Inspections: The building director is authorized to establish an annual or biennial inspection program for
those commercial, industrial and/or business uses that are determined by the director to have a higher degree of risk for poor maintenance, nuisance,
fire or health/safety hazards. Such inspection programs may be established by risk factor, use group, zoning district or geographic location. Such uses
shall be charged an annual inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) as part of their business license renewal. The standard for such inspections shall be
the same as for a new occupancy inspection for the same classification. (1965 Code § 7-16-5; amd. 2009 Code)
D. Refusal To Allow Or Provide For Inspections: A refusal to comply with a lawful inspection notice will not be deemed a violation of this chapter, unless
such refusal is made after the building code official has obtained a court issued warrant or order authorizing such inspection. (Ord. 04-21-09-01, 4-21-
2009)
12-1-5: PENALTIES:
A. Any person, partnership, company or other entity who shall violate a provision of this title or who fails to comply with any of the requirements or
referenced codes hereof or who shall violate direction issued under the rule making authority of the code enforcement officer, or who shall violate the
conditions of a permit, plan or certificate of occupancy, shall be guilty of one or more of the following: (1965 Code § 7-1-4)
1. A misdemeanor, punishable by a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and/or
imprisonment not to exceed six (6) months. (1965 Code § 7-1-4; amd. 2009 Code)
2. A civil infraction, punishable by the following fine schedule:
First offense: Minimum $50.00/maximum $350.00.
Second offense: Minimum $350.00/maximum $750.00.
B. Civil infractions may be prosecuted in a court of competent jurisdiction or pursuant to an adjudication system as promulgated by the village in
accordance with Illinois state statutes3.
C. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
D. A court or adjudicator of competent jurisdiction shall have the authority to impose an order providing for daily fines, within the fine schedule promulgated
by this chapter, until such time as the violation is abated and verified as such by the code enforcement officer. Such order may be entered as a lien
against the property in accordance with Illinois state statutes and may accumulate interest as provided by law. Upon verifying abatement, the code
enforcement officer shall cause, where a lien has been recorded, a certificate of compliance to be issued.
E. Failure to obtain inspections and inspection approvals as required by this title and under the rule making authority of the code enforcement officer,
including, but not limited to, preconstruction inspections, rough inspections, progress inspections, compliance and final inspections, sale and rental
inspections, is a violation of this title. (1965 Code § 7-1-4)
Chapter 2
PERMITS, FEES AND BONDS1
12-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to proceed with the erection, construction, alteration, addition, repair, upgrade, removal, demolition or excavation of any building or
structure or to make any change in plumbing, mechanical or electrical systems or appurtenances, open a street, parkway or sidewalk, pour concrete or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 200/307
asphalt, or occupy a portion of a street or alley before the proper permits for such work or occupancy have been obtained from the building department.
(1965 Code § 7-2-1)
12-2-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
A. Application for a permit shall be made on a form furnished by the building department and must be accompanied by the following documents:
1. Plans as defined and directed by the building code and as required by the building director to define scope of work and compliance with the
appropriate code. Such plans may include building elevations, floor plans, construction and engineering details and specifications, material lists, site
plan, gradient and utility plans, computations and plan views.
2. Plat of survey.
3. Certificates and estimates of costs.
4. Listing of all contractor names, addresses and telephone numbers. Such contractors shall be licensed by the village prior to issuance of a permit.
B. All building permit applications are to be signed by the property owner or his authorized agent.
C. Four (4) sets of plans and specifications shall be submitted with the permit application, as required by the building director. One set will be left on file
with the building department. One other, after being approved and properly stamped by the code enforcement officer, shall be kept on the job and
available to the inspector while the work is in progress and during the active period of the permit. Such plans shall be prepared, stamped and signed by
a state of Illinois licensed design professional for the type of work indicated. (1965 Code § 7-2-7)
12-2-3: ISSUANCE OR DENIAL OF PERMIT; BOND MAY BE REQUIRED:
When the application and the required documents have been approved and accepted by the code enforcement officer and the permit fee paid, the code
enforcement officer will cause the permit to be issued. A building permit shall not be issued wherein the code enforcement officer has made a
determination, for cause, that the applicant or his contractors do not possess the necessary licenses, insurance, bond, skills or experience to perform the
work in question. Commercial, industrial and multi-family projects, other than those that are minor in scope, shall only be permitted wherein licensed
contractors will be performing said work and are listed on the permit application. Owners of single-family dwellings may pull permits for projects not
involving licensed contractors, provided such owners are occupants of the subject property, and wherein the issuance of such permits is not otherwise
contrary to any other provision of this code. The code enforcement officer may, for purposes of liability and public safety, require single-family owners to
post a bond and insurance for major construction projects as may be required for contractors. (1965 Code § 7-2-8)
12-2-4: PARTIAL PERMIT:
A partial permit may be granted for reasonable cause, such as weather, time of year, etc., to begin the foundation or other preliminary work before the
complete plans are approved. Such a partial permit shall be used at the permit holder's risk with no assurance of getting a full permit. (1965 Code § 7-2-9)
12-2-5: TIME TO BEGIN AND COMPLETE WORK; EXTENSIONS:
A. Construction of a new structure, additions or major alterations shall start within thirty (30) days after permit issuance and shall be completed within one
year of permit issuance. If the construction or work identified in the permit does not start within the requisite thirty (30) days, or if significant progress
lapses, the building director may, upon notice, suspend such permit. Failure to reinstate a permit within thirty (30) days after notification of suspension
shall void same and cause bond forfeiture to the village. A reinstatement shall not extend the permit past its original expiration date. (1965 Code § 7-2-
3)
B. A permit may be extended past its expiration date, provided the property owner or his agent makes application for such extension prior to the expiration
date. The code enforcement officer may require a completion timetable and other such documents and information as a condition of extension in order
to provide reasonable assurances that the project will continue to make progress and be completed within the extended period of time. A permit may
be extended by the code enforcement officer for a period of time not to exceed one year. (1965 Code § 7-2-4)
12-2-6: POSTING PERMIT:
A permit placard shall be furnished to the applicant as the permit. It must be conspicuously posted on the premises when construction begins. The placard
shall remain conspicuously posted on the premises during the entire course of the work. If no structure exists on the property, the owner shall cause the
installation of a device to occur wherein such permit may be displayed in a weatherproof, easily visible container. (1965 Code § 7-2-10)
12-2-7: ACCEPTANCE OF PERMIT CONDITIONS:
Upon application for and issuance of a permit, the property owner and/or his agent is deemed to have consented to all code and inspection requirements
of the codes and provisions adopted under this title and those promulgated by the code enforcement officer in conjunction with his rule making authority.
Such language shall be included on all permit applications. The acceptance of a building permit shall also constitute permission for village inspectors to
enter the subject property to inspect open structures under construction in conjunction with the permit, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. In
the event an owner or his agent refuses to allow or fails to obtain such inspections, such refusal or failure shall be a violation of this title. A refusal or failure
to obtain a required inspection shall not grant the code enforcement officer the right to enter a premises without permission, but, in addition to being a
violation of this chapter, shall be probable cause to obtain an administrative search warrant from a court of competent jurisdiction. Each day an inspection
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 201/307
is refused or not obtained after notice from the village to obtain such inspection shall be a separate violation of this title and subject to its penalties. (1965
Code § 7-2-2)
12-2-8: ALTERATIONS OR ADDITIONS TO PLANS:
It shall be unlawful to alter any lines or figures shown on the stamped permit plans. If, during the progress of work, the permit holder or his agents desire to
deviate in any manner from the permit plans, the permit holder shall submit plans in duplicate of such changes and secure written approval from the
building director before proceeding with the work. (1965 Code § 7-2-11)
12-2-9: PERMIT DOES NOT ALLOW VIOLATIONS:
The issuance of a permit does not allow violation of any of the requirements or provisions of the building code or zoning regulations, even if shown by
plans or other documents but not corrected by the building department when application was made for the permit, nor does the village, its building
department, or officers assume any responsibility for the expense involved to make such building or structure comply with the building code or zoning
regulations. (1965 Code § 7-2-6)
12-2-10: SUSPENSION OR LIMITATIONS; REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
A. The building director shall have the authority to suspend or limit permit privileges for all contractors and property owners who are in violation of village
building or property maintenance code or zoning regulations until time as such violations are cured. (1965 Code § 7-2-20)
B. Any permit issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter may be revoked at any time for reasonable cause by the building director. (1965 Code § 7-2-5)
12-2-11: WORKMANSHIP:
All repairs, maintenance work, alterations or installations which are performed pursuant to a license or permit issued under this code shall be executed and
installed in a workmanlike manner. (1965 Code § 7-2-17)
12-2-12: PERMIT FEE REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS GENERALLY:
A. Cost Of Construction Determined:
1. Definition: Where certain fees are calculated upon a percentage of the cost of construction, such term shall have the following meaning: The "cost of
construction" shall be the fair market value of the sum of the cost of the labor and materials associated with the job.
2. Determination: The cost of construction shall be determined by the building director, utilizing the ICC cost of construction factor for the state of
Illinois, where applicable.
3. Appeals: Appeals from the building director's determination of cost shall be made to the village building board of appeals. (1965 Code § 7-2-19)
B. Minimum Fee: The minimum fee for all permits is fifty dollars ($50.00). All permit fee computations shall be rounded to the nearest dollar. (1965 Code
§ 7-2-20)
C. Payment Of Fee: All permit fees are to be paid at the time the permits are issued. Should it be necessary to issue temporary permits, fees will be
estimated and adjustments made at the time the final permit is issued. The permit fees to be paid shall be the total of the fees charged for building,
plumbing, electrical, heating and all other permit fees to be charged. (1965 Code § 7-2-16)
D. Inspections: The permit fees indicated in this title constitute payment for a rough and final inspection relative to each permitted item. Repeat inspections
beyond the scope of the original permit fee due to missed appointments, violations, poor workmanship and similar circumstances shall require an
additional payment of fifty dollars ($50.00) per inspection. (1965 Code § 7-2-20)
E. Working Without Permit; Fees Double: In instances where work is begun without obtaining a required permit, the permit fee shall be double the amount
indicated in this chapter. The building director may require the exposure of any covered work for the purpose of inspection approval. (1965 Code § 7-2-
21)
12-2-13: GENERAL BUILDING PERMIT FEES:
All fees shall be rounded, and the following fees do not include building systems such as electrical, plumbing, HVAC, water and sewer taps, etc. Such fees
are further listed in this title.
One- to two-family residence $ 0 .20 per square foot per floor, including basement
Multi-family residential 0 .35 per square foot per floor, including basement
Commercial structures 0 .55 per square foot per floor, including basement
Industrial structures 0 .55 per square foot per floor, including basement
All other 0 .0125 x cost of construction, minimum fee applicable

12-2-24: BONDS:
A. General Building Bond Required: In addition to any permit fees required by this chapter, no firm or persons shall be issued a building permit to perform
any construction or alteration of a building or structure within the village if the cost of such work is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more until such
firm or person shall deposit with the building department a cash bond as determined by the building director to be sufficient to construct or repair
damages to public property and sufficient to guarantee completion of the project in accordance with village codes and ordinances. A bond shall also be
required for any street, alley, sidewalk and/or parkway opening, as well as any demolition, excavation, blasting, building moving or other work that
poses a nuisance or threat to the health, safety or welfare of individuals or the general public. (1965 Code § 7-2-66)

outstanding inspection or other village fees that may be owed. (1965 Code § 7-2-68)
