J. Fuel Price Informational Signs: In a properly zoned district, signs advertising the price of motor vehicle fuel sold from a fuel pump located on the
premises shall be permitted, subject to the following conditions:
1. Only one fuel price informational sign shall be permitted per fuel pump.
2. Fuel price informational signs shall be limited in size to an area of two hundred sixteen (216) square inches.
3. Each fuel price informational sign shall be affixed directly and firmly to a fuel pump and shall be stationary.
4. One freestanding sign to include a changeable copy sign/reader board is allowed. The size of the freestanding sign shall be determined by using
eight (8) square feet per pump with a total of forty eight (48) square feet maximum allowed. The maximum size sign is to include company name,
logo, price information, etc., if applicable.
5. Two (2) tire racks for the purpose of displaying new tire casings shall be permitted for each gasoline or service station. Such racks shall only
advertise the product(s) contained thereon. Such racks must be enclosed after the closing of business.
6. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit the use of other signs meeting the requirements of this chapter.
K. Marquee Signs: A marquee sign is one that has changeable or movable letters. It is usually a freestanding sign, but can be a wall mounted box sign.
The following provisions will apply:
1. The size of the sign shall be computed by allowing seventy five percent (75%) of a square foot for each linear foot of lot frontage, with a minimum
surface display area on the sign of twenty (20) square feet and not to exceed the maximum surface display area of one hundred (100) square feet.
2. The sign will be no more than twenty feet (20') in overall height from the level street grade.
3. The sign will be no more than five (5) linear feet from the bottom of the sign surface area to the top.
L. Outdoor Menu Boards: Outdoor menu boards are only allowed on zone lots which have previously been approved for restaurants with drive-through
windows and under the following conditions:
1. Only one outdoor menu board shall be permitted, per order window, on a lot.
2. Display surface area shall not exceed thirty two (32) square feet.
3. Stacking lane (drive-through lane) shall be a minimum of eighty feet (80') from the menu board.
4. If the sign is lighted, it may be lighted by an illuminated sign only.
5. The outdoor menu board lettering may not be legible from any distance off the zoned lot for which it is approved.
M. Wall, Box Or Individual Letter Signs:
1. Box type wall signs shall not project more than eighteen inches (18") from the surface upon which they are mounted, provided the upper edge of the
wall sign which is mounted on a mansard roof may project more than eighteen inches (18") so long as the sign is perpendicular to the ground.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 225/307
2. Where a building houses more than one business, wall signs shall be limited to one wall sign per business on each wall, with a limit of two (2) wall
signs per business per building.
3. Permitted box sign surface display area will be computed as follows:
a. One and one-half (11/2) square feet allowed for each linear foot of building frontage.
b. Maximum size of surface display area of a box sign will be one hundred (100) square feet.
c. Maximum height of sign will be twenty feet (20').
4. Individual letter sign shall be computed as follows:
a. Two (2) square feet allowed for each linear foot of building frontage.
b. Maximum size of area, measuring from the four (4) corners in a square or rectangle from the edges and from the highest characters, will be one
hundred twenty five (125) square feet.
5. All illuminated signs must be equipped with an outside electrical disconnect.
6. Painted wall signs shall not exceed one hundred sixty (160) square feet.
N. Window Signs:
1. Signs painted on or affixed to glass surfaces of windows or doors are permitted in commercial districts if they pertain to the lawful business
conducted therein. These signs are allowed without a permit.
2. Nonilluminated temporary sale signs shall be permitted, and these signs are allowed without a permit.
3. The total of all window identification and window promotional signs shall not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the total area of the windows in which they
are located. A series of windows which are separated by frames and supporting material less than six inches (6") in width shall be considered as a
single window for the purposes of computation.
O. Banners: Sale or party banners shall be removed within forty eight (48) hours following the event to which the banner applies. Sale banners can only
have a duration of fourteen (14) days in any one calendar month. Party banners can only have a duration of thirty (30) days in any one calendar month.
(1965 Code § 7-9-24)
P. Temporary Commercial Signs: An A-frame, portable swinger, sandwich, or mobile attraction signboard containing a commercial message may be placed
temporarily on site to promote a grand opening, special event, or special service on the premises where the sign is located. Such a temporary
commercial sign shall require a permit from the village in accordance with section 12-11-5 of this chapter.
1. No temporary commercial sign shall be located off site.
2. No temporary commercial sign shall be attached to fences, trees, utility poles, or the like and shall not be placed so as to obstruct or impair vision or
traffic or in any manner to create a hazard to pedestrian or vehicle traffic.
3. Temporary commercial signs shall be located a minimum of five feet (5') from any curb or edge of pavement.
4. Temporary commercial signs shall not exceed sixteen (16) square feet in area and shall have a height no greater than six feet (6') above the ground
surface.
5. No temporary sign shall be illuminated.
6. A temporary commercial sign may be displayed only for the duration of the grand opening, special event, or special service that the sign is
promoting, but in no case shall a temporary commercial sign be displayed longer than thirty (30) consecutive days.
7. No more than one such temporary commercial sign shall be permitted for the grand opening, special event, or special service that the sign is
promoting for each seventy five feet (75') of frontage. (Ord. 07-21-09-01, 7-21-2009)
12-11-14: COMPUTATION OF SIGN AREA AND HEIGHT:
The following principles shall control the computation of sign area and sign height:
A. Area:
1. Individual Signs: The area of a sign face (which is also the sign area of a wall sign or other sign with only 1 face) shall be computed by means of the
smallest square, circle, rectangle, or combination thereof, that will encompass the extreme limits of the writing, representation, emblem, color, or
other display, together with any material or color forming an integral part of the background of the display or used to differentiate the sign from the
backdrop or structure against which it is placed, but not including any supporting framework, bracing, or decorative fence or wall when such fence or
wall otherwise meets the regulations of this chapter or other ordinances or regulations and is clearly incidental to the display itself.
2. Multifaced Signs: The sign area for a sign with more than one face shall be computed by adding together the area of all sign faces visible from any
one point. When two (2) identical sign faces are placed back to back, so that both faces cannot be viewed from any one point at the same time, and
when such sign faces are part of the same sign structure and are not more than forty two inches (42") apart, the sign area shall be computed by the
measurement of one of the faces.
3. Maximum Total Area: The permitted sum of the area of all individual signs on a zone lot shall be computed by applying the formula in the appropriate
section of this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 226/307
B. Height: The height of a sign shall be computed as the distance from the base of the sign at normal grade to the top of the highest attached component
of the sign. Normal grade shall be construed to be the lower of: 1) existing grade prior to construction; or 2) the newly established grade after
construction, exclusive of any filling, berming, mounding, or excavating solely for the purpose of locating the sign. In cases in which the normal grade
cannot reasonably be determined, sign height shall be computed on the assumption that the elevation of the normal grade at the base of the sign is
equal to the elevation of the nearest point of the crown of a public street or the grade of the land at the principal entrance to the principal structure on
the zone lot, whichever is lower. (1965 Code § 7-9-6)
12-11-15: CONSTRUCTION, DESIGN AND MAINTENANCE STANDARDS:
All signs shall be designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with the following standards:
A. Compliance With Provisions: All signs shall comply with applicable provisions of the building code and the electrical code of the village. The building
director may require the permittee to supply any and all information necessary to ensure that the sign is being built, or is to be built, erected,
constructed or modified in a safe and lasting manner.
B. Construction Requirements: Except for banners, flags, temporary signs, and window signs conforming in all respects with requirements of this chapter,
all signs shall be constructed of permanent materials and shall be permanently attached to the ground, a building, or another structure by direct
attachment to a rigid wall, frame, or structure. (1965 Code § 7-9-27)
C. Maintenance Requirements:
1. All signs shall be maintained in good structural condition, in compliance with all building and electrical codes, and in conformance with this chapter,
at all times.
2. All freestanding signs and the premises surrounding the same shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary, and inoffensive
condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds.
3. Signs where the paint has peeled or the lettering has become unreadable due to the rigors of the environment must be renewed or removed.
Unsightly signs will be considered a blight condition and will be cited by the village code enforcement officer.
4. a. If the building director shall find that any sign or other advertising structure regulated herein is unsafe or insecure, is a menace to the public, is
abandoned or maintained in a dilapidated condition, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this
chapter, he shall give written notice to the permittee and property owner thereof. If the permittee and/or property owner fails to remove or alter the
sign or advertising structure, it may be removed or altered to comply by the building director. Any expense incidental to such removal or alteration
shall be charged to the owner of the property upon which the sign is located and shall constitute a lien upon the property.
b. The building director may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is in immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily
without notice. Such signs or other advertising structures are hereby declared a public nuisance. When any sign is removed summarily without
notice, the owner or lessee thereof shall have the right to a postseizure administrative hearing before the village board to determine whether there
was a probable cause to remove the sign. (1965 Code § 7-9-28)
12-11-16: VARIATIONS:
When the applicant for a sign permit can show that a provision of this chapter would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and where a
departure may be made without destroying the intent of such provisions, the board of trustees may approve a variance and impose such conditions
thereon as they may deem necessary for the protection of the public interest that will not result in harm to the public health, safety and welfare. Such
variance shall first be subject to a hearing and recommendation as prescribed in the village zoning ordinance. The fee for sign variance zoning hearings
shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). (1965 Code § 7-9-32)
12-11-17: VIOLATIONS; ENFORCEMENT; REMEDIES:
A. Violations: Any of the following shall be a violation of this chapter and shall be subject to the enforcement remedies and penalties provided by this
chapter, by the zoning ordinance, by the building code and by state law:
1. To install, create, erect or maintain any sign in a way that is inconsistent with any plan or permit governing such sign or the zone lot on which the
sign is located.
2. To install, create, erect or maintain any sign requiring a permit without such a permit.
3. To fail to remove any sign that is installed, created, erected or maintained in violation of this chapter, or for which the sign permit has lapsed, or to
continue any such violation.
4. To post or display any advertisement of an obscene or immoral character, or an advertisement tending to promote or cause a riot, or breach of the
peace, or any advertisement of any unlawful gathering or advertisements of unlawful sales.
B. Separate Offense: Each sign installed, created, erected or maintained in violation of this chapter shall be considered a separate violation when applying
the penalty portions of this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-9-30)
C. Enforcement And Remedies:
1. Any violation or attempted violation of this chapter or of any condition or requirement adopted pursuant hereto may be restrained, corrected or
abated, as the case may be, by injunction or other appropriate proceedings pursuant to state law. A violation of this chapter shall be considered a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 227/307
violation of the zoning ordinance of the village. The remedies of the village shall include the following:
a. Issuing a stop work order for any and all work on any signs on the same zone lot.
b. Seeking an injunction or other order of restraint or abatement that requires the removal of the sign(s) or the correction of the nonconformity. (1965
Code § 7-9-31)
c. Imposing any penalties that can be imposed directly by the village under the zoning ordinance; seeking in court the imposition of any penalties that
can be imposed by such a court under the zoning ordinance; seeking a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per each offense.
(1965 Code § 7-9-31; amd. 2009 Code)
d. In the case of a sign that poses an immediate danger to the public health or safety, taking such measures as are available to the village under the
applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance, this chapter and the building code for such circumstances.
2. The village shall have such other remedies as are and as may from time to time be provided for or allowed by state law for the violation of the zoning
ordinance. All such remedies provided herein shall be cumulative to the extent that state law may limit the availability of a particular remedy set forth
herein for a certain violation or a part thereof. Such remedy shall remain available for other violations or other parts of the same violation. (1965
Code § 7-9-31)
ARTICLE A. BILLBOARDS AND SIGNBOARDS
12-11A-1: CONDITIONS PERMITTING BILLBOARDS AND SIGNBOARDS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect or maintain any billboard or signboard, or to attach the same to any structure unless such person
be the owner of the building or premises or the same be under lease to him; and provided further, that the signboard or billboard is to advertise the
business conducted in or upon said building or premises by the owner or lessee thereof; and provided further, that such signboard or billboard be
constructed in compliance with the provisions of this code. (1965 Code § 9-8-1)
B. No person shall construct, erect, or maintain any billboard or signboard other than expressly provided for in subsection A of this section, being the
express purpose and intent of this article to prohibit the construction, maintenance or erection of signboards or billboards within the corporate limits of
the village1. (1965 Code § 9-8-2)
12-11A-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required: No person shall erect or maintain a billboard or signboard unless a permit shall first have been secured by the person desiring to erect
or maintain such billboard or signboard, and before a permit is issued by the building director, the applicant shall pay the fee hereinafter fixed. (1965
Code § 9-8-5)
B. Permit Fees:
1. Established: The fee to be charged for a permit to construct billboards and signboards in compliance with subsection 12-11A-1A of this article shall
be ten dollars ($10.00) and, in addition, twenty five cents ($0.25) per linear foot. The annual fee of one dollar ($1.00) per linear foot shall be charged
every person as owner or in possession, charge or control of any billboard or signboard for inspection of such signboard or billboard; and provided
further, if the annual fee for the inspection of any billboard or signboard is not paid by the person as owner or in possession, charge or control of said
billboard or signboard or premises, the same shall be removed by the building director, after giving due notice in writing to the person or persons as
designated in subsection 12-11A-4B of this article. (1965 Code § 9-8-7)
2. Disposition Of Fees: Permit and inspection fees shall be paid to the corporate fund. (1965 Code § 9-8-8; amd. 2009 Code)
12-11A-3: ANCHORING REQUIRED; SIZE LIMITATION:
All billboards or signboards now erected or to be erected shall be securely anchored or fastened in a manner satisfactory to the building director and in
such a way as to be safe and substantial, and no signboard or billboard shall exceed two hundred (200) square feet without special authorization of the
president and board of trustees. (1965 Code § 9-8-4)
12-11A-4: UNSAFE STRUCTURES:
A. Any person who now maintains any billboards, unless the same come within the provisions of subsection 12-11A-1B of this article, shall remove said
signs, not repair or alter the same, when and as such signs become unsafe. (1965 Code § 9-8-3)
B. No material alterations of any existing billboard or signboard now erected shall be made nor shall the same be moved to another location within the
village, and for all billboards and signboards within the village that have been erected in violation hereof, or erected prior to the effective date hereof, or
are in an unsafe condition, or have become unstable or insecure, or in such condition as to be a menace to the safety or health of the public, the
building director shall cause to be issued a notice in writing to the owner or lessee or person in possession of such billboard or signboard, or to the
person in possession or control of said building, business or premises, directing him to make such alterations or repairs, or to remove the same, or to
do such other acts or things as are necessary or advisable to take care of said billboard or signboard, within such reasonable time as shall be stated in
said notice, and if the person so notified shall refuse, fail or neglect to comply with the requirements of said notice within the time fixed therein, said
billboard or signboard shall be torn down by the building director. (1965 Code § 9-8-6)
12-11A-5: LICENSE FEE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 228/307
The license fee for the privilege of maintaining an outdoor advertising sign shall be one dollar ($1.00) for each square foot of an outdoor advertising sign.
The license fee for a double facing outdoor sign shall be computed by using the square footage of each side of the sign. The license shall conform to the
general provisions relating to licenses. (1965 Code § 9-8-10; amd. 2009 Code)
12-11A-6: VIOLATION:
Any person owning, operating, maintaining or in charge, possession or control of any billboard or signboard within the village that shall neglect or refuse to
comply with the provisions of this article, or that shall erect, construct or maintain any billboard or signboard that does not comply with said provisions,
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1965 Code § 9-8-9)
Footnote 1: See also subsection 12-11-13A4 of this chapter.
Chapter 12
PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS
12-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:
PRIVATE SWIMMING POOL: One that is used by the occupants of the property on which the swimming pool is located and/or their guests.
SWIMMING POOL: A manmade rigid or semirigid receptacle for water, having a depth at any point greater than eighteen inches (18"), used or intended to
be used for swimming, wading, or bathing, and constructed, installed or maintained in or above the ground outside any building. This definition does not
include collapsible plastic pools intended for child use. (1965 Code § 7-10-2)
12-12-2: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
All owners and operators of "private swimming pools", as defined in section 12-12-1 of this chapter, or owners of properties having same, shall comply with
the provisions of this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-10-1)
12-12-3: PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS:
A. Permit Required; Application: No person shall hereafter construct, cause to be constructed, operate or maintain a swimming, wading or bathing pool
without first obtaining a permit from the village. Written application and plans or specifications shall be submitted for such permit as required by the
building director.
B. Inspections: Upon issuance of a permit, the owner shall stake the proposed pool area and have same inspected by the building department. Upon
approval of the proposed area, installation may commence. All underground electrical installations shall be inspected prior to covering same. A final
inspection shall be conducted upon completion of installation of the swimming pool, required enclosure and electrical installations. (1965 Code § 7-10-
5)
C. Permit Fee: The fee for a permit for the erection or construction of a swimming pool is fifty dollars ($50.00). Such fee shall adequately cover the cost of
review and inspection of the pool project. (1965 Code § 7-10-7; amd. 2009 Code)
12-12-4: LOCATION:
A. Swimming pools shall be so constructed that there will be at least ten feet (10') between the main building and the swimming pool, and there shall be at
least five feet (5') between a side or rear lot line, and there shall be at least five feet (5') between any garage and the swimming pool. The building
director may allow less than five feet (5') to the garage if the pool cannot be otherwise lawfully situated on the property.
B. No swimming pool shall be built within any front yard.
C. Pumps, filters and pool water disinfecting equipment installation shall be located at a distance not less than eight feet (8') from any side property line.
(1965 Code § 7-10-6)
12-12-5: DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS; OPERATION REGULATIONS:
Every person in possession of land on which a swimming, wading, or bathing pool is situated or will be built shall conform with the following regulations:
A. Water Supply: No source of water other than that secured from the village waterworks distribution system shall be used in private swimming pools. The
connection shall be as required by the plumbing code, by means of a permanent, rigid system of piping having an air gap delivery connection located
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 229/307
not less than six inches (6") vertically above the flood rim of the pool. No swimming, wading or bathing pool in excess of two thousand five hundred
(2,500) gallons' capacity shall be installed or operated without a recirculating and filtering system.
B. Outlets:
1. In swimming pools thirty feet (30') in width or less, water circulation system outlets shall be located so as to provide at least one outlet at the deepest
point in the pool. If the pool width is more than thirty feet (30'), multiple outlets shall be provided and spaced not more than thirty feet (30') apart,
closer than four feet (4') to any wall. All pool drain outlets shall be equipped with gratings having an area of opening not less than four (4) times the
cross sectional area of the outlet pipe. The gratings shall be of such design so they cannot be readily removable by bathers and will not injure
bathers' fingers. One outlet shall be provided for each eight hundred (800) square feet of surface area.
2. Pools shall be equipped with facilities for completely emptying the pool, and the discharge of the pool water to the sewer shall be at a rate not
exceeding two hundred fifty (250) gallons per minute. No direct connection shall be made to the sewer. Water drained from the pool shall not be
discharged to the sewer system during periods of rain or storms.
C. Structural Design: Residential swimming pools shall be designed to withstand water pressure from within and to resist pressure of the earth when the
pool is empty, to a pressure of two thousand two hundred (2,200) pounds per square foot. Materials used shall be subject to the approval of the
building director. Grade height of pools constructed hereafter shall not exceed established grade. (1965 Code § 7-10-4)
D. Diving Board Clearance: Where a swimming pool has a diving board or diving apparatus for the purpose of diving into the pool, there shall be a clear
area of not less than an eight foot (8') radius ahead of the furthermost projection of the diving board. (1965 Code § 7-10-9)
E. Walk Areas: Unobstructed walk areas not less than thirty six inches (36") wide shall be provided to extend entirely around the pool. The walk area shall
be constructed of impervious materials, and the surfaces shall be of such as to be smooth and easily cleaned and of nonslip construction. The slope of
the walks shall have a pitch of at least one-fourth inch (1/4") to the foot, designed so as to prevent back drainage from entering the pool.
F. Steps Or Ladders: At least one means of egress in the form of steps or ladders shall be provided for all private residential swimming pools. Treads of
steps and ladders shall be constructed of nonslip materials and be of sturdy construction. Permanent stairways shall further comply with the village
building code.
G. Electrical Requirements:
1. All private swimming pools shall comply with the provisions applicable to swimming pools as promulgated by the village electrical code.
2. All metal fences, enclosures or railings near or adjacent to private residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a result of
contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded.
3. Ground fault breakers shall be installed for all outside electrical receptacles and outlets to be used in conjunction with all private swimming pools.
Receptacles shall be in weatherproof boxes. (1965 Code § 7-10-4)
H. Operation And Maintenance:
1. The operation and use of a private swimming pool shall not produce nuisance conditions, including, but not limited to, damage of private or public
property, or loud or boisterous behavior that causes an unreasonable annoyance to others.
2. A suitable substantial protective cover shall be provided and installed over all private residential swimming pool surfaces during the nonswimming
season or when residents are absent for a period of more than three (3) days.
3. Every pool shall be designed and constructed as to facilitate cleaning and shall be maintained and operated in such manner as to be clean and
sanitary at all times. (1965 Code § 7-10-4; amd. 2009 Code)
12-12-6: FENCES, ENCLOSURES AND DECKS:
A. All swimming pools shall be located in an approved yard that is enclosed by a minimum four foot (4') high perimeter fence sufficient to provide a
significant deterrent to entry into the yard space by small children. The swimming pool shall also be protected by a minimum four foot (4') high
enclosure sufficient to enclose the pool and prevent at will entry by small children.
B. All perimeter fences and enclosures shall include a gate of equal height. All required gates shall be kept closed and latched at all times when the pool is
not occupied.
C. Enclosures shall not have gaps or openings, other than protected access areas, larger than four inches (4") in diameter.
D. Stairways to attached decks or which otherwise lead directly to the pool shall be the fold up type or otherwise protected from child access. Pool ladders
shall either be removed or folded up when the pool is not occupied.
E. All decks shall be protected against entry by a child through the use of guardrails constructed in compliance with the village building code. No portion of
the pool or deck shall have a ladder in effect by which a child could climb and gain access to the swimming pool. (1965 Code § 7-10-3)
12-12-7: NONCONFORMING POOLS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 230/307
Swimming pools installed prior to the effective date hereof that are not in compliance with the setback requirements of this chapter and/or the electrical
conductor clearance requirements of the Chicago electrical code are granted an amortization period of five (5) years, provided:
A. Such pools shall be registered with the village within one hundred twenty (120) days of the effective date hereof. Registration shall be accompanied by
a ten dollar ($10.00) registration fee. The village shall, upon the effective date hereof, make known this requirement to the village through
comprehensive notification to village residents and in any manner required by law.
B. Upon registration, such swimming pools shall thereafter be inspected by the building department. All swimming pools not in compliance with the
required enclosure, sanitary or electrical ground fault circuit interrupter (GFCI) or other requirements of this chapter, other than setback or electrical
wire clearance, shall be corrected as directed by the building department. The clearance for registered nonconforming pools may, at the discretion of
the code enforcement inspector, be less than the requisite ten feet (10'), provided such reduction in clearance meets with the spirit and intent of this
code, does not create a significant or clear and present hazard, and the owner signs a waiver of liability for such reduction.
C. Owners shall be advised as to the reasons for the electrical conductor clearance rule and acknowledge in writing that they have been informed as to the
safety risk involved in not correcting the violation. Owners shall further hold the village harmless from any damage or injury arising out of such
violations during the amortization period. (1965 Code § 7-10-10)
D. Upon expiration of the one hundred twenty (120) day registration period, all unregistered nonconforming pools are declared illegal and subject to
enforcement of this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-10-10; amd. 2009 Code)
E. Upon expiration of the five (5) year amortization period, all registered nonconforming swimming pools shall comply with this chapter or be removed.
F. All registered nonconforming swimming pools shall, regardless of the five (5) year amortization period, come into compliance with this chapter, or be
removed, prior to the sale of the real property upon which such pool is located. Compliance may be assumed by the purchaser, provided the pool is
brought into compliance by same or removed within sixty (60) days of purchase. (1965 Code § 7-10-10)
12-12-8: DANGEROUS POOLS:
If, in the opinion of the building director, a swimming pool constitutes and immediate and obvious danger to the swimming pool occupants or the public
health or safety in general, the village may take such action so as to remove or make safe said swimming pool at the owner's expense. Such action shall
be preceded by advance notice as may be reasonable and practical in consideration of the danger presented. (1965 Code § 7-10-11)
12-12-9: ABANDONED OR UNMAINTAINED POOLS:
Swimming pools which are not utilized for a period of ten (10) months or which fall into a state of disrepair, dilapidation or nonmaintenance, including, but
not limited to, unsanitary water, shall be removed or restored upon direction of the building department. (1965 Code § 7-10-12)
12-12-10: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL; RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The building director is hereby charged with the duty of enforcing this chapter. For this purpose, he is hereby authorized to enter upon any premises to
investigate the existence of a swimming pool and to determine whether or not any such pool complies with the requirements of this chapter. (1965 Code
§ 7-10-8)
12-12-11: PENALTIES:
Violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a maximum seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) per day fine for each day the violation exists. This chapter
may be enforced through the adjudication process adopted by the village pursuant to the code hearing provisions of Illinois state statutes1. Violations shall
also be punishable as a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. The village shall not be precluded from seeking other lawful
remedies to violations of this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-10-13; amd. 2009 Code)
Footnote 1: See title 1, chapter 5, article A of this code.
Chapter 13
FENCES AND HEDGES
12-13-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of a fence is to provide privacy, security, weather control, aesthetic appearance, boundary definitions and utility (snow fences) for residential,
commercial, industrial, public and quasi-public land uses within the corporate boundaries of the village. (1965 Code § 7-14-1)
12-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 231/307
For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall be applicable:
DOG RUN: Any fenced area intended to enclose a dog up to a maximum of one hundred (100) square feet.
FENCE: A tangible barrier constructed or installed of any material, including plant materials, erected for the purpose of providing a boundary or as a
means of protection, or to prevent uncontrolled access, or for decorative purposes (such as ornamental gate(s)), or to screen from view in or on adjoining
properties and streets, materials stored and operations conducted behind it.
FENCE, NATURAL: An enclosing structure or barrier of densely compacted brush, shrubs, low trees, or similar materials planted less than ten feet (10')
apart and exceeding thirty inches (30") in height.
FENCE, OPEN: A fence, including entrance and exit gates, designed and constructed so that the surface area of any segment of such fence contains at
least fifty percent (50%) open space as compared to solid materials.
FENCE, PRIVACY: A structural or decorative (lattice) fence which is designed to screen a patio, deck or swimming pool and which does not extend more
than five feet (5') beyond the perimeter of the patio, deck or pool. The area enclosed by the privacy fence shall be included in the maximum lot coverage
as regulated in the zoning ordinance. An enclosure that permits light and air to pass through more than fifty percent (50%) of its surface, such as lattice or
railings, shall not be considered a "privacy fence".
FENCE, SOLID: A fence, including solid entrance and exit gates, which effectively conceals from view, in or on adjoining properties and streets, materials
stored and operations conducted behind it.
SPAN: The entire length of a fence, generally parallel to a lot line and located within the area of a given front, side or rear yard as established by the village
zoning ordinance, or where a yard requirement is not established, generally parallel to the parcel or zoning lot line.
YARD, FRONT: The open space across the full width of the lot extending from the closest point of the front line of the principal building to the front lot line.
On corner lots, the front yard shall face the street adjacent to the shortest lot line dimension.
YARD, REAR: The open space extending the full width of the lot between the closest point of the principal building and the rear lot line.
YARD, SIDE: The open space between the closest point of the principal building and the side line of the lot and extending from the front line to the rear line
of the building. (1965 Code § 7-14-2; amd. 2009 Code)
12-13-3: PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS:
A. Permit Required; Fee: All work involving the construction, relocation or extension of fences, or the planting of hedges intended as a natural fence, on
any property, shall require the issuance of a fence permit prior to the initiation of such work. The permit fee shall be as set out in section 12-2-13 of this
title. (1965 Code § 7-14-3; amd. 2009 Code)
B. Application For Permit: All permit applications must be accompanied by a plat of survey showing the location of all proposed and existing fences, and a
description of the fence height, design, materials and type of construction. Other documentation may be required by the building director wherein
affected boundary lines or ownership is unclear or disputed. (1965 Code § 7-14-4)
C. Exemptions From Permit:
1. The following shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this chapter: (2009 Code)
a. Temporary fences erected for the sole purpose of protecting residential gardening plots located in the area between the rear of the dwelling and
the rear property line;
b. Fences which are a maximum of twenty four inches (24") in height and eight feet (8') in length and are installed for landscaping or decorative
purposes only and which are not designed or constructed so as to create an enclosed area; and
c. Temporary fences associated with construction, demolition and public projects as approved by the building director.
2. Such fences shall otherwise comply with the height and design standards of this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-14-3)
D. Inspections: Property owners and contractors are required to obtain inspection approval for all fence construction occurring under permit as follows:
1. Postholes shall be inspected and found to be of proper depth and construction prior to installation of posts.
2. Construction, repair or alterations of fences shall be inspected upon completion of work and found to be in compliance with this chapter.
3. All violations shall be corrected as required by the inspector within the time period specified. (1965 Code § 7-14-11)
12-13-4: PROHIBITED LOCATIONS:
A. Fences:
1. Front Yard: No fence shall be constructed in a required front yard. In zoning districts where a front or side yard requirement is not established by the
village zoning ordinance, no fence shall be permitted within ten feet (10') of the front property line.
2. Exceptions:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 232/307
a. On single-family residential parcels containing two (2) or more contiguous lots of record, a fence otherwise conforming to the requirements of this
chapter shall be allowed in the required front yard area of those lots not containing a dwelling structure to within one foot (1') of the front property
line. Such fences shall be removed from lots where new dwellings are constructed.
Front Yard Fence Permitted On
Contiguous Lot Without Dwelling
b. On residential corner lots only, a double rail, split rail fence may be placed along the property line at the corner of the lot common to both streets
and which shall not extend longitudinally in excess of eight feet (8') in either direction from the corner of the lot, and the top of the highest rail shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 233/307
not exceed thirty six inches (36") in height nor any support post exceed forty two inches (42") in height.
Split Rail Fence On Corner Lot
c. On residential corner lots only, a chainlink fence, providing an open and unobstructed view through the plane of the fence area, may be erected on
the boundary line contiguous to the side street, beginning at a parallel line equal to the front of the dwelling and continuing to one foot (1') inside
the front property line. Such fences shall begin at a maximum height of four feet (4') at a line parallel to the dwelling and taper to a two foot (2')
height at the termination of the fence inside the front property line. Such fences shall not otherwise be a hazard to traffic or pedestrians or the
cause of a nuisance, as determined by the building director.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 234/307
Corner Lot Front Yard
Tapering Fence Permitted
d. In residential zones, where an existing dwelling is nonconforming as to front yard setback, a fence which is otherwise in compliance with this
chapter may be erected on a parallel line extending from the front of the dwelling to the side lot line, and thereafter toward the rear of the property.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 235/307
Fences For Nonconforming Dwellings
e. In industrial zones, a fence otherwise conforming to the requirements of this code shall be permitted in the required front yard area, provided it is
located a minimum of one foot (1') off the front property line and, in the opinion of the building director, does not present any hazardous or blighting
conditions and is not out of character with the architecture and conditions of the surrounding neighborhood.
B. Dog Runs: Dog runs shall not be constructed in any front or side yard. Dog runs constructed in a rear yard shall not be within eight feet (8') of any
property line or within twenty five feet (25') of any neighboring dwelling. (1965 Code § 7-14-5)
12-13-5: HEIGHT STANDARDS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 236/307
A. The maximum height for all fences shall be six feet (6').
B. A maximum height of eight feet (8') shall be permitted where an industrial zone abuts a residential zone or an alley separating such zones.
C. The minimum fence height for perimeter fencing shall be no less than four feet (4'). Perimeter fencing shall constitute all fences erected within five feet
(5') of a property line. (1965 Code § 7-14-6)
12-13-6: MULTIPLE FENCES:
A. Only one perimeter fence shall be permitted.
B. The building director may permit an additional perimeter fence upon his determination that it is appropriate for the purposes of public safety or to abate
a nuisance. Such fences shall be freestanding and provide for an accessible maintenance gap of a minimum of one foot (1') between fences. (1965
Code § 7-14-7)
12-13-7: ARCHITECTURAL STANDARDS:
A. Every fence constructed, erected, altered, replaced or enlarged after the effective date hereof shall comply with the provisions of this chapter.
B. All fences shall be of an architectural design that is common to the community.
C. All fences shall be designed and constructed so as to be compatible with its environment and surrounding properties from an architectural and aesthetic
standpoint.
D. No fence shall be of such architectural design or construction that the same is manifestly inferior or is so radically different as to impair marketability or
property values of the existing property in the immediate vicinity.
E. All fences shall be constructed with the finished, smooth or decorative side facing toward adjoining properties.
F. All fences shall be constructed with the posts and supporting beams facing the fence owner's property.
G. Uniform design and type shall be maintained along the entire fence span.
H. All fences shall be constructed of new material.
I. All fences shall be designed and constructed to resist a horizontal wind load of not less than thirty five (35) pounds per square foot (psf) in addition to
any other forces to which it may be subjected.
J. Postholes shall be a minimum of forty two inches (42") below grade. In cases where geological conditions prevent excavation to said depth, the building
director may approve a lesser depth, provided alternative measures are taken, such as underpinning, to properly secure the posts.
K. Posts shall be of substantial material designed to carry the structural and wind loads to which they are subjected. All posts shall be set in concrete.
L. All fences shall have a top rail or beam. Fencing material must be continuous and uniform from top to bottom.
M. No fence shall have spikes, barbs or other pointed or sharp assemblies1. Top links shall be bent downward, and uprights shall be of a design so as to
preclude accidental impalement on same.
N. Barbed or razor wire, or similar devices, shall only be allowed in industrial districts upon receipt of special use approval as outlined in the zoning
ordinance.
O. Electrified fences are prohibited.
P. No fence, wall or shrubbery may be erected or maintained so as to impede natural stormwater runoff, interfere with drainage of contiguous properties or
cause nuisance ponding, flooding or retention.
Q. No fence shall cause a nuisance, hazard or otherwise adversely affect the public health, safety and welfare. The building director shall determine
whether a particular set of circumstances, design or element constitutes such condition. (1965 Code § 7-14-8)
12-13-8: NONCONFORMING FENCES AND HEDGES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 237/307
All permanent fences and hedges which were lawfully constructed and are in existence at the effective date hereof, but which do not conform to one or
more sections of this chapter, shall be allowed to remain until such time as they are damaged or significantly removed or altered. Such conditions shall
require the nonconforming fence to be removed or otherwise brought into compliance with this chapter. Fences which are of a hazardous design or
construction or which create a nuisance or hazard shall not have a protected nonconforming status and shall be subject to an order by the building director
to remove such fence or otherwise bring same into compliance with this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-14-9)
12-13-9: MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR:
A. All fences shall be maintained in a workmanlike condition and in compliance with this chapter.
B. All structural members shall be maintained free from breaks, deterioration, dilapidation and unsafe, unsightly or unsound conditions.
C. All fences shall be properly surface coated to protect them from the elements. There shall be no rust, peeling paint or deterioration of a surface coating.
D. All fences shall be maintained free from broken, jagged or sharp edges or members.
E. All fences shall be maintained as freestanding on solid supports as required by this chapter and the general building code where applicable.
F. Maintenance shall be the responsibility of the owner of the land upon which the fence is located. Where ownership of a perimeter fence is not claimed or
documented to the satisfaction of the building director, maintenance responsibility shall be equally assigned to all abutting property owners.
G. Ordinary repairs such as painting, patching and minor parts replacement shall not require a permit, provided such repairs do not change the design,
location, height, uniformity or structural integrity of the fence. (1965 Code § 7-14-10)
12-13-10: HAZARDOUS FENCES AND SHRUBS:
The village may remove any fence, shrub or other barrier which creates an immediate hazard to the health, safety or welfare of the community at cost to
the property owner. The cost of such abatement shall first be invoiced to the responsible party or property owner, after which all unpaid invoices shall be a
lien against the affected property, where applicable, in accordance with state law. (1965 Code § 7-14-13)
12-13-11: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
A. Enforcement Official: This chapter shall be enforced by the village building director or his designees.
B. Notice Of Violation: Upon discovery of a violation of this chapter, the enforcing agent shall provide written notification outlining the violation, required
remedy and compliance due date by one of the following methods:
1. By first class mail to the taxpayer of record, as contained in the records of the Lyons Township or Cook County assessor's office.
2. By posting the notice on the premises.
C. Citation: Upon expiration of a reasonable compliance time, the enforcing agent may issue a citation for the responsible party to appear in a court of
adjudication system of competent jurisdiction.
D. Suspension Of Permit: The building director may cause the permit privileges to be suspended for any property owner or contractor who is in violation of
this chapter until such time as the violations are cured.
E. Penalty: Each offense shall be punishable by a minimum fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) and a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
Compliance shall not abrogate the minimum fine provision of this subsection. Each day of noncompliance shall be considered a separate offense.
(1965 Code § 7-14-12)
12-13-12: APPEALS:
In the event any person affected by this chapter desires to appeal from the decision or interpretation of the enforcing agent, such person shall have the
right to file an appeal to the village zoning board of appeals/plan commission, provided such appeal is filed by approved form, and fee paid within thirty
(30) days of the date of the enforcing agent's notice of violation. Enforcement of the applicable provision of this chapter shall be stayed until such time as
the village board of trustees decides the matter. The filing fee for said appeal shall be equal to the required fee for a zoning variance2. (1965 Code § 7-14-
14; amd. 2009 Code)
Chapter 14
ANTENNA STRUCTURES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 238/307
12-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they will have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
ANTENNA STRUCTURE: Any structure, mast, pole, tripod or tower utilized for the purpose of either transmission or reception purposes.
COMMERCIAL ANTENNA: Any antenna structures used in conjunction with communication facilities for use in commerce or industry.
COMMERCIAL EARTH STATION: Any earth station used in conjunction with communication facilities for use in commerce or industry.
DISH: That part of a satellite signal receiving antenna characteristically shaped like a saucer or dish.
DISH OR DISK TYPE SATELLITE SIGNAL RECEIVING ANTENNAS: The terms, also referred to as "satellite" or "earth station" or "ground station" or
"satellite receiving dishes", shall mean one, or a combination of two (2) or more, of the following:
A. A signal receiving device (antenna, dish antenna or dish type antenna), the purpose of which is to receive communications or other signals from
satellites in earth orbit and other extraterrestrial sources.
B. A low noise amplifier (LNA) which is situated at the focal point of the receiving component and the purpose of which is to magnify, store, transfer
and/or transmit electronic or light signals.
C. A coaxial cable, the purpose of which is to carry or transmit said signals to a receiver.
EARTH STATION: Either flat, concave, or parabolic antennas, greater than two meters (2 m) in diameter, in a commercial or industrial zoned area, or
greater than one meter (1 m) in a residential zoned area, that are designed for reception of television, radio, or microwave signals from satellites or other
sources.
GROUNDING ROD: A metal pole permanently positioned in the earth to serve as an electrical conductor through which electrical current may safely pass
and dissipate.
NONCOMMERCIAL ANTENNA: Any antenna used for private radio and television reception for licensed amateur radio operators' citizens band facilities
and government and nonprofit organizations.
NONCOMMERCIAL EARTH STATION: Any earth station used for private radio and television only.
RECEIVER: A television set or radio receiver. (1965 Code § 7-15-1; amd. 2009 Code)
12-14-2: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
A. Permit Required:
1. No person, firm, partnership, corporation, trust or other legal entity shall construct an earth station without a permit, nor shall construction commence
before a permit is issued in accordance with this chapter. (1965 Code § 7-15-2)
2. The owner, or occupant with written permission from the owner, of any lot, premises or parcel of land within the village who desires to construct an
earth station on said lot, premises, or land parcel must first obtain a permit to do so from the building director.
B. Application For Permit:
1. The application must be accompanied by:
a. An accurate plan of the lot, premises or land parcel showing the exact location and dimensions of the proposed earth station.
b. The exact location and dimensions of all buildings or structures.
c. A description of the kind of earth station proposed.
d. Construction plans and specifications showing the elevations of the proposed earth station upon completion.
2. Each application shall specify, among other things, the names and addresses of the owner of the real estate, the applicant and the person to be
permitted to construct the proposed earth station. (1965 Code § 7-15-3)
C. Federal Or State License Or Permit Required: The applicant shall present documentation of the possession of any license or permit required by any
federal, state or local agency pertaining to the ownership, construction or operation of an earth station. (1965 Code § 7-15-4)
D. Permit Fee: The applicant shall submit with each application the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) which represents the permit fee. The permit fee shall cover
the costs of reviewing the construction plans and specifications, inspecting the final construction and processing the application. (1965 Code § 7-15-5;
amd. 2009 Code)
E. Issuance Or Denial Of Permit; Appeals:
1. When the application and the required documents have been approved and accepted by the building director and the permit fee paid, the building
director shall cause the permit to be issued. The building director shall accept or reject applications for permits within fifteen (15) days after filing. In
the event of refusing to issue a permit, the building director shall give the applicant the reason for refusal. (1965 Code § 7-15-6)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 239/307
2. The denial of a permit shall entitle the applicant to appeal to the zoning board of appeals/plan commission. The zoning board of appeals/plan
commission shall hold a hearing within fifteen (15) days of receiving notice of appeal. At said hearing, the applicant shall be entitled to be
represented by legal counsel and present witnesses to support his application. Upon the conclusion of the hearing, a finding of facts and a
recommendation shall be issued within ten (10) days to the president and village board. The village board shall retain the authority to make final
decisions on any recommendations of the zoning board of appeals/plan commission. (1965 Code § 7-15-7)
12-14-3: LOCATION:
A. Ground Mounted: The following provisions apply to ground mounted structures: (2009 Code)
1. No earth station shall be constructed in any front or side yard but shall be constructed to the rear of the residence or main structure. On corner lots,
no earth station shall be erected outside of the established building line of both street frontages, and where no building line is established, earth
stations shall have a minimum setback of thirty feet (30') from property lines fronting on any street or highway.
2. No earth station, including its concrete base slab or other substructure, shall be constructed less than eight feet (8') from any property line or
easement.
3. No ground mounted earth station shall be constructed without landscaping with appropriate evergreens, berming, hedging or fencing to reasonably
conceal said earth station from view, as approved by the building director. The earth station shall be of a neutral color so as to render the same
compatible with the surrounding neighborhood in appearance and character. The planting and/or screening shall be completed before final approval
by the building director.
4. No more than one such dish shall be installed or located on any lot, parcel or site.
5. No antenna shall protrude in any manner upon the public way or adjoining property. (1965 Code § 7-15-15)
B. Roof/Tower Mounted: No dish shall be located on, mounted, or attached to any portion of any building or structure situated on the property in any area
zoned residential. This restriction applies to nonconforming uses located in residential areas. (1965 Code § 7-15-16)
12-14-4: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
A. Ground Mounted: The following provisions apply to ground mounted structures: (2009 Code)
1. No earth station shall be linked physically or electronically to a receiver which is not located on the same lot, premises or parcel of land as is the
earth station.
2. All antennas must be installed per manufacturer's suggested mounting instructions.
3. Any driving motor shall be limited to one hundred twenty (120) volts maximum power design and be encased in protective guards.
4. An ark station must be bonded to a grounding rod.
5. Wiring between an earth station and a receiver shall be placed at least four inches (4") beneath the surface of the ground within rigid conduit.
6. Antenna structures may be constructed from one of the following materials: aluminum, galvanized steel, or an equally weather resistant steel, or
treated wood, subject to the written approval of the building director. Where two (2) dissimilar materials such as aluminum and concrete or aluminum
and steel are in contact, provisions shall be made to avoid electrolysis.
7. An earth station shall not exceed a grade height of fourteen feet (14') or the roofline established by the principal building, whichever is less.
8. No earth station shall exceed eight feet (8') in diameter. No advertising, logos, or symbols will be permitted on any earth station surfaces. All earth
stations shall be a neutral color.
9. No antenna shall be of a windmill type. A solid dish type construction or design shall not be permitted in a residentially zoned district.
10. All such dishes shall be of the open ribs, rim and wire mesh type construction in residential areas. (1965 Code § 7-15-20)
B. Roof/Tower Mounted: The following provisions apply to roof/tower mounted structures: (2009 Code)
1. Earth stations shall be mounted directly upon the roof of a primary or accessory structure, as defined in the building code, and shall not be mounted
upon appurtenances such as chimneys, towers, trees, poles or spires.
2. An earth station shall not exceed a height of more than three feet (3') above the roof upon which it is mounted.
3. No earth station shall be linked physically or electronically to a receiver which is not located on the same lot, premises, or parcel of land as is the
earth station.
4. All antennas must be installed to manufacturer's suggested mounting instructions.
5. Any driving motor shall be limited to one hundred twenty (120) volts maximum power design and be encased in protective guards.
6. All towers and/or roof mounted structures supporting antennas shall be grounded. The ground conductor shall be a minimum of no. 10 GA copper;
however, in all instances, construction shall follow the manufacturer's requirements for grounding.
7. Antenna structures may be constructed from one of the following materials: aluminum, galvanized steel, or an equally weather resistant steel, or
treated wood, subject to the written approval of the building director. Where two (2) dissimilar materials such as aluminum and concrete or aluminum
and steel are in contact, provisions shall be made to avoid electrolysis.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 240/307
8. An earth station dish shall not exceed three feet (3') in diameter.
9. No advertising, logos, or symbols will be permitted on any earth station surfaces. All earth stations shall be a neutral color.
10. No antenna shall be of a windmill type. A solid dish type construction or design shall not be permitted in a residentially zoned district.
11. All such dishes shall be of the open ribs, rim and wire mesh type construction in residential areas.
12. In residential areas, two (2) antenna structures will be allowed for each roof, one of which may be for radio, and one of which may be for television
purposes. The base structure which supports the mast shall not exceed three feet (3'). No guywires for additional supports shall support the base
structure or antenna mast.
13. In commercial areas, roof mounted antennas may not exceed thirty feet (30') from mounting base. Two (2) earth station antenna structures will be
allowed for each roof.
14. "Radials" used in amateur systems must not support the base structure or antenna or be higher than two feet (2') above the roof. (1965 Code § 7-
15-21)
12-14-5: INOPERABLE EARTH STATIONS:
Any earth station found to be inoperable by the village must either be repaired or removed from the premises within sixty (60) days. (1965 Code § 7-15-8)
Chapter 15
VACANT BUILDING AND PROPERTY REGULATIONS
12-15-1: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety, and welfare by enactment of this chapter which:
A. Establishes a program for identification, registration, and regulation of buildings which are or become vacant on and after the effective date of this
chapter.
B. Determines the responsibilities of owners of vacant buildings.
C. Provides for administration, enforcement, including abatement of public nuisances, and imposition of penalties.
This chapter shall be construed liberally to effect its purposes. (Ord. 10-21-08-01, 10-21-2008)
12-15-2: OTHER ORDINANCES:
This chapter shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations which prescribe
standards other than are provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall apply. (Ord. 10-21-08-01, 10-21-2008)
12-15-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated or clearly indicated by the context, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings
indicated in this section:
BOARDED BUILDING: A building which has had, in a manner intended to be temporary or permanent, any or all openings, which openings are windows
or doors which were present for the purpose of light, ventilation or egress, some material whether opaque, solid or transparent, affixed to such openings,
from the interior or exterior of the building, for the purpose of securing or preventing access or damage to the building or its components.
BUILDING: Any structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy.
BUILDING INSPECTOR: The building inspector or his or her designee.
DANGEROUS BUILDING: A building defined as a "dangerous building" in chapter 9 of this title, as it may be amended. Such buildings are public
nuisances.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such
person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court.
PERSON: Includes a corporation, a partnership, or other entity as well as an individual.
PREMISES: A lot, plot, or parcel of land including any structure thereon.
PUBLIC NUISANCE: Includes the following:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 241/307
A. The physical condition, or uses of any building regarded as a public nuisance at common law, under the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or under this
code; or
B. Any physical condition, use or occupancy or any building or its appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not
limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences or structures; or
C. Any building which has unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities; or
D. Any building designated by the building inspector as unsafe for human habitation or use; or
E. Any building which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or manifestly unsafe or insecure as to endanger life, limb or property; or
F. Any building which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or garbage, or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or
G. Any building that is dangerous, in a state of dilapidation, deterioration or decay; faulty construction; open or vacant and the doors, windows, or other
openings are boarded up or secured, by any means other than conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new
construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide shelter, in danger of collapse or failure and dangerous to anyone on or
near the premises; or
H. Any building defined as a "dangerous building" by this section, as it may be amended.
UNOCCUPIED BUILDING: A building or portion thereof which lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises,
including buildings ordered vacated by the building inspector pursuant to authority granted to him by this code.
In determining whether a building is "unoccupied", the building inspector may consider these factors, among others:
A. A building at which substantially all lawful residential or business activity has ceased.
B. The percentage of the overall square footage of occupied to unoccupied space or the overall number of occupied and unoccupied units shall be
considered.
C. The building is substantially devoid of contents. The condition and value of fixtures or personal property in the building are relevant to this
determination.
D. The building lacks utility services, i.e., water, sewer, electric, or natural gas.
E. The building is the subject of a foreclosure action.
F. The building is not actively for sale as part of a contractual agreement to sell the building, the building lacks "for sale", "for rent", or similar signage.
G. The presence or recurrence of uncorrected code violations.
VACANT BUILDING: A building or portion of a building which is:
A. Unoccupied and unsecured; or
B. Unoccupied and secured by boarding or other similar means; or
C. Unoccupied and a dangerous structure; or
D. Unoccupied and condemned by the building inspector pursuant to applicable provisions of this code; or
E. Unoccupied and has multiple code violations; or
F. Unoccupied and the building or its premises has been the site of unlawful activity within the previous six (6) months; or
G. Condemned by the building inspector and unlawfully occupied; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 242/307
H. Unoccupied for over one hundred eighty (180) days and during which time the building inspector has issued an order to correct public nuisance
conditions and same have not been corrected in a code compliant manner; or
I. Unoccupied for over two (2) years;
But not including: Unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable
ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations, and for which construction, renovation, or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion. (Ord.
10-21-08-01, 10-21-2008)
12-15-4: DETERMINATION:
Within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this chapter, the building inspector shall evaluate all buildings in the village he believes to be unoccupied
on the effective date of this chapter and make a determination for each as to whether the building is a "vacant building" within the meaning of section 12-
15-3 of this chapter. The building inspector may determine that a building which meets any of the criteria set forth in section 12-15-3 of this chapter is not
to be regulated under this chapter for a stated period, if upon consideration of reliable, substantiated and sufficient evidence, he or she determines that
regulation of the building under this chapter would not serve the public health, welfare, and safety and makes written findings in support of his decision.
The determination shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis for the determination. For buildings the building inspector determines to be "vacant
buildings", he shall, within seven (7) days of making that determination, send notice of his written determination with the factual findings to the last
taxpayer of record listed on the most recent Cook County tax roll. Said notice of determination shall be sent first class United States mail, with proper
postage prepaid. Failure of delivery shall not excuse a person from complying with this chapter. The building inspector may personally serve or cause
personal service of the notice of determination. Any person making such service shall execute an affidavit attesting to the facts of service. The building
inspector shall maintain an affidavit of such mailing for each notice of determination sent.
The notice shall specify a date and time on which the owner shall allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant building to determine
the extent of compliance with village property, building codes, health, fire, water and sewer codes. The owner shall pay the five hundred dollar ($500.00)
inspection fee to the village within thirty (30) days of the inspection. An unpaid fee shall be a lien upon the premises.
The notice shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the registration form the
owner is required to file pursuant to section 12-15-6 of this chapter, and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the building inspector's determination. (Ord.
10-21-08-01, 10-21-2008)
12-15-5: APPEAL OF DETERMINATION:
A. An owner of a building determined by the building inspector to be a vacant building as provided for in this chapter may appeal that determination to the
village manager. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the village manager within fifteen (15) days of the date of mailing of the notice of
determination. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register his building as required by this chapter. The appeal shall contain a
complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the building inspector's determination, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall
include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village manager shall decide the appeal on the basis of facts presented by the
owner in his or her written appeal and the building inspector's written determination.
B. The burden is upon the owner to present sufficient evidence to persuade the village manager that had the evidence been known to the building
inspector at the time the building inspector made the determination, the building inspector would more likely than not have determined that the subject
building was not a "vacant building" within the meaning of this chapter.
C. The village manager shall send written notice of its decision to the owner within ten (10) days of receipt of the appeal. The village manager may, but is
not required to, seek additional information from the owner. The village manager may, upon written notice thereof to the owner, take no more than ten
(10) additional days, to decide the appeal if it is determined that such additional time is required for consideration of the appeal.
D. An owner who wishes to challenge applicability of this chapter to his/her building without the building inspector's determination having been made, shall
set forth specific facts to support nonapplicability in a writing to the building inspector. In the event the building inspector determines that the subject
building is a "vacant building", the owner shall have the right to appeal the building inspector's determination to the village manager as provided for
herein. (Ord. 10-21-08-01, 10-21-2008)
12-15-6: OBLIGATION TO REGISTER:
The owner of a building who knows, or from all the facts and circumstances should know, that his or her building is or has become a "vacant building"
within the meaning of this chapter after the effective date of this chapter or the owner of a building, which the building inspector determines at any time to
be a "vacant building", or the owner of a building whose appeal from the building inspector's determination has been denied by the village manager shall
take the actions provided for in this section within fifteen (15) days after either the date of the building inspector's notice of determination or occurrence of
the facts which would cause a reasonable person to believe that the building was a "vacant building", or denial of the appeal, whichever is applicable.
Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, including this chapter, nor does it preclude any of
the actions the village is authorized to take pursuant to this chapter or elsewhere in this code.
A. Registration Requirements:
1. Register the building with the building inspector, on a form provided by the building inspector and pay the two hundred dollar ($200.00) annual
nonprorated vacant building registration fee. The form shall include, as a minimum, the name, street address, and telephone number of the owner;
the case name and number of any litigation pending concerning or affecting the building, including bankruptcy cases; and the name, street address,
and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest in the building or the premises. The form shall require the owner to identify a natural
person twenty one (21) years of age or older who maintains a permanent address in Cook County, Illinois, to accept service on behalf of the owner
with respect to any notices the building inspector sends pursuant to this chapter or service of process in any proceeding commenced to enforce any
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=613 243/307
provision of this chapter, and file with the building inspector on the registration form, the name, address, telephone number, of said person. A street
address is required. A post office box is not an acceptable address.
2. Renew the vacant building registration each year on the anniversary date of the first filing for the time the building remains vacant and pay the
required two hundred dollar ($200.00) annual fee; and
3. File an amended registration within fifteen (15) days of any change in the information contained in the annual registration. A new registration is
required for any change in ownership whatsoever.
B. Notice; Inspection: The registration form will include language that the owner agrees to consent to service of any notice required by this chapter by
posting on the building if the owner fails to: 1) renew the registration or 2) maintain current contact information with the building inspector for the person
designated to accept notice and service of process.
The owner shall allow for a code compliance inspection of the interior of the vacant building and shall pay the five hundred dollar ($500.00) fee therefor
within thirty (30) days of the inspection. Such inspection will determine the extent of compliance with village property, building codes, health, fire, water
and sewer codes. The village shall send the inspection report to the owner within thirty (30) days.
C. Insurance: Obtain liability insurance and maintain such insurance for as long as the building is vacant, and file evidence of such insurance with the
building inspector, as follows: five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for a vacant residential building of one to three (3) units; seven hundred fifty
thousand dollars ($750,000.00) for a vacant residential building of four (4) to eleven (11) units; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for a vacant
residential building of twelve (12) to forty eight (48) units; two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for a vacant residential building of more than forty eight
(48) units; and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for a vacant manufacturing, industrial, storage, or nonresidential commercial building.
D. Vacant Building Plan: At the time a building is registered as required herein, the owner shall submit a vacant building plan. The building inspector may
prescribe a form for the plan. If the owner fails to submit the plan as provided for by this chapter, the building inspector may determine the plan. The
plan shall contain the following as a minimum:
1. A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional
methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction or similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings being
secured by conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted for new construction of similar type with boarding
removed. Boarding shall be accomplished with materials and methods approved by the building inspector. The owner shall maintain the building in
an enclosed and secure state until the building is reoccupied or made available for immediate occupancy. If the owner demonstrates that securing of
the building will provide adequate protection to the public, the building inspector may waive the requirement of an enclosure.
2. For buildings and premises thereof which are determined by the building inspector as being or containing public nuisances, as defined in section 12-
15-3 of this chapter, then the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of action to remedy such public nuisance(s).
3. A time schedule identifying a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each improperly secured opening and nuisance
identified by the building inspector.
4. When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
5. A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in conformance with this chapter.
6. A plan of action, with a time schedule, identifying the date the building will be habitable and occupied or offered for occupancy or sale. The time
schedule shall include date(s) of commencement and completion of all actions required to achieve habitability. No plan which provides for
